DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Officials Extend Military Exchange Program
With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to extend a military exchange program to help eliminate the ``atmosphere of suspicion and mistrust'' between the two countries, a Soviet official said Thursday. Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, Soviet first deputy minister of defense, and his American counterpart, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, announced the agreement, signed earlier this week. It extends a program of goodwill exchanges between the two superpowers until 1992. The previous agreement, which included visits by U.S. and Soviet navy ships to Vladivostok and San Diego, respectively, expires this year. ``The plan include a wide range of military exchanges,'' said Moiseyev, speaking through an interpreter. ``I do hope that the result of that mutual exchange program will give us the possibility to get to know each other much better. And of course we do plan to carry on the military exchanges which will be instrumental in eliminating the atmosphere of suspicion and mistrust.'' Powell said improved relations between the former Cold War rivals had already opened new avenues of trust. ``Obviously we both protect that information which we believe is classified (and) is essential to our national security,'' Powell said. ``What is impressive is the degree of openness that now exists where we can share information with each other that a year or two ago we never would have thought of sharing.'' The two generals made their remarks following a tour of two U.S. Navy vessels, including a nuclear-powered attack class submarine, at the North Island Naval Air Station in San Diego. Moiseyev, who is on a five-day tour of the United States, is expected to travel to Washington on Friday with Powell to hold a joint news conference. The Soviet general said he was pleased with the welcome he had received at American military bases. ``I was especially deeply impressed by the degree of openness, by the degree of unlimited and open desire to tell us, the members of the military delegation, about their military hardware,'' Moiseyev said of his American hosts.

DOC.HEAD: Police Critic Denied Reinstatement on Force
DOC.TEXT: A former police lieutenant who criticized riot squad officers for acting like ``wild dogs'' has been rejected for reinstatement on the force, according to news reports. Gregory Rockman became a folk hero in some black areas last year when he publicly accused fellow officers of beating and whipping protesters in the mixed-race township of Mitchell's Plain near Cape Town. The independent South African Press Association on Thursday quoted a spokesman for Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok as saying Rockman's application for reinstatement was denied. Rockman, who is of mixed-raced, was suspended and later dismissed from the force for refusing a transfer to a border post.

DOC.HEAD: The Power of Suggestion: Fewer Painkillers Needed
DOC.TEXT: A study published today found that patients who listened to soothing tapes during surgery required less pain relief during recovery. Fifty-seven women undergoing hysterectomies at two hospitals in Glasgow, Scotland, wore personal stereos into the operating room, researchers reported in the current edition of the British Medical Journal. Half of the women were played blank tapes and the others listened to positive statements during the operation. Doctors found that the women who listened to the tape playing soothing remarks - including ``Everything is going very well, we're very pleased with your progress,'' and ``Any pain that you feel after the operation will not concern you'' - used 23 percent less morphine while recovering than those who were played blank tapes. The women were connected to a system that allowed them to administer the amount of morphine they wanted. The report said none of the patients could recall hearing any sounds during surgery. Dr. Phil Richardson, who has conducted three similar studies at London's St. Thomas' Hospital, said he agreed with the report's recommendation that more patients should be played tapes with positive messages during surgery. Richardson's studies have shown that patients who were played such tapes during surgery left the hospital sooner and had fewer unpleasant side effects than those who were played blank tapes.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf States Developing Joint Defense, U.S. Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: The sale of $7.3 billion in new weaponry to Saudi Arabia is just one step in creating a Persian Gulf ``coalition defense'' against the long-term threat posed by Iraq, say two senior Bush administration officials. That sale will be followed by more sales next year to the Saudis, perhaps to their neighbors Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, and new military help for Israel, Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and Undersecretary of State Reginald Bartholomew told Congress on Wednesday. In doing so, the United States hopes ``to build a Saudi and a gulf force capability that will, in effect, drive up significantly the costs to anybody looking to take a whack at them,'' Bartholomew said. ``We do not want to leave the road to Bahrain open, as it was on the second of August,'' the day Iraq invaded Kuwait, he told a hearing of two House Foreign Affairs subcommittees. President Bush has asked Congress for permission to sell $7.3 billion worth of weapons, including tanks, attack helicopters and anti-missile defenses, to Saudi Arabia. The two officials said the weapons would help the Saudis present a more credible deterrent to aggression from Iraq or elsewhere, and would permit them if attacked to resist long enough to allow reinforcements from friendly countries to arrive. They noted that past U.S. military sales to the Saudis, some $50 billion over the past four decades, helped build many of the facilities that now are supporting Operation Desert Shield, the American-led international troop deployment in that country. ``Some have said that once Desert Shield is over Iraq will no longer be a threat because the U.S. and allied forces will have destroyed the Iraqi military,'' Wolfowitz said. ``We cannot count on that. ... No outcome is likely to permanently eliminate Iraq as a regional power.'' U.S. strategy is based on a principle of ``coalition defense,'' Wolfowitz said. He said that includes strengthening the ability of gulf nations to defend themselves, encouraging defense cooperation among countries in the region and making it easier for them to receive reinforcements from allies. The sale of 150 advanced M1A2 tanks is particularly important, Wolfowitz said, noting that U.S. strategists were particularly afraid of Iraqi tanks in the early days of the military deployment. ``We had severe concerns about the ability of Iraqi armor to penetrate rather quickly,'' he said. ``We didn't have anything on the ground to stop Iraqi tanks. We don't want to ever be in the position of saying that again.'' The officials asked that Congress quickly approve the newest sale to Saudi Arabia. They said additional sales to Riyadh, as well as to the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, would be proposed early next year. Next year's Saudi package will include F-15 fighter planes, additional Patriot anti-missile batteries and more tanks and anti-armor weapons, Bartholomew said. The administration also is considering requests from Bahrain for Apache attack helicopters and multiple-launch rocket systems, and from the United Arab Emirates for Apaches, he said. Responding to concerns from supporters of Israel, Wolfowitz noted the administration is prepared to quickly transfer two Patriot batteries from current U.S. stocks and is looking at additional ways to aid Israel militarily. Asked by Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., whether it is U.S. policy to retaliate against Iraq immediately if it attacks Israel, Bartholomew said: ``I don't have any reason to open that up to question.'' Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., raised the possibility that weapons sold to Saudi Arabia could fall into enemy hands if its current government ever falls, and cited similar past occurrences in Iran and Kuwait. Bartholomew acknowledged that some U.S. weapons that had been sold to Kuwait now are in the hands of Iraqi forces, including a number of improved Hawk antiaircraft missiles, TOW anti-tank missiles, self-propelled 155-millimeter howitzers and ammunition, and about 16 A-4 attack aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Inside Bush's Speech: Reading the Entrails
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't the message but a word President Bush used that elevated eyebrows after his television speech on the deficit the other night. There he was in about the most solemn setting at a president's command - a prime-time Oval Office address, only the fourth of Bush's presidency - and he used a phrase more appropriate to a bumper sticker. ``And now let me tell you what this agreement will not do,'' the president said. ``It will not raise income tax rates, personal or corporate. It will not mess with Social Security in any way.'' ``... will not mess with ...'' Brilliant choice of words, said Ken Khachigian, a San Clemente, Calif., lawyer who used to write Oval Office speeches for Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan. ``That's the conversational Bush,'' he said. ``That's one of the reasons he is doing so well.'' No, ``mess'' was a bad choice, said a student of language, William Lutz of Rutgers University, chairman of the Committee on Public Doublespeak of the National Council of Teachers of English. ``The language does not flow from the man. It strikes our ear as artificial,'' said Lutz. ``In a matter of such grave seriousness and in a formal address by a president, people look for more formal language. A more elevated tone would have been more appropriate.'' If nothing else, the issue shows the importance that can be attached to every presidential word, especially those uttered in formal settings. Robin Lakoff, professor of linguistics at the University of California at Berkeley, thought Bush's choice of ``mess'' was ``very characteristic of Bush. He's trying to be a regular guy.'' ``American people like to see their presidents as populists,'' said Ms. Lakoff, author of ``Talking Power: The Politics of Language in Our Lives.'' ``Bush is by birth an aristocrat,'' she said. ``So he has to spend a whole lot of his energy proving that he isn't. ``He used `mess' as though saying, `See, I empathize with you,''' she said. ``I think it is too manipulative to work. It doesn't work for me. On the other hand, he has an 80 percent popularity rating.'' Ms. Lakoff also commented on another phrase in the same speech. Bush said, ``It is the best agreement that can be legislated now.'' That's an insiders' use of ``legislated.'' Usually, legislators legislate. Ms. Lakoff said Bush was expressing authority by choosing that buzzword. ```Mess' says, `I talk your language, I'm one of you,''' she said. ```Legislated' says `I understand complicated issues. I am at the hub of where things happen. So you can trust me as an authority.' They're two ways of appealing for trust.'' Fred Mish, the dictionary man, comes down on Bush's side. ``It's a little offbeat,'' said Mish, editorial director of Merriam-Webster, Inc. of Springfield, Mass., speaking of Bush's use of ``legislated,'' He added: ``What he means seems clear enough.'' As for ``mess,'' thus spake Mish: ``It's sort of an informal word in a fairly formal context. It's quite intentional, and possibly effective. ``If Franklin Roosevelt had said it, it would have been almost unbelievable. But the nature of public discourse has changed in the last 50 years.''

DOC.TEXT: Here are some key dates in the long negotiations to limit conventional arms in Europe.

October 1973 - The United States and six NATO allies open the ``Mutual Balanced Force Reduction,'' MBFR talks, in Vienna with the Soviet Union and three of its Warsaw Pact allies. April 1986 - Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev announces a plan to break the stalemated talks. June 1986 - In the ``Budapest appeal,'' the Warsaw Pact proposes a broadening of the talks to include all alliance members. Dec. 7, 1988 - Gorbachev announces unilateral Soviet troop reductions. Jan. 10, 1989 - The two alliances convene the ``Conventional Forces in Europe'' or CFE talks, consisting of all 23 members of the two blocs. Feb. 2, 1989 - The MBFR talks wind up after 470 meetings. March 9, 1989 - The CFE talks open. May 11, 1989 - Gorbachev gives important proposals to Secretary of State James A. Baker III in Moscow, and the two sides make proposals and counterproposals at frequent intervals. May 29, 1989 - President Bush makes proposals at the NATO summit. Dec. 14, 1989 - Both sides exchange draft treaty texts. Dec. 23, 1989 - Bush and Gorbachev agree to try to complete a treaty by the end of 1990. Jan. 31, 1990 - Bush proposes troop limits of 195,000 on each side in the central region, plus 30,000 in other areas for the United States. June 27, 1990 - Negotiators in Vienna nail down the tricky issues of limits on tanks and armored troop carriers. Sept. 27, 1990 - Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, meeting in New York, agree on the limits on the proportion of European arms any alliance member may hold. In meetings over the previous week, they agree to drop personnel ceilings from the treaty. Oct. 3, 1990 - Agreement in principal is announced by Baker and Shevardnadze after the final unresolved issue, aircraft limits, is put to rest.

DOC.HEAD: Another Sad Ending Shatters Royal Family's Realm
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When Grace Kelly married Monaco's prince, they seemed like lovers favored by the stars in an old romantic tale. Now, the oyal family is starting to seem as star-crossed as players in an ancient tragedy. The death Wednesday of Princess Caroline's husband, Stefano Casiraghi, in a speedboat crash added to the pain of a family troubled by marital problems and the death of Princess Grace eight years ago. Grace Kelly, a beautiful American film star, married a dashing Prince Rainier in a civil ceremony on April 18, 1956, after a courtship in his tiny Riviera realm. Miss Kelly, who came from a blueblood Philadelphia family, became Her Serene Highness Princess Grace. She gave up filmmaking and bore three children, Caroline, Albert and Stephanie. The couple looked down on their debt-free, tax-free, fully employed realm from the royal palace atop ``Le Rocher'' - the rock - which dominates the Bay of Monaco. The years passed smoothly, although some gossips whispered that Princess Grace grew bored with palace life and spent too much time visiting Paris. But the general sentiment was reflected in the words of a journalist who wrote on the occasion of the couple's silver wedding anniversary in 1981: ``They have been living happily ever after.'' The sky fell a year later. On Sept. 13, 1982, Grace and Stephanie were traveling a winding road from the family's summer residence near La Turbie, France, in the hills overlooking Monaco. The automobile failed to negotiate a hairpin turn and tumbled down a ravine. Grace, 52, died of a stroke a day later. Stephanie suffered neck injuries and deep emotional stress. The Royal Palace has steadfastly maintained that Grace drove the car, although persistent rumors put Stephanie behind the wheel. At the time, Stephanie was 17, a year too young to drive legally. Grace's death plunged the principality into mourning. A distraught Rainier seldom appeared in public for the next four years and was said to spend most of his time alone. Stephanie became the family's wild child, posing nude for a photographer, dancing through the night at discotheques and modeling swimsuits. She has been linked romantically to race driver Alain Prost, actor Rob Lowe, actor Jean-Paul Belmondo's son Paul, actor Alain Delon's son Anthony and the scion of another troubled clan, John F. Kennedy Jr. All that was to end when she became engaged to property developer Jean-Yves Le Fur in April. But the wedding, announced for June, never came off. No public reason was ever given. Brother Albert, the heir to the throne, strikes a sober contrast. The 32-year-old has worked in business and law and represented the nation on the bobsled team in the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary. Caroline, 33, has had troubles beyond the loss of her mother and husband. As the oldest child, she attracted enormous attention from celebrity-watchers when she came into adulthood in the 1970s. In 1978, Caroline married French playboy Philippe Junot, a man 17 years her senior. She later said she married him to rebel against her mother, who challenged her to marry Junot or dump him. ``And I think he married just because it was another lark,'' she told Le Figaro Magazine. ``It was as stupid as that.'' The union ended two years later, after several press photos showed him in the company of other women. Caroline dated Roberto Rossellini and tennis star Guillermo Vilas before marrying Casiraghi, an Italian financier, in 1983. The couple led a relatively low-profile lifestyle and had three children, Andrea, Charlotte and Pierre. A practicing Roman Catholic, Caroline unsuccessfully sought a Vatican annulment of her first marriage so her children could be recognized by the Church. A year after their marriage, Casiraghi developed a passin for the dangerous sport of offshore boat racing, in which speeds often exceed 125 mph. Casiraghi won the 1989 world championships and was defending his title Wednesday when his boat struck a wave and flipped, killing him instantly. One of his friends, Italian journalist Franco Bartolini, said Casiraghi planned to quit the speedboat circuit after this race. ``He was going too fast,'' Bartolini told reporters. ``I think he wanted to go all out, one last time, at his place, at Monaco.''

DOC.HEAD: Hue and Cry Over the Budget Package
DOC.TEXT: As Carl Gillis sees it, President Bush has a problem with hard-line anti-tax people in rural Georgia. ``He done told us one time he wasn't going to tax. I think in the backside of their minds there may be a little backlash.'' Not that Gillis is against the president. He's a Republican National committeeman from Georgia. But the people he's talking to, ``the vocal ones,'' are strongly opposed to the budget compromise Bush is trying to sell to the country and Congress. In Massachusetts, where a full-blown tax revolt is under way, the compromise also gets a negative reception, according to Republican Party chairman Ray Shamie. ``People don't blame the president,'' said Shamie. ``They blame Congress.'' As the House moved toward a vote on the outlines of the package of tax increases and spending cuts, there was a strong sense of bipartisan political nervousness around the country. Clearly the most nervous are those in tough political races. ``If you're a marginal member (of Congress), this is a disaster,'' said Democratic pollster Celinda Lake. She described the electorate as a ``very, very crabby and unhappy set of voters.'' She said Democrats are ``in a very hard place and conservative Republicans are making it harder for Democrats.'' Conservatives like House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia were quick to break with the Republican president on the budget compromises. Equally swift in putting distance between themselves and the package were GOP candidates. Reps. Tom Tauke of Iowa, Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, Lynn Martin of Illinois, and Bill Schuette of Michigan were among the first to declare their opposition to the package. All are Republicans, all are challenging Democratic senators and are behind in the polls but remain within striking distance. Rep. Pat Saiki, R-Hawaii, was the only GOP Senate challenger in the House who was not flatly opposed to the compromise. She also was the only one leading her Democratic opponent, Sen. Daniel Akaka, in the polls. ``I think most Republicans recognize we're in a very difficult position,'' said Richard Schwarm, chairman of the Iowa Republican Party. ``Republicans are truly divided over whether this is the best deal possible. How it falls out politically, I have no way of knowing.'' In Iowa, and in neighboring South Dakota and Nebraska, similar complaints were heard about the proposed increase in the gasoline tax and the higher premiums for Medicare as well as cuts in farm programs. But there also was a sense that the country needed to stand behind the president in a difficult time. ``My feeling is we have to do something,'' said Norm Riffel, the Nebraska GOP chairman. ``We have to share in taking care of this deficit.'' But candidates were less inclined to be supportive than party officials. Former congressman Hal Daub, challenging Nebraska Democratic Sen. James Exon, said he was skeptical of the figures included in the compromise. ``They're very false numbers,'' he said. ``They're not real-world numbers. They have painted far too rosy a scenario.'' Alabama Republican Bill Cabaniss, challenging Sen. Howell Heflin, said the plan was ``almost guaranteed to drive our economy into a recession.'' The budget compromise often provided an area of agreement between opposing candidates. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, joined with Tauke in opposition to the plan, as did the Republican and Democratic candidates battling to succeed Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., who is retiring. The accord is ``anti-growth, anti-jobs,'' said Republican Jim Ramstad. ``Another example of politics as usual,'' said Democrat Lou DeMars. ``The people I'm talking to in the real world ... don't want tax increases,'' said Ramstad. ``They are particularly angry with the gas tax increase.'' Lake said higher gasoline taxes were ``a key element'' in a public sense that the economy is rapidly going downhill. In a televised appeal for support for the compromise, Bush urged Americans Tuesday night to call members of Congress. The joke, however, said Rep. Pete Geren, D-Texas, is ``they're all calling their congressmen a whole lot more than yesterday, but they're all calling to say vote against it.'' The staff member who answered the telephone in the Washington office of Gingrich laughed when asked if the office was getting a lot of calls. Gingrich, the No. 2 Republican in the House, was on the budget negotiating team but opposed the agreement and refused to participate with the president in announcing the settlement. ``At 10 o'clock this morning in our Morrow, Ga., office we had 143 calls against it and 20 for it. And we'd only been open since nine,'' said the Gingrich aide. She said the Washington office had received 91 calls against the budget and 22 for it by the same time.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Pushes Deficit Reduction Plan as Regionally Neutral
With PM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is trying to quell regional concerns about the $500 billion deficit-reduction plan by arguing that failure to pass the package will hurt every area of the country equally. ``I'm not sure there won't be any adverse effects by one provision or another. I am totally sure that failure to get a deficit deal will adversely affect every region of the country,'' the president said Wednesday. Bush, budget director Richard Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady briefed regional journalists in an effort to win support in the heartland for the package of taxes and spending cuts. Bush defended the proposed 12-cent increase in gasoline taxes, which would be phased in over two years, against complaints that people living in the South and West would be hardest hit because they drive more. ``I think when you look around at world prices on gasoline, I mean, we are still substantially below world markets,'' the president said. ``So I would simply say that it is a tax that everybody has to pick up, as I said last night, some share of the burden.'' Darman argued that certain tax increases would be offset by an overall improvement in the nation's financial health. The package ``hasn't been designed to try to equalize by region,'' he said. ``It is also not, in my opinion, something that discriminates by region in a way that's especially preferential to one or unfavorable to another.'' Darman defended the budget negotiators' decision to increase the tax on home heating oil by 2 cents a gallon, a proposal that is opposed by New England legislators. ``It's legitimate and a legitimate worry,'' he said. ``On the other hand, you cannot say in the end that a package is balanced and fair and not have little bits and pieces from almost everything. And this is one more little bit and piece.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists are working with singers Carole King and John Oates to have logging and mining outlawed on 13 million acres of Northwest wilderness. The two appeared Wednesday at a news conference to pus a proposal from the Alliance for the Wild Rockies, based in Missoula, Mont. ``Some environmental groups are like the unpopular kids at a high school dance who stand around in the corner because no one wants to dance with them,'' said Oates, from the band Hall & Oates. ``I'm here to see if I can't get someone to dance with them,'' he said. King said taxpayer money should not be used to drill, build roads and clear-cut trees in national forests. ``If we stopped spending federal money to destroy our public lands maybe we wouldn't have to raise the taxes that President Bush talked about this morning,'' she said. The alliance wants to ban logging, mining and road-building on public lands in Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Oregon and Washington. --- FULTON, Mo. (AP) - Former President Reagan will dedicate a sculpture next month that marks the first anniversary of the Berlin Wall's demise. Reagan will dedicate the sculpture ``Breakthrough'' on Nov. 9 at Westminster College, where Sir Winston Churchill said in a 1946 speech that ``an iron curtain has descended'' on Europe. The sculpture was done by artist Edwina Sandys, Churchill's granddaughter. It includes eight concrete sections of the wall, which went up in 1961 to separate Germany and became the physical embodiment of Churchill's metaphor. Ms. Sandys went to East Germany soon after border restrictions were eased and persuaded the government to donate sections of the wall. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Mobster-turned-informant Henry Hill has seen ``GoodFellas,'' the movie based on his life, and gives it two thumbs up for reality. ``That movie was 99 percent accurate. That's the way we lived, that's (the way) we treated our wives, always on the hustle,'' Hill said in an interview with the syndicated television program ``Inside Edition.'' Hill, whose story was told by author Nicholas Pileggi in the book ``Wise Guy,'' took pride in the performance of Academy Award-winning actor Robert DeNiro. ``I spent a lot of time on the phone with DeNiro, coching him for playing Jimmy the Gent,'' said Hill, who appears on the show wearing a beard and sunglasses because he is in the witness protection program. Hill says life has changed dramatically since he turned government witness and slipped into anonymity. He is remarried and has a new baby. ``I can put my head on the pillow and not have to worry about a phone call in the middle of the night to `come and meet me with a shovel,' '' said Hill. ``All that craziness, that insanity, is gone from my life.'' The interview aired in some markets Wednesday. -- SAVANNAH, Ga. (AP) - Pat DiNizio, lead singer of the rock group the Smithereens, underwent an emergency appendectomy while on tour. As a result, the Smithereens have canceled a show Saturday in Harrisonburg, Va. But the group plans to resume the tour in a few days, the band's touring manager, Brendan McCabe, said Wednesday. McCabe said the singer began complaining of pains in his side late Monday after a performance in Savannah. DiNizio was diagnosed with appendicitis and surgery was performed Tuesday. ``He still has a little pain, but he's in good spirits and he's doing fine,'' said McCabe. ``He just needs a couple of days to recover.''

DOC.HEAD: Soares To Seek Re-election in Portugal
DOC.TEXT: President Mario Soares has announced that he will seek re-election in balloting scheduled for January, ending months of speculation. Soares, 66, three-time prime minister and a founder of the Portuguese Socialist Party, the announcement on Wednesday. In 1986, he became Portugal's first freely elected civilian president in 60 years. His opponents are seeking a contender to challenge Soares' bid for a second four-year term. Recent opinion polls indicate more than 60 percent of voters intend to back Soares. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva has said his center-right Social Democratic Party will not oppose Soares.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Spends Almost $600 Million to Feed, Clothe Gulf Troops
With PM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The cost of food, clothing and medical supplies for American troops in the Mideast is nearing $600 million as the deployment approaches the two-month mark and begins to generate lucrative business for Pentagon suppliers. In the past week alone, the Pentagon has issued $100 million in contracts for meals and new, desert-style suits designed to protect troops from deadly chemical weapons. The deployment of 170,000 troops some 7,000 miles from the United States is a major test for the military's supply operations. So far, Defense Department officials say they have filled from existing stocks about90 percent of orders from units deployed to the Middle East. But major orders already are going to suppliers to rebuild inventories and they will have to do so increasingly as the deployment drags on. Food, clothing and medical supplies are by far the greatest needs of the still-growing deployment. The need to feed troops sent so far from home has forced the Pentagon to scrap plans to cut purchases of the modern-day C-ration, Meals Ready to Eat, or MRE, and instead spend millions ordering more. Suplly depots also are being called on to supply cots to sleep on, coolers to protect ice from the heat of the Saudi Arabia desert, circuits, switches and other parts for radios and other equipment exposed to the harsh conditions and thousands of other items ranging from nuts and bolts to sunscreen and chigger repellant. At the Defense Industrial Supply Center in Philadelphia, for example, some $9 million worth of spare parts, from washers and bearings to heavy-duty cable, are being supplied for the deployment. Nearly 200 new contracts have been negotiated and 500 others modified because of the buildup, most of them to replenish stocks, according to center records. And the Defense Electronics Supply Center in Dayton, Ohio, has processed 22,000 orders for goods valued at $6.7 million for the Mideast buildup, filling 90.5 percent from depot stocks, according to its records. The center is letting 200 contracts a month to fill back orders, now totaling 1,600, for supplies earmarked for the Middle East. The biggest crunch is at the support center that handles orders for food, clothing and medical supplies, which as of Tuesday had received 47,208 requisitions for $563 million worth of goods directly related to Desert Shield, the Pentagon's code name for the Mideast operation. Those orders were for $55.8 million in medical supplies, $293 million in food and $214 million in clothing and textiles, according to records at the Philadelphia center. Requested so far by units in and around Saudi Arabia were nearly 40 million meals - 30 million MREs and 7.8 million servings of hot meals packaged in ready-to-heat trays. Just Monday, the Pentagon awarded two new contracts for MREs worth more than $52 million. The contracts with Southern Packing Co. of South Carolina and Cincinnati Packaging of Ohio were for nearly 33 million MREs, the 3,000-calories meals served to troops when they have no access to hot meals. Those companies assemble and box the meals, which on average cost the government $3.70 apiece. Some of the components are supplied by the government, others are purchased by the packing firms from subcontractors. Also on order are thousands of new desert uniforms and protective suits. Last Friday the Pentagon exercised an option it had with Isratex Inc. of West Virginia to provide 294,550 chemical suits, to be made with desert camouflage fabric. Isratex has supplied the suits to the military in the past, but in traditional dark green camouflage. One the same day it awarded that $18 million contract - roughly $61 a suit - the Pentagon also signed a $22 million agreement with Raven Industries of Sioux Falls, S.D., to produce 250,000 desert-style chemical suits. The latter contract pays the manufacturer $88 a suit. Those contracts are for the protective pants and jackets only. A separate depot is ordering the gas masks and gloves. Details of those orders were not immediately available. The two new contracts for chemical suits are in addition to orders for 800,000 suits made with three companies from late August through mid-September. Those contracts were worth a total of $61.7 million.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Canada Plan Talks Toward Deregulating Air Service
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Canada will open negotiations next year to dismantle barriers to free and open competition in the skies between the airlines of the two nations. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said the talks could result in an unprecedented deregulation of air traffic across international borders and add up to 2 million passengers a year to what is already the world's largest aviation market. Skinner and Canadian Transport Minister Doug Lewis made the announcement in a joint statement issued simultaneously in Washington and Toronto on Wednesday. Skinner told reporters that all aspects of air service between the two nations will be up for discussion when the talks begin in early 1991. Lewis said negotiators will explore the possibility of creating an ``open regime.'' The goal: Airlines from each country would be allowed to operate between any point in one country and any point in the other as well as between points in the other country. Skinner said the possibility of permitting Canadian airlines to open hubs in the United States and American air carriers to open hubs in Canada also will be on the table. In their statement, Skinner and Lewis noted that the current aviation agreement between the two countries has remained basically unchanged since 1974. They said it is now ``out of step with the transportation needs of Canada and the U.S.'' ``We want an aviation market in which the flow of goods and services would be unimpedd by governmental economic regulation,'' the two officials said. Skinner noted that the two countries have already deregulated their domestic airline industries and said that fact should make it easier to deregulate air service across their common border. The United States and Canada signed a free-trade agreement in 1988 and Skinner said that created a totally new economic atmosphere and the opportunity to expand and deregulate air links. ``We will basically take down the barriers that exist,'' he said. About 13 million passengers fly between Canada and the United States each year, producing annual revenue of more than $2 billion. U.S. airlines carry about two-thirds of the scheduled traffic, about 11 million passengers a year, while almost all of the charter passengers, about 2 million a year, are carried by Canadian airlines. Skinner said growth of the U.S.-Canadian air market has been sluggish in recent years because of the restrictions the two countries impose to limit the numbers of air carriers and flights. The National Transportation Policy announced by Skinner earlier this year calls for improving access to international markets for U.S. airlines. The transportation secretary said the U.S.-Canada air negotiations will mark a good first step toward that objective. Tom Lydon, a lawyer for the Air Transport Association, the principal trade group of U.S. airlines, said member carriers generally support the new negotiations, in part because the present air service treaty with Canada is ``one of the more restrictive'' of all such international agreements. For example, only one airline from each country may operate on any route, and U.S. carriers would like to serve more cities in Canada regardless of how many companies are doing so already, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Legendary Spymaster Reportedly Flees, Successor Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Markus Wolf, the late East Germany's spymaster of legend, is reported to have fled to the Soviet Union, but his successor was arrested hours after the two Germanys became one. For weeks, officials have been debating what to do with the spies from East Germany's hard-line Communist regime who routinely infiltrated West Germany during the Cold War era. Plans for an amnesty were rejected. When unification came on Wednesday, the spies became fair game for federal prosecutors eager to bring them to justice. East Germany had about 8,000 spies, but officials say fewer than 50 arrest warrants have been issued. Wolf is by far the biggest fish among them. An urbane espionage wizard who gained the grudging respect of his Western foes, Wolf left behind tales of intrigue before retiring in 1987. As the struggling East German Communists sought to hang on to power last fall, Wolf claimed he wanted to help reform the government. Pro-democracy figures mocked him, citing his role as a central figure in the Communists' well-maintained spy and secret police apparatus. Since then, Wolf has apparently lived off and on near Moscow, writing his memoirs in the relatively safe haven there. In today's editions, the mass-circulation Bild newspaper of Hamburg quoted the new Germany's chief prosecutor, Alexander von Stahl, as saying Wolf was ``probably in the Soviet Union'' right now. Von Stahl told Berlin's RIAS television on Wednesday that he had received a letter from Wolf. ``He wrote to me and said he wanted to avoid arrest,'' Von Stahl said, adding he still plans to try to apprehend Wolf. ARD television also said that Wolf had fled, as had Hans-Joachim Tiedge, a long-time East German spy in Bonn who fled to East Berlin in 1985. According to Bild, Wolf contacted the federal prosecutor's office through his lawyer last week, indicating he would turn himself in expecting to receive clemency. One of Wolf's major coups as head of the former East German spy network was the planting of top agent Guenther Guillaume as a close aide to then-West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. When Guillaume's true identity was revealed in April 1974, an embarrassed Brandt took full responsibility for the grave security breach and resigned. Wolf was replaced by Werner Grossmann, who was arrested on Wednesday in the eastern side of Berlin. The chief federal prosecutor's spokesman, Hans-Juergen Foerster, said investigators originally went to Grossmann's home early Wednesday to arrest him, but he was not home. He was there when they returned in the afternoon. Grossmann was the last spy chief in the now-dissolved East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies His Published Remarks Prejudiced Bush Case
DOC.TEXT: The judge considering a federal conflict-of-interest case against Neil Bush says he didn't prejudice the case by calling it ``a pain'' because his remarks didn't favor either side. But some legal experts said this week that administrative law judge Daniel J. Davidson went against professional ethics by talking to reporters about the case against the president's son. In two newspaper interviews published before a public hearing on regulators' charges against Bush, Davidson called the savings and loan case ``a pain,'' ``a political football'' and ``one of the minor ones'' from a legal standpoint. Stephen Gillers, a law professor at New York University, called Davidson's remarks ``ill-advised.'' ``You don't want the judge to become a player ... the judge is first of all a neutral,'' Gillers said. Judges shouldn't comment on cases outside of court because ``the public's confidence in the process becomes compromised,'' he said. ``The usual practice is that judges don't give interviews,'' said Nahum Litt, the chief administrative law judge at the Labor Department. Normally, he said, administrative law judges tell reporters seeking interviews to call an official spokesman of the federal agency where the judge works. Court judges rarely speak publicly about pending cases. Administrative law judges, who interpret federal law and regulations enforced by the agencies for which they work, are generally expected to follow the same standards as other judges. ``I am not infallible,'' Davidson told The Associated Press on Tuesday. He said he may have breached ethical standards by making the statements to the reporters, but that he spoke to them because ``I'm a nice guy.'' ``Shame on me for not hanging up'' the telephone, Davidson joked. He said his remarks didn't compromise the case because they didn't indicate that he leans ``one way or the other.'' Davidson, who has been an administrative law judge for 22 years, won't make a binding ruling in the case. He will recommend to the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision what sanctions, if any, should be imposed on Bush. Bush, 35, an oil and gas developer in Denver, could be barred from the banking and savings industry. He has been accused of conflict of interest in his role as a director of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, which collapsed in late 1988, several months after Bush resigned from the thrift. The failure is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. The OTS alleges Bush failed to adequately inform fellow Silverado directors of his business ties with two developers who eventually defaulted on more than $132 million in Silverado loans. ``This one is going to be a pain,'' Davidson told The New York Times in a story published Sept. 25, the day the Bush hearing began in Denver. ``It's a political football, and I don't get involved in politics.'' A day earlier, in The Denver Post, Davidson was quoted as saying the case had received public attention only because Bush is a son of the president and that from a legal standpoint, it is ``one of the minor ones.'' OTS spokesman Tom Mason and Bush's attorney, James Nesland, declined comment on Davidson's statements, as did American Bar Association spokesman Robert Evans. Bush testified last Thursday in a combative three-hour appearance, insisting that his actions as a Silverado director involved no conflict. Davidson showed a feisty, sometimes humorous style at the hearing, scolding Bush several times for interrupting the government attorney and making judgments from the witness stand that should be made by the judge. ``Please don't try to decide what questions are proper,'' Davidson told Bush. ``I'll do that. OK?'' Davidson, 56, first served as an administrative law judge at the Interstate Commerce Commission. He now works for the Food and Drug Administration but has been ``loaned out'' to other federal agencies. The Office of Personnel Management chose Davidson to preside over the Bush proceeding and his selection was approved by the OTS. The model code of judicial conduct for federal administrative law judges states: ``An administrative law judge should abstain from public comment about a pending or impending proceeding before a judge in any agency in which the judge serves, and should require similar abstention on the part of agency personnel subject to the judge's direction and control.''

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Ads Aimed at Women Decried by Medical Authorities
DOC.TEXT: A prominent physicians' organization and the U.S. surgeon general accuse the tobacco industry of being irresponsible by ``the unconscionable targeting of women'' in cigarette advertising. ``Tobacco companies must stop encouraging young women to smoke cigarettes,'' the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists said Wednesday. ``The health of women and of our future generations demand at least that much consideration.'' Surgeon General Antonia Novello said at a news conference that pregnant women who smoke are more likely to have miscarriages, premature deliveries and low-birthweight babies. Smoking is responsible for about 4,000 infant deaths in the United States each year, she said. ``Let no woman be deceived,'' Novello said. ``Tobacco is an addictive and deadly drug. It leaves its sinister mark across the entire physiological landscape; hypertension, bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, heart disease and cancer.'' The Ob-Gyn group said more than 126,000 women die each year from smoking-related disorders and that smoking causes 75 percent of lung cancer cases. About 27 percent of American women smoke, it said. ``It is irresponsible for tobacco companies to single out women, especially educationally or otherwise disadvantaged women, and encourage them to smoke,'' the organization said in a statement. ``Tobacco companies must stop encouraging young women to smoke cigarettes,'' it said. ``The health of women and of our future generations demand at least that much consideration.'' Thomas Lauria of the Tobacco Institute, representing cigarette manufacturers, said in response: ``We are pointing out it's 1990, and to segregate women as being incapable of making the same choices as men about an adult consumer product seems paternalistic.'' George Gross, executive vice president for the Magazine Publishers Association, said magazines support commercial free speech, ``the advertising of a legal product.'' Dr. Ezra C. Davidson, president of the physicians' group, said the most vulnerable women are teen-agers who have limited understanding of the health risks of smoking. ``The magazines they read extol the glamour of cigarette smoking in the advertising and the advertising revenue very often makes the magazines reluctant to publish the other side - the side that warns of miscarriages, low birthweight, stillbirths, lung cancer, heart attacks and the many other deadly results of the cigarette habit,'' Davidson said. Dr. Virginia Ernster of the University of California Medical School in San Francisco, said tobacco companies have dealt women a low blow. ``Their advertising is fictitious,'' she said. ``It associates female smoking with images of physical fitness and independence. ``The reality of smoking for women is often quite different - addiction and death,'' she said. ``The ads suggest that women who smoke are `in control,' but it is actually the women in our society who have the least going for them in terms of income, education and jobs who are the most likely to smoke.''

DOC.HEAD: Vitamin A Reduces Deaths Among Malnourished Children
DOC.TEXT: The childhood death rate in parts of the world where malnutrition is common can be cut in half by giving underfed children $2 worth of vitamin A annually, according to a study released today. Doctors who conducted the study in India gave children the same amount of vitamin A that they would get in a healthy diet, with dramatic results, according to the study published in the New England Journal of Medicine. The study was conducted by Dr. Laxmi Rahmathullah and colleagues from Aravind Children's Hospital in Madurai, India. The United Nations estimates that 20 million to 40 million children have at least mild vitamin A deficiency, and nearly half of them live in India. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Gerald T. Keusch of New England Medical Center called the results ``positive, impressive and convincing,'' but said the $2 pricetag still might be too high for impoverished nations. ``It is time that the international community did something more about this than talk,'' he wrote. The study was conducted on 15,419 preschool children in southern India. They were randomly selected to receive vitamins A and E or vitamin E alone. During the one-year study, 125 children died, but the risk of death among those taking vitamin A was only half that of those who got vitamin E alone. The vitamin A appeared to reduce the risk of dying from diarrhea or other infections in malnourished children. An earlier study conducted in Indonesia reached similar conclusions.

DOC.HEAD: McCain to Appear Before Ethics Committee in Lincoln S&L Case
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead unlikely; McCain meeting with committee scheduled 3 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John McCain says he's frustrated with the slow pace of an investigation of his and four colleagues' efforts to help political donor Charles H. Keating Jr. when his savings and loan was failing. McCain, an Arizona Republican, was asked to appear beoore the Senate Ethics Committee today to explain why he joined the four other senators to intervene with U.S. banking regulators on Keating's behalf. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, appeared before the committee Wednesday in a closed session, the first of the five asked to testify. Congressional sources, insisting on anonymity, have confirmed that committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett proposed that the investigation of McCain and Glenn be dropped. Bennett recommended the investigation go forward against Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, the sources said. The three are expected to meet with the committee individually next week. Glenn met with the Ethics Committee for 2{ hours and said afterward, ``I survived. I appreciated very much the fact that the committee would take the time to discuss this whole issue with me, which we did. There was adequate time to present everything.'' He would not discuss the substance of the meeting. Committee Vice Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said there was no committee decision in Glenn's case, nor would any action be taken on McCain today. McCain said Wednesday, ``I am frustrated by the lack of progress and I see no reason for delay now that the special counsel has made his recommendations.'' The five senators received a total of $1.3 million for their campaigns and political causes from Keating and his associates. All five have said they were trying to ensure that Keating was treated fairly by regulators. They said their contacts with the regulators were not motivated by the donations. Keating's Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln Savings and Loan was taken over by the federal government in May 1989, and its losses may cost taxpayers more than $2 billion. Keating has been indicted on state criminal fraud charges in California. Bennett submitted his recommendations on Sept. 10 to the committee, which announced its preliminary investigation on Dec. 22, 1989. One Republican congressional source, insisting on anonymity, said there was concern among Senate GOP members that any failure to act quickly on Bennett's recommendations would be seen as ``absolutely, totally political.'' McCain is the only Republican among the five, and if his case was dropped before the election, only Democratic senators would be under a Senate ethics investigation for their roles in the savings and loan crisis. This could be a counterpoint to a possible move by Democrats to make an issue of conflict-of-interest allegations against the president's son, Neil Bush, for actions he took as a board member of a failed thrift in Denver. Ethics Committee members have declined to comment on any aspect of the investigation, including their timetable, since receiving Bennett's report. McCain in the past has pointed out that Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., was based in Phoenix and has said, ``I did nothing that I wouldn't do for any major employer, or economic factor, in my state.'' The Arizona Republican received $112,000 in campaign contributions from Keating and associates, and said he would return the money if it was found to have been diverted from Lincoln. More than a third of the money was donated while McCain was a member of the House, including contributions that preceded Keating's purchase of Lincoln. In May and June 1989, McCain paid back $13,433 to American Continental for the cost of nine corporate and charter jet flights the senator and his family took to the Bahamas in Keating planes from 1984-86. The trips were not disclosed at the time by McCain, then a member of the House. McCain said his failure to pay for the trips earlier ``was a serious error. But it doesn't mean I did anything improper for Charles Keating.''

DOC.HEAD: Another Black Mayor Endorses Campbell For Re-Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note content of 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: The black mayor of the town of Denmark joined nearly 300 local officials across the state in publicly endorsing Gov. Carroll Campbell's re-election. The endorsement by Mayor Orlando White, who is an independent, came a day after Democratic opponent Sen. Theo Mitchell held his latest news conference in which he accused the governor of starting his political career on racism. A list of city and county officials statewide who publicly support Campbell was released at the news conference. It included 135 mayors, 109 county council members and 50 city council members. Mitchell, who is black, said he holds no animosity against the mayor for endorsing Campbell, but pointed out that White works for South Carolina State College, which is affected by the governor. Last week, Mitchell lashed out when Campbell got support from the Rev. Richard Fisher and five black mayors. Mitchell called them ``house niggers'' and ``Uncle Toms.'' White said Campbell is very strong in areas such as fiscal management and has worked hard to bring industrial development into small towns such as Denmark. The governor has made sure funds are distributed evenly in rural areas, White said. As an example, he cited a $100,000 grant given about a year ago by Campbell for indoor facilities in Denmark.
DOC.HEAD: Houstonians Parody Williams' Rape Joke in Song
DOC.TEXT: Two Houston businessmen have created a parody in song of Republican gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams' cowboy image and a controversial joke he made about rape. Donnell Price and Fred Cebrun of Futuristic Enterprises said Wednesday they hope ``Texas, It's a Cryin' Shame'' will attract Texas radio listeners before the Nov. 6 election. Cebrun sings it to the tune of ``Home on the Range.'' ``Clayton Williams on the range,'' the refrain begins. ``His sense of humor is strange. ``His types of jokes ``Offend lots of folks. ``Texas, it's a cryin' shame.'' The song specifically addresses a joke Williams made while at his ranch with reporters in April. Williams compared the rainy weather to rape, saying, ``if it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it.'' He has since apologized for the comment, but initially said it was intended to be ``campfire humor.'' ``Clayton, what did you say? No woman enjoys being raped,'' Cebrun sings. ``Everybody in the campaign'' of Democrat Ann Richards likes the song and ``asks for copies, but nobody's been willing to put up the money for it,'' Price said.
DOC.HEAD: Steve Collins Announces Campaign For Lieutenant Governor
DOC.TEXT: The son of former Gov. Martha Layne Collins says he will seek the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor, an office his mother held from 1979-83. Steve Collins has never held public office before, but he says he's familiar with the political arena from years of watching and helping his mother. And she will be his campaign finance manager. ``I had a lot of experience in that particular office,'' said Collins, 29. ``The one where I felt I could go in and hit the ground running was the lieutenant governor's office.'' Collins used the same room at the Woodford County Courthouse to make his announcement that his mother used 12 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: All New Buses, Vans and Rail Cars Must Be Accessible to Disabled
DOC.TEXT:
Transit authorities across the country must now buy only buses, vans and rail cars that are accessible to the disabled, says the Department of Transportation. Acting to implement the Americans with Disabilities Act, the department said Wednesday that access for the disabled must be ensured by transit authorities buying or leasing new buses, vans, light rail, rapid rail, commuter rail and intercity rail cars. The requirement is effective immediately, the department said.
---
DOC.HEAD: Congress Gives Final Approval to Bill Outlawing Age Discrimination
DOC.TEXT:
The House has given final congressional passage to legislation aimed at reversing the effects of a Supreme Court decision that allowed employers to limit job benefits for older workers. The House voted 406-17 Wednesday to approve the same version of legislation passed by the Senate on Sept. 24. It now goes to the White House for President Bush's signature. The Supreme Court held in a 1989 ruling that employee benefits were not afforded protection under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967. The measure puts Congress on record as taking the position that the high court's decision went against lawmakers' intent when they passed the landmark age discrimination bill 23 years ago. Several lawmakers had been seeking to reverse the effects of the court ruling more than two years ago in a case pitting June Betts of Cincinnati against the Employees Retirement System of Ohio. At 61, Ms. Betts, a speech pathologist in Hamilton County, Ohio, was disabled with Alzheimer's disease. She was denied disability retirement because she was over 60. The ruling denied her an additional $200 a month.
---
DOC.HEAD: DEA Seizes More Than $1 Billion in Cash, Assets in Fiscal 1990
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration seized more than $1 billion in cash and other assets from drug traffickers in the fiscal year that ended Sunday, says agency chief Robert C. Bonner. Reaching the $1 billion mark ``shows that DEA has been quite aggressive in stripping drug traffickers of their ill-gotten gains, the proceeds of their illegal activities,'' Bonner said. The $1.025 billion seized, according to preliminary figures for fiscal 1990, was far higher than the DEA's budget of $548.7 million for that year, Bonner said. It represented a 4.4 percent increase over the $979.1 million in assets seized by the DEA the previous year. But Bonner said in an interview Tuesday that the seizures won't help defray the federal budget deficit just yet. The assets must first be forfeited, which can take years.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Admiral Warns of Attitudes In Philippine Military
DOC.TEXT: At about the same time Philippine soldiers began a rebellion on the southern island of Mindanao, a U.S. admiral was expressing concern to Congress over attitudes within the country's military. Since a coup attempt in December 1989, said Rear Adm. M. A. McDevitt, it has become apparent that some Philippine officers want to take roles ``that transcend defense and security.'' McDevitt, speaking for the Pentagon, testified Wednesday afternoon before the House Asian affairs subcommittee. He was joined by committee members and other Bush administration officials in reiterating warnings that any military overthrow of President Corazon Aquino would bring an immediate cutoff of all U.S. aid. He spoke shortly after mutinous soldiers seized an army base and the city of Butuan on Mindanao at 1 a.m. local time - noon in Washington. Military leaders in Manila apparently remained loyal to the government, however, and said they were taking steps to isolate the uprising. ``A military takeover would only compound, not alleviate, current problems and frustrations,'' McDevitt said in written testimony submitted to the committee. ``It would not be, as some suggest, a short cut to solutions and reforms, but rather a short cut to disaster.'' McDevitt summarized his testimony for the hearing and answered questions from the panel. He said there is ``no hard evidence of serious plotting'' among leading elements of the Philippine military and discounted speculation in Manila of a possible ``constitutional coup'' in which top brass would back a bloodless overthrow of Mrs. Aquino. Even that kind of overthrow, said McDevitt, would require a total aid cutoff under U.S. law. ``However,'' he said, ``that has not deterred the plotters from moving twice in the past, and therefore probably would not be a pivotal factor in any future decision to launch another coup attempt.'' McDevitt said soldiers' attempts to influence issues that go beyond their traditional role ``seem now to be an established feature of the Philippine political landscape.'' ``We continue to hope and to emphasize that the military use its voice wisely and responsibly, and continue to reject radical action as a short cut to social, economic and military reform,'' he said. In other testimony, officials said the Philippines continues to lag behind in using foreign aid, but problems facing the country require more rather than less assistance. Congress has been cutting President Bush's aid requests to the country which is struggling to overcome devastation from a strong earthquake, drought and flooding and has been rocked by the Persian Gulf crisis's impact on oil prices and overseas Filipino workers' remittances. Carole Adelman, assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development, said $40 million remains uncommitted from the first-year U.S. contribution to a multinational aid plan and the pipeline of unspent aid to the Philippines from all sources totals about $500 million dollars. She said, however, that much of the backlog is understandable because of the windfall $3.5 billion dollars pledged under the Multilateral Assistance Initiative, which is in addition to aid tied to the U.S. bases and other bilateral assistance.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Gain in Brazilian Congressional and Gubernatorial Vote
DOC.TEXT: In what was seen as a vote of support for President Fernando Collor de Mello, conservatives led or won most races in nationwide congressional and gubernatorial elections, exit polls indicated. But polls also indicated that about 12 percent of Brazil's 83 million voters cast blank ballots Wednesday to protest Collor's harsh economic policies and to express a general sentiment that politicians are not serving the people. Final results will not be known for more than a week. However, exit surveys indicated conservatives had captured at least eight of 27 gubernatorial races and a majority of Senate and House seats. The far-right Liberal Front Party, which won only one governorship in 1985, won in five states on Wednesday. Collor's tiny National Reconstruction Party made gains across the country, including the governorship in Collor's home state of Alagoas in northern Brazil. Besides the governorships in all 26 states and the capital district of Brasilia, all 503 seats in the federal House of Representatives and 31 of 81 Senate spots were at stake. Runoffs will be held Nov. 25 if no gubernatorial candidate receives 50 percent of the vote. A majority is not required in other races. Voting is mandatory in Brazil and from the southern pampas to the northern Amazon jungle, voters lined up to cast ballots. Troops patrolled many areas to ensure peaceful voting, the first since December, when Collor became the country's first popularly elected president since 1960. The military gave up power in 1985 after ruling the country by dictatorship for 19 years. Collor cast his ballot before cheering residents in his home city of Maceio, 1,400 miles northeast of Rio. ``We have shown with this election that our democracy is stable and consolidated,'' the 40-year-old president said. Local issues largely prevailed in the election campaigns, but analysts said the vote was an important indicator of Collor's popularity. There has been growing resentment of his economic austerity plan, which aims to halt annual inflation of nearly 5,000 percent, but Brazil's left appeared unable to capitalize on the discontent. City streets were littered with pamphlets and streamers when the polls closed, but the election fervor that marked last year's presidential vote was absent. In major states, polls showed that most voters did not even know who the congressional candidates were. ``Politicians show up in the slums the day before the election and throw a few barbecue parties to get votes, then do nothing for the next four years,'' said machine operator Joao Alves Filho, 34, as he stood in a voting line in Rio's middle-class district of Vila Isabela. He said he would cast a blank ballot. In Sao Paulo, the top electoral prize with almost 19 million voters, rightist Paulo Maluf of the Social Democrats - the official party of the former military regime - led the gubernatorial race with 42 percent of the vote. Leftists won governorships outright in just two states, in Rio de Janeiro and in the northern state of Ceara, according to exit polls by the Brazilian Institute of Public Opinion and Statistics. The militant socialist Workers Party nearly captured December's presidential election and had been seen as a growing force in Brazilian politics. But it faded dramatically in this campaign. Only in one gubernatorial race, in the far-western Amazon state of Acre, was a Workers Party candidate close to the lead and even there he is expected to face a runoff. In remote areas, a number of elderly voters traveled miles by canoe, mule and horseback to reach regional electoral centers. Ballot boxes are delivered by mules and the vote count is mainly done by hand. The new congress will meet on Feb. 3, 1991. The winners in the governor's races take office on March 15.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Revolt On Southern Island In What Appears New Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT that Mindanao not southernmost island, MOVE up that coup leader took part in December coup attempt. Picks up 8th pvs, `The rebels ...' ^By EILEEN GUERRERO
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers mutinied across the northern coast of the country's second-largest island Thursday in what appeared the first stage of a new attempt to overthrow President Corazon Aquino. The mutineers on Mindanao, about 500 miles south of Manila, seized the city of Butuan and also appeared to be in control of Cagayan de Oro, a major port of about 200,000 people. They were led by the former chief of staff of Mrs. Aquino's guard force, who has been at large since participating in a bloody December coup attempt. Witnesses said rebels were marching around the streets of Cagayan de Oro in a virtual ``victory parade,'' attracting large crowds of curiosity seekers. The armed forces went on nationwide alert and Mrs. Aquino gathered with her Cabinet, senior military officers and congressmen at the presidential palace. ``I'm calling once again on the people to rally against these troublemakers,'' Mrs. Aquino said on the radio. ``The constitution will be upheld with force when challenged with force.'' Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said the mutiny appeared a secessionist move and vowed to do ``whatever is necessary to prevent any dismemberment of this republic.'' Officials said about 200 rebels launched the revolt about 1 a.m., seizing the 402nd Brigade army base in Butuan, about 500 miles south of Manila. Flights to Mindanao were canceled and schools on the island closed. The rebels later moved into Cagayan de Oro, 70 miles west of Butuan. Manila radio station DZXL interviewed their leader, renegade Col. Alexander Noble, at the regional national police headquarters in Cagayan de Oro. ``This shows that the free Mindanao movement is not just propaganda,'' Noble told reporters at Camp Evangelista. In the city of Iligan just west of Cagayan de Oro, loyalist troops secured government buildings and blocked roads to the nearby military camp after residents said a rebel helicopter had hovered overhead and urged troops to join the mutiny. The residents said government planes chased the helicopter away. National Security Adviser Rafael Ileto said that the rebels hope to establish a secessionist government on Mindanao, then ``move up north.'' There have been rumors that a coup attempt was brewing in the region for nearly six months. Military sources said the mutineers were planning to stage ``pocket rebellions'' in remote areas of the country before striking in the capital. Mrs. Aquino has survived six coup attempts since she took office in February 1986. In the most recent attempt, in December, rebels seized Manila's financial district in bloody fighting and nearly toppled the government. More than 100 people were killed. Also Thursday, a bomb exploded outside a Manila army base three hours after the Mindanao base was taken. There were no injuries. It was the 35th explosion in the capital since August. Officials see the bombings as the work of military officers hoping to destabilize the country. De Villa said soldiers from the 53rd Infantry Battalion, one of the units at the 402nd Brigade, organized the takeover. About 3,000 soldiers are based at the brigade. The brigade's commanding officer, Col. Hercules Galon, apparently escaped the rebel soldiers, said a military spokesman, Brig. Gen. Emiliano Templo. But later Templo said Galon may have joined the rebels. Templo said the dissidents cut off communication lines from Butuan, and officials in Manila were relying on commercial radio stations and the military regional headquarters in Cagayan de Oro. De Villa said he called commanding officers of various camps around the country and was assured of their loyalty. ``I think this is small thing and we can control this,'' de Villa said in a radio interview. ``We wish to inform the public that the armed forces is united. Except for this breakaway group, we are in control of all units in Manila and the entire country.'' Templo said there were no plans to send troops from Luzon, the main island, to reinforce government forces on Mindanao. ``We are guarding against the possibility that this Butuan incident has a second part in another part of the country that we are not aware of,'' de Villa said. ``We are just taking precautions.'' Rumors of a new coup plot in recent months have suggested that military dissidents would seize strongpoints in the south to draw government forces out of Manila, then start a new uprising there. The bomb Thursday exploded at a water pumping station at the Philippine Army headquarters in Manila, de Villa said. There were no injuries. De Villa appealed to the mutineers to surrender. ``I just want to tell them that this uprising is a big mistake and may endanger our civilians,'' de Villa said. ``What they did is something that cannot be supported by our civilains and the majority of the armed forces of the Philippines.'' ``Don't allow our armed forces to be divided. Think it over because there is still time,'' he said. Since August, government troops had been chasing Noble in the jungles of Agusan del Sur province south of Butuan. Noble was involved in the December coup and escaped to Mindanao, where he organized a private army.

DOC.HEAD: Last Shaker Eldress Dies at 93
DOC.TEXT: Bertha Lindsay, the last eldress of the Shakers, a celibate religious sect that promoted communal living and pacifism for more than 200 years, has died. She was 93. Lindsay, who died Wednesday, was one of the last members of the religion that once boasted 6,000 members in 24 communities. One woman in her 90s remains in Canterbury, once home to 400 Shaker residents. Fewer than 10 live in Maine. Able to add to their ranks only by taking in orphans or converts, Shaker spiritual leaders decided to halt new membership in 1965, but Lindsay often said the movement's beliefs would not die with the last Shakers. ``Mother'' Ann Lee, who brought the religion to the United States in the 1774, prophesied that ultimately Shakers ``would diminish to as many as a child could count on one hand, and then there would be a revival of the spirit,'' Lindsay once said. Lindsay, born July 28, 1897, in Braintree, Mass., died nearly 2{ years after Eldress Gertrude Soule, who also lived at Shaker Village in Canterbury. Only 94-year-old Sister Ethel Hudson remains in the New Hampshire village. A small community in Sabbathday Lake, Maine, includes five pre-1965 members and at least three admitted afterward despite the decision by Canterbury leaders. The religion originated in England in the 1770s as the Shaking Quakers and grew under Lee's leadership. She who moved to New York in 1774 with eight followers. The community in Canterbury was founded in the 1780s. The Shakers, formally the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearing, gained their nickname from trembling brought on by religious fervor. They advocated living apart from society at large in communal villages. Everyone was considered equal and Shaker government offered women leadership roles little known in the 19th and early 20th centuries. Two eldresses and two elders formed the ministry that made decisions for the society. Lindsay said she believed Lee's prophesy that Shaker beliefs would gain broader acceptance. ``It wouldn't be called Shakers,'' she said. ``They wouldn't live in communities. But it would be worldwide felt and known. And we think that is coming to pass.'' As evidence, Lindsay noted that more visitors come to Shaker Village every year, including many from Europe. They view exhibits of the efficient homespun handicrafts and furniture that made Shakers famous, including creations like the flat broom, clothespin and ladderback chairs. Lindsay came to Canterbury in 1905 as an orphan. Orphans taken in by the Shakers had to decide at age 21 whether to take a vow of celibacy and remain in the community or leave. ``I had studied the laws and regulations of the church and felt this was the life for me,'' Lindsay said. ``I could give as much here as I could anywhere else in the world and could have more friends, both men and women. If I had gone into the world and married, I wouldn't have had that. ... It has been a busy, active life and a wonderful experience.'' When she turned 90, Lindsay lost her sight and put her energies into recording her life story and memories of Shaker life. ``I want people to know we did have fun and plenty of it,'' she said. Lindsay is survived by a niece. At Lindsay's request, no funeral will be held, but a memorial service will be held at an unspecified date.

DOC.HEAD: County Bans Future Prostitution at Defunct Bordello
DOC.TEXT: Prostitution has been banned at Mustang Ranch, America's best-known legal brothel, by county officials who are tired of its notoriety. The prohibition leaves no room for the Internal Revenue Service to sell the 105-room, 440-acre ranch as a working bordello when it goes up for auction to pay the longtime owners' tax debt, estimated at $13 million. The Storey County Commission decided Tuesday to make prostitution illegal in the area of the county where the Mustang is located, leaving in the clear a nearby brothel. Commissioners stressed they remain in favor of legal prostitution in Nevada, but rezoned the Mustang because of the ``circus'' surrounding it for 35 years. ``It just wouldn't look good for Storey County,'' Commissioner Karl Larson said. The Mustang's owners, Joe and Sally Conforte, had tried unsuccessfully to sell the ranch. They filed for liquidation Sept. 18 and federal bankruptcy trustees assumed management of the Mustang. The trustees had expected to operate the ranch as a brothel to pay off creditors, but U.S. Bankruptcy Judge James Thompson said the only creditor of significance was the IRS, so he turned the Mustang over to the agency Sept. 21 to dispose of as it wished. IRS spokeswoman Norma Lally said Wednesday she did not know whether the commission action would affect bidding at the auction. The IRS said it will let the buyer decide what to do with the property. The agency is making an inventory of the brothel and its contents. The auction is at least one to two months away, Lally said. The County Commission's action gives Conforte's nephew, David Burgess, a monopoly in the county's brothel business at the Old Bridge Ranch next to the Mustang. Larson said the county would more than double Burgess' $30,000 annual license fee to make up for lost revenue from the Mustang. Burgess' wife, Ingrid, manager and co-owner of the Old Bridge Ranch, said business is booming. ``It's been very busy here ever since the Mustang shut down. We have all the girls over here we can hold,'' she said. ``I think it's sad a lot of people have lost their jobs. There is nothing wrong with a little competition.''

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Down Moderately, Dollar Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with closing. Picks up 6th pvs, `Currency traders ...'
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed sharply lower Thursday, and the dollar dropped against the Japanese yen. The dollar finished the day at 135.90 yen, down 0.75 yen from Wednesday's close. Trading ranged between 135.65 yen and 135.98 yen, after opening at 135.88 yen. It was the lowest opening rate for the U.S. currency in 14 months. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 571.20 points, or 2.56 percent, to 22,278.19 points. It had shed 49.04 points on Wednesday after a record surge the previous day. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark 10-year government bond fell to 8.290 percent , down from 8.310 percent on Wednesday. The price rose to 82.40 yen, up from 82.32 yen on Wednesday. Currency traders said the dollar weakened after U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said Wednesday that the proposed U.S. budget would ``almost certainly'' depress interest rates. Greenspan told a Congressional committee that failure to approve the budget's $500 billion deficit-reduction package would be a ``grave mistake'' with serious consequences for an already weakened U.S. economy. The market seems to have reached a floor at 135 yen to the dollar, however, said Hiroyuki Yamaguchi at Commerz Bank A.G. ``There seems to be a lot of buying orders at 135, I think maybe we will not see 134 for the rest of this week,'' he said. The recovery on the stock market, short-covering and pessimism about lower interest rates in the United States are moving the dollar-yen exchange, said Masato Hayashi, chief customer dealer for the Bank of Tokyo. ``Every morning we see a much lower level. So every day, at first, people try to sell. Then there are more buyers, until the dollar reaches the high from outside (markets). Then the dollar falls again,'' he said. The dollar probably already has hit its high for the day, he said. Stock traders cited higher oil prices and an overnight fall on the New York stock market as reasons for the falling Nikkei average. ``Basically, I think what we are seeing is a fair amount of profit taking,'' said Steve Usher of Kleinwort Benson International, Inc. Tuesday's record surge left people ``confused,'' but the basic sentiment is still depressed because of poor fundamentals and uncertainty in the externals, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dust Storm Blamed in Fatal Highway Crash
DOC.TEXT: A blinding dust storm triggered two mass collisions of cars and big-rig trucks on an interstate highway. One person died and at least a dozen were injured, authorities said. Interstate 82 in southeastern Washington was closed for more than nine hours Wednesday because of low visibility from dust blown by wind gusting to more than 33 mph, the Washington State Patrol said. Before it closed, two crashes involving 26 vehicles snarled lanes in both directions. Christina Rivera, 24, of Hermiston, Ore., died in a crash involving 15 cars and three tractor-trailer rigs on the southbound side, the state patrol said. Another mass collision, involving five cars and three big rigs was reported in northbound lanes, troopers said. At least 12 people were taken to hospitals, the patrol said. The interstate reopened before midnight.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Store Owner: Jury Verdict Was Racist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 2nd graf.
