They were presented at a private ceremony by Ambassador William Swing. ``To you, Nelson Mandela, we present `Song of Freedom' as an expression of our esteem and appreciation for the grace, dignity, strength, and unparalleled leadership you have brought to people of color and conscience throughout the world,'' said a letter from the 24-member Congressional Black Caucus. ``To you, Winnie Mandela, the soaring presence embodied in `The Masai Woman' reflects our respect for the courage you have shown under the greatest adversity that can be visited upon humankind - the challenge of survival in the face of separation from those whom we love,'' the letter said. It was signed by Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., the caucus chairman; and Rep. Alan Wheat, D-Mo., caucus vice chairman and president of the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Convicted of Laundering Drug Money with Noriega's Banker
DOC.TEXT: A court convicted a British financier on Thursday of conspiring with the personal banker of Panamanian Gen. Manuel Noriega to launder drug money. ``The banking community in London has got to learn the message that they are not to deal with drug money,'' Judge Michael Parker said in convicting Syed Akbar. Akbar, 46, was given an 18-month jail sentence and ordered to pay $94,500. He was the second of two London financiers to be convicted in connection with drug money laundering. Last month, a court sentenced Asif Baakza, 40, to two years on the same conspiracy charge, but suspended half the sentence. Both men worked in the corporate unit of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, and were convicted of conspiring with Amjad Awan and Akbar Bilgrami, BCCI officials in Miami. Awan, who once worked for the bank in Panama, told a U.S. Senate subcommittee that he kept a secret bank account for Noriega. The deposed Panamanian leader is awaiting trial in the United States on drug charges. Juries in the trials of Akbar and Baakza heard tapes made clandestinely in a U.S. Customs Service sting operation. On the tapes, the two financiers agreed to help in ``processing'' drug money. Baakza was said to have accepted about $1 million which was later withdrawn in the Bahamas under the guise of a loan. Akbar was said to have laundered drug money into gold on the London Futures Market. Both men were arrested by British customs officers shortly after arrests were made in the United States in October 1988. BCCI pleaded guilty in the United States earlier this year to laundering cash. A number of people, including Awan and Bilgrami, were found guilty and are awaiting sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Rioters Clash With Police Over Reports of Police Corruption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to ADD byline, UPDATE number of arrests, more protesters, background. Pickup 10th, `Such street...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people protesting alleged police corruption threw rocks at rows of police guarding a police station in Osaka today, the third day of street violence, which is rare in Japan. About 1,500 riot police were mobilized late today in response to the unrest in which at least 54 people have been injured - including 30 policemen - and 25 arrested in the western Japanese city, police said. The violence began on Tuesday following news reports that a local officer took a bribe from a gangster. Although the policeman has not admitted guilt, an Osaka police official issued an apology today in an attempt to ease the tension, according to the Kyodo News Service. But there was no immediate sign of lessening tensions. Since Tuesday, residents of the low-income Nishinari district have surrounded the area police station, burning cars and throwing rocks and beer bottles, police said. At its peak Wednesday, the crowd reached about 1,500. Several gangs operate in the Nishinari district, and the crime rate is higher than average, police said. Locals say there have been bad feelings between area residents and police, who have adopted harsh tactics to battle crime, including a 24-hour surveillance camera system on street corners. The rioters, mostly menial and day laborers, burned 20 automobiles parked nearby Wednesday night. More than 1,000 police were mobilized to block protesters from reaching the Nishinari police station. Tonight about 700 demonstrators confronted riot police in front of the station. Rioters, most of them high school-age youths, intermittantly lunged from the crowd and threw rocks and firecrackers at police. Such street violence is seldom seen in Japan, where public issues rarely inflame passions. In recent years, there have been few disturbances besides occasional battles between leftist extremists who oppose expansion of Narita Airport outside of Tokyo and riot police. The chief of the Osaka police headquarters, Masahiro Tsubakihara, issued an apology at the local legislature today in response to reports that an officer was involved in scandal, Kyodo reported. The violence began following news reports Tuesday that a police sergeant was suspected of having taken about $22,000 in bribes from a local gangster in exchange for leaking information on police operations. ``Come out dirty policemen. We will not stand this any longer,'' Kyodo News Service quoted one worker as shouting at the police headquarters as he hurled rocks. Local news reports said the officer allegedly leaked information on police operations to the gang in return for the money.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Klaus Leaves 2 Dead, 4 Missing in Martinique
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 8-9 pvs, `Klaus remained...Center said' with 2 grafs to UPDATE location. Pickup 11th, `It's far...'
DOC.TEXT: FORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique (AP) - Tropical Storm Klaus spawned torrential rain and severe flooding on this French island in the Caribbean today, leaving at least two people dead and four missing, authorities said. The storm, with winds of 60 mph, was centered about 140 miles north of Martinique and prompted tropical storm warnings and watches throughout the Leeward Islands. It was the 11th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season. Among the missing in Martinique were two sisters, aged eight and 14, who were swept from a flooded bridge Wednesday in St. Joseph in the center of the island. Rescuers were searching for the girls today. The bodies of two men were found late Wednesday. Authorities said one of the victims was a 56-year-old farmer, who fell from a tractor into a flooded ditch. Circumstances of the second man's death were unclear, but it was believed he also drowned in floodwaters that reached nearly 10 feet in places. Two fishermen were reported missing today in Riviere Pilote, in the southeastern part of the island. Officials told Radio Caribbean International that the local outdoor market and soccer stadium were under 5.5 feet of water. Many houses were flooded in the northern part of the island, which was particularly hard hit. Schools were closed throughout the island. Flooding disrupted telephone and electrical service. Martinique, a popular tourist spot, is an overseas department of France with a population of 336,000 people. Klaus remained almost stationary during the night and this morning. At noon EDT its center was near 16.6 north latitude and 60.5 west longitude, or about 95 miles east-southeast of Antigua, the Hurricane Center in Miami said. The storm was expected to resume a northwestward drift later today and pickup strength over the next 24 hours, the Hurricane Center said. ``It's far enough off ... so that if it stays on that track it won't move directly over the Leeward Islands. But just a little jog to the west and it certainly could hit some of the islands,'' said hurricane specialist Max Mayfield. ``Right now, there wouldn't be that much (damage) from the wind, the biggest damage would be done by the rainfall. They could have as much as 10 to 15 inches of rainfall,'' he said. ``But they could really have a problem with mudslides and flash floods.'' Tropical storm warnings were issued for the islands of the northeast Caribbean, including St. Martin, St. Barthelemy, Saba, St. Eustatius, Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and St. Kitts-Nevis. A tropical storm watch was in effect for the island of Guadeloupe and the neighboring French islands, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables.

DOC.HEAD: Log Book Recording Death of `Red Baron' is Sold
DOC.TEXT: A British fighter pilot's log book recording the shooting down of ``Red Baron'' Manfred von Richthoven in World War I was sold Thursday for $5,700. The auction house Christie's said a businessman in the northern English city of Manchester bought the log book in a telephone bid at the sale of aviation art and literature held at the Commonwealth Institute. The buyer wanted to remain anonymous. The log book belonged to a friend of the late Lt. Lionel Lomas, a member of the flight led by Capt. Roy Brown, a Canadian, who is credited with shooting down the famous German ace behind British lines over the Somme battlefield in 1918. Richthofen was known as the ``Red Baron'' because his Fokker triplane was painted red. He was credited with 80 victories. The log records that on April 21, 1918, 14 British Camel fighters attacked 24 enemy planes, shooting down three, and that Brown brought down Richthofen. The claim was contested by Australian troops who said they shot down Richthofen when they fired on his plane from the ground as it flew low, pursued by Brown. ``We think the log book kept by another pilot is good evidence to support Brown,'' said Susan Adams of Christie's South Kensington salesroom. ``We have never had a log book from the First World War in a sale here before and because of von Richthofen's fame we had many inquiries about it from Europe, Australia and Canada, as well as Britain,'' she said. Bidding began at $1,890 and went up in $189 increases. The final price was double the pre-sale estimate.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Counting Down for Discovery Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with accident involving Atlantis. Picks up 2nd graf pvs: `Discovery was ...'
DOC.TEXT: Success is sorely needed in shuttle Discovery's mission with the disputed, nuclear-powered probe Ulysses, said NASA, which encountered yet another problem today. A 70-pound metal beam, measuring 8-feet-11-inches long, was found inside another shuttle's engine compartment, where workers mistakenly had left it. NASA workers heard the beam bang around Atlantis' engine compartment as the orbiter was being raised into a vertical position inside the assembly building on Wednesday, NASA spokesan Bruce Buckingham said today. They were unable to open the engine compartment until today, after the solid rocket boosters and external tank were attached to the orbiter. Officials were assessing the damage, and an investigative team was being formed. It was not known whether the accident would affect Atlantis' secret military flight in early November, Buckingham said. The mission already is four months late because of Atlantis' hydrogen leaks. Discovery was scheduled to blast off at 7:35 a.m. EDT Saturday to launch the solar probe on a 1.86 billion-mile journey spanning five years. The countdown began Wednesday and proceeded without mishap. NASA test director Mike Leinbach said today two computer circuit cards in Discovery's mobile launcher need to be replaced, a minor job. ``Other than that, it's very clean,'' he said. The space agency's inability to launch a shuttle in nearly half a year because of technical glitches heightens the need for a successful mission, said Edward Smith, NASA project scientist for Ulysses. ``I think it's very, very important, considering all the problems that NASA has had,'' Smith said. ``We'd certainly love to have a success. It gets everybody's morale back up. It adds to their confidence.'' Ulysses, a European Space Agency probe, has been ready for a ride since 1983. After several delays that included changes in the satellite's upper stage rockets, the mission was set for May 1986 but was put back on hold after the shuttle Challenger exploded earlier that year. ``We've never gotten this close before,'' Smith said. ``I think all of us are excited and apprehensive at the same time.'' Anti-nuclear and environmental activists, however, want the $750 million mission canceled for safety reasons. They oppose NASA's use of nearly 23.7 pounds of deadly plutonium in a generator attached to Ulysses. As it decays, the plutonium will provide electricity for the satellite. A hearing was scheduled for late today in Washington before U.S. District Judge Oliver Gasch, who last year refused to halt Atlantis' launch with a plutonium-powered satellite bound for Jupiter. Peter Wenzel, project scientist for the European Space Agency, said a plutonium generator is the only means of getting Ulysses into an orbit over the sun's poles. NASA officials said there is little chance plutonium would be released and, if it did, would pose little health risk. The 807-pound spacecraft will be hurtled toward Jupiter, which will give Ulysses a gravity assist and push it out of the ecliptic plane. If all goes well, it will become the first spacecraft to pass over the solar poles. ``Everybody is quite optimistic that many of our views about the sun and the solar system will be absolutely revolutionized,'' Smith said. Columbia has been grounded by hydrogen leaks since May; none of its four countdowns in four months proceeded past fueling. Atlantis has been crippled by leaking hydrogen since June. Discovery was the last shuttle to fly when it carried the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit in April. Although the flight went smoothly, NASA suffered harsh criticism when the telescope's primary mirror was found to be flawed. NASA officials are confident Discovery will not spring any leaks when more than a half-million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen are pumped into the shuttle Friday night. Discovery boasts top-of-the-line plumbing that has been checked thoroughly. In addition, hardly any work was performed in Discovery's main engine compartment after its last flight.

DOC.HEAD: Gallery Director: Photos `Tough, Brutal' But Art Nevertheless
With PM-2 Live Crew, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to restore dropped words in Ed's note. Leads with 19 grafs to UPDATE with delay in today's proceedings over witness's credentials. Picks up penultimate graf pvs: `The U.S. ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: An art gallery director on trial for displaying Robert Mapplethorpe's work says graphic photographs at the center of the obscenity case are ``tough, brutal, sometimes disgusting'' - but worthwhile art. The nation's first obscenity trial of an art gallery and its director was expected to go to the jury by early Friday after rebuttal testimony from the prosecution and closing arguments. But today's proceedings were delayed by a defense challenge of the credentials of a rebuttal witness for the prosecution. ``We're in a holding pattern,'' Hamilton County Municipal Court Judge David Albanese told jurors. ``We're not under any pressure to rush it, and we hope you're not under any pressure to rush it.'' The prosecution wanted to present testimony by Judith Reisman, a former producer for the old ``Captain Kangaroo'' TV show and author of a 1,600-page study on children, crime and violence. Defense lawyers said Ms. Reisman lacked the qualifications to be a witness. Dennis Barrie, director of the Contemporary Arts Center, scoffed Wednesday at a prosecutor's suggestion that he and the gallery showed an exhibit of Mapplethorpe's photographs as a publicity stunt. ``This has been a strain on all of us, a strain on me personally and a strain on my family,'' Barrie testified. ``But we were very committed to the principle at stake here.'' Barrie and the gallery were charged April 7 with pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material, both misdemeanors. The trial is focused on seven of 175 photos in the exhibit, ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.'' Three of the photos show penetration of a man's anus with various objects. One shows a man urinating in another man's mouth. A fifth shows penetration of a penis with a pinkie finger and two show children with their genitals exposed. Barrie said some of the acts depicted in the show were ``tough, brutal, sometimes disgusting,'' but part of the photographic challenge Mapplethorpe accepted in trying to create a work of art. ``As difficult as the subject matter may be, you see the ability of the man working through. He was brilliant with a camera,'' Barrie said. ``Every standard I had in terms of art exhibitions said this was a perfectly fine exhibition and there should be no change in the way the exhibition was presented.'' Mapplethorpe, who was known for pursuing homosexual themes, died of AIDS in March 1989 at age 42. The exhibit set an attendance record - 81,000 - for an art exhibit in Cincinnati during a seven-week run at the gallery ending in May. The show closes this week in Boston, where 103,000 tickets have been sold. In January 1989, the Contemporary Art Center's board endorsed Barrie's proposal to schedule an exhibit of Mapplethorpe photos. In June 1989, three months after Mapplethorpe died, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., disputed use of National Endowment of the Arts funding for work that might be considered obscene. Barrie said the board talked about the controversy and decided to go ahead with the exhibit. The board's legal counsel, Stuart Schloss Jr., testified earlier Wednesday that the board tried to get legal protection before the show. The board filed a lawsuit asking the court to rule whether the exhibit was obscene, but the case was dismissed the day before the public opening of the exhibit in Cincinnati. After Barrie's testimony, Albanese refused a defense request to dismiss the charges. Defense lawyers argued the prosecution never proved its case. The U.S. Supreme Court's legal test for an obscenity determination asks whether the dominant theme of the artwork appeals to prurient interest in sex, whether the work is patently offensive based on contemporary community standards, and whether the work lacks serious artistic or political value. If convicted of both charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000 for conviction on both counts.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Stops Sudanese Freighter From Entering Gulf of Aqaba
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy guided missile frigate prevented a Sudanese freighter from entering the Gulf of Aqaba today after a boarding party found that its cargo manifest did not account for all of its cargo, the Pentagon announced. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said no shots were fired. Williams said a party from the frigate Samuel B. Roberts boarded the 12,900-ton Blue Nile, registered to the Sudanese Shipping Line, in the Northern Red Sea. Williams said it was the seventh time a U.S. ship had diverted a vessel as part of the enforcement of the United Nations embargo on most shipping to Iraq and Kuwait. He said the vessel was a roll-on, roll-off ship carrying mostly industrial equipment. ``The problem that resulted in the diversion was that the maniest on board the ship did not indicate the shipper and destination for all the cargo found during the boarding,'' Williams said. He said he did not know where the Sudanese ship headed after agreeing not to enter the Gulf of Aqaba. He said Navy personnel left the ship after the diversion. Williams said there had been 170 boardings since the beginning of the embargo, 139 of them by U.S. ships. He said 1,675 ships had been intercepted.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Dole A Big Draw on GOP Fund-Raising Circuit
DOC.TEXT: When President Bush scrapped a New England campaign swing to lobby Congress for a deficit-reduction plan, the White House scrambled for a popular Cabinet secretary to take his place. The president's political operatives quickly settled on Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, consistently a big draw on the national campaign scene. ``She's warm, sincere and one of the best campaigners I've ever seen,'' said Steve Beaujon, a spokesman for Gary Franks' congressional campaign in Connecticut. Bush had been scheduled to appear for Franks on Thursday in Waterbury, Conn., but Mrs. Dole was asked to make the trip instead. She also was asked to step in for Bush at a $1,000-a-plate luncheon in Boston to raise money for the Massachusetts GOP, gubernatorial candidate William Weld and Senate candidate James Rappaport. Mrs. Dole, 54, is campaigning in more than a dozen states this fall for more than 60 gubernatorial and House and Senate candidates. Among Bush's Cabinet secretaries, she's at the top of the list of campaigners that GOP candidates eye when scouting for big names to invigorate rank-and-file party members, Republican officials said. Jack Kemp, secretary of housing and urban development, also is in high demand. ``She gets down off of the pedestal and she becomes one of the many,'' said Hillard Selck, a Republican National Committeeman from Missouri. ``There's no `Stay away from me, stay behind the barrier, I'm too good for you.' That impresses people. They like to be able to touch,'' Selck said. Sen. Pete Wilson of California has lured Mrs. Dole in twice since July to help his gubernatorial race. He's made a bid to have her back for a third swing right before the November election. On her last visit to help Wilson, 600 tickets for a $100-a-plate dinner sold out, netting Wilson a quick $50,000 or more that evening, said campaign manager Otto Bos. Mrs. Dole also has campaigned for Rep. Lynn Martin in Illinois, who is trying to unseat Democratic Sen. Paul Simon; Gov. Kay Orr in Nebraska, running for re-election; Clayton Williams, bidding for the governorship in Texas; Gov. Mike Hayden, seeking a second term in Kansas; and Rep. Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, attempting to oust Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell. Part of her draw, Republicans say, is that Mrs. Dole herself is a GOP success story. The Harvard-educated lawyer served as President Reagan's transportation secretary before Bush nabbed her for the Labor Department post. ``She's a good speaker and very dynamic. Here you have a prime example of someone who is a pro, who excels at what she does. To have someone like that showcased for you is a plus,'' Bos said. Mrs. Dole is not without critics. Champions of workers' rights give her credit for resurrecting an agency widely considered a nonentity during the Reagan era. Yet they also wonder if some of her projects - such as well-publicized crackdowns on child labor violators and mandatory seat belts for job-related travel - carry much substance. ``I don't think anyone in the administration signifies the dichotomy within the White House better than Liddy Dole,'' said Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont. ``She presents a kinder and gentler face, but precious little decision-making or leadership.'' Joseph Kinney, who runs the National Safe Workplace Institute, a private watchdog group in Chicago, contended that Mrs. Dole's pledge to improve worker safety is ``all bark and no bite.'' Still, despite her skeptics, Mrs. Dole has few enemies on Capitol Hill. She dismisses speculation that she plans to step down to run for the North Carolina Senate seat now held by Terry Sanford, a first-term Democrat up for re-election in 1992. ``I have plenty of challenges right where I am,'' Mrs. Dole said during a recent interview from her Labor Department office. ``One politician in the family's probably enough for the time being,'' she said, referring to her husband, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. But she didn't rule out a future bid for some type of elective job. ``That's not to say that some time, at some point ... I think if you're a person who enjoys people, who has been in the political system all your life, that's a possibility ... but I have no plans to do that now,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Steams Out of Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 5th pvs, `In Washington...' to UPDATE with Pentagon comment. Pickup 6th pvs, `The carrier, with...'
DOC.TEXT: The USS Independence, the first American aircraft carrier to enter the Persian Gulf in 16 years, headed out of the waterway today after a brief show of force. The carrier and its battle group entered the waterway on Tuesday. The 79,000-ton Independence left through the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow outlet of the gulf, in the early afternoon. The carrier and its battle group were sailing out to the Arabian Sea, said a U.S. military source in the region who spoke on condition of anonymity. In Washington, a Defense Department public affairs officer, Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist, confirmed that the Independence and its crew had left the gulf because ``they completed their operation there.'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said, ``We consider the mission of the Independence in the gulf a success. The mission was to demonstrate to our friends and allies in the region that it is possible to put a carrier in the gulf and carry out operations. Those were the goals, and they were accomplished.'' He said flight operations were carried out. He declined to say what the Independence would do next. The carrier, with at least 70 aircraft aboard, had been inside the gulf on a training mission. Few details had been publicized. The gulf voyage was seen as a way of showing Saddam Hussein the extent of the U.S. naval air power in the U.S.-led military buildup confronting him. The Independence was ``not meant in any way to increase regional tensions,'' Lt. Cmdr. Mark Walker, a Navy spokesman, had said earlier. He said its presence was ``a visible demonstration of the operational capabilities of a carrier battle group to our friends and allies in the region.'' The Independence had been in the northern Arabian Sea since July, before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Aircraft carriers rarely enter the gulf because it is a restricted body of water that has a high volume of shipping, leaving little room for maneuvering. There is also only one outlet, the Strait of Hormuz. In addition, its aircraft can reach Iraq and Kuwait even when the carrier is outside the gulf. The last U.S. aircraft carrier to enter the gulf was the Constellation in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Dartmouth Students, Faculty, Administrators to Protest Student Paper
DOC.TEXT: Two trustees of The Dartmouth Review apologized today for an anti-Semitic quote that appeared in the off-campus weekly, but they also criticized the college president for creating a ``lynch-mob mentality.'' Students, faculty and others at the Ivy League school planned to rally in protest of the quote by the independent paper, known for its attacks on minorities. President James Freedman and other top administrators planned to speak. The newspaper infuriated Jews by printing a quote from Adolf Hitler in its latest edition. That edition was distributed Saturday, Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement and Judaism's most solemn day. The quotation, from Hitler's ``Mein Kampf,'' was inserted unattributed into the statement of principles on The Review's masthead: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Backlash from the quote prompted the resignation of the Review's president and two staffers. Student officials of the independent newspaper said the quote was put in by an unknown staffer without the authorization or knowledge of editors. One called it ``sabotage,'' and the paper offered ``heartfelt apologies to Jews at Dartmouth and to the Dartmouth community at large.'' Trustees Dinesh D'Souza and Wendy Stone apologized at a news conference called by the Review today. D'Souza lashed out at Freedman. He called Freedman a ``bully ... who has contributed to the lynch-mob mentality on campus.'' He said Freedman and other administrators have manipulated the case to ruin the lives of the staffers at the Review. He said the trustees will contact the Jewish organization B'nai Brith to send someone to Dartmouth to help investigate the incident. Editor in Chief Kevin Pritchett, who also has taken over as president, said he ``should have been more vigilant. I will do everything in my power to find the person who did this.'' Pritchard said that, if anything, the paper is pro-Israel. Alumni and even congressmen protested the incident, some saying conservatives who've supported the Review should withdraw that support. About 2,000 members of the campus community signed positions denouncing the quote. It was not the first time the paper has attacked Jews. In 1988, the Review ran a column likening Freedman - who is Jewish - to Hitler and the effects of his campus policies to the Holocaust. On Tuesday, U.S. Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass., asked his Republican challenger in the general election, John MacGovern, to resign from the Review's board of directors. Atkins called the newspaper ``nothing more than a fountain of venom.'' MacGovern, an 1980 graduate of Dartmouth and one of the Review's founders, said he would not resign unless a senior editor was found responsible for putting the quote in. A day later, an angry open letter to the Review's advisory board signed by 84 congressmen was obtained by The Associated Press. The letter, which originated in the office of Reps. Mel Levine, D-Calif., called the paper's actions ``inexcusable and offensive,'' and said ``the time has come to end all alumni and public support for The Review.'' Students have published the Review since 1980. In their numerous clashes with the school's administration, they have enjoyed backing from some of the nation's most prominent conservatives. The Review's 10-member advisory board includes syndicated columnist Patrick Buchanan and former U.S. Rep. James Cleveland, R-N.H. In their letter, the congressmen said conservatives ``should no longer dirty their hands with this kind of anti-Semitic, racist rhetoric.'' The letter said the Review should not be censored, but that anyone who supports the paper financially or otherwise must understand that by doing so they support its views.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate Journalist Says He's Just Trying to Inform Public
DOC.TEXT: Convicted bank robber Dannie Martin has broken the rules most of his life, so he's not intimidated by prison regulations affecting his writing for the San Francisco Chronicle. A recent court ruling upheld U.S. Bureau of Prisons regulations that say a federal prisoner can't be paid for writing for a newspaper, can't be given a byline and can't ``act as a reporter.'' The ruling is being appealed, and Martin continues to write the features and commentary about prison life that have fascinated Chronicle readers since 1986. He's not getting paid and his stories don't carry a byline. But he says he risks additional jail time if he is found to have acted as a reporter. ``I've been an outlaw so long and saw myself that way, I've usually been against what rules they had anyway, so that doesn't bother me as much as it would a square,'' said Martin, a former drug abuser who has spent 25 of his 51 years in prison. ``I think the heart of the problem here, what really gets them worried, is the experiences of prison, the things that happen in here, have never been defined in a mainstream newspaper,'' said Martin, who is 10 years into a 33-year sentence for two bank robberies in Washington state. Martin has written more than 40 essays about prison life for the Chronicle's Sunday Punch section since 1986. He spent time in solitary confinement at the federal penitentiary in Lompoc, Calif., after he wrote an article in June 1988 that warned of a possible riot because of restrictions imposed by a new warden. Shortly after that, he was transferred to the federal prison in Phoenix. Martin and the Chronicle then filed suit to challenge the rules the Bureau of Prisons said he violated. U.S. District Judge Charles Legge ruled in June that the regulations were justified by the bureau's authority over prison security. He said outside newspaper reporting by inmates could cause rifts within a prison and improperly focus attention on individual inmates. Dan Dunne, a spokesman for the Bureau of Prisons, said the rules were made for security reasons long before Martin started writing for the Chronicle. ``Reporting for a newspaper from the inside can focus attention on individuals. And when you focus on individual prisoners, it could lead to violence or unrest or create situations where you have tension within the prison,'' Dunne said. Free speech advocates say the rules infringe on freedom of the press by denying the Chronicle its editorial discretion in soliciting free-lance work, purchasing outside articles and deciding who merits a byline. For their efforts to overturn the regulations, Martin and his Chronicle editor, Peter Sussman, are to be cited by the Society of Professional Journalists at the group's national convention Oct. 12. ``As the criminal justice system is collapsing all around us, it is important that we hear articulate voices from inside the prison. It's clear that the government does not want us to hear those voices,'' said Bruce W. Sanford, a Washington, D.C., lawyer who is the journalism group's First Amendment counsel. Since the ruling, the Chronicle has published articles by Martin, without his byline, describing the prison system's war on drug smuggling and a fellow prisoner's ordeal when he was wrongly accused of having swallowed contraband drugs. Martin said he is working on a story on how prisoners react to very long sentences. He said the courts should throw out the regulations he is challenging because the prison system has enough other rules in place - against lying or inciting a riot - to curb abuses by inmates writing for newspapers. ``They let people write books and get the money for it, or sell leather goods or paint pictures. That rule (against compensation) is ridiculous. There's no logical reason for it,'' Martin said. The prohibition on bylines is ``nothing but a thinly veiled attempt to destroy my credibility,'' he said. ``My readers know me and they know that's me writing. But if I hadn't established that, they'd be saying, `Who is this guy and why is he saying these things?' I wouldn't have any credibility.'' Martin said he would like to get a job as a journalist when he leaves prison. He's up for parole in February 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Cleaned Statue Returned
DOC.TEXT: A statue of the late President Kennedy that was defaced with spray paint has been cleaned and returned to its pedestal outside the Statehouse. A crane was used to lower the 8-foot statue into place Wednesday. The statue was unveiled on May 29, Kennedy's birthday. It was vandalized Aug. 5, the 28th anniversary of the death of actress Marilyn Monroe. Police said the vandal was obsessed with the death of Ms. Monroe. A 21-year-old Everett man was charged with malicious destruction of property.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested in `St. Peter Rapist' Cases
DOC.TEXT: A man was jailed for investigation in a series of sex assaults that included bizarre ritualistic acts on at least three women. The attacker identified himself as ``St. Peter, the messenger of the Lord'' before sexually assaulting the women. He also used a knife with an 8-inch blade to carve upside down crosses in their backs. The rapist also hacked off the victims' hair with the knife, saying he would ``present their hair to God in order to cleanse their souls,'' said police spokesman Jay Fogg. The rapist threw the victims nude from his car. Joseph Brian Socha, 29, was arrested Wednesday. Detectives acted with the help of a person who recognized Socha from news reports. Three women reported the rapist picked them up in a Volvo. Socha himself drives Volvo with a vanity plate with the letters ``GIMMEMO.'' Socha was arrested in his rented room in Rancho Palos Verdes, a wealthy seaside community. He had been a renter about two weeks and told his landlord he was a college student. Socha was booked for investigation of rape, sodomy, forced oral copulation, kidnap and assault with a deadly weapon. He was jailed in Los Angeles in lieu of $50,000 bail. The rapes occurred in and around Long Beach on Sept. 16, 21 and 28. The victims all entered the man's car voluntarily, investigators said. Two women said they were hitchhiking and the third said she accepted a ride.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor With Link to Thomas Jefferson Tapped For Federal Bench
DOC.TEXT: A 35-year-old federal prosecutor who is said to be a descendant of Thomas Jefferson has been nominated to become a federal judge. Timothy K. Lewis was selected for the lifetime appointment from a field of four candidates by Sens. John Heinz III and Arlen Specter, R-Pa. The candidates were chosen in July by the Federal Judicial Nominating Commission. ``I'm a very fortunate man,'' Lewis said after the nomination. Lewis, who is black, is a descendant of Lewis Woodson, who settled in the Pittsburgh area in 1831. Woodson was the son of Thomas Woodson, who was said to be the son of Jefferson and Sally Hemmings, a slave believed to have been the mistress of the third U.S. president. The nomination now goes to the Justice Department, which will conduct a background check before forwarding Lewis' name to the Senate for consideration. An aide to Heinz said the process probably will take about six months. If confirmed, Lewis would succeed Senior U.S. District Judge Paul A. Simmons, who announced this week he will retire at the close of the year. Lewis has been an assistant U.S. attorney since 1983. He also spent three years as an assistant district attorney in Allegheny County.

DOC.HEAD: Contest Draws Sarcastic Entrant
DOC.TEXT: Eric Sorlien didn't want to sugar-coat Philadelphia's problems. But he did anyway. Sorlien cooked up a sarcastic entry for a cake-baking contest organized to celebrate the re-lighting of the restored City Hall tower Wednesday night. Sorlien's chocolate representation of City Hall was complete with construction scaffolding and plastic rats and and pigeons. The tower's clock was carefully frosted to show 11:55. ``Midnight is bankruptcy,'' Sorlien said, referring to the city's money woes. Dinosaurs bearing the transit agency's logo prowled below. ``I'm trying to bring attention to Philadelphia's problems,'' said Sorlien, 22. But on the drive in from suburban King of Prussia, Sarlien encountered some of the city's potholes and his cake tower toppled. He entered it anyway. Judges chuckled at his entry but gave it no prizes. Sorlien said he wasn't concerned about what city officials might think. ``I've never seen Mayor (W. Wilson) Goode hit anybody, so I'm not worried about that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says He Realizes Enormity of Task Awaiting Him on Court
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter said today he realizes the enormity of the task he will face when he joins the U.S. Supreme Court next week. ``Nothing prepares a person for the responsibilities of that court,'' he said. ``So many of the justices have said or written that ... and I know that's going to be true in my case,'' Souter said. ``I can feel it already.'' He said he will get a jump on his high court career by reading briefs this weekend - when he's not house-hunting in the nation's capital. ``I will get the briefs read,'' Souter said in discussing his weekend plans for getting ready for his first week as history's 105th Supreme Court justice. Confirmed by the Senate last week, the 51-year-old judge is to be sworn in Tuesday, shortly before taking the bench with his eight new colleagues. Finding a place to live in Washington ``is one of the first orders of business,'' Souter said in an interview. As he did during his three days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Souter steered clear of any questions that might evoke a controversial answer. Asked what current justice he most closely resembles in judicial outlook, Souter declined to answer. ``You'll just have to keep score,'' he said. Souter said a contingent of lawyer friends from the Concord area and some neighbors will travel to Washington to see him sworn in. But his mother, who turns 83 this weekend, will not make the trip because of health concerns. ``There will be familiar faces to get me through,'' Souter said. Souter said he had seen an article in The Washington Post that called him one of Washington's most eligible bachelors, and said it pleased him. ``I've got to wait to see the results,'' he said, smiling.

DOC.HEAD: Sullivan Awards Community Drug Grants
DOC.TEXT: Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan told drug dealers Thursday to beware of an ``angry and active community'' as he announced grants of $42 million to 95 coalitions of community groups. ``Those who deal in drugs and death will lose this war. Those who deal in community spirit will win,''' Sullivan said at a White House news conference attended by many of the grant recipients. ``Let the traffickers and drug dealers take note of what we do here today,'' he said. ``They may fear the police, but they should fear an angry and active community even more.'' The Community Partnership Demonstration Program to fund local drug prevention efforts was part of the initial National Drug Control Strategy developed by William J. Bennett, national drug control policy director. ``Our experience indicates that nothing works as well as a community mobilized top to bottom to prevent drug use,'' Bennett said, describing the program as ``remarkably unbureaucratic.'' The 95 recipient coalitions - generally consisting of a minimum of seven organizations or agencies, including at least one local government - were selected from 200 applicants, Sullivan said. The money, included in the budget for fiscal 1990, which ended Sunday, will cover the first 15 months of the five-year program, he said. Plans developed by the coalitions will be reviewed, he said, but he rredicted the recipients will receive additional federal grants in the future to carry out their programs, and that other coalitions will be added later. Unlike many federal programs, the money will go directly to the 95 recipient coalitions, not to state governments that usually dole out federal dollars. ``We don't view this as going over the heads of the governors,'' Sullivan said. ``We view this as working with local organizations. And these are, of course, grants that are competitive. ``These awardees today are those who really developed the best coalitions, the best plans, and have the best projections for future success,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Senators Back Democrat, Urge Defeat of David Duke
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 4th graf pvs, Bagert pulled, to UPDATE with GOP confirming Bagert to drop out.
DOC.TEXT: Eight Republican senators are helping out a Democratic colleague by urging Louisiana voters to reject the GOP candidacy of former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke. ``All of us would be embarrassed and mortified to have to serve in the United States Senate with David Duke masquerading as a Republican,'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said Wednesday. The senators endorsed Democratic Sen. Bennett Johnston's re-election bid in Saturday's Louisiana primary election. Duke represents hatred and bigotry, and GOP-endorsed candidate Ben Bagert can't win, the senators said. Bagert pulled his ads from a radio station, cancelled scheduled campaign appearances today and scheduled an afternoon news conference. Charles Black, chief spokesman for the national Republican Party, said Bagert planned to drop out. ``I think that's just the final insurance against Duke getting any further,'' Black said. Five of the GOP senators signed an open letter to Louisiana voters urging Johnston's re-election, and three more are joining in the public endorsement. Duke ``has no place in our party or in this body,'' their letter said. ``The need to speak out against hatred and bigotry far outweighs any partisan interest we may have in this election, and we urge the Republicans in Louisiana to vote for Sen. Bennett Johnston.'' Duke's candidacy, and his previous election to the state Legislature as a Republican, have caused discomfort for national Republicans and prompted the Republican National Committee to repudiate him. Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, campaigned for Johnston in Louisiana recently and urged Bagert to drop out. Still, the occasion was the first any could recall that a group of Republican senators had urged re-election of a Democratic colleague. Johnston is seeking a fourth term. In Louisiana's unique open primary election system, a candidate can win the election outright by receiving more than half of the vote Saturday. But if no candidate achieves a majority, the two top vote-getters will face each other in the general election Nov. 6. In addition to Johnston, Duke and Bagert, a state senator, the field also includes two political unknowns, both Democrats. Bagert has run a distant third in polls, and the GOP senators said it appeared he could not win. Stevens said he took the step after seeing three polls each showing Bagert with less than 10 percent of the vote. Polls have shown Johnston's support at around 50 percent. The senators said they hoped Louisiana voters would give Johnston a majority Saturday and deny Duke the opportunity to run as the sole Republican candidate in the general election runoff. ``While the Republican tent is a large one and really can include just about anyone, it has no room for hatred, it has no room for racism, it has no room for anti-Semitism and some of the other things David Duke ... has espoused,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn. Bagert called the national GOP support for Johnston ``treachery,'' and denounced the senators. The letter was signed by Boschwitz, Danforth, Stevens and Sens. Warren Rudman of New Hampshire and William Cohen of Maine. Sen. Dave Durenberger of Minnesota intends to sign it, aides said. In addition, Alaska Sen. Frank Murkowski of Alaska endorsed Johnston at a news conference with the others, and Boschwitz said Sen. Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas was joining them too. Should Duke win election to the Senate, Stevens said he and others would seek to deny him membership to the Republican caucus, in effect ostracizing him. Rick Shelby, political director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, said it still was backing Bagert. But if Duke is in a runoff with Johnston, Shelby said, ``my recommendation would be that everyone from the president on down endorse Bennett Johnston.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget, Bjt
Motorists Outside White House Give A Toot About Budget Package
DOC.TEXT: Auto and truck horns outside the White House trumpeted a clamorous lunch-hour protest Thursday to the $500 billion package of tax hikes and budget cuts pushed by President Bush and congressional leaders. Responding to a half dozen demonstrators bearing ``Honk if You Hate Taxes'' signs, motorists leaned on their horns by the scores. ``Let George Bush read your lips,'' one demonstrator, dressed in a dark pinstripe suit, shouted at traffic. ``Want to pay 12 cents more for gas? Then honk,'' another yelled. A majority of motorists - and nearly all cab drivers - seemed to go along with the suggestion, eagerly leaning on their horns and raising an ear-rending racket along Pennsylvania Ave. outside the White House gates. Several booming blasts from truck horns added to the din. ``We figured if we came down here, maybe George Bush would look out the window and say, `hey, what's the racket?''' said Amy Morris, an organizer of the protest. She said she was with the National Center for Public Policy Assessment, a conservative research organization, but that ``various groups'' were participating in the demonstration. ``We plan to stage as many high-visibility events as we can to protest the package,'' she said. At the time of the demonstration, Bush was having lunch inside the White House with House Speaker Thomas S. Foley to discuss the budget stalemate. Although there was no indication that either heard the noise, the blaring horns were clearly audible throughout the White House grounds and inside the press area.

DOC.BYLINE: Criticism Mounts Of China's Handling of Crash ^By JOHN POMFRET
DOC.TEXT: China faced severe criticism Thursday for the handling of its worst reported air disaster, with aviation experts, Western diplomats, relatives of passengers and a pro-Beijing newspaper joining the chorus. Aviation experts and Hong Kong newspapers questioned Chinese authorities' decision not to evacuate Canton's Baiyun International Airport Tuesday morning while a hijacked Boeing 737 circled above for 40 minutes before it crashed into two parked jets, killing an estimated 127 people. Forty-seven of the deaths occurred aboard a full Boeing 757 that was parked awaiting takeoff to Shanghai. ``The management of the airport was in a mess,'' said Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po. ``There should be an urgent review.'' The editorial was highly unusual because the paper is considered a strident supporter of Beijing's hard-line leadership. Experts and Hong Kong newspapers also expressed surprise at the apparent decision to fight the hijacking attempt with little regard for the possible consequences. Chen Kaizhi, a high-ranking official of the Communist Party in Guangdong province, said the pilot was told ``he could follow international practice and fly the hijacked plane outside China.'' But survivors of the crash quoted the pilot as saying the plane did not have enough fuel to fly to Taiwan or Hong Kong. In reality, both destinations could have been reached, Chen said. Once the hijacker discovered he had been tricked, he either detonated explosives or scuffled with the pilot, causing the plane to lose control and careen into the two parked jets, engulfing them in a ball of flames. ``This is cops-and-robbers stuff,'' said one Hong Kong-based aviation expert, who spoke on condition of anonymity because his company does busiess in China. ``They are playing with hundreds of people's lives and still they want to get the bad guy.'' The expert noted that Chinese flight crews on previous hijacked airliners were also more concerned with thwarting hijackers than ensuring the flight's safety. The policy has apparently backfired at least once before. More than 100 people are believed to have been killed in 1981 when a jetliner went out of control and crashed after pilots struggled to resist an armed hijacker. China's state-run media never reported the incident. Chinese survivors also noted this as a factor in the crash. ``Is killing one hijacker worth the deaths of more than 100 people?'' one Chinese woman said from her hospital bed. ``Why didn't our leaders just let the plane leave China?'' Relatives of passengers hurt or killed in the disaster said they were angry because Chinese authorities gave them no information about the crash. Taiwanese relatives had to wait two days to see injured family members. A group of relatives of the 31 Taiwan passengers killed in the crash issued a statement blasting the Chinese authorities for their slowness. ``We were anxious and upset that details were only released 30 hours after the crash,'' the statement said, referring to a list of dead and injured circulated by Chinese authorities more than a day after the accident. A Hong Kong resident, Choi Man-choi, said he learned of the death of his brother, Choi Man-fat, from a news report in the British colony on Wednesday. ``I've had no confirmation from Chinese authorities whatsoever,'' he said. ``Their arrangements are in chaos.'' Taiwanese and Hong Kong relatives of deceased passengers were told they would have to wait until Friday to view the remains of their kin. Richard Stites, spokesman for the U.S. Consulate in Canton, reported that U.S. officials had been turned back at the gates of Canton's mortuary when they went to view the remains of the lone dead American, identified by her parents as Mary Anna Gilbert, a 23-year-old English teacher from Alexander City, Ala. China's media has so far issued little information on the disaster. The first official report, two sentences from the Xinhua News Agency, came about eight hours after the jet went down.

DOC.HEAD: UDC Trustees Balk at Resignation Demand
DOC.TEXT: A trustee of the University of the District of Columbia Thursday said negotiations with protesting students seeking the resignation of 11 of the 15 board members have been set back by the students' release of a tape of a closed meeting. ``The trustees who have not resigned felt that the ethics of the negotiations were violated'' by releasing the tapes, board member Alonza Evans said. ``It set us back 48 hours minimum.'' Student protest leader Mark Thompson Wednesday night broadcast a tape recording of a meeting with trustees to reporters to buttress the students argument that board members are not taking the university or the protest seriously. The students said they believe the board has done a poor job of running the 12,000-student public institution. Protesters said the board has allowed the quality of the school's academic programs to decline to a point where their accreditations are in jeopardy. Thompson Thursday said that he and other protesting students are not losing support and that negotiations are continuing. Dozens of students barricaded themselves inside a university building Sept. 26. They are refusing to leave unless all 11 mayoral appointees to the 15-member board submit resignations effective March 31. Five of the 11 board members in question have agreed to resign, including board chairman Nira Hardon Long.

DOC.HEAD: Institute Says Iraq Could Survive Just Weeks In Wr
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed by source until 4 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq could survive for a matter of weeks at most against the multinational force in the Persian Gulf, the International Institute for Strategic Studies said Thursday. ``In Cold War days, NATO commanders talked in terms of days and weeks of their capacity to sustain conventional battles,'' institute Director Francois Heisbourg said at a news conference to present an annual survey of global forces, The Military Balance 1990-91. ``The situation is not very different given the nature of conflict in that part of the world,'' he said, adding that the impact of sanctions on Iraq would also mean ``the conflict would not last terribly long.'' Analysts presenting the report said Iraq totally rearmed 11 army divisions between the end of its eight-year war with Iran in 1988 and invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. But President Saddam Hussein was forced to abandon an attempt to raise 10 new divisions - 100,000 to 150,000 troops - for his nearly 1-million-strong army because the nation of 16 million people simply does not have enough men, the analysts said. Assessing Iraqi strength and tactics if hostilities break out, institute spokesman Andrew Duncan said Saddam likely will turn his chemical weapons against civilians because of the difficulty of attacking well-protected and mobile U.S. troops in the gulf. The institute, like American analysts, assumes that Iraq has surface-to-surface missiles capable of carrying chemical weapons. But Duncan said Iraq would find it tough to pinpoint U.S. and other multinational forces with missile-borne chemical attacks in the desert, while its aircraft would be highly vulnerable to airborne attacks. The institute said the 955,000-strong Iraqi army varied from six formidable divisions of Republican Guards, well-paid and politically motivated, to poorly armed and trained conscripts. The army includes seven armored divisions and 40 infantry divisions as well as the Republican Guards which led the Kuwait invasion. ``There are 1 million men in the forces and there are less than 1 million men aged 18 to 22 in the country,'' Duncan said. ``That's one of the reasons there are over 1.5 million Egyptian farm laborers in the country.'' The institute analysts also said Iraqi tanks will be highly vulnerable to U.S. air attacks if they move in the desert, rather than acting as static firing platforms heavily defended in the desert. On Iraq's nuclear capability, institute director Heisbourg said: ``Iraq in a peacetime situation - with reasonable access to outside markets - would be a number of years away from a nuclear bomb.'' On Soviet-U.S. tank strength, the survey showed the Soviets have increased their overwhelmingly superior forces despite the end of the Cold War and the imminence of a major conventional arms reduction agreement. By early 1990, the report said, the Soviets had destroyed some 2,600 tanks and converted 500 to civilian use, but still had 61,500 main battle tanks compared with 60,000 last year. The United States has 15,440 main battle tanks, slightly down from 15,600 last year, the institute said. The institute said the Soviets appear to have pulled some 7,000 tanks east of the Ural Mountains, out of the area covered by the arms negotiations. ``These games are tolerated games as long as the numbers don't become wholly unreasonable,'' Heisbourg said. The survey was released a day after the United States and the Soviet Union announced agreement in principle on a major conventional arms reduction treaty. The treaty, requiring the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to withdraw 40,000 tanks from eastern and central Europe and move them east of the Urals, is likely to be signed at a 34-nation East-West summit in November. Draftees into the Red Army have fallen by 26 percent in the past year, the survey said. It predicted that Soviet active forces, nearly 4 million strong compared with the United States' 2.17 million, will be cut by half into a better equipped and more able army. The institute, an international, non-governmental center for research on security and arms control, is funded by private foundations, membership fees and sales of its publications.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Leaders Worried but Optimistic on First Budget Vote
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders pressed an all-out lobbying blitz today for their $500-billion deficit-cutting plan, still shy of enough votes to move the election-year plan through the House. Bush and House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., discussed strategy at a White House lunch as arm-twisting continued on Capitol Hill. Congressional leaders planned to hold off a vote until enough support was assured. With Congress poised to vote on an outline of the budget compromise, Foley and other lawmakers said specific elements of the plan could be changed slightly before the package itself comes to a vote in two weeks. ``They are not necessarily voting for every `i' and every `t' in the budget agreement summit agreement,'' the speaker said. The focus of the battle was in the House, where despite public expressions of confidence by Democratic and Republican leaders, the White House and Bush's top allies said they did not yet have the votes to pass it. Bush wooed 60 Republicans over coffee and doughnuts at the White House this morning. House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., emerged to say Bush had convinced several of the Republicans to vote for the pact. But Michel acknowledged, ``We're not there yet.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We're inching along but we don't have the votes yet. ... We're getting closer.'' Democrats and Republicans met separately on Capitol Hill as their leaders tried to drum up votes. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., expressed confidence that 130 Democrats - a majority of the 258 Democrats in the House - would support the plan. ``We don't have 130 people who said yes, count me in, but we have enough expressing indecision ... that I think we can get to the number,'' Gephardt said. Facing a possible vote later in the day, sources on Capitol Hill said Wednesday night that each side was about 40 votes short of getting majority support in the House for the measure, with many uncommitted members in both parties. ``I feel real good about our meeting with the president this morning with a number of those who were on the fence,'' Michel told ABC-TV as he emerged from the White House today. ``Several said, `Your arguments are compelling. ... The alternatives just are not acceptable.''' Michel said he was still hoping to have the showdown vote today. Bush will ``absolutely not'' sign another stopgap spending bill without a deficit agreement, he said. ``We just can't delay any more. We're up against it,'' said the Republican leader. ``We're still worried,'' one Democratic staff aide said late Wednesday. ``We're still working hard.'' Some 27 GOP lawmakers made the trip down from Capitol Hill to the White House on Wednesday to hear Bush's pitch. The president cancelled a five-day political-and-holiday trip to New England to stay in the capital and keep the pressure on fellow Republicans. Bush also dispatched lieutenants to the Capitol to buttonhole lawmakers in corridors in what one White House aide called the administration's biggest lobbying effort. ``We have people who have been ... advocating certain positions, coming out of the left, coming out of the right, coming out of the broad center, and I'm having to say to them, `Now look, lay aside that passion for that specific issue ... and put the national interest first,''' the president told reporters. Senate leaders seemed more confident of prevailing in today's vote, which was to be on a broad outline of the spending plan. Congress will vote in two weeks on a separate measure containing the actual spending cuts and tax boosts. ``I've got mine, unless somebody discovers a time bomb in there,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., when asked if GOP senators would support the compromise. Lobbyists for various interest groups also fanned out across Capitol Hill. Dole, for instance, was visited by vintner Ernest Gallo, who was unhappy with the package's eight-fold increase in the 3-cent-per-bottle tax on wine. The plan would produce $134 billion in new taxes, $109 billion in cuts in benefit programs, and about $200 billion in reduced military spending over the next five years, including $40 billion in savings in the fiscal year that started Monday. Taxes would be raised on alcohol, tobacco, yachts and other luxury items, gasoline, heating oil and a small portion of the incomes of the wealthy. But since its unveiling Sunday after four months of White House-congressional bargaining, the package has been under attack from lawmakers on both ends of the political spectrum. Liberal Democrats are unhappy with the $60 billion in cuts in Medicare, especially the $30 billion in higher costs and reduced benefits for the elderly and handicapped people. They also believe the taxes would dispropotionately hurt poor people and that the plan's $11 billion in tax breaks for small businesses were nothing more than a gift to the wealthy. ``We're making available for the very wealthy an opportunity to shelter income,'' complained Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. Rostenkowski, chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, said he did not know how he would vote. But he and other lawmakers said they would push for changes in the package before it is considered in two weeks. Conservatives were upset with the tax increases and with what they considered insufficient spending cuts and benefits for business. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., a leader of the opposition, said he believed the vote was too close to call. He had predicted Tuesday that the supporters would win. ``I've had members walk up to me and say they've gotten so many phone calls from their districts against the package that they don't know if they can stay with it,'' said Gingrich, the No. 2 House GOP leader. Supporters of the plan readily conceded that it contained something for everyone to dislike, but they argued it was needed to help the economy and no alternative was available. ``It's sort of an indulgence to pick the agreement apart when you don't have anything else to put on the table that has the possibility of passing,'' said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga., who was a budget negotiator.

DOC.HEAD: Party Over, Kohl Says Hard Work and Sacrifices Needed to Build New Nation
LaserPhotos BER3-5
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl signaled an end to the nation's wedding celebrations Thursday, telling Germans to expect hard work and sacrifices as they rebuild the east's shattered economy. During the first meeting of the new German parliament, lawmakers from all sides urged that they work together to face the enormous tasks ahead. Otto Lamsdorff, the head of Kohl's junior coalition partner Free Democrats, said ``the bottom has not been reached'' in revamping the failed businesses in what before Wednesday was East Germany. Labor statistics showed that 444,825 East Germans were unemployed when the two Germanys merged - up from 361,286 in August. Some predictions say East Germany's transition to a free market economy after four decades of communism may throw 4 million people out of work within a few mnnths. As the leaders of former East and West Germany met in Berlin's war-scarred Reichstag building the day after unification, nationwide celebrations were quickly fading into memory. ``The German wedding party is over,'' said Wolfgang Thierse of the opposition Social Democrats. ``Now, the married couple has to earn a living, set up a home in a humane way, and take care of the children.'' Chancellor Kohl said economic recovery ``will call for great exertions, and we shall also have to make sacrifices. The destruction caused in the course of four decades (in East Germany) cannot be set right within a few weeks and months.'' The chancellor also cautioned that ``financial demands'' of unification will have to be weighed against the need to keep the overall economy sound. Five former East German officials, including Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, were sworn as ministers in Kohl's cabinet. Differences in style were immediately evident among the lawmakers. Most of those from the West wore dark suits or appropriately reserved dresses. Some of those from the East wore more casual clothes and no ties. Gregor Gysi, a member of parliament and head of the renamed Communist Party, wore a tie but left his top button unbuttoned. ``Quite frankly, I feel a little bit like a guest here,'' Gysi said before his speech. Gysi had pleaded for a preservation of a socialist German state - or at least some of its advantages. In his speech, he promised to fight for such things as goverment financial support for children and the sick. ``I warn against using the history of East Germany just to glorify West Germany,'' Gysi said, noting that even the West has poverty and social troubles. Thierse, a leading member of the Social Democrats from what was East Germany, said people are worried about looming massive unemployment, women's right to work and pensions for the elderly. Thierse also cited the ``worry that we soon will lose our apartments, because we won't be able to afford the rent.'' The lawmakers spoke at the daylong, televised meeting of the parliament, made up of 144 members from the former East Germany and 519 from the West. They will hold office until parliamentary elections Dec. 2. The Reichstag hall was hastily renovated by workers under tight deadlines, and a giant eagle - Germany's emblem - was brought in from the old West German parliament building in Bonn and placed on the front wall. Outside, the patched-over bullet holes in the rugged sandstone building's walls testify to the heavy fighting that raged there as Adolf Hitler's Third Reich was collapsing in flames. Kohl remarked on the developments that crushed Erich Honecker's Communist government in the east and led to unification. ``We have been able to restore German unity in freedom without war and violence, without bloodshed, in full agreement with our neighbors and partners,'' Kohl said. Kohl also paid tribute to the victims of the Holocaust and those who suffered at the hands of the Communists. Kohl later sat impassively as Oskar Lafontaine, the Social Democrats' candidate for chancellor, berated him for alleged mistakes in the unification process. Lafontaine chastised Kohl for refusing to disclose the costs of unification - estimated by some in the hundreds of billions of dollars. He said the ``mistakes'' included the promise not to raise taxes and an allegedly overly favorable exchange rate given the East Germans for their now-worthless money. ``The bad decisions of the government will cost an extra 100 billion marks (nearly $65 billion) a year for the next few years,'' Lafontaine said. In Berlin, authorities freed East Germany's spy chief from jail but forbade him to leave Germany. Werner Grossmann, arrested Wednesday, is being investigated on espionage charges. Grossman's organization was a division under former East German secret police chief Erich Mielke. Mielke and another member of the former Communist leadership, labor boss Harry Tisch, were moved to a prison in the western part of Berlin on Thursday, officials said. Both men were arrested earlier this year. Mielke is being investigated for persecution of dissidents and for giving sanctuary to West German terrorists, while Tisch is under a investigation for corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses To Reinstate Campaign Contribution Limits In California
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice Thursday refused to reinstate campaign contribution limits for California's gubernatorial and other state races to be decided next month. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor rejected, without comment, an emergency plea to suspend a federal judge's ruling that threw out contribution limits imposed by California voters in 1988. The lower court ruling lets candidates for governor, other statewide posts and some local offices exceed the contribution limits from now until election day Nov. 5. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton ruled on Sept. 25 the limits give an unfair advantage to incumbents. Karlton also tossed out a ban on transfers of funds between candidates that was imposed by the same ballot initiative. His ruling invalidated Proposition 73, which, among other things, limits individuals to a maximum of $1,000 in contributions to a particular candidate per fiscal year. The measure also limits political action committee donations to $2,500 or $5,000 per candidate per fiscal year, depending on the size of the committee. It is unclear what effect the ruling may have on the gubernatorial race between Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Pete Wilson. Wilson, who had only token opposition in the June primary, raised $12.5 million through June and had $3.9 million in the bank as of July 1. Feinstein raised $8.1 million through June but had only $645,344 left over from her primary campaign against state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. The limits were challenged by the Democratic Party and labor unions, which said Proposition 73 unfairly limited constitutional rights to free speech and association. California Assembly Minority Leader Ross Johnson, a Republican, and independent state Sen. Quentin Kopp, two of the co-authors of Proposition 73, asked O'Connor to block Karlton's ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Arms Pact Will `Redraw Military Map' of Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today hailed a tentative East-West agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe, saying it would ``redraw the military map'' to match dramatic political changes. He said the agreement, announced Wednesday in New York, would pave the way for the signing of the treaty next month in Paris at a 34-nation conference. Twenty-two nations will be signatories to the treaty - the 16 nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the six members of the Warsaw Pact. Bush said that, despite the recent easing of tensions throughout the region, ``Europe is still the site of the greatest concentration of armed strength in the world,'' Bush said. Bush, standing beside Secretary of State James A. Baker III in the White House news briefing room, said, ``We must also redraw military map of the continent and lift some of the shadows and fears lived with for a century.'' Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze announced the resolution of all remaining major issues on Wednesday on the most comprehensive arms reduction accord since World War II. The two nations next will try to conclude a second pact slashing their nuclear arsenals. Success in completing both treaties would carry arms control to new heights and contribute to the reduction in East-West tensions. Bush said that the Soviet Union and the United States had ``agreed in principle on all the remaining issues'' on the Conventional Forces in Europe Treaty ``and on essential details as well.'' Baker, giving some new details of the agreement, said that tanks would be limited to 20,000 each for both NATO and Warsaw Pact sides; armored combat vehicles to 30,000; helicopters to 2,000. Baker said that, within that ceiling, any one country can have up to 13,300 tanks, 13,700 artillery pieces, 1,500 helicopter and 5,150 combat aircraft, Baker said. However, he said there was still no agreement on the overall ceiling on combat aircraft. ``This is still subject to some discussion with allies on both sides,'' he said. Baker said he did expect to bring an agreement on overall combat aircraft levels to Paris for the Nov. 19-21 conference. Baker and Shevardnadze both cautioned that final approval must await consultation with their allies. But if the allies go along, the treaty should be ready for signing at the summit. Baker flew home to Washington on Wednesday, planning to return to New York on Friday for a critical meeting with Shevardnadze on nuclear weapons limits. They made some headway on cutting intercontinental ballistic missiles, nuclear submarines and bombers by up to 30 percent, but after nearly six hours of talks they decided on a one-day break. Baker and Shevardnadze want to push on while the Soviet foreign minister is in New York for the U.N. General Assembly session. The Conventional Forces in Europe treaty will set ceilings on non-nuclear weapons that may be deployed in Europe. But it does not cover the number of soldiers that may be put in the field, a topic Baker and Shevardnadze agreed to skip in order to meet the Paris deadline. Shevardnadze said one sticking point remained concerning limits on helicopters, ``but that is not very difficult'' and could be resolved by negotiators in Vienna who have been working on the treaty for 19 months. The last issues settled were limits on land-based airplanes and verification procedures to guard against cheating. The two superpowers agreed in 1989 to limit their intermediate-range nuclear weapons in Europe. In May, Bush slowed the competition in short-range nuclear weapons by terminating a program to develop more potent U.S. Lance missiles and deciding to withdraw short-range U.S. nuclear artillery. Bush's action was prompted by a series of moves by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to end the Cold War. A steady withdrawal of Soviet troops and tanks and U.S. cutbacks already are doing what the treaty seeks to accomplish. But a treaty represents a formal commitment by both sides. The conventional arms treaty would require the Warsaw Pact to withdraw 40,000 tanks, more than 51,000 artillery pieces and more than 40,000 armored personnel carriers from eastern and central Europe - four-sevenths to two-thirds of estimated current deployments. The arms would have to be moved east of the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union, about 1,200 miles east of the Soviet border with Poland. The restrictions on the smaller NATO forces would be minimal, requiring only the removal of about 2,000 tanks. Artillery strength could be built up to a new ceiling of 20,000 for each alliance. The ceiling for tanks would be 20,000 as well and 30,000 for armored personnel carriers. The Soviets agreed to limit naval-based aircraft with a statement outside the treaty. Turning to another unfinished arms accord, one between the United States and the Soviet Union to cut long-range nuclear weapons, Baker reported that ``we have been able to make substantial progress.'' The three major unsettled strategic arms-reduction issues are: -The kinds of restrictions to impose on the 154 heavy, ground-based SS-18 intercontinental missiles the Soviets will retain under the treaty. -Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a strategic weapon, as the United States demands. That would mean counting Backfires against limits established in the treaty. -The restrictions to be imposed on U.S. and Soviet transfers of weapons barred under the treaty to allies - from the United States to Britain, for instance.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Tonight, tonight, in fact through next week there's a place again for Carol Lawrence and Larry Kert, who are sharing a stage for the first time since they starred in ``West Side Story'' 33 years ago as Maria and Tony. This time, it's not a Broadway theater with an inner-city backdrop but the Rainbow and Stars nightclub in posh Rockefeller Center. And they're not sticking to the tunes they were assigned as the tragic teen-age lovers whose story put Juliet and Romeo on the gang-ridden streets of New York. Kert gets to sing ``I Feel Pretty'' and together Lawrence and Kert do ``America,'' the fanciful Puerto Rican ``anthem'' by composer Leonard Bernstein and lyricist Stephen Sondheim. Lawrence, who turns 56 on Friday, and Kert, 59, cover lots of other musical ground in an offering a New York Times reviewer found praiseworthy Thursday. He had just one complaint. Unlike Tony and Maria, Kert and Lawrence got to reach maturity, a point they note a bit too often ``as if,'' said the Times, ``they're about to move to a home for retired actors.'' --- NEW HAVEN, Conn. (AP) - Bob Hope, Barbra Streisand, Elizabeth Taylor and Shirley MacLaine have joined actress Katharine Hepburn in donating items to an art auction Saturday for the North American Wildlife Association. The association, based in East Lyme, provides the only 24-hour wildlife rescue service in Connecticut. Taylor has donated a signed tote bag. MacLaine is contributing an autographed book. An oil painting by Hepburn will be one of 90 artworks auctioned. Hepburn, who has a home in Old Saybrook, became a backer of the group after it rescued a seabird with a broken wing she had found. Hope, Streisand and Charlton Heston have donated autographed photos and actor Chad Everett is expected to provide three original poems, said Steve Sosensky, an auction organizer. --- FULTON, Mo. (AP) - Former President Reagan once challenged Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to tear down the Berlin Wall. Now the wall is gone but hardly forgotten and on Nov. 9 Reagan is to be at Westminster College to dedicate a sculpture marking the first anniversary of the day the wall was breached. It was at the same school 44 years ago that Winston Churchill made his prophetic speech about an iron curtain descending across Europe. The Berlin Wall, erected in 1961, became the physical symbol of Churchill's metaphor. The sculpture by Churchill's granddaughter Edwina Sandys uses eight concrete sections of the actual wall. --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - At 72, singer Ella Fitzgerald says she still enjoys performing because she has something to offer. ``I like to feel like I can give people something they know and want and maybe something that's new to them,'' Miss Fitzgerald said in a telephone interview from her home last week. When she performs, Fitzgerald gives more than a simple musical retrospective of five decades on stage.
