She also surprises. ``I even did a rap in a concert in Washington,'' she said. ``I was just messing around and they seemed to like it. Sometimes people will ask for a song and I try to do it.'' ``You'd be surprised how many young ones there are there,'' she said of her concerts. ``They tell me their parents have my records and that's how they learned.'' --- LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) - Maxene Andrews, one-third of the boogie-woogie Andrews Sisters, is singing the praises of staying youthful by staying active. ``People say to me, `When are you going to retire, Maxene?' I say, `Well, when I retire, you'll only know I'm retired when you see them carrying me off the stage,' '' the 72-year-old singer said Wednesday during a weeklong visit to Nebraska. While in the Nebraska she will make speeches, including one at a dance to raise money for senior centers. ``I love doing these things,'' Andrews said. ``I talk to them (senior citizens) about not getting old, if you know what I mean. Just because you've passed that mark, you don't have to think that the world is leaving you behind.'' --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - Director Milos Forman, winner of Oscars for ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' in 1975 and ``Amadeus'' in 1984, was saluted by Hollywoodas a master filmmaker and educator. About 400 people gathered Wednesday at the Beverly Hills Hotel to pay homage to Forman, recipient of the fourth annual Eastman Kodak Second Century Award for achievement in finding new talent. The native of Czechoslovakia has been co-chair of the film division at Columbia University's School of the Arts for the past 12 years. Forman acknowledged the universities may be turning out more new filmmakers than Hollywood can absorb. ``That's one of the aspects you feel sad about and bad about,'' Forman said. ``It's always like that. You have hundreds and hundreds every year who want to be Picasso or want to be John Ford or Hemingway. ``How many will become that?'' --- FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) - Pianist Van Cliburn is planning a New Year's Eve concert with the Fort Worth Symphony at the Fort Worth-Tarrant County Convention Center Theater. Cliburn, 56, ended a 10-year absence from the stage last year and has since appeared in Philadelphia, Dallas and the Soviet Union. On Tuesday, he gave his first solo recital in 10 years in his boyhood hometown of Kilgore before a sellout crowd of 1,600. The international piano competition named in Cliburn's honor is held every four years in Fort Worth.

DOC.HEAD: Open Your Mouth and Say `Espresso'
DOC.TEXT: Espresso flows at cafes and street-corner stands throughout this caffeine-charged city. It's served to moviegoers, store-browsers - and now to patients awaiting tooth work at Espresso Dental. ``It wouldn't fly in Topeka,'' Dr. Ron Wallach acknowledges. But in Seattle, where red neon espresso signs seem nearly as abundant as stoplights, Wallach is booked weeks in advance. He's been only in operation one month. ``It's been an overwhelmingly positive response,'' Wallach said, standing in open casual shirt and cotton slacks in his north Seattle office. Coffee, especially the carefully steamed concoctions from elaborate espresso machines, is as essential to most Seattlites as a raincoat. The brew can be found in video shops and laundries, movie houses and sporting goods stores, and the city boasts nearly 150 espresso carts on its streets. Wallach's office, a former home, was split into a reception area in front, with a pressed-wood log burning in the fireplace and a silvery espresso machine sitting on a corner stand. In the rear are three dental chairs, including one in a children's room where two stuffed bears sit before coffee cups at a cafe table. The name is intended to overcome patients' fear of dentists, Wallach said. ``With the connotations of the word dental - it's the last place you'd want to go. But espresso is leisure time, friends, conversation.'' Encouraging further relaxation is Sharing Lawrence, a licensed massage therapist whose hands help calm patients traumatized before they go under the drill. ``Coming to a dentist is one of the hardest thing for people to do,'' Lawrence said. ``When you even mention a root canal people's shoulders go up 3 inches.'' Lawrence said her massage is ``a human connection, and that's what's missing in health care.'' The steamed espresso drinks and massages are free to patients. Lawrence said several people have walked in off the street thinking they could order a cafe mocha or latte. They can if they make a donation to Greenpeace, or the Protective Animal Welfare Society, she said. Wallach talked of opening a full-service espresso cafe in an extension of the office if the business continues to do well. The experience wouldn't be foreign. Before his 17 years as a practicing dentist, Wallach helped friends manage a couple of vegetarian restaurants in Vancouver, British Columbia. He described them as places to ``hang out all night, listening to guitar,'' and drink coffee. He hopes to capture that same atmosphere at Espresso Dental. ``It's like coming home,'' said patient Cherie Paulo, 35. Espresso Dental is ``just everything I would want in a dentist,'' she said. Paulo's 12-year-old daughter, Christine, was in for some drill work, and while Wallach looked in her mouth, Lawrence massaged her feet. Espresso Dental's first patient, Dennis Clancy, had some work done on old fillings Wednesday morning. When he returned to talk about billing in the afternoon he was treated to a full upper-body massage by Lawrence. ``There's something going on here that I'm very, very comfortable with,'' Clancy said.

DOC.HEAD: Unusual 3-Year-Old Kansas Boy's Abilities Attracting Wide Interest
DOC.TEXT: It's been a whirlwind of activity for Troy and Trina Kinast and their son Seth since people started hearing about what the 3-year-old boy can do. Since last week, Seth has been in newspaper headlines and he's been sought-after for network talk shows. Appearances are scheduled with syndicated talk-show hosts David Letterman and Sally Jesse Raphael. Seth is in demand because of his amazing ability to learn. He can count in three languages, recite the English alphabet forward and backward and read at an upper second-grade level. His parents say he has already mastered the Greek alphabet. ``We are just overwhelmed,'' Mrs. Kinast said of the numerous telephone calls requesting interviews with her son. ``I feel like I am in a fog,'' said Kinast, just back a trip to New York on Tuesday and Wednesday for an appearance on CBS' ``This Morning.'' ``I don't think I have awakened yet.'' The family was returning to New York for an appearance on the David Letterman show on NBC on Friday. He said Seth stared, mouth agape, at New York's skyline and played in the large back seat of the limousine that took them to the airport. ``It was crowded,'' Seth said Wednesday after arriving home from New York. He described the limo as the ``longest.'' Mrs. Kinast said she and her husband never thought of their son as a genius. ``We just took our time with him,'' she said. ``He is just a normal 3-year-old kid full of orneriness.'' Her husband said that because he and his wife are first-time parents, they had no one to compare to Seth and were surprised by all the attention. ``We have friends that have children Seth's age, and we didn't see a whole lot of difference,'' Kinast said. ``When 3-year-olds converse, the Greek alphabet and the names of shapes don't come into play.'' Seth has access to nearly 1,000 books and ``the computer is his toy,'' his father said. Learning has become like playing. ``This is an everyday thing for him,'' said his mother. ``It is just fun and games. We don't have a television, and Seth has to play an active role instead of a passive role.''

DOC.HEAD: Republican To Bow Out To Give Democrat Edge Over Ex-KKK Leader
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, ``At the ...'' to CORRECT `realistic' to `unrealistic.'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-GOP-David Duke
DOC.TEXT: The Republican Senate candidate is dropping out of the race, leaving former Ku Klux Klansman David Duke as the only major candidate to challenge the incumbent, a ranking GOP's official confirmed today. Charles Black, the Republican Party's main spokesman in Washington, said GOP hopeful Ben Bagert planned to drop out and urged his supporters to vote for the 18-year incumbent Democrat, Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. ``I think that's just the final insurance against Duke getting any further,'' said Black. Asked if national party leaders had urged Bagert to drop out, Black replied: ``Not exactly.'' ``At the point at which we concluded that it was unrealistic to think that he (Bagert) could get into a runoff, we sort of encouraged him not to carry the thing through,'' he said. Black said it was clear to him three weeks ago that Bagert could not beat out Duke and get into a runoff against Johnston. The party spokesman said that, although he and other party leaders had no role arranging endorsements of Johnston by Senate Republicans, ``we sure didn't discourage anybody.'' He added, ``The Republican National Committee should not endorse a Democrat while there is a bone fide Republican in the race.'' Johnston is seeking a fourth term. In Louisiana's open primary system, a candidate can win the election outright by receiving more than half of the vote Saturday. But if no candidate achieves a majority, the two top vote-getters will face each other in the general election Nov. 6. Besides Johnston; Duke, a first-term state representative; and Bagert, a state senator, the field also includes two political unknowns, both Democrats. Bagert has run a distant third in polls, which also have shown Johnston's support at about 50 percent. Local radio and television stations earlier said Bagert had canceled all commercials and would announce his withdrawal today. Bagert's staff confirmed that he had canceled all campaign appearances and scheduled a 2 p.m. news conference. Kelly Johnston, deputy political director of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, earlier said a runoff between Johnston and Duke ``would be the worst possible thing that could happen to us.'' It would allow Democrats across the nation to link any Republican in the November general election to Duke, she said. On Wednesday, eight Republican senators in Washington urged Louisiana voters to reject Duke. Duke represents hatred and bigotry, and Bagert can't win, the senators said. ``All of us would be embarrassed and mortified to have to serve in the United States Senate with David Duke masquerading as a Republican,'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels Kill Seven Soldiers in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels ambushed and killed seven government soldiers early Thursday and injured a dozen more in the troubled north, military officials said. It was the single largest casualty toll the government has acknowledged in recent weeks. The soldiers were killed near the Chettikulam village in the Vavuniya district, 135 miles northeast of Colombo, according to the officials, who cannot be identified by name. They said many of the injured soldiers were in critical condition. On Wednesday, police commandos killed six Tamil Tiger rebels in skirmishes in the east. Military officials said three of the rebels were killed after an unsuccessful grenade attack near the village of Karaitivu and a fourth was killed near Rufus Kulam. Two more rebels died when police raided a guerrilla hideout near the Wattamadu village, they said. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the seven-year separatist war being waged by Tamil militia against the Sinhalese-dominated government. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people, say they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who are 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Subpoenas Records in Probe of Price Hikes
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Thursday stepped up its investigation of the steep rise in gasoline prices by subpoenaing records of major U.S. oil companies. The department's announcement that it had sought records from a large number of oil companies, independent refiners and marketers signalled that the civil antitrust investigation was entering a new phase. In August, Justice Department lawyers began informally interviewing petroleum industry executives to seek explanations for the steep rise in gasoline prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. James F. Rill, assistant attorney general for antitrust, said the records being sought by civil investigative demands (CIDS) would enable investigators ``to examine more closely those explanations and also pursue some issues for which we don't yet have answers.'' Within two days of the invasion, U.S. oil companies raised their gasoline prices an average of 4 cents a gallon, according to one survey. Another showed that wholesale gasoline prices jumped 9.5 cents a gallon in the three days. The public outcry over price rises of up to 15 cents a gallon prompted several major oil companies to freeze or roll back their wholesale costs. ``We aggressively will pursue this investigation until we determine whether or not violations of antitrust law contributed to the rise in gasoline prices,'' Rill said in a statement. To establish antitrust violations, investigators would have to determine that producers, refiners or marketers colluded to raise prices. Antitrust laws carry both civil and criminal penalties. The department has not opened a criminal investigation into the price hikes. To do so, prosecutors would have to convene a grand jury. The Federal Trade Commission, the Energy Department and several state attorneys general are assisting the Justice Department's investigation. Rill said the interviews with petroleum industry executives ``developed substantial information about the nature of crude oil and gasoline markets and how they behaved in the wake of the August 2 invasion.'' ``It also provided us with an opportunity to have the parties explain the factors that caused them to raise gasoline prices,'' he said. The department's antitrust division will continue to interview executives of oil companies as well as independent refiners and marketers and collect price and supply information, Rill said. The average pump price of gasoline has risen 27.1 cents a gallon since the invasion, according to a survey issued this week by the American Automobile Association. Crude oil prices have nearly doubled and the threat of war in the Persian Gulf have produced wild price gyrations on commodities markets. Oil company spokesmen expressed confidence that investigators would conclude there was no illegal conduct. Mobil Oil Corp. spokesman John Lord predicted that the Justice Department probe would result in the same conclusion that antitrust investigators reached when they found no evidence of price gouging during a jump in heating oil prices last winter. ``When the cold weather passed, the prices fell but the investigations continued and when the investigations were completed, as usual, they found no price gouging whatsoever,'' Lord said. ``That will be the case again.'' Mike Libbey, a spokesman for Chevron Corp., said that gasoline prices went up in August to keep pace with the rising cost of crude oil, which shot up after the invasion. ``We are quite confident there was absolutely no price gouging of any kind,'' Libbey said.

DOC.HEAD: Trendy Club Vows Appeal of Verdict Favoring Group Denied Entry
DOC.TEXT: A trendy club is trying on old-fashioned justice, appealing a court ruling that it was too discriminating when it kept out four people who couldn't pass muster with the doorman. A small claims court on Wednesday ordered the owner of the downtown Mayan club to pay $250 each to the plaintiffs, who weren't allowed in on May 19 apparently because of their appearance. Larry Nagler, a Beverly Hills attorney representing the club, said he would appeal the case in Superior Court. The plaintiffs, meanwhile, celebrated the verdict as a victory over arbitrary discrimination. ``I feel vindicated,'' plaintiff Jeff Stolzer said. ``This will give these nightclubs something to think about. ``Either there will be some guidelines that are known to everybody or they should just stop all door policies altogether and let people in first come, first serve.'' The Mayan opened about six months ago in an old porn theater by the same name. In a custom more typical of New York clubs than West Coast nightspots, getting in is a seemingly mysterious process: some arriving patrons get waved right in while others must wait to be chosen, if at all. The case pitted Stolzer, Kenneth Lipton, Teresita Dubrall and Stephen Ambrosini against Sammy Chao, president of the company that owns the Mayan. Chao testified Tuesday that there is no dress code and that the doorman is picky about who is let in to keep out people who are drunk or otherwise look like trouble. That system also saves room inside for people with reservations. Stolzer differed. He told the court: ``I think we were met at the door by a flippant and arrogant doorman. They just looked you over like you were scum.'' The plaintiffs argued that the decisions are arbitrary. If there had been a posted dress code, they said, they would have been able to comply. Vertigo, a nearby club, is facing a similar legal problem. The state Alcoholic Beverage Control Department has recommended a 30-day suspension of Vertigo's liquor license because undercover inspectors were refused entry. The club's owner has said the state inspectors weren't dressed properly.

DOC.HEAD: Two Solidarity Veterans to Compete for Polish Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki agreed Thursday to run for president of Poland in a contest that would pit him against his former ally and mentor, Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa. The decision opens the way for the first popularly contested race for president in Polish history and for a competition that will involve the country's two best-known politicians. When Mazowiecki became the first non-Communist head of government in the East bloc in the summer of 1989, his nomination was engineered by Walesa. Since then, however, Walesa has accused Mazowiecki's government of being too slow to privatize the state-dominated economy and to dismiss former Communists from positions of authority in government and industry. Mazowiecki supporters accuse Walesa of personal ambition and demagoguery. Mazowiecki made his announcement on national television. ``The time for an answer has come and today I want to give this answer, a short one,'' Mazowiecki said, speaking into the camera at the start of the main evening news program. ``Following great deliberations and consideration of all circumstances I have decided to express approval (to run for president) if my candidacy is put forward,'' he said. ``One must move forward. One cannot retreat from the path Poland has chosen and fought for so hard this year.'' Elections are scheduled Nov. 25. Aside from Walesa and Mazowiecki, several minor candidates are also expected to seek a place on the ballot. Walesa announced his campaign for president Sept. 16 and held his first meeting with potential voters Monday in the central city of Torun. The office will be vacant because Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist leader, last month asked parliament to have his six-year term shortened after 17 months as president, citing public demands for a popularly elected leader. The Senate passed the final legislation setting up the elections Saturday and Jaruzelski signed it into law Monday. Mazowiecki, 63, a longtime Catholic journalist and former political prisoner, became prime minister Aug. 24, 1989. His nomination came after Communists failed to win sufficient support to govern in partially free elections in June 1989. For most of the 1980s, Mazowiecki was an adviser and ally to Walesa, participating in the Gdansk shipyard strikes in 1980 and 1988 that helped to topple Communist rule in Poland. Supporters of Mazowiecki have already begun gathering the required 100,000 nominating signatures. ``It is true we have started to collect signatures,'' said Halina Bornowska, spokesman of Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, known by its Polish initials ROAD, the main group supporting Mazowiecki. ``For the time being, we are doing it among ourselves, among our sympathizers. ... That is why we are not making much fuss about it,'' she told The Associated Press in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Runner Hits Wrong Start Line, Runs 26.2 Miles Instead of Intended Five
DOC.TEXT: MILTON-FREEWATER, Ore. (AP) - A mentally handicapped man who was prepared to run a five-mile race instead found himself finishing the 26.2-mile Portland marathon after a mix-up at the starting line. Art Pease stopped only once to walk and finished with an unofficial time of 4 hours, 18 minutes and 23 seconds. Pease, 23, said it was just as well he didn't discover he was running the wrong race right away. ``If I had known I was going to do all that, I might not have finished,'' he said. When Pease discovered the mix-up, he was going strong and decided to finish. Pease said he originally intended to run the marathon, but settled for the five-mile race because the combination of a hot summer and a busy work schedule left him without time to train seriously. Pease's father, Charles, blames himself for the mix-up at the starting line. The races were scheduled to begin within half an hour of each other Sunday. Pease's father told him to get ready while he went back to a hotel to pick up a friend who was taking part in a five-mile walk. In the meantime, the gun went off and Pease, who happened to be in the marathon line, started the race with thousands of other runners. He became suspicious after about four miles when he noticed that other runners were wearing green and orange tags but his was white. But by then, he decided to see if he could stick it out. Pease's parents contacted race officials, who spotted Pease at mile 16. The couple said their son had run 17 miles in the Special Olympics Torch Light Run two years earlier and he was allowed to continue after officials checked on him. ``We were very proud. It was such an accomplishment,'' Charles Pease said. ``The doctor said he was in better shape than a lot of them in the race.''

DOC.BYLINE: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are Thursday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
The USS Independence left the gulf two days after entering the waterway in a show of strength to Iraq. In Washington, a Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist, said the Independence had ``completed its operation there.'' --- Five Europeans were found by the Saudi coast guard drifting in a small boat in a Persian Gulf shipping lane off the Saudi-Kuwait border, British diplomats and Saudi officials said. The British escapees told London's Daily Mail newspaper that they had spent 25 hours in rough seas after taking the 10-foot boat through the marshes of southern Iraq, into the Shatt-al-Arab waterway and then the gulf. --- Yevgeny Primakov, a senior adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, arrived in Baghdad carrying a message from Gorbachev, Soviet diplomatic sources said. Its contents were not disclosed. In Moscow, Gorbachev said he did not think the crisis would lead to war, and he also told reporters he saw no reason to send Soviet troops to the gulf. --- In the Jordanian capital, Amman, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan met with Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan. Ramadan rejected a negotiated settlement to the gulf crisis as long as foreign troops remain on Arab lands, Baghdad's official Iraq News Agency reported. Kaifu insisted on Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait first, said Shigeo Takenaka, Kaifu's spokesman. --- In Saudi Arabia, King Fahd met with French President Francois Mitterrand, whom Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has tried to engage in separate peace talks linking the invasion with Israel's occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank and Syria's military presence in Lebanon. There was no immediate statement on the Saudi-French discussions. --- In Baghdad, a radical Palestinian group loyal to Iraq threatened to launch ``powerful strikes'' if the United States endangers Iraqi aircraft while enforcing the U.N. air embargo on Iraq. The statement by the Arab Liberation Front was the second such threat in as many days by radical Palestinians and heightened fears of a terrorist campaign against the Western and Arab nations confronting Iraq. --- Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said American sailors from the Frigate Samuel B. Roberts boarded the Sudanese freighter Blue Nile and turned it away from the Gulf of Aqaba. Williams said no shots were fired. Williams said the freighter, carrying industrial equipment, was diverted because the ship's log did not account for all of its cargo. Under the U.N. embargo, shipments to the Jordanian port of Aqaba, a prime port for Iraqi cargo, has been cut severely. --- Iraq, hurting from the international sanctions following its invasion of Kuwait, planned to argue its case before the United Nations on Thursday night. The world body, which has condemned Iraq's invasion and placed a naval and air embargo on the country, may consider stronger measures. --- An Australian newspaper said Iraq has set up two interrogation centers in Kuwait City that are being used to torture prisoners. The Sydney Morning Herald quoted unidentified Western diplomats and another source who said at least 230 mutilated bodies had been removed from one site since August. --- Iran's foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati, said on Tehran television that his country wants a peaceful settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis. He also said ``force should be the last possible resort for solving this crisis.'' Concerning armed conflict, he said: ``Iran will not be participating in this in any way.'' The remarks, monitored in Cyprus, indicated Iran is distancing itself from Iraq, following earlier suggestions that it could circumvent the U.S.-led embargo and provide food and medicine. --- The proposed sale of $7.3 billion in weapons to Saudi Arabia is one step in creating a Persian Gulf ``coalition defense'' against the long-term threat posed by Iraq to other countries in the region, according to administration officials in Washington. The sale would be followed by more sales to the Saudis next year and perhaps to Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates as well, Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and Undersecretary of State Reginald Bartholomew told Congress. --- The Bush administration is ready to quickly provide two Patriot anti-missile batteries to Israel to strengthen its position against military action by Iraq, Wolfowitz told Congress. He said the administration is also looking at other ways to help Israel. But Bartholomew declined to say whether the U.S. would retaliate immediately against Iraq if it attacks Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Frees Wholesale Prices - Somewhat
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved to boost the output of Soviet businesses on Thursday by allowing them - with certain restrictions - to negotiate their own wholesale prices. A presidential decree on prices, released by the Tass news agency, was billed as a step toward a market economy. It was Gorbachev's second decree since the Soviet legislature on Sept. 24 gave him sweeping new powers to rescue the collapsing economy and maintain law and order. Economists have said freeing prices to respond to market forces, rather than having them set by the government, is essential to curing the economy. It is unclear, however, whether the decree frees prices enough to make a difference. The decree says businesses can sign contracts with each other for 1991 using negotiated wholesale prices. But it then adds three restrictions. It says the prices must be based on those outlined by the Council of Ministers in June 1988, that profits over a state-set limit will be taxed and that wholesale prices of some goods will remain fixed. Finance Minister Valentin Pavlov told Soviet television the decree was a compromise but did not say what the differences had been. A correspondent for the nightly TV newscast ``Vremya'' said the decree should put more goods into the stores, by offering price incentives for increased production. Shortages have left many stores nationwide bare of such essential goods as flour, matches, cheese and bread. Pavlov insisted the decree has no direct relation to retail prices and assured viewers that state subsidies will continue. But it appeared stores would have to raise retail prices if they had to pay more to receive wholesale stocks. The finance minister said the decree was necessary so businesses can know now what prices they will be able to charge - and therefore how much product to plan - in 1991. In his first decree, issued one week ago, Gorbachev ordered businesses to fulfill supply contracts and the government to ensure distribution in 1991. He threatened businesses with fines if they did not fulfill supply contracts to government retailers. Many workers and businesses are uncertain how they will fit in the market economy Gorbachev is trying to establish and find it more profitable to trade goods on the black market, rather than distribute them in the established structure. The Supreme Soviet legislature is to choose a plan for switching to a market economy on Oct. 15. The most radical blueprint, written by economist Stanislav Shatalin, calls for junking the central planning system and moving to a market economy within 500 days by selling factories to private owners and breaking up collective farms.

DOC.HEAD: Joe Garagiola Returns to ``Today''
DOC.TEXT: After five weeks off for elective surgery and recuperation, Joe Garagiola will return Monday to NBC's ``Today'' show and on Tuesday report on the baseball play-offs, NBC said Thursday. Garagiola, 64, has declined to say what kind of surgery was performed. A former ``Today'' co-anchor, he returned to the show last June on a three-day-a-week basis as part of NBC's effort to revive the show's ratings. The once-dominant program suffered a ratings slump after the replacement in January of Jane Pauley by Deborah Norville, a co-anchor with Bryant Gumbel. NBC's efforts to boost the show back into first place haven't worked yet. ABC's rival ``Good Morning America'' was first in morning ratings last week fo the 39th consecutive week. It averaged a 4.4 rating, A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates showed.``Today'' had a 3.2 and ``CBS This Morning'' a 2.6. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Escapees: Fear of Iraq Sustained Them During Rough Voyage to Freedom
LaserPhoto DHA3
DOC.TEXT: Three Britons who escaped from Iraq by sea said Thursday their fear of Iraq sustained them through their long hours bobbing in 10-foot swells of the open Persian Gulf. The three, rescued Wednesday morning along with two Frenchman off the border city of Khafji, spent 25 hours in a 10-foot fiberglass boat floating through the marshes and canals of southern Iraq, down the Shatt-al-Arab waterway and into the gulf. They avoided lights, used a small compass to navigate and got lost several times before being picked up by a Saudi coast guard vessel. ``It's a trip I wouldn't like to do again, but it was well worth it now that I am here,'' Mike Teesdale, 40, told a news conference. ``My fear was of Iraq, not of the trip.'' The men said they would fly back to London early Friday. It was the first report of Western men escaping Iraq in over six weeks. Baghdad has permitted hundreds of women and children to leave Iraq and Kuwait since its invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait, but has restricted departures of thousands of Western men. Iraq has taken several hundred of the hostages and put them near key military and civilian targets, describing them as ``guests'' serving to prevent a military attack on Iraq. Western leaders have described them as a ``human shield.'' The Britons said they knew of some Americans being held near the oil installation where they worked south of the Iraqi port of Basra. They said they did not want to reveal the information about the detainees publicly. The other escapees were Britons Ivan Manning, 44, and Keith Barkworth, 36. The Frenchman were Amedee du Paty, 53, and Janel Cellier de Buriane, 55, both barge masters. They refused to talk to the press on the advice of their embassy. The Britons said they had been planning their trip for a month. While they had plenty of food and water and were not being held at gunpoint, they were worried about what might happen if a war breaks out over the Iraqi occupation. ``The conditions were OK,'' Teesdale said. ``What we feared most was if trouble started who knows what would have happened. I just don't trust a lot of people in Iraq.'' Actual preparations took ``one day and it took about four weeks to build up the courage to do it,'' Barkworth said. Throughout the time the men ``were pretending to work,'' he said. The boat was readily available to them because of their exploration work in the marshes, so they chose it over a land route. They packed the boat with beer, whisky, vodka and cheese sandwiches like they were going out for a picnic. In hindsight, Manning joked: ``We hadn't enough ice for the trip.'' At the last minute, at least one Briton backed out, he said. They made their way along canals out into the gulf through the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, closed to shipping since the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. A 10-foot swell prevented them from using their diesel engine as they tried to follow the shoreline in the gulf past Kuwait. A rare heavy mist and overcast skies helped prevent them from being sighted. The five worked in rotation, one on lookout, one steering and one working the bilge pump. After 25 hours they thought they were near Bahrain but had actually gone just 80 miles and were drifting back to Kuwait when they were found by a Japanese barge, which notified the Saudi coast guard. Saudi officials said the men were suffering from exposure but all felt fine after a night in Khafji.

DOC.HEAD: Victims, Friends Seek Ban on Assault Rifles
DOC.TEXT: Gun attack survivors and friends of gunshot victims pleaded with Congress on Thursday to ban assault rifles. Mike Campbell, who was shot when a man with an assault rifle went on a rampage at a printing plant in Louisville, Ky., last year, said: ``What he did to myself and fellow workers will be with us forever. It is devastating.'' Campbell was joined at a news conference by James Brady, the former White House press secretary shot in the assassination attempt on President Reagan, and by friends of John ``Nick'' Sheehy, a University of California student killed last week when a gunman held hostages at a pub in Berkeley, Calif. ``Something has to be done'' to ban assault weapons, said Tracy Carney of Los Gatos, Calif. ``I can't believe this is even an issue.'' They urged passage of a bill banning assault weapons. They also urged defeat of an amendment, sponsored by Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., that would protect domestic assembly of assault weapons. ``They are weapons of war, designed for human slaughter,'' said Betty Campbell, Mike Campbell's wife.

DOC.HEAD: Seats By Plane Exit Doors To Be Restricted To Able-Bodied
DOC.TEXT: Beginning Friday, seats by exit doors on U.S. airlines will be restricted by government order to the able-bodied only. The Federal Aviation Administration regulation says only people able and willing to open exit doors in an emergency and help flight crews evacuate the airplane will be seated in rows adjacent to them. Those barred from seats near exit doors include parents with small children, people too frail to operate the door, passengers with broken limbs or other disabilities that would inhibit movement, obese people, children under 15 and the blind. The FAA regulation limits seating in exit rows to passengers who can locate the door quickly, follow instructions for its use, are physically able to open the heavy doors and can judge whether it is safe to leave the aircraft. They must also understand verbal and hand-signaled instructions from flight attendants and be able to get around obstacles to lead other passengers off the aircraft. At the time the regulation was issued last January organizations representing the blind called it discriminatory and said it would reduce a blind person's chances to survive an airplane crash. Some airlines already bar blind travelers from exit-door seats and several blind people have been arrested in recent years for refusing to move from the seats. A lobbying effort to prevent implementation of the regulation proved unsuccessful. Under the new procedures, gate agents at each airport will assign the exit row seats to passengers who meet the new requirements and appear able and willing to perform emergency functions. Information cards will be provided at exit row seats describing the functions passengers sitting there may have to perform during an emergency. Flight attendants will describe these functions before each flight. ``This is an important safety initiative,'' said William Hoover, executive vice president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the nation's airlines. ``Airline accidents are rare, but when they do happen it is essential that the people seated in exit rows are capable of hearing and understanding instructions, opening emergency exits and assisting their fellow passengers in an evacuation of the aircraft,'' Hoover said. The FAA describes an exit row seat as one from which passengers may go directly to an exit without stepping first into an aisle.

DOC.HEAD: Nynex Pays $1.4 Million to Treasury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Materiel, sted Material, throughout
DOC.TEXT: New England Telephone and New York Telephone have agreed to pay $1.4 million to the U.S. Treasury and cut long-distance rates $35.5 million to resolve allegations they overcharged customers through a subsidiary, the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday. The payment is a voluntary contribution and doesn't constitute a fine, the FCC said. Under the consent decree, Nynex Corp. admitted no guilt and the FCC said it made no findings of wrongdoing and was ending its enforcement action. Nynex is the regional parent company of New England Telephone and New York Telephone. The FCC said in February that it intended to fine the two telephone companies $1.4 million over apparent violations of FCC rules governing transactions between regulated telephone companies and unregulated affiliates. The FCC had ordered the companies to return $35.5 million to customers because of alleged $118.5 million in overcharges to the companies by Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated Nynex purchasing subsidiary. Nynex agreed to the $35.5 million rebate, to be made within 30 days, and said the two phone companies would reduce their capital accounts by $32.6 million to ``remove the alleged excess profits on plant and equipment'' bought from the purchasing subsidiary. Local phone rates won't be affected. ``We hope this puts to rest any questions concerning Nynex's desire to comply with all FCC regulations and policies in transactions among affiliate companies,'' Nynex Chairman William C. Ferguson said in a statement. The agreement ends one of several pending federal or state actions against Nynex, one of the seven regional Bell holding companies created in 1984 from the old Bell System. Nynex also has been the focus of investigations that New York Telephone suppliers helped pay for bawdy parties and prostitutes at annual conventions of company employees in Florida from 1984 to 1988. Nynex has denied that any ratepayer funds were involved in the conventions. In May, the Justice Department filed a one-count criminal indictment alleging that Nynex had violated the information services restrictions in the 1982 consent decree that created the regional Bell companies. Nynex denied any wrongdoing. On Wednesday, New York state utility regulators authorized a study into whether Nynex should be forced to divest New York Telephone. Toby Webb, Nynex vice president for government affairs, said Thursday he could not estimate how much the $35.5 million rebate would affect long-distance prices for New York and New England phone customers. Webb said Nynex had agreed to the latest consent decree to avoid a potentially long court battle over accounting and purchasing procedures that no longer were in effect. Materiel Enterprises was merged into New York Telephone and New England Telephone earlier this year, making Materiel a fully regulated company under FCC rules. ``The agreement is preferable to engaging in prolonged litigation over past events and practices which have been changed,'' Webb said. The $1.4 million contribution to the Treasury will be paid by Nynex shareholders, Webb said, and will not affect rates.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Reject Calls to Abandon Celebrations of Bolshevik Revolution
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party on Thursday rejected demands to abandon the traditional celebration of Revolution Day on Nov. 7, saying such suggestions are ``unjustified and unfounded.'' The mayors of Moscow and Leningrad have proposed the traditional celebrations be scrapped because shortages and long lines give Russians nothing to celebrate this year. The anniversary of the 1917 revolution is one of the major holidays on the Soviet calendar, a day usually devoted to praising the glories of communism. But this year, instead of plastering cities with propaganda posters and carrying giant portraits of Marx, Engels and Lenin through the streets, Mayors Gavriil Popov of Moscow and Anatoly Sobchak of Leningrad suggested that Russians spend the day planting bushes and insulating buildings for winter. The Communist Party Central Committee's Secretariat, however, said in a statement released by the Tass news agency that the holiday was valid as ``an outstanding date in the revolutionary renewal of the world.'' ``Any attempts to deprive our multinational people of its main all-state holiday are unjustified and unfounded,'' the secretariat, the party managers, said. ``It has become a holiday for all who believe in the creative potential of socialist ideas.'' In the past, Revolution Day has been marked in the capital by a parade of military equipment, including tanks and rockets, followed by a vast ``people's demonstration'' in which hundreds of thousands of Moscow residents streamed through the city's main avenues and across Red Square. There, at the heart of Soviet power, members of the Communist Party's ruling Politburo and top generals stood on Lenin's tomb. The celebration marks the day the Bolsheviks seized power - Oct. 25 by the old Czarist calendar, Nov. 7 by the new one introduced later. Popov and Sobchak urged Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to limit the festivities in Moscow to a military parade. So far, he has not responded. May Day, another major Soviet holiday, was marked this year by counter-demonstrations involving tens of thousands of people in Moscow. As they passed through Red Square, many shouted ``Resign!'' and jeered at Gorbachev, who suffered the embarrassment stoically for 20 minutes and then left the reviewing stand.

DOC.HEAD: Four Executed in Public Hangings
DOC.TEXT: Four men were hanged in Al-Abbasyen Square on Thursday, three for taking part in a shootout in which two customs officers and a policeman were killed. Khald A'Di, Mohammed Al-Hafez and Maemoun Yousef also were convicted of wounding two other members of a security patrol that intercepted the three as they were smuggling carpets and cigarettes by donkey. Fuad Quwaider was hanged for killing Ahmad Al-Shamat, who authorities said was his partner in smuggling heroin from Beirut, Lebanon, to Syria. Police said Quwaider and Al-Shamat had a falling out over money.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds House Challengers Can't Compete Financially
DOC.TEXT: In a measure of how severely the political playing field is tilted against challengers, a private study released Thursday found that 95 percent of House incumbents are in financially uncompetitive races. The study by the lobbying group Common Cause found that only 23 of the 405 House members who are seeking re-election face challengers with comparable campaign funds. The other 382 had opponents with less than half as much money to spend on a campaign, or no opponents at all. The money could serve to protect incumbents against a widely reported public disgust with Congress, said Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer. ``House members are shielded by a wall of political money that makes them nearly invincible,'' Wertheimer said. ``House incumbents will have a free ride in 1990, largely financed by special-interest PAC contributions.'' Of the $119 million total raised by all incumbents so far during the election cycle, just under half - $57.2 million - came from political action committees. Challengers received just $1.9 million from PACs during the same period. Topping the group's list of the ``financially unopposed'' was Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., who has nearly $2 million amassed against an opponent who hasn't even filed a campaign finance report. Candidates are not required to file unless they raise or spend at least $5,000. In all, 296 House members faced opponents with less than $25,000 in campaign money or no opponents. Incumbents in that category had a total of $130 million, compared with just $1.1 million for their challengers. Another 86 House incumbents were in what Common Cause called ``financially non-competitive'' races, where the challenger had more than $25,000 but still less than half the war chest of the incumbent. The most lopsided was the contest between incumbent Democrat Mel Levine in California, who had $2.1 million on hand, and Republican David Cohen, with just $31,000. The total on hand for lawmakers in that category was $40.3 million, compared with $7.9 million for challengers. Seventy-eight incumbents had no major party opposition, but those lawmakers still raised $19.2 million in the current two-year election cycle, more than half of it from PACs.

DOC.HEAD: Bystander Dies in Gun Battle Over Baseball Cap
DOC.TEXT: A 23-year-old woman died Thursday, hours after she walked into a gun battle apparently arising from a stolen baseball cap. Sandra Smith was standing on a street when bullets sailed from an apartment complex during a fight between two 18-year-old men arguing over the cap, police said. Witnesses told police Zarail Joiner shot Robert Greer with a .30-caliber rifle then repeatedly rammed Greer's body with the rifle stock until it broke. Joiner was charged Thursday with attempted murder. He remained jailed Thursday on $4,500 bond. Greer was in critical condition Thursday at Parkland Memorial Hospital. While Greer was being battered, a 15-year-old friend began shooting at his attacker and struck Ms. Smith, police said. She was taken to Parkland and died about five hours later from a single gunshot wound to the abdomen. The 15-year-old was arrested, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Dinkins Orders Wage Freeze; Considers 15,000 Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Two days after announcing plans to hire 8,000 new police officers, Mayor David Dinkins ordered a freeze on city hiring and promotions Thursday and was considering 15,000 layoffs. He said the freeze would save $115 million during this fiscal year and the next one. His Office of Management and Budget had recommended the layoffs and other agency reductions, which Dinkins said would cut an additional $800 million from an expected budget deficit in fiscal 1992 of $1.4 billion. Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, meanwhile, said the budget gap for next year could reach $2.6 billion. She also projected a budget deficit in the current fiscal year of as much as $738 million. The mayor claims the budget is balanced for this fiscal year. Holtzman called for a summit meeting of the city's top fiscal officers, labor leaders and academic and financial experts to deal with the problem. Dinkins issued a statement saying that ``a recessionary economy and the hard times that come with it are facts of life in our city and region.'' ``With hard times come hard choices,'' the mayor said. ``We all hope and pray for better economic times. Until they arrive, however, I will continue to impose strict budgetary discipline.'' On Tuesday, Dinkins announced a $1.8 million crime-fighting plan that included the hiring of nearly 8,000 police officers. Mayoral spokesman Leland T. Jones said Dinkins has ordered Budget Director Philip Michael to devise a plan for layoffs to determine what impact they would have on city services. ``He's inclined to do it,'' Jones said. The last layoffs of such scale were at the height of the city's fiscal crisis in 1975, when about 25,000 workers were laid off.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Murder Rate Declines
DOC.TEXT: Canada's annual murder rate declined slightly in 1989, according to government figures released Thursday. Statistics Canada reported the number of murders committed in 1989 increased to 657 from 575 a year earlier. But it said the figure represented a drop in the homicide rate from 2.57 murders per 100,000 people in 1988 to 2.51 last year. By comparison, preliminary estimates indicate there were 21,500 murders in the United States in 1989, for a rate of 8.7 murders per 100,000 people or 3{ times higher than Canada's rate, the agency said. Quebec led all provinces with 215 murders, including 14 women massacred at the University of Montreal last December by Marc Lepine, who committed suicide during a gun battle with police. Manitoba had the highest homicide rate for the fourth year in a row, with 43 murders or a rate of 3.96 per 100,000 people. Prince Edward Island, with one murder and a rate of 0.77, had the lowest homicide rate for the eighth consecutive year, the agency said. New Brunswick, where six murders in the Miramichi River region terrorized residents in the final half of 1989, reported 18 murders for the year, compared with eight in 1989, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Roberts, Lonsdale Gain Ground
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Barbara Roberts is deadlocked with Republican Dave Frohnmayer in the race for Oregon governor, a new poll says. The statewide poll commissioned by The Oregonian also showed that Sen. Mark Hatfield has lost ground but still has the lead over his Democratic challenger, Harry Lonsdale. Attorney General Frohnmayer has 44 percent support to 43 percent for Secretary of State Roberts, well within the poll's margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points. One month ago, Roberts was seven points back. Independent Al Mobley has 7 percent, and Libertarian Fred Oerther was backed by fewer than 1 percent. Meanwhile, Lonsdale has made huge gains in his campaign against Hatfield, a 24-year U.S. Senate veteran. Hatfield, who led by 36 points in an August survey, now leads Lonsdale 49 percent to 43 percent. The random telephone poll of 600 Oregon voters was taken Sept. 25-30 by Griggs-Anderson Research of Portland.
DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Illinois Governor's Race Dead Heat
DOC.TEXT: Republican Jim Edgar and Democrat Neil Hartigan are still running neck-and-neck in the race for governor, according to new polls. A random telephone poll conducted by Champaign-based Midwest Television Inc. showed Hartigan was preferred by 44 percent of those questioned, while Edgar was selected by 40 percent. But Hartigan's 4 percentage point edge was within the poll's margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. One percent of those polled supported another candidate, and 15 percent were undecided. The sample included 415 likely voters questioned between Sept. 26 and Monday. A similar poll by Midwest Television in August found Edgar was the choice of 42 percent of those polled, while 40 percent backed Hartigan, 1 percent favored another candidate. Seventeen percent were undecided. Another poll released late Wednesday by Chicago television station WLS-TV showed 43 percent of the voters favoring Edgar, 42 percent favoring Hartigan, and 15 percent undecided. The WLS poll of 900 registered voters was conducted Sept. 23 to Oct. 1 by Richard Day Research Inc. It was said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: New Wellstone Ad Adds To Friction Between Senate Candidate Camps
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Senate candidate Paul Wellstone's latest TV ad shows him in a madcap effort to engage Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz in debate. The ``Looking for Rudy'' ad, which aired Wednesday and Thursday, is a takeoff on the 1989 documentary ``Roger and Me'' in which a filmmaker tries to track down General Motors Chairman Roger Smith to ask him about auto-worker layoffs. The two-minute video - four times the usual length of a TV political spot - shows Democrat Wellstone striding into Boschwitz's campaign headquarters and Senate offices, confronting startled campaign staff members and getting politely rebuffed. Wellstone's newest entry in the TV ad campaign and earlier radio and TV ads have prompted Boschwitz's campaign press secretary to label the challenger a ``leftist hustler'' and an ``Abbie Hoffman-type character.'' An Oct. 14 debate between the candidates tentatively has been agreed on and negotiations on two additional debates are under way, said Boschwitz's press secretary, Jay Novak. Wellstone ``is more interested in dramatic gestures ... and generating notoriety for himself than in advancing any serious agenda,'' said Novak. Wellstone adviser Pat Forciea said Boschwitz should be the last to criticize anyone's use of ads. ``His entire career ... has been based on show business and ads,'' said Forciea, who added that Boschwitz is spending far more on ads than Wellstone is. ``I guess our pea-shooter's got pretty good aim,'' Forciea said.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Mom Fatally Stabbed, Five Other Teens Shot
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old mother carrying her week-old son on a Brooklyn street was fatally stabbed, bringing one day's toll of teen-age victims in the city to one dead, five wounded. Deborah Joseph was stabbed once in the chest Wednesday afternoon by another 17-year-old girl with whom she had a long-standing dispute, polic said Thursday. Joseph was holding her week-old son, Darren, and walking with a friend when she saw her attacker brandishing a knife. The mother handed the baby to her friend and began to flee, but was outrun by the assailant, who fatally stabbed her in the chest. The suspect fled after the stabbing, and had not been arrested, police said. A spate of shootings that left five teen-agers wounded Wednesday began at a popular Manhattan dance club at 3:30 a.m., when a 17-year-old-girl was shot in the face by a young man with whom she refused to dance, police said. Rodney Selby, 22, was charged with attempted murder and criminal possession of a handgun, which was not recovered, Police Officer Fred Weiner said. The victim, Sayeeda Kelly, was listed in stable condition at St. Vincent's Hospital. Two girls in Harlem, ages 13 and 14, were shot and wounded by a 14-year-old boy at 7 p.m., during what police said was a lover's quarrel. An investigator at the 32nd Precinct detective squad would only say of the shootings, ``It's typical. You have a gun, you use it.'' The 14-year-old suspect, identified by police as Vaughn Chiddick, was charged with attempted murder, first-degreee assault, criminal possession of a deadly weapon and first-degree reckless endangerment. In the Bronx, two 15-year-olds were shot and wounded in separate incidents. In the first shooting, the victim was shot in the left leg shortly after 9 p.m. The motive, as well as the suspect and the type of gun used, were not known. The other youth was shot at 10:15 p.m. on what was described as a drug-prone street in the Fordham section. Police said the shooting was believed to be motivated by a previous street fight between the two teen-agers. The suspect fled and was not immediately arrested. Lt. Joel Pierson, head of the detective squad that investigated the two Bronx shootings, said the average age of shooting victims in the city was getting younger. ``Throughout the city there's an overall increase in shooting incidents and it works its way down to younger people being shot,'' said Pierson. ``In every precinct there are more and more young people being shot.''

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Who Defended Soviet News Blackout of Watergate Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Sergei G. Lapin, a former diplomat and journalist who told U.S. correspondents during the Watergate scandal that the story was not worth reporting in the Soviet Union, died Thursday, according to state television. He was 78. In a career that spanned six decades, Lapin served as head of two of the most powerful Soviet media organizations - the Gostelradio television and radio agency and the official Soviet news agency Tass. ``Sergei Georgiyevich Lapin put all his strength and heart into all this. And today his heart stopped,'' said an anchorwoman on Soviet television's nightly newscast ``Vremya.'' The obituary did not give a cause of death, mention survivors or say when memorial services are planned. Tass, where Lapin once worked, did not immediately carry a report of his death. In a 1974 interview with U.S. reporters in Moscow, Lapin was repeatedly asked why Soviet TV viewers had been kept in the dark about then-President Nixon's Watergate troubles. He said the story was an ``internal problem'' of the United States and that Soviet media did not report ``rumors.'' ``Only facts, without forecasting, without rumors. We never analyze rumors,'' he said when asked why Soviet media didn't report the possibility Nixon might be impeached. Soviet media have since become much more open in line with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost. Lapin headed Gostelradio from 1970-85 and before that was general director of Tass for three years. He was ambassador to Austria from 1956-60 and to China from 1965-67. He began his journalistic career in 1932, working for Leningrad newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Mazowiecki Presidential Declaration
With AM-Poland
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's announcement that he will run for Poland's presidency, made on a national televised newscast Thursday.

I would like to answer today a question that has been put to me for many weeks. It is the question about whether I will agree to run for the office of president of the Polish republic, if my candidacy is put forward. This is the question I have been thinking about for many hours, many days and weeks. It was even commonly thought that it took too long. But this is a question that is very difficult for me personally, and generally; personally, with regard to the circumstances in which I must answer it, and generally, in view of the great responsibility of this office. The time for an answer has come and today I want to give this answer, a short one. Following great deliberations and consideration of all circumstances, I have decided to express approval if my candidacy is put forward. One must move forward. One cannot retreat from the path Poland has chosen and fought for so hard this year. One cannot expose it to dangers. One has to go forward in a better, faster and more sure way - but along this path, not a different one. Poland, which has a great chance in today's world and in Europe, should take the place that is due to it - of a wise country, based on Christian values, of a country of people who are tolerant toward each other, a country that co-exists well with all its neighbors. I want to defend this line and these values, and my decision stems from these motives. I am making it with a total feeling of modesty. I know there are many who are more worthy of this position. I am making it because the historical situation has put me in such a position. This is all I can say today. About the difficulty of this decision, about a broader and further program, I will talk at some other time. Today I only want to pass my best greetings to all of you who are listening to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Wet and Stormy in South
DOC.TEXT: Storms caused damage and injuries Thursday in Mississippi, and rain was scattered across broad sections east of the Mississippi Valley. High wind whipped through a trailer park at Verona, Miss., during heavy thunderstorms early Thursday, slightly injuring two people, damaging several mobile homes and uprooting trees, authorities said. Officials worked to restore power for residents, schools and City Hall. Officials said schools were open despite power outages. National Weather Service and civil defense officials had not determined if the damage was caused by a tornado. The weather service reported a storm that might have been a tornado at Royal, Ala., and damaging gusty wind at Hartselle, Ala., and near the Louisa-Fluvanna County line in Virginia. During the afternoon, showers and thunderstorms reached across western South Carolina, eastern Tennessee, the northwest half of Georgia, Alabama, the Florida Panhandle, southern and central Mississippi, southern and central Louisiana and the upper Texas Gulf Coast. Showers and thunderstorms also reached from the South Carolina coast across northeastern and east-central Florida. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.75 inches at Galveston, Texas; 1.32 at Mary Esther, Fla.; 1.28 at Columbus, Miss.; 1.25 at Valparaiso, Fla.; and 1.09 at Huntsville, Ala. It also was warm across the South. Brownsville, Texas, tied its record high of 95, on the books since 1900. Corpus Christie, Texas, warmed to a record 95 and Jacksonville, Fla., hit a record 94. Showers occurred along a cold front extending over western Vermont, New York state, eastern Ohio, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, western Maryland, western Virginia and western North Carolina. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over western Lower Michigan, northwestern Idiana, southeastern Wisconsin, northern Illinois and east-central Ohio. Thunderstorms produced small hail in Lower Michigan during the early afternoon, the weather service said. In the Northwest, showers and thunderstorms spread across western Montana, the Idaho Panhandle, northeastern Washington state and western Washington state. Wyoming had high wind with gusts to around 50 mph at Cheyenne, Laramie and Vendauwoo, and 59 mph at Cody. Wind gusted to 63 mph at Livingston, Mont. The center of Tropical Storm Klaus was near the island of Antigua, with strongest sustained wind speed of 60 mph. The National Hurricane Center said the storm was likely to strengthen and hurricane warnings were posted for the northern Leeward Islands. Another tropical storm, Josephine, was in the mid-Atlantic with winds of 65 mph. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 24 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 44 at International Falls, Minn., to 97 at both Beeville and Harlingen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: More Americans to Leave Iraq and Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Another group of Americans will be flown out of Iraq and Kuwait next Wednesday on a U.S.-government charter flight, the State Department said Thursday. The approximate number of Americans who will board the flight was not disclosed but officials said the total could be significant because a Boeing 747 has been chartered. During September, about 1,900 Americans - almost all of them women and children - were allowed to fly out of Iraq and Kuwait. The flights were halted Sept. 22 because the State Department said virtually all those who wanted to leave and had permission to do so had departed. But U.S. officials, asking not to be identified, said that since Sept. 22, a number of Americans with permission to leave have made their presence known to U.S. diplomatic officials and said they wanted to return to the United States. The State Department said late last month that at least 900 U.S. citizens remained trapped, including 600 to 700 in Kuwait and 300 to 350 in Iraq. Almost all are adult males, more than 100 of whom have been detained by Iraqi authorities and taken to military and industrial sites. The Iraqis believe the presence of the Americans these locations will deter a U.S. military attack.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is President Bush's statement at the White House on Thursday on prospects for a conventional-arms treaty: Yesterday in the Rose Garden we celebrated the dawn of a new era for Germany and welcomed the prospect of a Europe whole and free. But despite these dramatic political events, Europe is still the site of the greatest concentration of armed strength in the world. As Europe is transformed politically, we must also redraw the military map of the continent and lift some of the shadows and fears that we and our allies have lived with for nearly half a century. Today, Secretary Baker will describe our latest efforts to ensure that the political transformation of Europe is matched in the military field in our negotiations to reduce and limit conventional armed forces in Europe - the so-called CFE talks. Some of you here will remember when in May of 1989 at the NATO summit I proposed a series of initiatives to quicken the pace in CFE, and I pledged then to devote our full effort to the speedy conclusion of a CFE agreement, a treaty that would decisively improve the balance of military power on the continent and back our hopes for lasting stability. We followed through on that commitment, and there is still - let's face it - more work to do. And I want to remind you that CFE is not an accord between the United States and the Soviet Union. It will be a treaty among 22 states, East and West. All must be satisfied with the treaty's provisions. We've consulted repeatedly with our allies about our efforts, both before New York and then during the many talks up there. We believe our allies are pleased with the progress being made. Pending further consultation with our NATO partners, we have agreed in principle with the Soviet Union on resolution of all the major remaining issues in CFE and on many of the essential details as well. Along with our allies, we will continue to push to complete this treaty next month so that the way is clear for convening a CSCE summit in Paris. In conclusion, I want to thank the secretary of state and the people that have been working with him during these negotiations. And let me just say how pleased I am with the progress that we have achieved here. And I would like to now turn to Secretary Baker who has a statement and then he'll be glad to take your questions. Well done. Good luck to you.

DOC.HEAD: Official GOP Candidate Drops Out to Help Democrat Beat Duke
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to add that Bagert a state Sen. and raise reference to votes not being counted; picks up 3rd graf pvs; SUBS grafs 12-13 pvs, ``Bagert's name ...'' with three grafs to DELETE now redundant graf and UPDATE with pollster comment.
DOC.TEXT: The official GOP candidate dropped out of Louisiana's U.S. Senate race Thursday to boost the Democratic incumbent's chances of defeating ex-Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke without a runoff. State Sen. Ben Bagert's withdrawal turned Saturday's Senate primary election into essentially a two-man race between three-term Sen. Bennett Johnston and Duke, a state legislator who is running as a Republican without party support. Bagert's name will remain on the ballot, but the Secretary of State Fox McKeithen said votes for Bagert would not be counted if he formally notified state officials he was out. That makes it almost certain one candidate would get more than half the votes and avert a runoff. National GOP leaders had openly expressed fear that Bagert would pull enough votes to force Duke and Johnston into a runoff Nov. 6. With Duke on the ballot, labeled as a Republican, the race could hurt GOP candidates nationwide. ``All of us would be embarrassed and mortified to have to serve in the United States Senate with David Duke masquerading as a Republican,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. Bagert said his polls indicated that Duke's support was unwavering and that the Bagert ads were drawing votes from Johnston. ``As my campaign finally began to get on track in the last couple of weeks,'' Bagert said, ``it became more and more apparent, that instead of forcing a runoff between myself and Bennett Johnston, I might very well be forcing a runoff between somebody else and Bennett Johnston.'' After announcing his decision, Bagert was asked if he would vote for Johnston. ``Yes, reluctantly,'' he replied. ``I'm not endorsing anybody, but I'm not voting for David Duke.'' Duke and Johnston said Bagert's withdrawal was good news. ``It's been a two-man race for some time and this makes it very clear. The Bagert vote kind of confused things,'' said Johnston. ``I'm very much hoping that that Bagert vote, which has been about 8 percent, would come to me.'' ``I think if he gets out we'll just have to whip Johnston in the first primary,'' Duke said. He called it a clear choice between a liberal and a conservative. Louisiana's unique open primary system puts all candidates on one ballot, regardless of party. If no one gets more than 50 percent of the vote, a runoff is held between the top two vote-getters. Despite several polls that have shown him a distant second to Johnston in recent months, Duke said his own polls show him running even with the incumbent. He said Bagert's withdrawal will help him win the election because he will pick up Bagert's votes. But pollster Joe Walker said Bagert's decision ``kind of decides it for Johnston.'' ``The polls I've seen indicate that the Bagert vote is not a Duke vote,'' said Walker. ``Bagert has run as a very strident anti-Duke candidate from the very beginning. So as a result, the vote he did attract is not one that would transfer to Duke.'' Although Johnston has voted a conservative line on such issues as defense spending and aid to the Nicaraguan Contras, he was attacked by Duke and Bagert as an ``ultra-liberal.'' One reason was his lead role in defeating former President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert Bork to the Supreme Court. Another was his support of the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which his opponents said would impose racial hiring quotas on American businesses. ``I'm going to vote for the things the people of this state want and now we're going to have a clear-cut choice and I can win on Saturday,'' said Duke, who has run a campaign calling for welfare reform and an end to affirmative action programs. But the most recent poll indicated Johnston could eke out a first-ballot victory even with Bagert in the race. The poll released Wednesday by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research of Columbia, Md., showed Johnston was the choice of 53 percent of voters surveyed. Duke drew 26 percent, while Bagert polled 8 percent. Thirteen percent were undecided, according to the poll, which had a margin of error of 3.5 points. The poll of 825 registered voters was taken Sunday through Tuesday. Still, Mason-Dixon officials and other pollsters generally agree that Duke has hidden support. As Susan Howell, a pollster at the University of New Orleans put it, Duke ``flies under radar.'' Bagert had been endorsed by President Bush in radio and television ads. But polls consistently showed him running a poor third. Eight Republican senators from other states endorsed Johnston on Wednesday - a move Johnston called unprecedented in party politics. In Washington, Charles Black, chief spokesman for the Republican Party, said Bagert's withdrawal was ``just the final insurance against Duke getting any further.'' Three minor candidates also were on the ballot, but one dropped out earlier this week ``to help Johnston.'' The others weren't expected to affect the outcome.

DOC.HEAD: Education Department Stops Loans to 14 Trade Schools
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos, vowing to ``protect the integrity of the federal student aid programs,'' on Thursday stopped funding to 14 trade schools for alleged violation of rules. Using emergency authority granted the Education Department less than two weeks ago, Cavazos said an investigation found the for-profit institutions violated rules governing student financial assistance programs, including falsifying student records and misrepresenting education programs, facilities, tuition and fees. ``We are honoring our pledge to take action against those who would abuse such programs,'' Cavazos said in a statement. The schools named include: Transwestern Institute and Metropolitan Business College, both of Long Beach, California; Balin Institute of Technology, Atlanta; Metropolitan Business College, Port Orchard, Wash.; and Hartford Modern School of Welding, Hartford, Conn. Nine others are located in Florida. They are Cocoa Beach Beauty College, Cocoa Beach; National Beauty Academy, Tampa; Titusville Beauty School, Titusville; and various Romar schools in Winter Park, Palm Bay, Merritt Island, Melbourne and Kissimmee. The schools will have an opportunity to show cause why the sanction should be lifted. Cavazos' action is the first under regulations implementing the Student Loan Reconciliation Amendments of 1989, which became effective Sept. 21. Those rules say that funds may be withdrawn from a school and its students if there is reliable information that the school is violating the law and immediate action is necessary to prevent misuse of federal funds. According to officials, the emergency actions taken against the 14 schools were based on: -Falsification of student records; -Using the availability of federal student aid funds to recruit students to an institution that has misrepresented its education programs, facilities, tuition and fees, or the employment prospects of its graduates; -Failure to make required refunds to students who withdrew prior to graduation; -Approving federal financial aid for students enrolled in ineligible programs; -Failure to account for federal funds received; -Approving federal financial aid for students who did not have the ability to benefit from the training.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper That Prints Only Arrests Goofs, Costs Man Job
DOC.TEXT: The Informer was supposed to fight crime by printing the names of everyone arrested for a crime in the St. Petersburg area. But readers of the newspaper's very first issue were misinformed. The Informer erroneously reported that a man had been arrested on a cocaine charge, costing him his job. The newspaper's publisher, Ray Aden, is contrite but still believes his publication can serve its purpose. ``Unfortunately,'' he said, ``some people might be hurt.'' ``He was relying on his people to be accurate and one of them messed up,'' said Shawn Exposito, 23, who was fired from his $500-a-week job as a carpet installer just a month after the birth of his third child. ``It couldn't have come at a worse time.'' Aden said he will print a retraction and do everything he can to help out Exposito, but that doesn't include an offer to make up for his lost income. Exposito's boss at M&M Floor Co., co-owner Bert Butler, has tried to help by giving him a lesser job at half the pay until his previous position reopens. Butler already had hired someone else to replace his employee of eight years. Even before its first issue, The Informer drew skeptical comments from civil libertarians concerned that it would overlook the presumption of innocence until guilt is proven. The Informer correctly printed that Exposito was arrested last month for driving with a suspended driver's license. It also printed that he was arrested on a cocaine charge, which jail records show is inaccurate. Butler saw the drug arrest item Friday and fired Exposito the next day. ``Maybe I acted a little too quickly, but still, in my business I'm sending this man into another person's house,'' Butler said. ``Would you want a drug addict, someone that's thought of as doing drugs, in your home? I know I wouldn't.'' Exposito took work in the carpet warehouse until his old job opens up. ``It's a raw deal for Shawn,'' Butler said. ``These people shouldn't print anything before they get the facts straight.'' Aden said he is still trying to determine how the mistake was made and is trying to find another job for Exposito. ``He calls me sometimes two or three times a day,'' Exposito said. ``I'm sure he's losing sleep over this, probably not as much as I am.''

DOC.HEAD: Monaco Palace Flag at Half-Staff as Principality Mourns Casiraghi
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Casiraghi standing up at time of accident, public funeral, championships canceled, edits to conform. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The flag atop the royal palace flew at half-staff Thursday as the family prepared to bury Princess Caroline's husband, killed in a speedboat accident defending his world champion title. A public funeral for Stefano Casiraghi was scheduled for Saturday morning at the Cathedral of Monaco, three days after he died during the World Offshore Championships, the palace announced. The 41 other boats competing in the event withdrew from the third and final round, also scheduled for Saturday, and planned a memorial Mass on Friday followed by a wreath-laying at sea, organizers said. Several racers competing Wednesday against the 30-year-old Casiraghi said he was driving too fast to handle the choppy water. One newspaper called his boat a ``floating coffin.'' The catamaran, which hit by a large wave, somersaulted and Casiraghi slammed into the water. The principality press office said Casiraghi was strapped in to a seat in the boat but was standing, as was his custom, at the time of the accident. ``That explains why he died on impact,'' said a spokesman, adding that Casiraghi's head caught the brunt of the crash. In a seated position, the driver has some protection in his plexiglass cockpit. Race organizers had announced the resumption of the competition Saturday, saying the interrupted second round would be abandoned. But organizers, speaking at a news conference, said all 41 remaining boats withdrew from the competition and the 1990 offshore championships were canceled. Press reports said Casiraghi had told his family he would quit racing after the championships. In a letter reproduced in the event's official program, Casiraghi paid homage to Caroline, 33, ``who supported me throughout, despite the fears that I caused her ...'' It was not immediately clear whether Casiraghi would be buried in the royal family's tomb or in the Casiraghi family's chapel at Fino Mornasco in Italy. Residents of the principality, but not tourists, were allowed to file past Casiraghi's body in a mortuary near the Princess Grace Hospital. He lay in a simple, brass-handled mahogany coffin, still wearing the red-and-white racing suit in which he died. There was a slight cut under one eye. A press aide to the royal family said Caroline went to the mortuary Wednesday night, after hurrying back from a visit to Paris, and again Thursday morning. She was described as composed and dignified. Prince Rainier III, who never married after the death of former Hollywood star Princess Grace eight years ago in a car accident, spent the day at the Casiraghi home, not far from the palace, according to press reports. Several drivers and crew members, while expressing sorrow at his death, said Casiraghi was going too fast and should have realized he was risking death. ``The guy was driving like a madman,'' said Simon Fletcher, a British mechanic for one of the other boats. ``All the other boats had slowed down after the first buoy after it (the water) got rough.''
