Nice Matin, the main regional newspaper, claimed the ``Pinot de Pinot'' was a ``floating coffin,'' its design ill-suited to its enormous potential for speed. Bruno Plchetti, another Italian driver, was quoted as telling the newspaper France-Soir: ``We were going much too fast, but nobody wanted to slow down because we wanted to catch the ones in front of us (including Casiraghi).'' Several people connected to the offshore racing circuit said Casiraghi normally has his own helicopter rescue crew flying near his boat during a race but did not have one in the air Wednesday. Shops and businesses in Monaco remained open Thursday, and streets were busy. Throughout the city, there were posters promoting the speedboat race, showing a picture of Casiraghi and his co-pilot, Patrice Innocenti. According to other racers, Innocenti - who was injured - was handling the steering, while Casiraghi was controlling the throttle of the boat. The 42-foot boat flipped over while ahead of the pack at the start of the second round. Innocenti ejected, but Casiraghi did not as the two-engine, five-ton boat slammed into the water upside down. It sank moments after rescuers reached it. Casiraghi had competed in offshore racing since 1984, winning 12 of 80 races, including last year's world championship held off Atlantic City, N.J. Caroline, the oldest child of Prince Rainier and Princess Grace, divorced French playboy Philippe Junot in 1980. She married Casiraghi on Dec. 29, 1983 in a simple civil ceremony under a portrait of her late mother. They had three children - Andrea, 6; Charlotte, 4 and Pierre, 3.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel OKs Abortion Bill; Conservatives Vow Floor Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs `The subcommittee ...' with 1 graf to INSERT vote. ADDS 6 grafs to UPDATE with comments from opposition
DOC.TEXT: A House subcommittee approved a bill Thursday that would put into federal law a woman's right to an abortion as ruled in the Supreme Court decision Roe vs. Wade. ``The language of the bill is drawn directly from Roe,'' said Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights. He said the Freedom of Choice Act was necessary to preserve the reproductive options women have had since the Supreme Court decision was issued. ``It is clear from recent Supreme Court decisions that Roe is in jeopardy,'' Edwards said. ``American women can no longer rely on the courts to protect their right to choose. Nor can we leave this vital issue up to a patchwork of state laws.'' Five Democrats voted for the bill and three Republicans voted against it. The action came after two days of hearings. A similar version is pending in the Senate. Edwards said he would press the House leadership for speedy consideration of the measure. However, time is running out on the session and the prospects of the bill making it through Congress this year are dim. Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., said he would welcome a floor fight on Edwards' bill, calling it an ``abortion on demand'' measure. Although Smith said it was unlikely to reach the floor during the current session, he said the bill ``would seek to overturn many state laws'' restricting abortion. Among other things, he said, it would override state laws requiring spousal and parental consent for the procedure. Republican Reps. William Dannemeyer of California and James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin offered a host of amendments seeking provisions restricting abortions under certain circumstances, and each failed by a straight party line vote. ``I think the bill is an extremist bill,'' said Sensenbrenner, who failed in an attempt to attach an amendment permitting states to enact laws shielding physicians who refuse to perform abortions for religious or moral reasons. ``This goes far beyond the scope of Roe vs. Wade,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Loss of Privately Held Wetlands Slowed in Mid-80s, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: The loss of wetlands on private lands slowed significantly during the mid-1980s, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Thursday. Yeutter said new figures by the department's Soil Conservation Service indicated wetland losses ranged from 100,000 to 200,000 acres per year from 1982 to 1987, including areas that reverted to open water. This was ``significantly less'' than wetland loss estimates before 1982, he said. No previous conservation service estimates were available. Spokeswoman Diana Morse said the agency began its five-year surveys in 1977. The new figures comparing 1987 with 1982 were the first, she said. The new figures came from the agency's 1987 National Resources Inventory, or NRI, which is conducted on non-federal lands every five years in cooperation with the Iowa State University Statistical Laboratory. Officials said the inventory serves as the main source of information on the status, condition and trends of soil, water and related resources. It also provides a soil-and-water data base for non-federal rural lands. The report said there were about 82 million acres of wetlands on non-federal rural lands in 1987, down from 83.2 million acres in 1982, a decline of nearly 1.2 million acres. However, the service estimated the loss of wetlands to agricultural and development uses at ``closer to 500,000 acres,'' or an average of 100,000 acres a year. ``The remaining change in wetlands was due to factors such as 300,000 acres changing from private to federal ownership - still likely remaining in wetlands but not included in the service's non-federal lands inventory - and over 400,000 acres that changed to open water, primarily adjacent to the Great Salt Lake in Utah and in southern Louisiana,'' the report said. Of the nearly 500,000 acres lost to agriculture and development, about 215,000 were converted farmland, including wetlands drying up because of drought and about 280,000 acres to development. Regionally, the inventory indicated wetland losses over the five-year period were greatest in the Southeast, Mississippi Delta states, and the Great Lakes states. Losses were reported at 170,000 acres in the Southeast, 150,000 in the Delta, and 80,000 in the Great Lakes. Morse said that there were no available breakdowns by state and that the service considered those estimates too inexact for publishing. She said the regional estimates were the only ones the agency had available at the present time.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Meningitis Vaccine Safe For Infants
DOC.TEXT: A vaccine that prevents bacterial meningitis and other life-threatening diseases now can be given to infants as young as two months to protect them when they most need it. The Food and Drug Administration, in approving Thursday use of the vaccine at younger ages, said new studies show it is safe and effective for these infants and could prevent hundreds of deaths a year. The vaccine was approved in 1988 for use in children 18 months and older, and later for use in children 15 months and older. However, bacterial meningitis and other diseases caused by the Haemophilus influenzae type b bacteria take their heaviest toll in infants ages six to 12 months. The vaccine has significantly reduced incidence of the Haemophilus b diseases in children 18 months and older, but physicians still diagnose about 10,000 cases of Haemophilus meningitis a year, mostly in children under 18 months, the FDA said. About 500 of these children die and of those who survive, about 3,800 children suffer blindness, deafness, mental retardation and other neurological complications, the FDA said. When the vaccine was first approved, federal health officials said data were not available to show the vaccine was effective in younger children. But a recently completed two-and-a-half year, multiracial and multiethnic study of more than 60,000 infants less than six months old showed the vaccine was safe and would protect against the Haemophilus b diseases, the FDA said. The vaccine can be given at the same intervals as the diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis vaccine - two months, four months and six months, the agency said. A booster dose would be given when the child is 15 months or older. Researchers found only mild and transient side effects among the infants in the study, including swelling and warmth at the vaccination site and occasional fever. Besides bacterial meningitis, the vaccine is effective against epiglottitis, which is an often fatal inflammation of the flap that covers the breathing tubes, pneumonia, septicemia and septic arthritis. The vaccine is not effective against viral meningitis. The vaccine, marketed under the name HibTITER, is made by Praxis Biologics Inc. and is distributed by Lederle Laboratories, both part of American Cyanamid of Wayne, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Editor Says He Was Set Up
DOC.TEXT: The former editor in chief of the Johnstown Tribune-Democrat, who resigned after being charged with impersonating a deputy state attorney general, insists he was set up. ``The politics that might have been involved in this is so bizarre that it is beyond my imagination,'' editor Theodore N. Beitchman told the Tribune-Review of Greensburg. ``I just know that on Tuesday morning I got a bunch of anonymous calls and people were applauding in the background.'' Beitchman, 43, a former senior editor at Sports Illustrated, resigned Monday after 18 months on the job. Earlier that day, he was arraigned in Bucks County on charges of impersonating a public servant and harassment by communication. The Bucks County district attorney's office has alleged Beitchman threatened a Bucks County man for trying to collect $921 in damages against Beitchman's brother, Arthur, after a May 8, 1989, car accident. In one of four telephone calls made to the man on March 13, Beitchman allegedly used the name and title of Deputy Attorney General William Finnegan. Beitchman said Wednesday he will prove his innocence at a hearing next week but does not plan to return to the paper. ``I think it is a sign from above that it is time to move on,'' he said. Beitchman faces other charges in Cambria County. West Hills Regional Police charged him with drunken driving on Sept. 2, when Beitchman was heading home from a wedding reception. Police said he had a blood-alcohol level of 0.237 percent, more than twice the state's legal intoxication limit of 0.10.

DOC.HEAD: West African Continue Assault, Bombing, of Rebel Forces
DOC.TEXT: West African soldiers ousted rebel leader Charles Taylor from positions in the capital Wednesday and fought over an airfield that could be used to fly much-needed supplies to the starving capital. A spokesman for the multinational army said its 4,000 soldiers had forced Taylor's rebels out of the city center and were fighting his troops at Spriggs Payne airfield and the national radio station, which Taylor has been using. Once the West Africans gain control of the airfield it could be used to fly in desperately needed food and medicine. Most of Monrovia's 400,000 residents have had little to eat for weeks. Remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's army and rival rebel leader Prince Johnson support the West African offensive, now in its third day. The West Africans aim to neutralize Taylor and install an interim government to organize fair elections. Taylor is opposed to foreign intervention in Liberia's 9-month-old civil war, which Taylor started Dec. 24 when he invaded from Ivory Coast. The five-nation West African force also set up armored cars and sandbags around the presidential palace and the downtown barracks Wednesday to prevent Prince Johnson from launching attacks on government troops holed up there. Johnson's soldiers captured and killed Doe in September and have been hunting down the remnants of his army. In fighting against Taylor's forces, the West Africans gained control of Gardnersville, a suburb 2{ miles north of the city center, and wiped out artillery batteries, said a West African spokesman. Taylor had used the base to shell the port of Monrovia, where the West African army has its headquarters. Ten refugees waiting to be evacuated were killed by shells Tuesday and Wednesday, the spokesman said, speaking on condition he not be named. Nigerian warplanes have made more than 30 sorties against Buchanan and Robertsfield International Airport to cut Taylor's lines of supply, said a West African diplomat in Freetown, capital of neighoring Sierra Leone. Robertsfield is 35 miles east of Monrovia and Buchanan is 50 miles further east. Taylor had left the multinational army no choice by refusing to attend peace talks toward the establishment of the interim government, said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The only option left for the Economic Community of West African States is to shoot at him, and more bombing attacks will take place,'' the diplomat said. Taylor has declared himself president of Liberia. His men have overrun most of the country, but have been unable to capture Monrovia. Johnson, a former aide to Taylor, split off to form his own guerrilla band in the spring. The war has claimed more than 5,000 lives, most of them civilians, many killed simply because of tribal affiliation. Members of Doe's Krahn tribe have been targeted by the rebels. In an incident Wednesday in the Mamba Point diplomatic enclave, reporters watched as rebels of Johnson's army captured a woman. ``I am not a Krahn,'' the woman screamed. Ghanaian soldiers from the West African force arrived from a checkpoint down the road and forced the rebels to release the woman.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Five Dead in Apartment Blast
LaserPhotos PAR4,5
DOC.TEXT: Crews using body-sniffing dogs searched Thursday through an apartment building destroyed by an apparent gas explosion that killed at least five people. Cause of the pre-dawn blast was not established officially, but firemen and gas company officials said it appeared to have been a gas leak. Thirty-seven apartments were destroyed in the low-income building near the western outskirts of Paris. Gas company investigators said preliminary findings suggest a gas leak in in one of the apartments, rather than in a conduit serving the entire five-story building. At least eight people, including a child, were injured. Seven of the 49 residents were still unaccounted for late Thursday, authorities said. ``We haven't heard any call for help from under the debris,'' said Jean-Louis Duffeigneux, a regional administrator. The search by about 170 rescue workers, including some teams equipped with specially trained dogs, progressed slowly because of danger from weakened walls and roof. Names of those killed were not immediately released.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Congressman Says Tickets Lifted in Retaliation
With AM-Budget a0690
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, had hoped to spend Wednesday evening in the president's box at the Kennedy Center, watching ``The Playboy of the Western World'' with constituents. But the White House took away his seats because he opposes the giant deficit-reduction bill that President Bush and congressional leaders are trying to ram through Congress, Regula said Thursday. Regula said he received a telephone call Wednesday from a White House lobbyist seeking his support for the package of tax increases and spending cuts. When he said he remained in opposition, ``It was clear the box wasn't available.'' The congressman bought six tickets on his own for the play. ``There have been better moments,'' he said. Regula and his wife had planned to use the seats with two couples who had won a trip to Washington at an annual charity auction for Aultman Hospital in Canton, Ohio. Members of Congress and the Cabinet may use the president's box when the president is not there, and they frequently do. But the president controls the tickets. Regula said he opposes the budget measure because its $134 billion hit poor people too hard, and because it doesn't shrink spending enough. White House spokesman Stephen Hart said he was not aware of the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Black Community Leaders Act To Help Catch Professor's Killer
DOC.TEXT: Black community leaders, worried that police may be preoccupied with finding a serial killer, have mobilized to help track down the killer of a black college professor. Charles W. Thomas, a professor at the University of California's San Diego campus, was found mortally wounded in his car Friday night. His death has prompted James Del Rio, a retired Michigan judge and legislator, to organize a reward fund for information leading to an arrest. ``I think black people owe him. They are indebted to him and I'm seeking to get them to repay it,'' said Del Rio. ``He used to have a famous saying, `Don't mourn. Organize.' That's what we're trying to do.'' Del Rio, a longtime friend of Thomas, made a personal $1,000 donation to start the fund this week. By Thursday, he said, the fund had reached $4,200. Though he said he would work closely with police and the local Crime Stoppers chapter, Del Rio said the fund is an independent effort by the black community to try to help bring Thomas' killer to justice. Police spokesman Bill Robinson said the department welcomes assistance from the black community and will take the tips passed on to investigators seriously. ``There's no law preventing citizens from helping police and as long as these efforts don't interfere with our investigation, we welcome the help,'' Robinson said. Del Rio noted that the police department's resources are being taxed by the manhunt for a serial killer believed responsible for the murders of five women in San Diego this year. ``They've got more murders going on than this one. That's why I feel the black community should get off their duff and do something,'' he said. Robinson insisted that the Police Department is working vigorously to solve the Thomas case, despite the personnel drain caused by the serial killer investigation. Thomas, 64, died Saturday at a hospital. Before he died, he was able to describe his attacker, but police had not determined a motive. ``A lot of people are trying to catch the peron who committed this crime,'' said the Rev. George Walker Smith, who is black. ``White folks do it all the time. Black folks don't. I don't know why, but now we're trying to do this so whoever did this gets caught.'' Smith, pastor at Christ United Presbyterian Church in southeast San Diego, contributed $1,000 to the reward fund. Businessman Hartwell Ragsdale said he contributed $1,000 because ``we've had too many unsolved murders in the black community.'' ``The black community must do what we can do ... to see to it that the people who are destroying our leaders and other citizens are brought to justice.'' Memorial services for Thomas were scheduled Friday at UCSD and at the First United Methodist Church. At the college, flags flew at half staff this week in memory of Thomas, a psychologist and urban studies professor at the university since 1971. Thomas sometimes surprised people with his teaching methods, which were geared toward helping people understand root causes of societal problems. For instance, to help his students understand racism, Thomas brought white supremacist Tom Metzger into the classroom. ``Thomas didn't consider that reading a person's work was enough. He wanted the students to see, for example, that racists truly believed in racism,'' said Cecil Lytel, a provost at UCSD. ``He took teaching beyond teaching and created lasting learning experiences for his students.''

DOC.HEAD: Oklahoma Indictment Accuses California Producers
DOC.TEXT: Two California producers of adult videotapes were charged Thursday with violating federal obscenity laws by shipping what prosecutors called hard-core pornography to Oklahoma. The indictment of the president and vice-president of a Van Nuys, Calif. video company ``stakes out our commitment to aggressively pursue large-scale producers of illegal hard-core pornography,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. ``They will be pursued in every state in the nation.'' The indictment returned in Tulsa, Okla., is one of the few federal obscenity cases brought against producers of pornography, officials said. The Justice Department's pornography unit, which has generally targeted distributors rather than producers, has been criticized by civil libertarians since it was begun in the Reagan administration. Sidney Niekerk, the president of Cal Vista Ltd. of Van Nuys, Calif., and Jack Gallagher, the company's vice president, were charged in the five-count indictment with shipping four movies to Broken Arrow, Okla. The indictment, which also named the company as defendant, charged the two with conspiracy, interstate transportation of obscene material, aiding and abetting and engaging in a business of selling obscene matter. If convicted, Niekerk and Gallagher could be sentenced up to 25 years in prison and fined as much as $1.25 million. The company faces a maximum fine of $2.5 million. The indictment resulted from a series of 24 searches in the Los Angeles area conducted earlier this year by the the FBI and Los Angeles police, the Justice Department said. The videocassettes showed a variety of sexual acts, including group sex and lesbianism, the department said. Denver defense attorney Arthur Schwartz, who represents Niekerk, said evidence will show that the company had never shipped its videocassettes to Oklahoma until it was lured into doing so by undercover federal agents. ``They were really ensnared into doing it,'' Schwartz said. The lawyer charged that Justice Department chose to bring charges against his client in Oklahoma to take advantage of conservative moral standards in that part of the country. ``The approach of the government in trying to regulate access to sexually oriented material is to go to the most conservative areas in the United States in an effort to pressure companies located in more liberal areas out of existence,'' Schwartz said. ``Are the people in Tulsa going to decide what the people in New York feel they have a right to have?'' Federal juries are allowed to apply prevailing community standards in deciding whether material is obscene. What may be found to be obscene in Utah or Oklahoma may not be considered so by a jury in another federal jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Damaged as NASA Prepares Discovery for Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf starting `An investigative ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with NASA reviewing Discovery's paperwork and inventory as a result of Atlantis accident.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: NASA suffered another setback Thursday when a toppled beam was found inside the space shuttle Atlantis, but the countdown continued for the scheduled weekend launch of Discovery. The space agency also faced another hurdle, in a Washington, D.C., courtroom. A federal judge took under advisement a request by anti-nuclear activists to halt Discovery's launch because its satellite is powered by highly radioactive plutonium. He did not say when he would rule. The satellite, called Ulysses, is being sent to study the sun in the Discovery mission scheduled for liftoff Saturday. The 70-pound metal beam, painted bright yellow, was accidentally left by workers inside Atlantis' engine compartment, said Forrest McCartney, director of Kennedy Space Center. The beam was heard crashing around in the compartment Wednesday when the orbiter was being raised into an upright position in the assembly building. Workers found the 8-foot-11-inch-long beam on a pile of cables inside the compartment after the solid fuel booster rockets and external tank were attached to the orbiter Thurday. McCartney said a quick survey of the compartment found that insulation covering some components and plumbing had been dented. He said it was too soon to tell if the accident will delay Atlantis' secret military flight scheduled for early November. Atlantis' mission already is four months late because of hydrogen fuel leaks that grounded the craft in June. The leak repairs were completed Friday. The beam, which had been used in a work platform, was left by an experienced crew, McCartney aid. The paperwork indicated everything had been removed, he said. ``It should have been caught and wasn't,'' McCartney said. McCartney said he did not see any connection between the latest mishap and other accidents this year involving the shuttle fleet. An investigation board concluded last week that workers' failure to follow procedures and improper use of a clamp led to an accident involving a thruster in July. The thruster, one of 14 on Discovery's right orbital maneuvering system pad, was dented when it fell off a work stand. ``I don't think we can say procedures were a problem'' with Atlantis, McCartney said. ``I don't think we can say training was a problem. I think what we can say is that we did not do the job in the way we intended to do it.'' An investigative team was being formed to look into the matter. NASA officials also were reviewing Discovery's paperwork and equipment inventory to make sure nothing was overlooked in that shuttle's engine compartment. Brewster Shaw, deputy director of shuttle operations, said he did not anticipate any problems with Discovery. In Washington, the activists said they fear an accident like the explosion of the shuttle Challenger would spew the deadly plutonium over Florida. The same judge, Oliver Gasch of U.S. District Court, refused to interfere with Atlantis' launch last October with a plutonium-powered satellite bound for Jupiter. The activists, in their latest action, cited NASA's inability to launch a shuttle in nearly half a year. Columbia, like Atlantis, has been grounded for months by hydrogen leaks. Ulysses carries nearly 23.7 pounds of plutonium-238, half as much as the Jupiter satellite. The decaying plutonium will provide electricity for Ulysses during its 1.86 billion-mile journey through space. To place it into an orbit over the sun's poles, Ulysses will be sent to Jupiter to be kicked back by the planet's gravity. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration insist a plutonium generator is the only way to power Ulysses through its long journey. Solar panels large enough to collect light as far away as Jupiter could have been built. But they would have added so much weight to 807-pound spacecraft that there would not be a powerful enough launcher to lift it, said Derek Eaton, Ulysses project manager for the European Space Agency. The agency provided the $250 million spacecraft. NASA's environmental impact study on Ulysses indicates a less than one in 1 million chance of an accident resulting in a plutonium-related cancer death. An Energy Department team of 70 people is setting up radiation-monitoring equipment as a precaution. After Ulysses is released from Discovery, a two-stage engine and a smaller booster engine will send it hurtling toward Jupiter at a record speed of 34,450 mph. After Jupiter gives it a gravity slingshot, it will pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. Scientists expect to know whether Ulysses is safely on its way shortly after the last engine fires and the spacecraft separates from the booster, about 7{ hours after liftoff. Ulysses, ready to go since 1983, was assigned after several launch delays to a May 1986 flight aboard Challenger. The shuttle's explosion earlier that year resulted in the spacecraft being put back in storage. If Discovery does not lift off by Oct. 23, the mission will have to wait 13 months for the proper planetary alignment. ``It (success) is important for the project because we've been around for a long time, and a delay means a delay in science and more money,'' said Willis Meeks, NASA's project manager for Ulysses. ``But I think it would be very important to the morale of all of us in this business to see the shuttle flying again.''

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Report Gives Important Weight to Timing of Contributions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf: ``McCain was,'' with 5 grafs bgng: ``McCain met,'' senator's remarks after meeting with the committee
DOC.TEXT: A special counsel's report that recommends an ethics investigation proceed against Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. gives important weight to the timing of a fund-raiser held by savings and loan figure Charles H. Keating Jr., sources close to the probe said Thursday. The March 23, 1987, fund-raiser occurred just before meetings between senators and U.S. banking regulators. Five senators intervened with regulators on behalf of Keating, a major political donor, as his S&L headed for collapse. Also influencing the recommendation was a brief discussion about Keating between Riegle and the top U.S. thrift regulator - Edwin J. Gray - on March 6, 1987, the sources said. Riegle suggested Gray meet with senators and such a meeting occurred the next month. The information on Bennett's report was confirmed to The Associated Press by sources who spoke only on condition of anonymity. The Ethics Committee is looking for any connections between actions by the senators and the $1.3 million in political donations they received from the businessman and his associates. Congressional sources previously confirmed that Special Counsel Robert S. Bennett recommended the probe continue against Riegle, D-Mich., and Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., and Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. He also proposed that two senators be dropped from the investigation: John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. McCain met with the committee privately Thursday, a day after a similar session with Glenn. The other three senators are to appear over the next two weeks. Emerging after about three hours, McCain said he ``felt good'' about the session and predicted he would be exonerated before the Senate adjourns later this month. The senator said the investigation has been politically damaging and that Arizonans will ``judge my conduct'' by the outcome of the inquiry. ``I refuse to believe the Ethics Committee would be motivated by political concerns,'' said McCain, the only Republican among the five. If his case is dismissed, only Democrats in the Senate would be under investigation for their roles in the savings and loan mess. In the recommendations on Riegle, one source said Bennett was ``throwing up for committee the possibility that when a political contribution is so close to an event, is there way it cannot be connected?'' ``He's wrestling with a new concept not articulated before in an ethics ruling,'' the source said. ``There's never been a case like this where people are looking to the appearance and proximity (of contributions) as possible problems. Riegle epitomizes this because his conduct, absent (receipt of Keating's) political contributions, amounts to nothing.'' Both the March fund-raiser and Riegle's meeting with Gray were in close to crucial meetings between senators and banking regulators April 2 and 9, 1987. Riegle only attended the second meeting, while the other senators went to both sessions. The senators said they were trying to ensure that Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan was treated fairly and have denied any links between Keating's money and their assistance. The Irvine, Calif., thrift was taken over by federal regulators in April 1989 and it may cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover its losses. At the April 2 meeting between four senators and Gray, the chief regulator said the lawmakers offered a deal that would have helped Keating. The senators vigorously denied such an offer was made. The April 9 meeting was between all five senators and the San Francisco-based regulators who were investigating Lincoln. The examiners told the senators they were referring results of their investigation to the criminal section of the Justice Department. Riegle's office has denied any links between the timing of the March 23, 1987, fund-raiser and the April meetings. The senator's aide, David Krawitz, has said the event ``was confirmed and scheduled on Jan 30, 1987,'' months before the meetings with regulators were set up. Riegle raised $78,250 at the fund-raiser from Keating and his associates. A year later, while maintaining there was no connection between the contributions and the April 9 meeting, Riegle announced he returned the money because it could ``create the appearance of a conflict of interest.''

DOC.HEAD: A Once-Bitten Fan Fails to Get Excited
With AM-Souter a0647
DOC.TEXT: The perils-of-Pauline finish of the Boston Red Sox atop the American League's Eastern Division has not captivated once-bitten David Souter, who will become the newest Supreme Court justice Tuesday. ``After 1967 (when the team lost the World Series) I said I'm never going to let myself get excited again about the Red Sox and I have not done so,'' Souter said Thursday, the day after the Sox won the division title. The Sox have many fans in New Hampshire and throughout the New England states. Souter said he's a casual observer, not a true fan, and attended a Red Sox-Baltimore Orioles game the day after concluding his Senate confirmation testimony mainly because friends wanted him to go. The biggest fan in the Souter family is the judge's mother, who will be 83 this week. As a girl, she saw Babe Ruth play for the Red Sox before his celebrated trade to the New York Yankees 1919, a trade fans have recalled as ``the curse of the Bambino'' in predicting eventual repetition of the team's late-season collapse. ``If I want to know a batting average or something,'' Souter said, ``I can always call her up. She's the fan.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebellious Slovenia Annuls Federal Law
DOC.TEXT: Deputies in Slovenia on Thursday proposed a plebiscite on independence from Yugoslavia after declaring many federal laws incompatible with the republic's newly drawn constitution. In the neighboring republic of Croatia, deputies voted down a proposal to follow Slovenia's lead and declare independence. Debate also raged over ethnic tensions between Croats and Serbs. One irate deputy hurled his briefcase at an opponent. In the Parliament of Slovenia, the smallest of Yugoslavia's six republics, legislators ruled that 30 federal laws touching on the economy, politics and defense were incompatible with the Slovenian constitution as it was amended last week. A legislative committee called for a plebiscite on the creation of an ``independent, sovereign state of Slovenia,'' the state news agency Tanjug reported. But it was unclear whether such a vote would have legal standing. The committee proposed the vote take place before the new constitution is adopted in early November, Tanjug said. Slovenia has about 2 million people, less than 10 percent of the Yugoslav population. Most leaders in the republic favor transforming Yugoslavia, a loose federation of six republics, into a confederation in which each state would have de facto sovereignty. This view is supported by Croatia, the only other republic to have held free elections. Center-right parties trounced the Communists in recent balloting in both republics. But the Communist rulers of Serbia, the largest republic, favor more centralized control and vehemently oppose confederation. Tensions eased somewhat Thursday in a Serbian-majority enclave of the Croatian republic that has been wracked by rioting in recent days. In Knin, where armed Serbs set up roadblocks last Friday, rail traffic to the coast gradually resumed, Tanjug said. The protesting Serbs, who make up 10 percent of Croatia's 5 million people, claim the center-right government of the republic discriminates against them. Croatian authorities charge the Communist government of Serbia is whipping up ethnic tensions to destabilize Croatia's newly established democracy. Deputy Croatian Interior Minister Perica Juric said scores of guns and 60,000 rounds of ammunition were seized by Serbs from police armories in Petrinja, Glina and Dvor na Uni last week. Serbian Democratic Party delegate Radoslav Tanjga of Knin accused Croatian authorities of ``continuous tyranny against the Serbian people in Croatia.'' Deputy Ivan Bobetko of the governing Croatian Democratic Party hurled his briefcase at Tanjga, hitting the lectern, Tanjug said.

DOC.HEAD: France, Japan, Soviets Try Diplomacy to Resolve Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Iraqi U.N. address postponed because of nose bleed by ambassador, plans for American evacuation, Saddam meeting with Soviet official and PLO chairman. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,7,AMM1,2,PAR6, DHA3
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet envoy carried a secret message from Mikhail Gorbachev to Baghdad and Japan's prime minister met with Iraq's No. 2 leader Thursday in new efforts for peace in the Persian Gulf. Five Europeans used a 10-foot boat in a daring escape from Iraq and plans were announced to evacuate more Americans. The USS Independence - the first American aircraft carrier in the gulf in 16 years - left the waterway after a brief show of force. A Navy warship enforcing a U.N. embargo on Iraq stopped a Sudanese freighter from entering the Gulf of Aqaba, the Pentagon said. Iraq, hurting from the international sanctions following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, planned to argue its case before the United Nations. The world body, which has condemned Iraq's invasion and placed a naval and air embargo on the country, may consider stronger measures. At the United Nations, Iraq's planned address to the General Assembly was postponed after the nation's U.N. ambassador suffered a nose bleed. Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari was expected to read a statement in response to President Bush's suggestion Monday that an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could lead to ``opportunities'' toward a broad Middle East peace settlement. The ambassador was taken to a U.N. medical office for treatment and then went home to rest. Cause of the nose bleed was not immediately known. U.N. officials said the speech would be rescheduled, possibly for Monday. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, following up on Bush's suggestion, said Thursday that Israel must be prepared to negotiate the Palestinian problem once Iraq withdraws from Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has tried to link a pullout from Kuwait with Israel's occupation of territories it captured in the 1967 Middle East war. In the Middle East, other diplomatic attempts to resolve the 2-month-old crisis continued. Yevgeny Primakov, a senior adviser to Gorbachev, arrived in Baghdad carrying a message from the Soviet president, Soviet diplomatic sources said. Its contents were not disclosed. Tass quoted him as saying in Baghdad that a negotiated solution was needed ``toavoid a military explosion.'' Primakov planned to request that some of about 5,000 Soviet citizens, most oil industry workers, be allowed to leave Iraq, the diplomatic sources said. Primakov also met early Thursday with Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat in Amman, Jordan, and delivered a message from Gorbachev, said a PLO source who requested anonymity. Arafat met later in Baghdad with Saddam and the two ``agreed that a political solution to the crisis is possible within an Arab context,'' said a PLO source. The PLO has maintained ties with Iraq since the invasion. Gorbachev said Thursday he saw no reason to send Soviet troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf. In response to a query, Gorbachev told reporters in Moscow: ``I think there are already more than enough troops there.'' In the Jordanian capital of Amman, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan met with Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan. Ramadan, considered No. 2 to Saddam, rejected a negotiated settlement to the crisis as long as foreign troops remain on Arab soil, Baghdad's official Iraq News Agency reported. Kaifu insisted on Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait first, said Shigeo Takenaka, Kaifu's spokesman. Kaifu, meeting later with Jordan's King Hussein, granted $250 million in development loans to Jordan, which has been hard-hit by the embargo of Iraq. French President Francois Mitterrand assured Saudi King Fahd that he backed international efforts to isolate Iraq. The meeting in the Saudi port of Jiddah followed Iraqi attempts to engage France in separate peace talks. Also in Saudi Arabia, three Britons on Thursday said their fear of Iraq sustained them during their daring escape. The three Britons and two Frenchmen crammed aboard a 10-foot boat and spent 25 hours - much of the time being tossed in 10-foot swells - before being rescued Wednesday. ``It's a trip I wouldn't like to do again, but it was well worth it now that I am here,'' Mike Teesdale, 40, told a news conference in the Saudi border town of Khafji. ``My fear was of Iraq, not of the trip.'' It was the first report of Western men escaping Iraq since August. Iraq has allowed hundreds of Western women and children to fly home aboard chartered planes. The British escapees said they had taken the 10-foot boat through the marshes of southern Iraq, into the Shatt-al-Arab waterway and then the gulf. Teesdale said the men had only a compass to guide them and got lost several times before being picked up by the Saudi coast guard. The Britons said they had been working on an oil installation near the Iraqi port of Basra and the two Frenchmen were barge masters. They were among a small number of Europeans living on dwindling food supplies and denied permission to leave. Iraq is holding about 2,200 Westerners hostage in Kuwait and Iraq, some at strategic installations to discourage attack by the U.S.-led military forces that began massing in the region after Iraq seized Kuwait. Nine of those hostages - all Frenchmen - returned to Paris on Thursday after being freed by Iraq. Also Thursday, 173 Brazilians arrived home after Brazil negotiated their release from Iraq. The U.S. State Department announced Thursday that another special flight is planned for Wednesday for Americans to leave Iraq and Kuwait. The exact number of Americans expected to board the U.S.-government charter was not disclosed, but a Boeing 747 is scheduled to be used. Some 747s can carry more than 500 passengers. The last U.S.-sanctioned special flight was Sept. 22, but more Americans with permission to leave Iraq or Kuwait have come forward, said U.S. officials who askednnot to be identified. The State Department said late last month that at least 900 U.S. citizens - mostly men - remained trapped in Kuwait and Iraq. In Baghdad, a radical Palestinian group loyal to Iraq threatened to launch ``powerful strikes'' if the United States endangers Iraqi aircraft while enforcing the U.N. air embargo on Iraq. The statement by the Arab Liberation Front was the second such threat in as many days by radical Palestinians and heightened fears of a terrorist campaign against the West. The United States now has about 170,000 troops in Saudi Arabia and on ships in the area, making up most of the estimated 200,000-member international force. The Pentagon says Iraq has massed 460,000 troops in Kuwait since the invasion. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said sailors from the Navy frigate Samuel B. Roberts boarded the Sudanese freighter Blue Nile on Thursday. Williams said the freighter, carrying industrial equipment, was diverted from the Gulf of Aqaba because the ship's log did not account for all of its cargo. Under the U.N. embargo, shipments to the Jordanian port of Aqaba, a prime port for Iraqi cargo, has been cut severely. Williams also said the aircraft carrier USS Independence, which left the Persian Gulf two days after entering the waterway, had sucessfully completed its mission ``to demonstrate to our friends and allies in the region that it is possible to put a carrier in the gulf and carry out operations. Those were the goals, and they were accomplished.'' He declined to say what the Independence would do next.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Changing Military Strategy For Europe
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is responding to the unification of Germany by altering its strategy in Europe to a military presence rather than troops massed near the borders, a top Pentagon official said Wednesday. ``Forward deployed forces will be smaller, with greater emphasis on mobility and versatility than in the current NATO structure, to allow maximum flexibility in times of crisis,'' said Army Maj. Gen. John Seawall. The vice director for strategic plans and policy and two other Defense Department officials described for the Senate Armed Services Committee details of the unification and its impact on American and NATO troops. As the Soviet Union withdraws its forces from what was East Germany - with a target for completion of 1994, the military situation undergoes significant changes. In the past, the United States and its NATO allies maintained forces shoulder-to-shoulder with the best defense closest to the Warsaw Pact nations. Under the new strategy, the concept is ``defense of the borders as opposed to defense on the border,'' Seawall said. Stephen Hadley, assistant secretary of defense for internationl security policy, said that based on dramatic changes in Europe, the withdrawal of Soviet troops and the expected treaty to reduce conventional forces, a new NATO force is warranted. The allies will move toward ``a reduced reliance on nuclear forces; smaller and restructured active forces which are highly versatile and rely increasingly on multinational corps composed of national units; and greater reliance on reserves and the ability to reconstitute larger forces as and when necessary.'' President Bush has proposed a troop level of 195,000 in Central Europe. However, the withdrawal of Soviet forces and action by the Congress could cut deeper into the troop strength. The Senate, in its defense bill, approved a reduction in active duty troops of 100,000, including 50,000 in Europe. The House adopted a budget calling for a cut of 129,500, including 50,000 in Europe. Negotiators for the two sides are currently working on a final package. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the planned change in strategy represented a ``very, very important statement.'' ``This is the first reference I have seen to a new thinking of NATO strategy,'' Nunn said.

DOC.HEAD: New Co-Anchors Named by CBS News
DOC.TEXT: Starting Friday, Robert Krulwich and Edie Magnus will co-anchor the Friday editions of CBS' new late-night news series, ``America Tonight,'' CBS said Thursday. Charles Kuralt and Lesley Stahl will continue to anchor the series on Monday through Thursday. Their half-hour series premiered Monday. Krulwich, an economics correspondent, and Magnus, a former co-anchor of the flop ``USA Today: The Television Series,'' were put on the Friday anchor shift to give Stahl and Kuralt more time to prepare for their Sunday shows, a CBS spokeswoman said. Kuralt anchors ``Sunday Morning'' and Stahl moderates ``Face the Nation'' on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Rwandan Army Checks Rebel Invasion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf pvs `The French' to ADD report of Belgian troops leaving for Rwanda, Red Cross plans. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `President Juvenal...'
DOC.TEXT: Rwandan forces firing helicopter-borne rockets and cannons blocked rebels advancing toward the central African nation's capital in a bid to overthrow the government, a diplomatic source said Thursday. ``Frankly, the tide has turned,'' the diplomat said from Rwanda's capital, Kigali. ``It's not looking good for the rebels.'' He said the invading force, estimated at several hundred to more than 1,000, was sharply reduced during the army's counterattack Wednesday and Thursday near Gabiro, 40 miles northeast of Kigali. There were no reliable reports of casualties. Diplomats in Kigali said the government was trying to move civilians out of the combat zone. The region is sparsely populated and relatively flat compared with the steep hills covering much of the impoverished nation. Despite the two-day blitz on the rebels' main force around Gabiro, a group of more than 100 guerrillas reportedly has reached the shores of Lake Muhazi, 30 miles east of Kigali, using unusual hit-and-run tactics. The rebels have eluded government forces by changing into civilian clothes aften's conference in New York. The well-armed rebels, made up of Rwandan refugees, predominantly of the Tutsi tribe, invaded Rwanda from its northern neighbor Uganda on Sunday. Many are deserters from Uganda's army. The rebels have lived in Uganda since fleeing bloody ethnic battles in Rwanda in the late 1950s and early 1960s when the majority Hutu tribe gained control of the country. Uganda has denounced the invaders and closed its border with Rwanda, cutting off any possibility of retreat or resupply by the rebels. The rebels admit their forces are predominantly Tutsi, but say that is a function of history and deny they are bent on ethnic revenge, according to interviews with guerrillas in Uganda's state newspaper New Vision. But in Kigali authorities have arrested about a dozen prominent Tutsi and Hutu citizens, including army officers, government officials, business people and intelligentsia. Charges against them were not immediately announced. Eighty-five percent of Rwanda's foreign earnings come from coffee exports and have fallen by more than half in recent years because of lower coffee prices on the international market. The rebels said they also would like to end the refugee problem and give citizenship to all Rwandans, including those outside the nation's borders. There are more than 100,000 Rwandan refugees in Africa and the rebels estimate more than 1 million worldwide. Rwanda says it has no place to put the refugees. The nation is among the most crowded in the world with an estimated 566 people per square mile. It also has a population growth rate of nearly 4 percent annually, among the world's highest.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Klaus Bears Down on Caribbean, Hurricane Warnings Issued
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with six dead, two missing, hundreds evacuated in Martinique, 6 p.m. EDT storm positions. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus bore down Thursday on the eastern Caribbean after causing severe flooding on the French island of Martinique, where six people were reported dead and two missing. The National Hurricane Center in Miami said Klaus, the 11th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, had sustained winds of 60 mph and could grow into a hurricane by Friday. Hurricane warnings were issued for the Leeward Islands along an arc from the French and Dutch island of St. Martin-St. Maarten in the north to the British colony of Montserrat in the south. Tropical storm warnings remained in effect for Martinique and its sister island of Guadeloupe. ``The storm has been showing signs of getting stronger, and we're forecasting the possibility of it becoming a hurricane within the next 24 hours,'' said forecaster Miles Lawrence at the hurricane center. Klaus was expected to pass near the sparsely populated island of Barbuda late Thursday or early Friday, the center reported. Tropical storms are upgraded to hurricanes when their maximum sustained winds reach 74 mph. The hurricane center said rainfall of 10 to 15 inches was possible for the islands of the northeastern Caribbean. That could trigger flash flooding and mudslides. Stan Cieniewicz, administrative officer for the Pan-Caribbean Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Project in Antigua, said commercial airlines were flying to the region as scheduled. He said authorities in Guadeloupe warned residents to move cattle to protected areas, to avoid long road trips and to keep away from rivers that could overflow in heavy rains. At 6 p.m. EDT, Klaus was centered near latitude 17.0 north and longitude 61.0 west, or about 55 miles east of Antigua. It was moving northwest at 6 mph, with tropical storm-force winds extending 115 miles from its center. Earlier, Klaus dumped torrential rain on Martinique, a French overseas department of 336,000 inhabitants, where six people were reported drowned in floodwaters that reached nearly 10 feet in places. Hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes as rain continued for a second day Thursday. Among the dead were two sisters, aged 8 and 14, who were swept from a bridge Wednesday in St. Joseph, authorities said. Rescuers found their bodies Thursday. Four men were drowned in different parts of the island. They included a 56-year-old farmer who fell from his tractor into a flooded ditch. Two fishermen - a father and son - were reported missing Thursday in Riviere Pilote. Officials told Radio Caribbean International that the local outdoor market and soccer stadium were under 5{ feet of water. Jocelyne Van Elverdinghe, an aide to Prefect Jean-Claude Roure, the French government's representative on the island, said flooding forced 750 people from their homes in Lamentin. Schools were closed throughout the island. Flooding disrupted telephone and electrical service. In Barbados, southeast of Martinique, floodwaters forced the evacuation of a few families overnight and temporarily blocked some roads, although the major tourist hotels on the western coast were unaffected. Lightning knocked out electricity across the island Wednesday night. High wind downed utility poles and trees in Dominica to the north. Islands covered by hurricane warnings included St. Martin-St. Maarten, St. Barthelemy, Saba, St. Eustatius, Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, the British Virgin Islands, Montserrat and St. Kitts-Nevis. Many of the same islands were battered by Hurricane Hugo, which devastated the region in September 1989 before hitting the Carolina coast. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Josephine, with winds near 70 mph, was reported at 6 p.m. to be drifting north at 8 mph in the mid-Atlantic about 1,050 miles southwest of the Azores. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Washington
Robertson Continues Campaign Against NEA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Frohnmayer quotes; picks up 5th graf, `In Washington ...' Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mapplethorpe Trial, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts said Thursday that evangelist Pat Robertson should apologize for lying about whether federal money was used to produce an Atlanta puppet show he said featured simulated oral sex. NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer said the charge was false. At a news conference in Atlanta, where he flew to talk to local arts leaders about the controversy, Frohnmayer said Robertson has subjected Americans to ``an irrational, sometimes irresponsible debate about public support for the arts in this country.'' Earlier in the day, Robertson charged on his ``700 Club'' television show that if members of Congress vote to give the federal arts agency more money next year, ``it shows they are totally out of touch with America and with morality.'' A report on Robertson's show said Atlanta puppeteer Jon Ludwig ``had use of a large bloc of NEA money'' when he presented the controversial puppet show Sept. 21 at the Arts Festival of Atlanta. Frohnmayer urged Robertson ``to apologize to Congress, to apologize to the people of Atlanta, and to apologize to those who look to him for truth.'' He said he hopes the issue can be put to rest and a healing process can begin. ``I believe the time has come for fairness. I believe the time has come for honesty,'' said Frohnmayer. In Washington, the NEA released a copy of a Sept. 28 letter in which Frohnmayer told Robertson that the evangelist's claim of endowment support for the festival to present the puppet show was ``categorically false.'' In that letter, and in an NEA letter circulated in Congress, Frohnmayer denied that any federal funds went either to the arts festival or the puppet show. His assertion was supported last week by festival officials and the executive director of the Georgia Council on the Arts, a state agency that receives NEA funds. Festival officials said the puppet show was financed entirely by ticket sales and concession receipts and did not receive any government money. Robertson earlier said the puppet show included simulated foreplay followed by an exhibit of oral sex acts before an audience of 800, including children. Ludwig said the scene was a satirical treatment of sexual temptation, as part of an adult morality play, but that it did not include oral sex. The Rev. John Norton of Marietta, Ga., who originally complained about the pupet show, later backed down. The Methodist clergyman said he objected not to the performance but to allowing unaccompanied children to view adult material. Festival officials promised they would solve that problem. In an indirect reference to Robertson, Norton said: ``We do not feel it is appropriate for us to be placed in the position of being connected with the greater issues others have attempted to draw us into.'' The Christian Coalition, a non-profit organization headed by Robertson, said the NEA gave $132,500 last year to the Center for Puppetry Arts in Atlanta, where Ludwig is artistic director. That was confirmed by the NEA, but the agency denied that any of the money was spent on the puppet show. Vincent Anthony, the center's director, said the festival signed an independent contract with Ludwig to produce the show. Robertson told his TV viewers that there is ``this incredible shell game that goes on in Washington with the NEA'' and its grant money. At a time when Congress is considering raising taxes to reduce federal budget deficits, Robertson said, ``there shouldn't be one dollar of it spent on oral sex at puppet shows, or Jesus Christ immersed in urine, or the Mapplethorpe exhibit of homoerotic art.'' The evangelist, who ran for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination, was referring to controversial NEA grants for exhibitions of works by artist Andres Serrano and photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, which conservatives have denounced as obscene and blasphemous. In his letter to ``a Christian whose religion values truth,'' Frohnmayer told Robertson that Robertson ``clearly made a mistake'' about NEA support for the puppet show and should correct his error. Robertson said Thursday he had not actually seen the puppet show but relied on newspaper accounts. In an Oct. 1 reply to Frohnmayer, the evangelist said the puppet show was ``another example of what can happen when federal money is given without supervision and oversight.''

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister of Trinidad Blames U.S. on Arms Purchase Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister of Trinidad and Tobago said Thursday that U.S. authorities failed to tell his government of arms purchases in Miami by Moslem coup-plotters. ``If we had the information possessed by U.S. authorities in Miami, this coup would have been avoided,'' Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson told a news conference. Later, a U.S. State Department official, requesting anonymity, said, ``We did not withhold information which would have enabled Prime Minister Robinson to prevent the coup d'etat.'' On July 27, Moslem militants stormed Parliament and the government-run TV station and took the prime minister and more than 50 others hostage. The ensuing six-day siege and accompanying looting left 24 people dead and 500 wounded. Trinidad is a Caribbean island nation of 1.2 million people off northeast Venezuela. The fighting caused an estimated $60 million damage to the main shopping district in Port-of-Spain. In answer to a question, Robinson said his government has evidence the rebels had ties to Libya. ``In fact, the leader of the terrorist organization has confessed openly about his visits and relations with Libya.'' He declined to say, however, whether the coup was backed by Libya, saying the case was in the courts. Rebel leader Yasin Abu Bakr, a former policeman who converted to Islam, and 113 followers were jailed to face charges of treason and murder after the coup was suppressed. Saying it fearing that Bakr's supporters might be plotting another attack, the government extended a state of emergency until mid-November. The proclamation gives security forces unrestricted rights of search and arrest. Robinson, who was shot in the leg by the rebels, said in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly that the coup was launched by ``a new breed of fanatics claiming divine inspiration, but acting rather under satanic impulse.'' Robinson walked with a cane as he went to the podium at U.N. headquarters. After his speech, Robinson told reporters that he would raise the issue of exchanging information about security when he meets President Bush on Monday in Washington. ``We must find out why there was not a proper transfer of information,'' he said. ``We want to ensure that in the future, more effective arrangements are made about information exchange.'' He said it was common knowledge that some of those later involved in the coup were buying weapons in Miami with large amounts of U.S. currency and shipping the arms to the island nation, a former British colony. U.S. authorities in Miami knew about the arms purchases, he said. ``Oh, yes,'' he said, ``there was much more information that U.S. authorities had'' which was not passed along to his government. Federal agents from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms arrested an Moslem, Louis Haneef of Pompano Beach, Fla., on charges of supplying assault rifles, ammunition and other equipment to the coup leaders. But Jack Killorin, a spokesman for the bureau in Washington, said its agents were not aware of any contact between the man buying the guns and Trinidad until after the coup attempt. ``Had it been known that the firearms were going to go to Trinidad, the Trinidad authorities would have been notified,'' Killorin said. ``It simply was not known until Trinidad authorities captured the arms and we matched them to the arms shipment in Miami.'' ``We couldn't agree more with the prime minister that governments should set up avenues of communication to crack down on this gun running,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Rests, Closing Arguments Expected Friday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with closing arguments expected Friday sted jury getting case Friday morning, picking up 6th graf, `If we ...; INSERTS 10 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `Ms. Reisman listed ..., to UPDATE with her testimony, courthouse demonstration; pick up 12th graf, `The exhibit ...
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto CS1
DOC.TEXT: The defense rested its case Thursday at the obscenity trial involving Robert Mapplethorpe's photos, and closing arguments in the case were expected Friday. Most of the day was taken up with legal arguments over the qualifications of a rebuttal witness for the prosecution, prompting an expression of frustration by defendant Dennis Barrie. ``I just wish something would happen,'' said Barrie, who could go to jail if the jury finds him guilty of the misdemeanor charges of pandering obscenity and using children in nudity-related material. Barrie, 43, is director of the Contemporary Arts Center. A Hamilton County grand jury indicted Barrie and the art gallery April 7 because of seven photographs in a 175-picture exhibit that day. Five of the photos depict sexually explicit acts involving men, and two show children with their genitals exposed. If convicted of both charges, Barrie could be sentenced to one year in jail and fined $2,000. The gallery could be fined $10,000. Although the jury could get the case as early as Friday, Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese told the eight-member panel he felt no pressure to speed things along. ``If we have to recess over the three-day weekend, we will,'' Albanese said. The court won't be in session Monday because of Columbus Day. The defense contended the exhibit was legitimate art by a nationally known photographer and that the display was part of the art gallery's cultural mission. In testimony Wednesday, Barrie said some of the acts depicted in the show were ``tough, brutal, sometimes disgusting,'' but part of the photographic challenge Mapplethorpe accepted in trying to create a work of art. ``As difficult as the subject matter may be, you see the ability of the man working through. He was brilliant with a camera,'' Barrie said. Defense lawyers Thursday challenged the credentials of proposed prosecution rebuttal witness Judith Reisman of Arlington, Va. They said she was not qualified to offer expert testimony regarding the seven photographs. Ms. Reisman listed among her qualifications having prepared educational videotapes and slide presentations for the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. She said she also has been a consultant for television's ``Captain Kangaroo'' show, former Attorney General Edwin Meese's commission on pornography and for the conservative American Family Association. Albanese allowed the testimony. Ms. Reisman, who practices what she called content analysis of images, was asked to testify about the five photographs on which the obscenity charges are based. ``Do you see in them any expression of human feeling?'' Assistant City Prosecutor Frank Prouty asked. ``No, I do not,'' Ms. Reisman said. ``There is no expression of joy, anger, fear, shame, happiness, sadness, intent or distress.'' By displaying sexually explicit photos that lack human emotion, ``one receives the information that that is an appropriate activity,'' Ms. Reisman said. She said that displaying nude photos of children ``is a standard technique for getting children into a child abuse situation.'' Art experts testifying for the defense have described the exhibit as a retrospective of the career of Mapplethorpe, who died of AIDS in March 1989 at age 42. As the trial recessed for the day, Albanese cautioned jurors to ignore about 40 demonstrators in front of the Hamilton County Courthouse. Most of the protesters were dressed in black, some wearing death masks as they staged a ``funeral'' for the Bill of Rights. It was the first such demonstration at the trial since jury selection began Sept. 24, when about 150 gay rights and anti-censorship demonstrators marched outside the courthouse. The exhibit drew 80,000 people during its seven week run, an attendance record for an art exhibit in Cincinnati. The show closes this week in Boston, where 103,000 tickets have been sold. The exhibit was canceled at a Washington museum because of controversy over the photographs.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ambassador Ill with Nose Bleed, Speech Postponed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with speech scheduled for Friday, ambassador to rest at home, ADDS date of speech. Picks up 5th pvs, `Bush, in...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's U.N. ambassador suffered a serious enough nose bleed Thursday to force the postponement of the Iraqi representative's speech to the General Assembly. The address was expected to be Iraq's response to President Bush's hint that Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait could pave the way for Mideast peace talks. Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari was seen bleeding profusely from his nose in the United Nations headquarters and was taken to the U.N.'s medical office Thursday afternoon for treatment. Cause of the nose bleed was not immediately known. U.N. officials said al-Anbari would be the last speaker Friday. The ambassador headed home to rest late Thursday, Iraqi officials said. In his speech Monday, Bush said that after Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, there might be ``opportunities for Iraq and Kuwait to settle their differences permanently; for the states of the gulf themselves to build new arrangements for stability; and for all the states and peoples of the region to settle the conflict that divides the Arabs from Israel.'' Bush, in the speech and in a later news conference, did not elaborate on what settlements could be possible. The United States has long been committed to a Mideast settlement in which Israel would exchange territory for Arab recognition of its right to exist. Bush's remarks echoed French President Francois Mitterrand's speech to open the 45th General Assembly on Sept. 24. ``If Iraq were to withdraw its troops and free hostages, everything may be possible,'' said Mitterrand. In other diplomatic moves in the Middle East, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu met in Amman, Jordan with Iraq's deputy prime minister, and later with King Hussein, and Mitterrand discussed the gulf crisis in Jiddah with Saudi Arabia's King Fahd.

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Crowded House Kills Five; 7-Year-Old Blamed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with police saying child responsible, not arsonist, picking up 4th graf, `The victims ...; SUBS grafs 10-12, gng, `Patricia Ann ..., with 1 graf to DELETE outdated material; pick up 13th graf, `Leo Balderas ...
DOC.TEXT: A fire started by a 7-year-old boy swept through an overcrowded inner city home Thursday, killing two women and three children. Nineteen people survived the blaze. Police said at first they suspected arson. But ``an investigation during the course of the day determined the fire was started by a 7-year-old at the house,'' Capt. Joseph Purpero said. The boy apparently was playing with flammable materials when fire broke out in the three-story dwelling, Purpero said. A man held for questioning was released. Police didn't say whether the 7-year-old would be turned over to juvenile authorities. The victims included a 22-year-old mother and her three children, ages 9 months, 3 years and 6 years. An 18-year-old woman also died. Fire Chief August Erdmann said a man and three children on the first floor and 15 people on the upper floors of the home escaped, some by jumping from windows. Twenty-four people were living in the house, officials said. Rescue workers took five people to Sinai Samaritan Medical Center, including a 25-year-old woman who fractured her pelvis and a 32-year-old woman who injured her spine, spokeswoman Susan Lebergen said. Both women were injured after jumping from the house, she said. The fire broke out about 5 a.m. and spread quickly through the wood-frame house, trapping the five victims on the first floor, Erdmann said. Deangelo Barron, a friend of a first floor resident, said he spotted the fire and then saw a man running from the building. Jon Moore, who lives nearby, said his children overheard one of the boys who escaped from the house tell police a man set the fire. ``I was told he saw the guy who started the fire. He (the man) woke the little boy up and told him to get his mother out,'' Moore said. Patricia Ann White, a neighbor, said five families were living in the 80-year-old house. ``That's too crowded,'' she added. ``There were too many people. It's a wonder everybody didn't burn.'' Leo Balderas, 40, the owner of the house, said he rented the building to eight people this summer and was unaware 24 people were living there. He said smoke detectors were operating in the house. ``I've seen extra people staying in houses before,'' he said. ``When I confront the tenants, they say they're visiting or only staying a couple of days. I don't know how you can watch that.'' Balderas, who owns 30 houses in the area, blamed the crowding on a housing shortage.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Migrants Bolster Israeli Conscription, Military Reserve
DOC.TEXT: The influx of Soviet Jews into Israel will significantly add to the Jewish state's military potential, the International Institute for Strategic Studies said Thursday. ``While this (Soviet immigration) will not in the long term redress the demographic imbalance between Jews and Arabs (both in Israel and the West Bank and Gaza Strip), it will add significant numbers to the pool available for conscription and reserve,'' the institute said. The institute noted in its annual survey of global forces, The Military Balance, that the Soviet Jewish immigration is the ``focus of much attention'' among Israel's Arab neighbors. It said a total of 100,000 Soviet Jews were expected to arrive in 1990 ``with perhaps as many as 1 million coming over the next 10 years.'' The report said Israel's defense forces have accepted they cannot quell the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which began in December 1987. It said military service there continues to erode training standards among Israeli troops and undermine moral. Elsewhere, the institute said in its section on the Middle East that both Iran and Iraq continued to rebuild their forces following the end of the eight-year gulf war in 1988. The report, written before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said Iraq's new acquisitions included 12 Soviet-made MiG-29 fighter planes this year. ``(Iraq's) ballistic missile development has been relatively successful with the 900 km(560 mile)-range Al-Abbas (missile) and the 600 km(370 mile) Al-Husayn having been deployed and five other types under development,'' the report said. ``Iraq has deployed at least six Al-Husayn launchers to an airfield close to an area commonly known as H-2 ... in the western Iraqi desert from where targets throughout Syria and most of Israel can be engaged.'' It said the Egyptian Army has received 700 U.S. M-60A1 tanks from surplus stocks in Europe. It said Saudi Arabia took delivery of a squadron of American UH-60 transport helicopters, 24 Tornado fighter planes and six British mine hunters.

DOC.HEAD: Skirmishes With Rebel General in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi consulted with other leaders Thursday about asking for Syria's help to launch an assault on rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's stronghold in east Beirut. Police said Aoun's troops and militia under rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea traded mortar and gunfire during the morning across their front lines in Beirut's Christian sector. No casualties were reported. Geagea backs Hrawi's government. Hrawi held six hours of talks with senior members of his Cabinet, the Parliament and top army officers at his west Beirut residence Thursday, according to sources close to the president. The talks focused on a letter Hrawi drafted to Syrian President Hafez Assad, seeking logistical support to help crush Aoun, said the sources, who spoke on condition they not be named. Parliament speaker Hussein Husseini and the Cabinet have approved the draft, the sources said, but it will have to be endorsed by Prime Minister Salim Hoss before it is sent to Assad. Assad, who met with Hrawi in Damascus last week, has offered any assistance necessary to end Aoun's mutiny. The Syrian army's deputy chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Ali Aslan, visited Moslem west Beirut on Tuesday and met with Hrawi's senior military aides, including Gen. Emile Lahoud, the army commander. Aoun, who refused to recognize Hrawi's election as president Nov. 24, is holding out with 15,000 mainly Christian troops in parts of east Beirut and the adjoining Metn Mountains. Hrawi sacked Aoun as army commander last November. Aoun rebelled and claims he is the only legitimate authority in Lebanon. He has rejected an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war between Christians and Moslems because it does not guarantee the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops, in Lebanon since 1976. Hrawi, a Maronite Catholic who enjoys the support of most Moslem factions, has ordered the 20,000 troops under his command to tighten a blockade on Aoun's enclave Sept. 30. Food and other essentials have been cut off to about 150,000 Christians living there. Aoun has been in revolt since March 1989, when as army commander he began a campaign to smash Moslem militias. Dismissed as commander, he seized control of part of the Christian enclave of east Beirut and north of the capital. Geagea's 6,000-strong militia has gained control of about 80 percent of the 310 square miles in the Christian area.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Will Try To Force Vote on Cuts in Social Security Tax
With AM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., said Thursday he will offer his proposal to cut Social Security tax rates as an amendment to a stopgap budget bill when it goes before the Senate. ``This measure is not a deal-buster,'' Moynihan said in a letter to his Senate colleagues. `It is transparently just; overwhelmingly popular; economically sound; and as a matter of public trust, an elemental duty.'' Moynihan has attracted much attention this year with his plan to cut Social Security tax rates, but the idea has never come to a vote. The Senate was slated to consider a combined stopgap budget and an extension of the debt ceiling Friday. The House passed both measures Sunday, and if the Senate can't finish work on the bills by midnight Friday, the federal government will run out of money. If Moynihan's gambit succeeds, the House and Senate would have to appoint a conference committee to come up with a reconcilation of differences. Moynihan's press secretary, Brian Connolly, dismissed concerns that such an outcome would gum up the works. ``They've done it before,'' he said. The Social Security payroll tax is currently producing more revenue for the federal government than the government is paying out in benefits - an estimated $74 billion more in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Last December, Moynihan introduced a bill to cut the Social Security tax rate for two years, reducing collections this year by about $60 billion, and to take Social Security off-budget - that is, not use its surplus to make the overall federal deficit smaller than it would otherwise appear. In July, he modified the plan to spread the cuts over five years, reducing the rate more gradually in an attempt to appeal to convert Congress to his cause. This latest version would spread the cuts over six years and provide for a trust fund reserve equal to a year-and-a-half's worth of benefits by 1995. Under this plan, the Social Security tax rate would be reduced from the current 6.2 percent to 5.1 percent by 1996.

DOC.HEAD: Physician Jailed for Refusing To Turn Over Personal Notes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with doctor released, attempts to get comment from him and judge, CORRECTS in last graf that Patterson sted Rice treated Bruce.
DOC.TEXT: A doctor was jailed overnight for contempt after he refused to give his personal notes to the defense in an injury trial, but he was released Thursday afternoon. Rice County District Judge Herb Rohleder cited Dr. Michael Patterson after he refused to turn over notes on a man suing a woman for injuries in an auto accident. Attempts to reach Rohleder and Patterson by telephone at their homes Thursday evening were unsuccessful, and the Rice County jail would not release any information about why Patterson was released. Patterson, director of the rehabilitation section of a Hutchinson hospital, said he withheld the notes because they would violate the privacy of his patients. The patients he treats have been severely handicapped by strokes or have suffered traumatic head injuries and have diminished control of themselves, Patterson said. ``If releasing this information is a condition for my release, something else will have to be decided,'' Patterson said prior to gaining his freedom. ``I'm not leading any kind of crusade. This is an individual thing.'' Patterson treated Curtis Bruce of Lyons after Bruce was injured in an auto accident in 1988. Bruce is suing the driver of the other car.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Says Philippines Could Become `Economic Backwater'
With AM-Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The overthrow of President Corazon Aquino could prompt the world to ``turn its back on the Philippines in disgust,'' the chairman of the Senate's Asian affairs subcommittee said Thursday. And the result could be that in 20 years the country will turn into ``an economic backwater, similar to Burma today,'' Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., added in a floor speech.
