Cranston urged senators to support the Bush administration next week in providing the current $200 million U.S. installment of the five-year Multilateral Assistance Initiative pledged with Japan and other countries to speed economic recovery in the Philippines. He voiced concern that Wednesday's attacks by military rebels against government positions in Mindanao island represent the start of ``the long-threatened next coup attempt'' against the Aquino government, target of six attempted coups in four years. ``Now is the time for the United States to demonstrate anew its support for Philippine democracy,'' Cranston said. ``At this very moment when democracy is once again being challenged by totalitarian elements, we must not be pusillanimous.'' U.S. law requiring an end of American aid to any country whose democratically elected government is overthrown.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Pays Surprise Visit to Natal Townships
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk was cheered Thursday when he made an unannounced visit to black townships in Natal Province that have been wracked for years by factional fighting. He praised local leaders of the warring factions for negotiating a Shongweni township truce that halted the fighting, which has claimed 5,000 lives in Natal in five years. Such a trip would have been unthinkable a year ago, before de Klerk pushed for an end to apartheid and freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela from prison. The white-led government and the ANC have held peace talks since May on eliminating apartheid. The black faction fighting spread to Johannesburg area townships in August, killing about 800 people. It has eased the past two weeks, but strained relations between the government and the ANC. Most of the fighting has pitted Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. It was the second time in a month de Klerk has ventured into black townships, an extremely rare act by a South African leader. He also drew a warm reception on his visit last month to the Soweto township southwest of Johannesburg. Residents of Shongweni and the Imbali township cheered and sang Thursday when de Klerk appeared, accompanied by his wife and other government leaders. Tight security was evident, with yellow police helicopters circling the presidential party's helicopter. De Klerk presented bibles to Victor Kabisi of Inkatha and Tulani Zulu of the United Democratic Front, an ANC affiliate, and praised them for the peace agreement in Shongweni. ``I hope other leaders throughout the country will follow your example,'' de Klerk said. The entourage also visited the King Edward Hospital in Durban, where patients lying on mattresses on the floor cheered de Klerk. He announced the government had allocated an additional $20 million for health services in Natal and the KwaZulu tribal homeland. He later expressed disappointment that Mandela and Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi were not meeting to discuss the violence. ``The time has arrived for us to put down our instruments of conflict and to turn our back on conflict and violence, and to speak our minds in a peaceful manner,'' de Klerk said. Mandela and Buthelezi, who also is KwaZulu leader, had been invited to take part in an ANC-called meeting with homeland leaders Friday to discuss the violence. But Buthelezi rejected the invitation, saying he should meet with Mandela as the Inkatha leader because the fighting involves Inkatha and ANC supporters. He said Thursday he doubted a meeting with Mandela would happen in the near future. Mandela is scheduled to leave the country Sunday for a trip abroad of almost four weeks. The ANC has refused to meet with Buthelezi in a one-on-one format. It charges Inkatha spread the violence from Natal to the Johannesburg townships to broaden its constituency. Inkatha accuses the ANC of trying to monopolize power among black opposition groups as the country moves toward negotiations on a new constitution. The ANC and Inkatha both oppose apartheid but differ on a future South Africa. Inkatha wants a free market economy and appeals to Zulu nationalism, while the ANC is more leftist and pan-tribal.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand Meets Wih Saudi King
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand spoke with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia on Thursday amid Iraqi overtures apparently aimed at driving a wedge between Paris and other nations confronting Iraq in the Persian Gulf. Earlier this week, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein praised Mitterrand's ideas on the Middle East and suggested France as a possible negotiator in the gulf crisis. He also freed nine French captives, who arrived Thursday in Paris. But French officials have declared Paris remains committed to the international campaign to force Iraq to leave Kuwait, the oil-rich emirate it overran and annexed in early August. The two leaders met for two hours before Mitterrand left to inspect France's 4,000-man rapid action force at Yanbu, further north on the Red Sea coast. He planned to return to Paris Thursday night. There was no immediate statement on the talks. But members of his entourage quoted Mitterrand as affirming that France was ready to respond to any call by Saudi Arabia or other countries feeling menaced in the region. They said the two leaders backed an enforcement of the U.N. Security Council's trade embargo against Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: John Groff, Oldest Marine General, Dead At 100
LaserPhoto GO3
DOC.TEXT: Retired Brig. Gen. John Groff, a World War I hero and the Marine's oldest surviving general, has died of a heart attack at age 100. Groff died Tuesday at Oceanside's Tri-City Hospital, Kathie Graler, the service's historian at Camp Pendelton Marine Corps base, said Thursday. ``He was the grand old man of the Marine Corps,'' said a family friend, Lance ``Dutch'' Parker, a retired Marine chief warrant officer whose late father, David ``Whitey'' Parker, served with Groff. Graler said Groff had been the oldest surviving Marine general and the last member of the World War I Lodge in Oceanside, about 45 miles north of San Diego. Born in Syracuse, N.Y., in 1890, Grof enlisted in the Marines in 1912. He was a gunnery sergeant and patrol leader when his unit fought in France in the Battle of Belleau Wood, one of the bloodiest and most storied battles in the Corps' history. Groff was wounded in the battle, which stopped a German push toward Paris. He was awarded the Navy Cross, the Distinguished Service and the Purple Heart and promoted to second lieutenant. ``We didn't realize we were going to get shot like that,'' Groff said in a newspaper interview earlier this year. ``We lined up and went into the woods, and then all hell broke loose.'' Promoted to major in 1938, Groff became commanding officer of the Marine Corps Recruit Depot in San Diego, a post he held for six years, helping train Marines who would fight in World War II. Groff participated in the 1942 dedication ceremonies opening Camp Pendleton and in recent years was frequently guest of honor at Marine Corps ceremonies. Groff retired in 1946 and was promoted from colonel to brigadier general for his distinguished service, Graler said. He worked for Hughes Aircraft Co. and Douglas Aircraft Co. during the late '40s and early '50s. He moved to Oceanside in 1969. Groff is survived by daughters Mildred Ann Hanson of Bothell, Wash.; Pauline Ethel Ralston of Victorville, and son John Louis Groff of Poway.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Delays No Longer Major Problem
LaserPhoto CX5
DOC.TEXT: Officials said Thursday they were close to eliminating a bus driver shortage that caused thousands of pupils in the nation's third-largest school system to miss some classes. ``Early in the year bus delays affected about 4,000 students in 15 to 20 of the more than 350 schools served,'' said Robert L. Johnson, director of student transportation for Chicago Public Schools. ``As of (Thursday) morning, the number of children that are still affected would be less than 150.'' Some children missed entire school days because their buses never picked them up. But Johnson said no one apparently missed school Thursday because of bus problems. Johnson said a new, tougher federal commercial drivers' licensing law caused ``tremendous difficulty'' for bus companies. ``But they knew what our needs were going to be,'' he said. ``There's no doubt that when contract renewal comes up, those companies that have not performed satisfactorily will feel the effects,'' Johnson said. Mark Schmidt of the secretary of state's office said the bus companies were able to recruit enough potential drivers but more than usual failed the tests because of the tougher law. Drivers were so sparse early this year that more buses than usual had to make double runs, causing some students to miss their first hour of school - and important classes often taught in the morning, like reading. Some children also had to wait longer than usual for afternoon buses. The delays were particularly hard on disabled pupils who must receive medicine and physical therapy on schedule, said Sue Stoll, assistant principal at Hanson Park School.

DOC.HEAD: Singh Ready to Face Backlash of Job Quota Policy
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh said Thursday he will not rescind a program guaranteeing nearly half of government jobs to low-caste Hindus despite a wave of riots and suicides. ``When we go for reforms, we should be ready to face consequences. I am ready to face it,'' Singh said during a debate in Parliament's lower house, the Lok Sabha. Singh was replying to demands for his resignation by the opposition Congress Party, led by former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. During the 2{-hour debate, Congress Party members accused Singh of driving the country to the brink of ``disintegration.'' ``My resignation has been demanded. May I say, you cannot make me resign from my commitment,'' said Singh, accompanied by the loud thumping of desks by members of his National Front coalition. Singh on Aug. 7 announced the government will reserve 27 percent of federal jobs for the low-caste workers to offset centuries of discrimination. That is added to an existing 22.5 percent quota for the lowest of the Indian social system - the untouchables and the tribespeople. Untouchables are below the four major castes, which determine social position by birth and often sets economic and educational paths. The decision touched off widespread riots across northern India, killing at least 53 people and prompting curfews in more than a dozen areas. At least 26 young people have committed suicide by burning themselves or eating poison. White-collar civil service jobs are coveted by many graduates. The government employs about 18 million people. Many upper-caste students say they will be bypassed for jobs in favor of unqualifid candidates. At present, there are about 17 million educated but unemployed youths in the nation of 800 million people. In the Lok Sabha, Singh said he was deeply anguished by the suicides, and hoped the students will accept his offer for talks. Several student groups have refused to open negotiations until the job policy is withdrawn. India, which is 82 percent Hindu, professes secularism and outlaws discrimination by caste, but the practice persists. Singh has said the government plans to generate 3 million more jobs and is ready to give loans to youths who want to start businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Suspected Palestinian Terrorists Opens in Frankfurt
DOC.TEXT: Two suspected members of a Palestinian terrorist group linked to the Pan Am Flight 103 bombing went on trial Thursday on charges of attacking two U.S. military trains. German officials say they have no evidence linking the two, Hafez Kassem Dalkamoni and Abdel Fattah Ghadanfar, to the Pan Am disaster. But searches of their apartment found explosives similar to that that exploded aboard the plane. Both men were arrested in Germany two months before Flight 103 exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland. The Dec. 21, 1988, explosion killed all 259 people aboard the New York-bound Boeing 747 and 11 people on the ground. In Dumfries, Scotland, a Lockerbie constable testifying Thursday in a public inquiry on the tragedy recalled seeing an orange fireball drop from the night sky. ``The debris ran like a carpet across the countryside, a trail of devastation and bodies,'' said Constable Michael Stryjewski. Dalkamoni, 45, and Ghadanfar, 49, are believed to be members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, a radical group that is believed linked to the Pan Am bombing. Ghadanfar, a Jordanian, and Dalkamoni, a Palestinian, were arrested in a Franfkurt apartment in October 1988. Investigators found anti-tank grenades, Kalashnikov rifles, hand grenades and more than two pounds of plastic explosives in their search of the apartment. They also found a portable radiocassette recorder containing plastic explosives, of the type that apparently blew up Flight 103. A policeman was killed attempting to defuse a radio containing another bomb at the apartment. Dalkamoni and Ghadanfar are charged with forming a terrorist organization and attempted murder for the two bomb attacks aimed at U.S. military trains in August 1987 and April 1988. A woman was slightly injured in the first attack. The defense attorneys Thursday demanded the replacement of two suspects' court-appointed Arabic translator, who they claimed was working for German investigators. A ruling on a new translator was expected by Oct. 15, when the trial resumes. If found guilty, Dalkamoni and Ghadanfar could receive up to life imprisonment.

DOC.HEAD: `Stand-Up Tragedy,' A Play by Bill Cain, Opens on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Stand-Up Tragedy'' is music video theater, a contemporary kaleidoscope of story, song and dance about the futility of teaching in an inner-city high school. If that sounds depressing, well, it is and it isn't. The play, which opened Thursday at Broadway's Criterion Center Theater, is fast, furious, often funny and startlingly different. Call it a raw, raucous updated ``Blackboard Jungle'' with a rap beat, but with no easy answers and a pessimistic ending. The story comes from author Bill Cain's real-life experiences teaching in a Catholic school on Manhattan's Lower East Side. Tom Griffin, played by Jack Coleman, is an idealistic new teacher from a wealthy WASP family. He's trying to save a little bit of the world and until now, his only problem has been deciding on whether or not to go to law school. Instead, he finds himself battling to teach young Hispanics, particularly a withdrawn student named Lee (Marcus Chong) who has a problem home life. Lee, an accomplished artist, also has an overactive imagination. The youth has created a fantasy world of comic-strip superheroes, an exotic environment where he can block out his junkie of an older brother and his alcoholic mother. Tom tries to get through to Lee but the more he tries to help, the more it hurts Lee. ``Your family's your fate,'' says the fatalistic student. And playwright Cain pooh-poohs the quick-fix solution of education lifting these teen-agers out of a life of poverty and crime. His spokesman is a craggy, nearly disillusioned cleric, Father Ed Larkin, played with a fine sandpaper edge by Charles Cioffi. Larkin explains that ``an ecology of evil'' permeates the neighborhood and once you upset the balance, who knows what will happen. This environment is portrayed at warp speed by director Ron Link who never lets ``Stand-Up Tragedy'' stop. One scene blends quickly into the next, the dialogue and music often machine-gunning the actors all over the stage. And some of the performers play more than one role, often at the same time. The baby-faced Chong does triple duty. In an unnerving series of transformations, he changes from the bewildered Lee to his defiant brother to the boy's haughty mother. It's an amazing performance. Coleman exudes the right amount of white-bread benevolence as the do-good teacher, and there are distinctive portraits drawn by John C. Cooke and Dan Gerrity as his cynical cohorts in the teaching profession. Four other students rap and jive their way through the production, under the rapid-fire choreography of Charles Randolph-Wright. They are all over designer Yael Pardess' grim, graffiti-scarred set with four high school lockers placed at stage center. ``Stand-Up Tragedy'' is unlikely Broadway fare. It's unconventional and almost aggressive in its determination to turn the norms of straightforward plot and character upside-down and inside-out. But stay with it. It's a wild and most satisfying ride.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Council Signs Observer Agreement With OAS
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The Electoral Council signed an agreement Thursday for the Organization of American States to provide observers for Haiti's elections on Dec. 16. About 25 observers will arrive for the three-week registration period, which starts Friday. The observers will return for the elections to choose a new president, legislature and mayors. The president-elect was to be sworn in Feb. 7, 1991, on the fifth anniversary of the overthrow of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier. Since then, the country has suffered a series of military coups, violence and economic crisis. In 1987, the last attempt at free elections collapsed when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. The agreement was signed at Electoral Council headquarters by council president Jean-Robert Sabalat and OAS representative Pierre Cote. More observers will be sent by Caricom and by former President Carter. A Haitian request for United Nations observers is under review. ``We want to have as many witnesses as possible,'' council member Emmanuel Ambroise said. ``Certain forces which want to hold the country hostage'' are opposed to the observer, he said. In recent months, figures linked to the security apparatus of Duvalier's government have returned to the country and are alleged to have carried out several murders.

DOC.HEAD: Senator: State Department Withdraws Envoy Nominee
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``Another official,'' with source confirming that Vreeland indeed dropped
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is withdrawing the nomination of Frederick Vreeland to be ambassador to Burma, a Republican senator who raised questions about the nomination said Thursday. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato of New York said State Department officials told him that Vreeland's name had been withdrawn because of objections from Burma about pro-democracy statements Vreeland made. But D'Amato said the real reason was evidence linking Vreeland to efforts to cover up Bulgarian and Soviet involvment in the 1981 assassination attempt against Pope John Paul II. ``If you believe the State Department reason, you believe the moon is made of green cheese,'' D'Amato said. State Department spokesman David Denny said he could not confirm that Vreeland had been dropped as the ambassadorial nominee for Burma. Another official, however, confirmed that Vreeland had been dropped. This official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Burmese objections to Vreeland's pro-Democracy statements were indeed the real reason, and the attempt to kill the pope had nothing to do with the case. The pro-Democracy statements were described as nothing more than ``oft-stated U.S. policy.'' Denny said Assistant Secretary Richard Solomon met with Burmese Deputy Foreign Minister Ohn Gyaw on Wednesday and had expressed concern about lack of progress toward democracy in the country, ``harrassment of U.S. Embassy employees and continued opium production.'' He declined to say what Gyaw replied, and said he could not say whether there was any discussion of Vreeland. D'Amato said one State Department official told him Vreeland had irked the Burmese with statements concerning the need for a free and independent government in Burma, where a military junta has refused to yield power to a civilian government elected in May. A Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Vreeland's nomination Monday was held behind closed doors. At the request of D'Amato and Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the committee had scheduled a second hearing on the nomination Thursday but later postponed it until next week. D'Amato said he wanted to question Vreeland about reports that he tried to cover up details about the assassination attempt and discourage journalists from writing about the Bulgarian connection. Congressional sources said some senators were concerned over published reports about Vreeland's career as a CIA agent. An official biography supplied to the committee by the administration described Vreeland as a career diplomat with several State Department assignments. Vreeland, 63, is son of the late Vogue magazine editor, Diana Vreeland. D'Amato said that by law he could not discuss whether Vreeland was a CIA agent, but he said the Senate hearing would have questioned him about his activites as a U.S. Embassy officer in Rome at the time the attempted assassination was being investigated. Ali Agca, a Turk who wounded the pope in St. Peter's Square, is serving a life term in Italy. Agca at first said he acted alone but later claimed Soviet involvement. An Italian court ruled there was not enough evidence to convict three Bulgarians charged in the case. D'Amato said he has met with the new president of Bulgaria, Zhelyu Zhelev, and asked him to pursue an inquiry into both the Bulgarian connection to the attempt on the Pope and any U.S. efforts to cover it up. Zhelev, on a U.S. visit last week, said he would press for an independent investigation into charges that Bulgarian police participated in the papal attack. The motive for the coverup, said D'Amato, may have been to prevent an escalation of U.S.-Soviet differences or to prevent facts from coming out that might be embarrassing to U.S. officials.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Join Government, Private Business in Talks
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista labor unions agreed to participate in talks Thursday with the government and business groups seeking a common program to relieve the country of its economic ills. It was a victory for President Violeta Chamorro's 5-month-old government, which had met stiff Sandinista resistance to its economic recovery program. Former President Daniel Ortega has said the Sandinista Front would support any agreement the unions reach with the government. The Sandinista-linked unions have about 200,000 members. After meetings with Ortega this week, Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's senior aide, announced the government would distribute food, create job banks and freeze planned layoffs of government workers. The Sandinistas in turn agreed not to oppose a government review of state property the Sandinistas gave away during the two-month transition period between their Feb. 25 election loss and Mrs. Chamorro's April 25 inauguration. The government also has agreed not to return property previously owned by the family of the late dictator Anastasio Somoza, ousted by the Sandinistas in 1979. The Sandinistas had refused to take part in a first round of talks, which began Sept. 20, but decided to submit to the forum after a series of protest marches failed to muster support. The Superior Council of Private Enterprise, Nicaragua's most important business group, opposed the Sandinista unions' participation. The group blames Nicaragua's economic woes on Sandinista mismanagement and claimed the government has showed weakness in dealing with the ousted leftists. Lacayo, the most powerful member of the government, has taken great pains to obtain the cooperation of the Sandinistas. Further discord can only hurt Nicaragua's chances of getting badly needed foreign aid, he has said. The Sandinistas have opposed to nearly every facet of Mrs. Chamorro's economic plan. That plan aims at reigning inflation, which has been running at about 80 percent monthly, reducing a fiscal deficit and increasing production. The government has tried to slash the public payroll, privatize most of the 400 state enterprises confiscated by the Sandinistas during their decade in power, end state subsidies of public services and devalue the currency to make Nicaraguan exports such as coffee and bananas competitive.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Speed Up Death Row Executions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5th graf: ``Final passage,'' debate dropped without final vote
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Thursday to do away with ``endless, endless, endless delays'' in carrying out death sentences, handing the Bush administration a major victory in debate on a wide-ranging anticrime bill. The 285-146 vote came as angry words and sarcastic cries of `kill, kill, kill'' rang out in protest over repeated victories by supporters of placing harsher death penalty provisions in the bill. ``Would it be possible to bring the guillotine directly to the House floor?'' Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., said with a mordant smile after lawmakers added 12 more offenses to a growing list of federal crimes punishable by death. The House also voted 257-172 to allow domestic manufacture of semi-automatic assault rifles, whose importation has been banned by President Bush, but only if American-made parts are used. The vote threw out of the bill a section banning domestic manufacture of semi-automatic weapons whose importation has been banned by the president. Final passage had been expected Thursday evening, but the House dropped the debate without a final vote in order to take up the budget compromise. The measure calls for the death penalty for assassination of the president and numerous other government officials. Treason and espionage also would be punishable by death. Other features range from a shutoff in federal benefits for convicted drug offenders to a one-year prison term for illegal possession of steroids. In a victory for Bush, the House voted 285-146 to replace major provisions requiring Death Row inmates to file their habeas corpus petitions in federal court no later than a year after exhausting direct appeals. Prisoners use these petitions to claim they were denied their constitutional rights. Some Death Row inmates have filed repeated petitions and thus delayed their executions for more than a decade. Democratic sponsors of the crime bill had incorporated in the bill a plan that, besides setting a time limit for filing petitions, would have guaranteed prisoners competent lawyers in capital punishment cases. It also would have limited the defendants to one habeas corpus petition in normal circumstances. Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., a leading critic, said exceptions to the limit would result in ``endless, endless, endless delays.'' The House adopted instead a Hyde provision leaving the matter up to individual state legislatures to limit the time in which their prisoners could file habeas appeals in federal court. Conservatives who seek to shorten delays in carrying out executions hailed the plan while liberals blasted it. Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., complained that the plan, drafted by a commission headed by former Supreme Court Justice Lewis Powell, actually represented ``a plot ... by the chief justice'' of the Supreme Court. Chief Justice William Rehnquist has been pressing for changes in the habeas corpus law. As it came to the floor, the bill prescribed capital punishment for 10 groups of offenses approved by the Judiciary Committee. The House approved 271-159 an amendment sponsored by Rep. George Gekas, R-Pa., calling for the death penalty for offenses ranging from genocide to murder by mail bombing. It included murder through terrorist bombing of an airplane, train wreck and destruction of a motor vehicle. Gekas told the House that the bill needed stiffening and that his plan was supported by a wide range of Americans ``from the cop on the beat to the man on the street.'' Democratic sponsors of the measure said some of its provisions appeared unconstitutional. ``I hope we never bring up another crime bill a month before an election,'' Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., said. ``Because today we are tearing up a document that has served us well for many years.'' Sarcastic cries of ``kill, kill, kill'' wafted briefly from a knot f lawmakers near a door on the Democratic side of the chamber. The Senate already has approved a different bill that, unlike the House version, would curb nine semiautomatic assault weapons. Differences will have to be resolved by a House-Senate conference committee. As it became clear that the Gekas plan would be approved overwhelmingly, tempers started to fray. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, accused Gekas of not answering his question about how the amendment would work. ``Thank you for not answering my question,'' he said. ``Thank you for not quoting a good question,'' Gekas said. Washington, who had already left the microphone and taken his seat, shouted: ``You wouldn't know a good question if you heard it.'' The substititute provision on semi-automatic weapons was sponsored by Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash. Handgun Control Inc., a Washington-based group that campaigns for firearms restrictions, released a report to the Federal Election Commission from Unsoeld's campaign committee, reflecting a $4,950 contribution from the National Rifle Association shortly after she introduced the amendment. The group issued a statement saying Unsoeld ``sold her political soul to the assault weapon lobby in the hope it will help her get reelected.'' ``Absolute baloney,'' Unsoeld said. She said she had not discussed the amendment with the NRA before introducing it and had not known about the campaign contribution at the time. She said the amendment was needed ``because there are a lot of us who support the Second Amendment (right to bear arms) who would feel compelled to vote against the bill otherwise.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Honors Member of Prewar Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to CORRECT to `without' sted `with' concerning Nazi law. Picks up graf 12 pvs, `Felder attended...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The last time Josef Felder attended a Parliament session at the Reichstag, the future looked ominous as he and other opposition lawmakers battled vainly against growing Nazi powers. On Thursday, however, Felder returned to the building full of hope for the newly united Germany. ``I believe we have a good development in the sense of securing democracy,'' said Felder, 90, the only member of the prewar Parliament to attend the opening session. Felder took a seat next to President Richard von Weizsaecker to observe the first meeting of Parliament in the Reichstag since Dec. 9, 1932, when Felder was a newly elected deputy in a nation in chaos as Nazis consolidated power. In the coming years, Felder would face Nazi harassment, flee underground and, ultimately, be sent to a concentration camp. Adolf Hitler dissolved the legislature after he was named chancellor on Jan. 30, 1933, and called new elections. A fire gutted the Reichstag before the vote was held March 5. Felder, a Social Democrat from Bavaria, was re-elected, but faced increasing threats from the Nazis. The regime had already jailed many opposition communists and socialists, the first targets of Hitler's repression. More than 100 members of the Reichstag were killed or imprisoned. ``The election campaign in February 1933 was exceptionally difficult for the opposition. The Social Democrats were forbidden access to the press by Hitler,'' recalled Felder. After the Nazis marched into Bavaria on March 9, 1933, Felder and other lawmakers changed apartments to avoid arrest, determined to take their seats in parliament. Felder recalled the tumultuous March 23, 1933, session - held in the nearby Kroll Opera - when Hitler forced through a plan allowing his government to make laws without the Reichstag's approval. Some of the Social Democrats were called ``scoundrels'' by crowds. Felder attended a Parliament meeting May 17, 1933, when a resolution calling for equal treatment of Germany at the Geneva disarmament convention was debated. It was his last session. In July, the Nazis banned the Social Democrats and Felder fled to Austria. He continued underground work under an assumed name until 1934, when the Nazi threat forced him to flee for Czechoslovakia. But fearing reprisals against his family, Felder returned to Bavaria and was thrown into the Dachau concentration camp outside Munich for two years. He worked as an accountant following the war and gradually returned to politics. In 1957, he was elected to the West German legislature in Bonn. The Bundestag, the West German parliament, is also the name of the new German legislature. After his third term expired in 1969, Felder devoted himself to political education, traveling thousands of miles each year to talk to school children about his experiences. Parliament President Rita Suessmuth on Thursday warmly welcomed Felder, who said it was a ``great satisifcation'' to attend the historic meeting. Felder warned the new government must not permit the rise of obsessive nationalism, which ``would endanger everything we achieved through negotiations with our allies.''

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says Colleagues Eager for Swearing In, to Avoid Ties
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``The difficulty,'' to insert parenthetical word ``not.'' Though Souter did not state the word, it was clearly implied
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter said Thursday that soon-to-be colleagues on the Supreme Court are eager for him to be sworn in to avoid the possibility of tie votes in controversial cases. Souter, who will take his oath Tuesday as history's 105th Supreme Court justice, said he needs to find a home and would love to play tourist - perhaps ``with a paper bag over my head'' to hide his newly famous face. But he said of the other justices, who have already heard three days of case arguments, ``They very much wanted me to start sitting on Tuesday because there is always the possibility of a 4-4 decision if they're sitting without the full complement.'' ``The difficulty with that is if the case has to be re-argued, everybody knows that the whole re-argument is going to be addressed to the one judge who is sort of there to make the difference.'' Souter said in an interview with The Associated Press. ``They were very solicitous about (not) getting me in that position if we could avoid it.'' The court is expected to be closely divided in the first major case Souter will participate in, a sex-bias dispute over an employer's fetal protection policy barring all women of child-bearing age from some hazardous jobs. The case will be argued Wednesday. Souter said he knows he has a big task ahead. ``So many of the justices have said or written that nothing prepares a person for the responsibilities of that court, and I know that's going to be true in my case. I can feel it already.'' The 51-year-old judge said finding a home in the nation's capital ``is one of the first orders of business.'' He said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., would be showing him some prospects over the weekend. Souter indicated he intends to live in the District of Columbia, not its Maryland or Virginia suburbs. Told that all the current justices are suburbanites, he said, ``I'm going to break new ground for a year anyway.'' When not house hunting, Souter's weekend will be spent reading legal briefs in preparation for his first week on the high court. He said he would have to put off a secret ambition: Playing tourist. ``There are some things I have never done that most school kids have done. I have never, for example, toured the Capitol,'' he said. ``Some day - I may have to do it with a paper bag over my head - I'm going to do some of those touristy things.'' Souter said he once was more familiar with his future home. ``Right after law school, I had various friends down there and there was a woman down there I was interested in, so I made some trips to Washington,'' he said. Acknowledging a recent Washington Post article that named him one of the city's most eligible bachelors, Souter smiled and said, ``I've really got to wait and see what effects it brings. It sounded pretty good to me.'' Asked about his emotions during his three days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee last month, Souter said, ``There wasn't time to be that reflective. I guess I could tell you this much, as we got toward the end of the third day, sure, I was getting tired. I'm glad that the most vigorous questioning of the three days did not come at the tail end.'' Souter said neighbors and lawyer friends from Concord would be on hand for his swearing-in, but that his mother, who will be 83 this week, would not make the trip. ``She gets along fine but she said she does it by not pushing herself too far,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cristiani Returns from U.N. With Peace Proposal; Rebels Denounce It
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran guerrillas Thursday denounced President Alfredo Cristiani's recent cease-fire offer as a tactic taken only to win more military aid for his government. In a speech Monday to the 45th General Assembly of the United Nations, Cristiani proposed a government cease-fire if the FMLN would do the same. ``It is an old offer that seeks to end the war without ending the causes that originated it,'' the rebels said in the broadcast on Radio Venceremos, their clandestine voice. The offer ``isn't really directed at us, who have a promise with the government and the United Nations to negotiate ahead of time the conditions for a cease-fire,'' the rebels said. ``It is aimed at the American Senate, who Cristiani is trying to impress ... to get more military aid for the war.'' Cristiani returned this week to El Salvador after meeting in New York with President Bush, who is seeking $85 million in new military aid to El Salvador. The aid package faces an especially tough battle in Congress, where there is indignation over continuing human rights abuses. Six Jesuit priests who taught at the University of Central America were murdered in November. Little progress has been made in bringing evidence against officers believed to have ordered the killings. Cristiani told a news conference Thursday that he met with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar during his trip and wanted to step up the pace of talks with the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National LIberation Front. ``I consider it necessary to implement some formulas whic will make the process more dynamic,... which will move more quickly than what has happened until now,'' Cristiani said. Government and guerrilla representatives met under U.N. sponsorship five times this year, but failed to reach agreement on terms for ending the decade-old civil war which has claimed at least 73,000 lives, mostly civilians. Cristiani expressed regret at the guerrilla rejection of his proposed cease-fire, saying he had offered it ``thinking that the Salvadoran people should not have to continue suffering violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge's Ruling Allows Church To Evict Theater Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sbeglia is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled Thursday that the Roman Catholic Church may evict a theater company from a former parochial school where it staged a play about a cardinal who kills a pregnant woman while driving drunk. The church had sought the ruling against the RAPP Theater Co., charging that the group violated the lease by performing material ``detrimental to the landlord's reputation as a Roman Catholic Church.'' An attorney for the church, Frank C. McLaughlin, argued before state Supreme Court Justice Irma Vidal Santaella that the lease on the building states clearly that the church is the ``sole and absolute judge'' of what is detrimental to its reputation. Thomas Disch, who wrote the play, ``The Cardinal Detoxes,'' and RAPP's artistic director, R. Jeffrey Cohen, both accused church officials of trying to censor the play because they find it offensive. RAPP attorney Richard Sbeglia argued that it was ``unconscionable'' and a violation of public policy to force a tenant to give up free speech rights to get a lease. But Santaella found that the lease was not unconscionable because there was not a lack of meaningful choices by either of the parties. She also said Cohen had voluntarily relinquished his constitutional rights. ``He read the lease and signed of his own free will.'' ``I'm astonished,'' said Disch after the ruling. Santaella's ruling lifted a temporary restraining order and allowed the church to begin eviction proceedings immediately. However, Cohen and Sbeglia said they would seek another restraining order from the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division. If they fail to get it, Cohen said he has rented a storefront across the street from the former school and will stage the play there. The play is a 35-minute monologue by a cardinal who is being treated for alcoholism by the church after he kills the woman. After the cardinal calls the church a sham and suggests he will expose its problems, a silent monk in the room with him gives him poisoned wine.

DOC.HEAD: Precede TOKYO
Rioting Enters Fourth Day, Stores Burned by Rioters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with more rioting, stores torched. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of rioters in a crime-ridden neighborhood torched stores and threw rocks at police Friday in a protest that began over reports a policeman took a bribe from a gangster. At least 88 people, including 58 police, have been injured since the violence in the Nishinari district began Tuesday, police said. Forty people had been arrested by early Friday, authorities said. The scope of the violence is extremely rare for Japan, where public issues rarely inflame passions to such a degree. The rioting started after news reports a police sergeant had taken $20,000 in payment for leaks of police information. The officer has not admitted guilt, but the Osaka police chief apologized Thursday in an attempt to ease the tension. Early Friday, a convenience store was set ablaze and ransacked and a grocery store also was looted as the violence spread to the northern areas of the Nishihari area. Up to 1,000 demonstrators confronted about 600 riot police Thursday night on streets near the station. High school-age youths lunged out of the crowd to throw rocks and firecrackers at police. ``Come out dirty policemen! We will not stand this any longer!'' Kyodo quoted one of the workers as shouting as he hurled rocks at the police headquarters in this city in western Japan. Some charged police shields with their shoulders and were driven back. ``Most of the people who are throwing rocks at us are ... juvenile delinquents who saw this on television and thought it was a rare chance to take advantage of the police,'' said one officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Police earlier had said the demonstrators were mostly menial and day laborers who live in the shabby hotels of the seedy district. There have been bad feelings between area residents and police, whose anti-crime tactics include a 24-hour surveillance camera system on street corners in Nishinari. Residents also complain of widespread gang activity. Since Tuesday, as many as 1,400 residents of the district have faced off with police about a quarter-mile from the district police station, burning cars and throwing rocks, bicycles and beer bottles, police said. Such street violence is seldom seen in Japan. In recent years, there have been few disturbances other than occasional battles between riot police and leftist extremists who oppose expansion of Narita Airport outside of Tokyo. Osaka police chief Masahiro Tsubakihara issued an apology at the prefectural legislature Thursday in response to reports the officer had taken the bribe, Kyodo News Service reported.

DOC.HEAD: Technicality Shouldn't Keep Measures Off Ballot, Oregon High Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: A technical foulup by state officials shouldn't block Oregon's initiative petition process, the Oregon Supreme Court said Thursday in explaining its decision to return five measures to the Nov. 6 ballot. The court had no desire to ``entirely thwart ... the right of citizens to propose laws and amendments to the constitution and enact or reject them independently'' of the Legislature, Chief Justice Edwin Peterson wrote in the opinion written Sept. 28 and released Thursday. The unanimous ruling overturned a lower court decision that removed five of 11 measures from the ballot. The problems began when a state committee missed a deadline for certifying statements for the ballot that explained what the measures would cost. Marion County judges invalidated those statements because of the missed deadline. Marion County Circuit Judge Richard Barber later invalidated five measures because they wouldn't be accompanied by the cost estimates. The measures targeted by Barber's ruling would limit property taxes, shut down the Trojan nuclear plant, ban some non-recyclable packaging, allow tax credits for private schooling and set up a pilot work program for welfare applicants. The nine-member Supreme Court reversed Barber but upheld the lower court decisions to keep the estimates off the ballot. Despite the failure to meet the deadlines on fiscal impact statements, a statewide vote on the measures ``goes on without the estimates,'' Peterson's opinion said. The ballot measure dispute has become an issue in the governor's race. Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer, the Republican candidate, said Secretary of State Barbara Roberts must accept blame because as the state's top election officer she should have kept closer tabs on the deadlines. Roberts, a Democrat, in turn has accused Frohnmayer of playing politics with the issue. She said Frohnmayer also has missed deadlines as attorney general.

A proposal to give $11.1 billion in newttax breaks to small corporations is being criticized as opening the door for wealthy investors to duck their share of federal taxes. The Bush administration is pushing the new incentives as a substitute for the capital gains tax cut that congressional leaders refused to accept. Some of those leaders are suspicious of the substitute, which actually includes a small capital gains reduction. The proposal is attached to the $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction agreement that President Bush and congressional leaders reached this week. The tax break proposal ``has very serious flaws,'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Wednesday. ``I think it will lead to a substantial increase in tax shelters and great abuse.'' ---= NEW YORK (AP) - The United States and the Soviet Union are in substantial agreement to reduce non-nuclear weapons in Europe and now will try to conclude a second pact slashing their nuclear arsenals. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze announced the resolution of all remaining major issues Wednesday for the most comprehensive arms reduction accord since World War II. The U.S.-led North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact would limit their tanks, anti-aircraft artillery, land-based airplanes, armored combat vehicles and helicopters across Europe - from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural Mountains that separate Soviet European from Asian regions. Baker and Shevardnadze both cautioned that final approval must await consultation with their allies. But if the allies go along, the treaty should be ready for signing at a 34-nation summit in Paris on Nov. 19-21. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The sale of $7.3 billion in new weaponry to Saudi Arabia is just one step in creating a Persian Gulf ``coalition defense'' against the long-term threat posed by Iraq, say two senior Bush administration officials. That sale will be followed by more sales next year to the Saudis, perhaps to their neighbors Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, and new military help for Israel, Undersecretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz and Undersecretary of State Reginald Bartholomew told Congress on Wednesday. In doing so, the United States hopes ``to build a Saudi and a gulf force capability that will, in effect, drive up significantly the costs to anybody looking to take a whack at them,'' Bartholomew said. ``We do not want to leave the road to Bahrain open, as it was on the second of August,'' the day Iraq invaded Kuwait, he told a hearing of two House Foreign Affairs subcommittees. ---= FORT LAUDERDAE, Fla. (AP) - A black record store owner convicted of obscenity for selling a sexually explicit album by the black rap group 2 Live Crew says the all-white jury ``doesn't represent my community.'' ``It's unfair. The jury was all white. They don't know where E-C Records is. They don't know a goddamned thing about the ghetto,'' Charles Freeman yelled to reporters after he was convicted Wednesday. Critics of the rap group hailed the verdict as a milestone in the battle against material they consider obscene. The music industry and civil libertarians decried it as censorship. 2 Live Crew and its album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' have been at the center of a First Amendment dispute since June 6, when a federal judge deemed obscene lyrics that include references to sodomy and sexual intercourse. Some also have objected to the lyrics as violent and degrading to women. ---= WATERVLIET, Mich. (AP) - When Dave Backus graduated from Watervliet High School in 1978, there was never any question what he'd do next. Like many of his classmates, he went to work in the town's 80-year-old paper mill, following his father and grandfather, as well as his mother and aunt and uncles. Now the future is anything but clear. Watervliet Paper Co., the biggest employer in this southwestern Michigan town of 1,867, has been idle since June, when its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection. The mill's employees are among hundreds of thousands of factory workers left jobless in recent months as the nation's unemployment rate worsens. Michigan has the worst unemployment among top industrial states. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Elizabeth Dole's status as the top woman in the Bush administration - and her flair for charming Republican troops - are making the secretary of labor a big draw on the national campaign scene. ``She gets down off of the pedestal and she becomes one of the many,'' said Hillard Selck, a Republican National Committeeman from Missouri. ``There's no `Stay away from me, stay behind the barrier, I'm too good for you.' That impresses people. They like to be able to touch,'' Selck said. Mrs. Dole, 54, is campaigning in more than a dozen states this fall for more than 60 gubernatorial and House and Senate candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Levinson Mines his Baltimore Boyhood for Films
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: You can take the boy out of Baltimore, but Barry Levinson keeps returning to his home town for distinctive movies. Between such commercial ventures as ``Rain Man,'' for which he won an Academy Award, ``Good Morning, Vietnam,'' ``The Natural'' and ``Young Sherlock Holmes,'' he has weaved the story of his life growing up in Baltimore. His debut as a director came in 1982 with ``Diner,'' about neighborhood pals who reunion at their old gathering place. Then came ``The Tin Men,'' with Richard Dreyfuss and Danny DeVito as aluminum siding salesmen at war with each other. Now, ``Avalon.'' The title is the name of the Baltimore rooming house where members of Levinson's family, the Krinchinskys, first settle on their arrival to the United States early in the century. The movie spans 50 years, tracing the changes in the family and the nation. Levinson is portrayed in ``Avalon,'' first as a boy, then as a young man visiting his dying grandfather (played by Armin Mueller-Stahl, the East German actor). The director recently talked about on why he keeps returning to Baltimore for films in an interview with The Associated Press. Q. Just how autobiographical is ``Avalon''? A. More than I thought. I wasn't necessarily trying to make it absolutely true to life. But when I finished it and took a look, I realized it was even more (autobiographical) than I thought. Most of the incidents that take place did happen. ... I was surprised. Q. What was the origin of the film? A. One day I realized, perhaps because I have kids, how different it is for them nowadays. I grew up with grandparents around me, and my parents, and my uncles, and my aunts and friends of the grandparents. They were all around, and you were i touch with that as a kid: people talking different languages, telling different stories. You had this big extended family. That's almost ended, and I think it's a loss. That's what I started to write into, and more and more of the things from my life kind of got into the piece. Q. You have a large, ensemble cast. Does that present certain problems? A. Unfortunately, the jeopardy that you run into when you're making non-action, non-crazy comedy things is that you're putting an enormous demand on the actors to accomplish the work, because if we miss in a scene in a relationship, the movie is like derailed. Action movies can sustain scenes that don't really work. Because you say, ``Wait till we get to the big action scene.'' Q. Is there a quality that runs through the Levinson films? A certain gentleness, perhaps? A. I think what I try to do is not hype the characters. I try not to push them beyond what they may in fact do. I'm looking for what you might call the smaller dramatic moments, rather than the bigger ones. I'm trying to find those little moments that we laugh at and recognize. ... ``Avalon'' is not a gritty, gritty movie, because this was not a gritty environment. It was the end of the '40s, before things began to radically change. Q. How did you break away from Baltimore? A. I left to go off to college - American University (in Washington, D.C.). Q. That's not far from Baltimore. A. No, 40 miles. ... I ended up coming to L.A. I didn't know what I was going to do out here; I just came out. ... Then I got involved in a theater group here. Q. What did you study in college? A. I took broadcast journalism. I worked in local (Baltimore) television and did OK in it. But I got fed up with it and didn't know what else to do. There was not really any place to go unless you were interested in sales. After you'd directed a news show, you'd done it. So I came out here with absolutely no idea of what to do. Q. When you started writing for comedy shows (Carol Burnett, Tim Conway) and films (``Silent Movie,'' ``High Anxiety''), did you think about directing? A. Not at all. But working with Mel Brooks was like an apprenticeship. We were writing when we were on the set. Since he was in the movie, he'd say, ``What d'ya think?'' You're watching it, you saw it being edited and scored. Things start coming into your head. When I got to ``Diner,'' then I knew it was something I wanted to direct. Q. What's so great about Baltimore? A. I think it's a great-looking city in terms of a period kind of look. Different, you know. Row houses. Suburbia. Old wood-frame homes and trees. It's always made sense to do those movies there. Q. During one scene in ``Avalon,'' a diner is being set in place by a crane. Is that your own kind of grace note? A. Yeah, I like the idea that it began with ``Diner'' and whatever link these movies might have. I like the idea that this kid might be going to that diner in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Wages Lonely Struggle for Pandas ^LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Smiling, cavorting cartoon pandas look out on every street, but real ones are fading quietly toward extinction. Poachers defy the death penalty to capture their pelts. Farmers and foresters encroach on the shy animal's feeding grounds, even inside reserves. Scientists, either from lack of funds or flagging interest, have stopped studying pandas in the wild. All except one. Pan Wenshi, a biologist at Beijing University, spends half of each year huddled on the cool, damp slopes favored by pandas, tracking their movements in hopes of devising better preservation strategies. He has studied the rare animals for a decade, and said he nissed his daughter's childhood in the process. ``I want to know why pandas are becoming extinct, and . . . to help them,'' Pan, 52, said in an interview. ``Only after study can we come up with a method for saving pandas. Otherwise, any proposals will be blind and unscientific.'' For a national symbol whose name and image adorn hundreds of Chinese products, surprisingly little is known about the panda. Organizers of the Asian Games held in Beijing last month chose the panda as mascot and plastered images of it all over the city, but depicted the animal with four digits on each paw. Real ones have six, Pan pointed out. Ignorance can have more serious consequences. Hopes of using pandas born in zoos to replenish the wild population, now estimated at 1,100 to 1,500, have foundered because of the panda's poor breeding record in zoos. Pan said many zoos give pandas too much food and too little exercise, which makes them too fat and weak to mate. Only 37 pandas have been born in captivity in five decades, and 14 of them died within six months, he said. Even the $1 million breeding center at Wolong in Sichuan province, built help from the World Wildlife Fund and great fanfare, has succeeded in producing only one panda, in 1986. Scientists have virtually deserted the facility. ``People don't know what conditions a mother needs to raise cubs,'' Pan said. ``Does the mother need quiet? What diet does she need? What kind of cave?'' Such questions have sent him to the remote Qinling Mountains of Shaanxi province, more than620 miles southwest of Beijing, where an estimated 220 pandas roam. He snares the animals, fits them with radio-transmitting collars, then releases them and tracks their movements. Sometimes, college students and teachers join him as short-term volunteers, but graduate student Lu Zhi is his nnly steady assistant. It's easy to see why. ``Look at this,'' Pan said, holding up the 25-year-old woman's hand to show knuckles permanently swollen from cold. ``You lose a lot, but the rewards are great,'' she said. Among them was the sound of a suckling panda mother and cub. The mother wore a radio collar. Pan and Lu have videotaped hours of mother-cub scenes. They learned that mother pandas leave their cubs for up to two days to hunt for food, which means cubs found alone in the wild may not be abandoned after all. They learned that fewer than half the Qinling Mountain pandas are fertile and their isolation has led to much inbreeding. Some scientists have proposed introducing one or two pandas from another part of the country to enlarge the gene pool, but Pan said the Qinling pandas might not accept a newcomer. One of Pan's major concerns is how much human presence pandas can tolerate. Tradition and bureaucracy have prevented the removal of thousands of peasants from designated panda reserves, despite the pleas of scientists. ``China has so many people, moving them won't work,'' Pan said. ``We need to find out ways that people and pandas can exist in a common area.'' He has found up to 60 percent of the forest cover in panda habitats can be cut down without ill effect. He said farming is possible if limited to the lower slopes of mountains and if forested corridors between mountains are preserved. Firm policing and clear directives from the central government are necessary, and Pan said he would ask for such directives in a 2,000-page report he was submitting to the Forestry Ministry. Too much logging already has been done in some forest areas of the Qinling Mountains, he said, and others are threatened. Pan said prompt action was needed to save the habitat, which he described as more promising for long-term panda survival than Sichuan province to the south. More pandas live in Sichuan, but also many more people. ``I think there is hope,'' Pan said. ``The problems are great, but we have to continue making efforts. If we don't, it is over.''

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Services Fight Over Military Budget
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish army wishes the Gripen combat plane were as imaginary as the mythological bird-beast whose name it bears. Army officers, competing with the air force for dwindling military funds in a neutral nation, call the single-seat Gripen the greatest threat to defense since Sweden's last war, with Napoleon, ended in 1814. The griffin, which had the head and wings of an eagle on a lion's body, symbolized strength and vigilance. The supersonic Gripen, way behind schedule, is more than $1 billion over budget and the first prototype crashed. Sweden, a neighbor of the Soviet Union with only 8.4 million citizens, says it needs a strong defense to reinforce its neutrality. It has a conscript army of 750,000 and produces most of its own weapons, including missiles, tanks, submarines, artillery and explosives. Inflation has reduced the value of military budgets for two decades, and some experts fear the Gripen's rising costs will force Sweden to compromise security for lack of money. Gen. Bengt Gustafsson, supreme military commander, told Parliament last month the military budget of $4.6 billion must be increased or Sweden will have to revise its defense plans, close bases, reduce military service and dismantle the defense industry. He also says, however, that the computerized jet is essential. It can be programmed for aerial interception, ground attack or reconnaissance. In Sweden, which has long borders and is surrounded by water, the air force would hold off an enemy until the army could mobilize. The Gripen is a about 45 feet long with a takeoff weight of eight tons - half the size of the Viggen warplane Sweden has used for 15 years - and is much more maneuverable. Army commander Ake Sagren, anticipating a budget battle, launched a public attack on the Gripen in August. The army ``risks being phased out,'' the general wrote in the newspaper Svenska Dagbladet, and ``Sweden will have an excellent air force well into the next century'' without the new plane. At a tank training center in Kristianstad, the southern regional capital, Col. Roland Appelqvist's face turned grim when the Gripen was mentioned and said his base was targeted for closure. If the aircraft project had stayed within its budget, ``there would have been money'' for the base, he said. Sweden budgeted the Gripen, its largest industrial project, at $8.66 billion when work began in 1982, but cost overruns total $1.16 billion so far and it is 18 months behind schedule. The second prototype has made several test flights, but the first crashed after six flights. The air force has ordered 30 planes and is expected to increase that to 140 by the end of the year. Money for the aircraft has been allocated in the long-term defense plan, but the cost probably will rise to at least $80 million each from the original $65 million. No outsiders are participating in the Gripen project. Israel was building a similar plane, the Lavi, a few years ago, but gave up after the United States withdrew its backing because of mounting costs. Some of Sweden's largest companies are involved with the Gripen, including Saab, the Ericsson telecommunications group and Volvo Aircraft Engines. Saab officials say the civilian aircraft industry they have nurtured for a decade would die without the experience and spinoffs provided by the warplane Gripen project. Parliament must decide by next year how to allocate defense money through 1996. Gustafsson, the supreme commander, says increasing costs have had the effect over 20 years of nearly halving the number of operational defense units. He said the military needs a grant of $410 million and annual 3 percent budget increases through the 1990s to finance the Gripen and current defense policies. It is unlikely Parliament will grant his request at a time when the Soviet Union, perceived as the main threat to Sweden, is reducing military spending.

DOC.HEAD: The Real News in ``Murphy Brown''
DOC.TEXT: It's hard enough to separate reality from make-believe on television. On CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' the line between fact and fiction is forever blurred. Real-life news broadcasters walk into the fictional ``FYI'' newsroom as themselves. Last season saw TV journalists Connie Chung, Kathleen Sullivan and Linda Ellerbee in guest roles on the comedy series about a make-believe television news magazine based in the nation's capital. Besides cameos by news personalities, the highly rated program also consistently draws its scripts from headline stories. This season is no different. The Sept. 18 premiere of ``Murphy Brown's'' third season saw the cast and set of ``FYI'' undergo a total overhaul - complete with toupees, short skirts and a Santa Fe nightmare of new furniture - all in the name of chatty, user-friendly news and bigger ratings. The next episode concerned the ever-intense liberal and feminist lead character Murphy Brown, played by Candice Bergen, doing an interview with a racist, sexist comedian whom she despised (guess who the comedian was modeled after). The show's writers also are working on a script tackling the issue of what happens when news personalities say regrettable things, a la Andy Rooney's now infamous remarks about gays and blacks. ``People like to see issues from news and things that affect them personally,'' said Diane English, the program's creator, co-executive producer and frequent writer. ``The topicality of our shows is one of the favorite things about `Murphy Brown.' '' Last month, the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences awarded the critically acclaimed show an Emmy for best comedy series. Bergen also won her second outstanding lead comedy actress trophy for her acid-tongued portrayal of a star TV journalist. Despite such heady honors, English said the show will remain largely the same. Some subtle, unexpected plot twists are being planned, but she wouldn't divulge them. ``We like to have surprises for our viewers,'' English said. And while ``Murphy Brown'' uses news for entertainment, real-life journalism has decided to use ``Murphy Brown'' for news. ``PrimeTime Live'' co-anchor Diane Sawyer just finished a week on the set, taping a segment on the making of ``Murphy Brown.'' If Sawyer's schedule would have permitted, English said, the former ``60 Minutes'' correspondent might have made an appearance on the comedy series while doing a news story about it. In fact, English said, her show has extended several invitations to Sawyer and ``all the `60 Minutes' guys'' including CBS evening news anchor Dan Rather (a former ``60 Minutes'' guy) and Mike Wallace. Rather is ``really not sure whether this is a good thing for him to do,'' English said. ``He has a great sense of humor and it would be great if people could see that.''' Cable talk show host Larry King's involvement is being sought for an upcoming episode in which Brown is taken hostage by environmentally conscious ``eco-terrorists,'' English said. ``She's trying to convince people that she's really been kidnapped and no one believes her because she's such a practical joker,'' English said. In captivity, Brown sees King on television and tries to call in on the talk show's viewer line. English said she and husband Joel Shukovsky, the show's other executive producer, also are considering an episode about management survival trips, at the suggestion of Sawyer. According to English, Sawyer said ABC had sent her and ``PrimeTime Live'' co-anchor Sam Donaldson into the wilderness to rough it for a few days - a kind of management retreat that bigger corporations are increasingly employing. English should just film Sawyer and the notoriously pugnacious Donaldson hanging out with Mother Nature - now that would be entertainment. Although ``Murphy Brown'' is lauded by critics and has climbed steadily - if sporadically - in the ratings, English and Shukovsky were very close to leaving the show this year because of protracted contract battles with Warner Bros. Television. ``The negotiations were very long and very tedious and very dismal at times,'' English said. ``We had even approved a press release that CBS was going to put out in April saying we would not be coming back to the show.'' At the last minute, the studio agreed to give the pair more money, a higher ownership percentage in the program and the right to make other shows for other networks. In return, English and Shukovsky signed on for 100 more episodes. ``We made this show,'' English said. ``Without us, there was no `Murphy Brown. And we saw the network coming out way ahead of us. I'm doing everything but catering the meals.'' When it comes to monetary issues in the television business, the line between reality and make-believe is very clear. --- Elsewhere in television ... REASON NO. 1,289 TO CONTINUE LIVING: If T-shirts, thermoses and pinball machines are not enough, the animated ``Simpsons'' show now has spun off into a board game called ``Mystery of Life.''

DOC.HEAD: Investment Opportunity Amid Disaster
DOC.TEXT: The third quarter in the stock market was a disaster for investors who had to sell. Almost every market average and category took a drubbing. Only oil, gas and gold stocks were major exceptions. The Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and stock mutual funds lost 15 percent of their value, but averages for smaller stocks fared worse. The over-the-counter composite index plunged 25 percent. Those who tend to invest in certain categories of stocks might have done much worse. Among New York Stock Exchange listings, apparels lost 32 percent, textiles 31 percent, electronics 29 percent and automotives 27 percent. Some small-company shares lost more than half their value during the three months of July, August and September. It wasn't very unusual to see over-the-counter stocks with one-day declines of 25 percent in a single day. In some instances, professional pickers did as poorly as amateurs. Many stock mutual funds lost more than 30 percent of their value during the three months; that is, they performed worse than dart-throwers. The statistical evidence is indeed a picture of disaster, but as Chinese philosophers, inspirational teachers, evangelists and some smart investors try to explain, disaster may also spell opportunity. ``Stock prices have now declined to the point where above-average long-term investment returns can once again be expected,'' says Wright Investors, a large portfolio management and advisory company that stresses the long term. For old investors who were forced to sell, the bad news is bad indeed, but for new investors the bad news is good news, a two-for-one promotion, a discount sale the like of which no marketing executive ever imagined. It doesn't come without risk, of course, because the stock market could fall even lower before the bear market ends. And the sad fact is that the eventual rise in the market is likely to be slower than its earlier fall. Nevertheless, this is the type of market in which patient investors who stress fundamental values and maintain long-term perspectives make lots of money. It has been demonstrated again and again, but forgotten as often. The long term is stressed, for example, by investment clubs that make up a large percentage of membership in the National Association of Investment Clubs. The ups and downs of the economy don't matter to them; they go right on buying. As a result, they automatically exploit economic dips and stock market declines. When the market is high, they might have to pay $10 a share, but when it falls they might get two shares for what used to be the price of one. The assumption they make, of course, is that the general tendency of the U.S. economy is to expand, and the general direction of stocks, which reflect that economy, is to rise. They buy and wait and profit. Some do, anyway. In spite of the professions of optimism and patience, many individuals and investment clubs lose faith when the market falls. They fail to perceive opportunity. NAIC records show many clubs dissolve. It isn't easy to see beauty in the debris of a bull market, or view it as a two-for-one sale. They might buy toothpaste that way, but not stocks.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Children Orphaned or Abandoned in Romania
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Stan Barbu is 3 and runs on his knees because the parents who abandoned him will not let surgeons fix his twisted legs. The 50 other children in the orphanage are blind, retarded or maimed. They are the dregs of tens of thousands of abandoned or orphaned children who owe their plight to Nicolae Ceausescu's obsession with population growth. Ten months after the Commuist dictator was overthrown and executed, no one knows just how many children languish in Romania's 78 orphanages and in dozens of hospitals. The government says there may be 60,000 in a total population of 23 million, but other estimates range up to 100,000. What to do with them has yet to be decided. Some foreigners believe adoption is part of the answer. Stan is pale and fair-haired, with a broad grin and bright eyes that make his crippling infirmities difficult to believe. His fingers and toes are grown together and his legs bend inward in arcs so severe that he must walk and run on his knees. He delights in showing visitors what he can do. Although Stan's parents abandoned him two years ago, Romanian law gives them the right to say whether he should have surgery. They have refused, and ``there's nothing we can do but watch him suffer'' unless the law is changed, one of his nurses said. Ceausescu, put to death last Christmas Day, did not permit contraception and abortion was illegal, with few exceptions. Women were required to have regular medical examinations to determine whether they were pregnant. Couples were encouraged to have at least four children each, but Ceausescu's economic policies made it difficult to afford more than one. Parents abandoned tens of thousands of children to state institutions. Dr. Emil Tomescu, deputy health minister, estimates no more than 3 percent of the children in orphanages actually are orphans. Of the approximately 800 Romanian children diagnosed this year as having AIDS, most are abandoned. Doctors said the fatal disease was spread among them through transfusions of infected blood given before Romania had blood-screening equipment. Tomescu said he expected legalized abortion, new family planning centers and an improved economy to help ease the problem of abandoned children and orphans. Dr. Marghareta Creteanu, director of Stan's ward at the St. Catherine Home for Children in Bucharest, said the institution had admitted only 120 children since January, about half the number of the same period in 1989. Barry Child of Orphanages Trust, a British organization that aids Romania, said his organization plans to buy some houses and put two to four children in each, along with subsidized house parents helped by British volunteers. ``This way, fewer would have to live in orphanages'' and fewer might go to orphanages, where he said ``conditions are absolutely terrible.'' Child said the most serious problem in orphanages was understaffing, ``so we first want to provide groups . . . to teach the Romanian staff wat to do to take good care of the children.'' Liz Brown, team leader of four young Scottish nurses working as Orphanages Trust volunteers, said: ``A head nurse won't just jump in and help . . . as we would in other countries, and this exacerbates the problem.'' The deputy health minister, Tomescu, said the government recognized the problem and had decided to increase the nurse-child ratio from 1 to 23 to 1 nurse for each 10 children. Mariana Gheorghiu, a nurse at the Bucharest home, said the new policy had not yet taken affect and ``things haven't really changed much, despite the efforts of some dedicated people who came here to help.'' ``We have more milk and meat, but there is a grave crisis in terms of personnel . . . too many kids, too few nurses,'' she said. As she spoke, Ms. Gheorghiu changed the diaper of Gabriela, who was 9 months old and dying of pneumonia. St. Catherine's is known as one of the best children's homes in Romania. Conditions there are poorer than in the West, but far better than at other Romanian orphanages. David Livianu, director of the American Center for Romanian Adoptable Children, said adoption is ``their only way out of a lifetime of struggle and indignity.'' He took the photographs of 16 children with him to the United States in August, and said adoptive parents awaited them in the United States. Livianu recently established an adoption center and his organization also has offices in the Health Ministry. ``It can cost people up to $15,000 to come here, stay in Romania for months and pay middlemen and lawyers en route to adopting a child,'' he said. ``We want to . . . encourage people to instead make donations, which can be used to buy much-needed biomedical equipment such as incubators.'' Adoption was simplified in August by repeal of a law that required presidential approval of all adoptions. Under the new law, adoptions are handled by local courts and need only the approval of child-care specialists and the child's parents, if they are alive. Dan Koch, 36, the first American to adopt under the new law, said he ``encountered very little'' bureaucratic delay or corruption. ``I believe it would have taken longer and been more complicated . . . back home,'' said Koch, who works for the Delaware state insurance commission. He returned to his wife, Kathleen, with 3-year-old Ioan, now named John Nicholas.
