DOC.HEAD: Why Do 65,000 Americans Live in Tumultuous Israel?
DOC.TEXT: Two thousand Americans on a hillside sang ``Amazing Grace,'' and it seemed for a moment like a folk fest of the 1960s. But Syria is just over the mountain, the valley is only a few thousand yards from Lebanon and, in Israel, each day brings a new threat from Saddam Hussein, protests by Palestinians, a tax increase or other bad news. Israelis from the United States have come to Horshat Tal, in the shadow of Mount Hermon, for 15 years to sing of adventure, Jewish independence, religious freedom and hopes for a better world. Organizer Menachem Vinegrad said Americans and other English-speaking immigrants started the Jacob's Ladder Festival because they were ``liberals interested in changing the world'' and missed folk and protest songs from home. A few thousand American Jews arrived in the first years after independence in 1948, then victory in the 1967 Middle East war brought a surge of Jewish pride and a rush of immigrants. About 65,000 Americans now live in Israel, one of the highest population ratios of U.S. expatriates in a foreign country. They also have one of the highest dropout rates - 35 percent. Among the reasons cited by Americans who return home are low salaries, high taxes, the military draft and government bureaucracy. One who stayed is Yoav Peck, who in the late 1960s became disillusioned with the power of the American establishment and failures in the anti-war movement. ``Instead of fighting against some encrusted social injustices and everything I saw in America, I got to be a positive part of building a nation in its adolescent years,'' said Peck, director of the Association of Americans and Canadians in Israel. He said friends in America who were part of the 1960s protest movement at the University of California's Berkeley campus now seek meaning for their lives in the 1990s. In his own case, Peck said, he realizes every day that ``I have a lifelong Berkeley'' in Israel. Americans have gained recognition in nearly every walk of Israeli life, from Golda Meir, who grew up in Milwaukee and became prime minister, to weatherman Bob Ulinski from New Jersey, who enchants morning radio listeners with his heavily accented Hebrew. Most male American immigrants do reqired army service and reserve duty. More than 150 have been killed defending the Jewish state. Israelis from the United States cut across Israel's political spectrum from Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League on the extreme right, to the Peace Now movement, which favors Israeli concessions to the Arabs. They are among Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who argue that those areas are Israel's by biblical right. Unlike Israelis who sought refuge from persecution, most American Jews have come as willing volunteers. They always have been free to return to the United States. ``I wasn't a refugee,'' said Steve Lebowitz of Laurelton, N.Y. ``The only thing I was running away from in the U.S. was the rat race.'' Lebowitz, 38, is Israel's football commissioner, presiding over 11 amateur touch-football teams. ``Israel is a smaller society,'' he said. ``I really feel that in Israel you can have an impact.'' Sara Chark said she was called anti-Semitic names while growing up in Lafayette, La., a predominantly Roman Catholic area. She has three children and moved to Israel seven years ago. ``Here, I can go into the street and my neighbor is Jewish and I know he may hate me because my kids make too much noise or something else,'' she said, ``but if there is trouble, I know he is my brother and will help me.'' In 1983, Rabbi Shlomo Riskin of New York arrived with 40 members of his synagogue to live in Efrat, a West Bank settlement four miles from Bethlehem. ``In America, we're at best a footnote to Jewish history,'' he said. ``In Israel, we have the possibility of becoming chapter headings.'' Riskin said he views those who came to Israel as ``heroes, putting the lives of their children and grandchildren on the line for the cause of Jewish independence.'' Hebrew is a major challenge for immigrants, but the poor grammar and heavy accent of Joe Criden, an American who arrived 40 years ago, has helped make a hit of his television show about car maintenance. ``We continue being Americans,'' said Marc Leventhal, a lawyer. Leventhal, from New Haven, Conn., is a member of the Democratic National Committee representing Americans living abroad. He said Americans in Israel have the highest absentee voting rate. ``I think most of us discover the meaning of patriotism only after we immigrate to Israel,'' Peck said. ``The real sense of belonging and common destiny with a country for many of us is only born here.'' Lenny Ravich, a founder of the Jacob's Ladder Festival, came to Israel from Birmingham, Ala. One habit he gave up was celebrating American holidays, he said, but now he brings hot dogs and relish to Israeli Independence Day celebrations. ``While we sing Israeli songs I'll close my eyes and eat a hot dog,'' he said. ``That, for me, is the Fourth of July.'' David Krizelman, arrived soon after graduation from the University of Michigan in 1967. ``If you could tell me I could walk around America for a half hour during Christmas season, or go to a college football game on a Saturday in autumn, I'd find that absolutely wonderful,'' he said. ``But I don't miss it enough to look for an excuse to go back.''

DOC.HEAD: A Courtly Gentleman Retires From Congress
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: He arrived in time for the tidal wave of Great Society activism, championed social concerns during the penny-pinching Reagan era and leaves as he came, fighting for civil rights. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, 83, chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, is a black man who never played racial politics; a liberal who inspires affection among conservatives; a courtly gentleman who rarely gives up or gives in. The diminutive, soft-spoken Democrat is retiring this year after 28 years in Congress representing Watts, the Los Angeles neighborhood notorious for the riots that tore it apart in the 1960s. In the brave new Capitol Hill world of sound bites, cynicism and big money, the void left by Hawkins' departpre may not be immediately obvious. But there will be one. Ask any education, labor or civil rights lobbyist; the senior Republican on his committee; even Rep. Tom Downey, who bested him in a recent dispute over how to channel child-care money to states and parents. ``This institution is going to miss him terribly,'' said Downey, D-N.Y. ``He has been a relentless pursuer of social justice,'' said Michael Edwards, chief lobbyist for the National Education Association. ``He has very deeply held principles and a great sense of mission. And yet he was always able to bring people together.'' Hawkins' basic philosophy - that government must help its less fortunate citizens - hasn't changed much since he was elected to the California Assembly in 1934. ``I truly believe every person in our country is entitled to equal opportunities. If we give them those opportunities, it will help everybody else. That's good, ordinary common sense,'' he said in an interview last week. The son of a British-born adventurer who moved his family to the United States after exploring Africa, Hawkins won his House seat in 1962. He was the first black member from a Western state, and one of the first things he did was sponsor the equal employment section of the landmark 1964 Civil Rights Act. It was an early triumph in a congressional career that has spanned eras of plenty and parsimony, pendulum swings in political thought, and the inevitable mixture of achievements and disappointments. Chief among the latter was the 1978 Humphrey-Hawkins full employment bill, which put forth an admirable goal but lost a federal job guarantee before passage. ``It's been an outright failure in terms of implementation,'' Hawkins said bluntly. ``No one's taken it seriously, beginning with the Carter administration.'' The widely supported 1988 welfare reform law, with its requirement that some recipients take jobs, was another setback from Hawkins' perspective. Workfare is ``a punitive approach to forcing people off the rolls,'' he declared on the floor. It was an unusually harsh stand for a man who, despite his enduring New Deal concerns, generally prefers compromise to confrontation. Hawkins' grasp of political reality was put to the test in 1984, when he became committee chairman amid rampant conservatism and a scarcity of domestic resources. For the most part he adapted well, building coalitions and inching ahead where possible. ``If you only have a potato, the only thing you can make is potato soup. You can't make stew,'' said Bob McGlotten, chief lobbyist for the AFL-CIO. ``Under severe circumstances, Gus has done a tremendous job to make sure the educational systems in our society don't fall apart.'' The kind of money Hawkins wanted to spend on education and programs for disadvantaged children wasn't available, but he settled for modest gains and was rewarded with near-unanimous passage of many major education bills. There was far more contention in the labor area, including protracted battles over raising the minimum wage and guaranteeing unpaid family leaves to workers. But civility was always the order of the day. ``We don't have any animosity. We have differences,'' said Fred Krebs, manager of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce's labor and human resources department. The same civility characterized Hawkins' relations with Republicans on the committee, who recently threw him a retirement party. Among his gifts was a homemade gavel to crack crabs and a gag picture of Downey with a forged inscription that said ``I really enjoyed working closely with you.'' ``I'm very saddened that he is leaving,'' said Rep. Bill Goodling, R-Pa., the senior Republican on Hawkins' committee. ``He is one of the finest gentlemen I've ever met.'' The two men had a close partnership, with the chairman often testing his ideas on Goodling and molding them to attract broader support. ``If he doesn't agree with what I'm trying to do, I try to find out why. I know I will get the same disagreements from others,'' Hawkins said. ``If I can make modifications, we'll get something done. If you are really interested in results, why not be cooperative?'' Hawkins, so light-skinned he is often thought to be white, has never chaired the Congressional Black Caucus and prefers to cast issues in economic rather than racial terms. He has promoted education, health care and nutrition for the needy, and been instrumental in securing passage of many civil rights laws that opened up opportunities for minorities and others. Ironically, as he leaves Congress, Hawkins is once again trying to restore some of the protections he first fought for in 1964. Bush is threatening to veto this year's Kennedy-Hawkins civil rights bill, although Hawkins said he amended it 22 times to try to please the administration. ``In some ways we're back where we were,'' Hawkins said. ``It is discouraging, but not to the point where we're giving up. You have this ebb and flow in American politics... You win a few and you lose a few. By and large you try to be incremental in making advances.'' When Hawkins retires, he won't vanish onto the Chesapeake Bay in his beloved fishing boat. Instead he intends to speak, volunteer and organize on behalf of Job Corps, Head Start and other programs he fostered in Congress. ``You don't have to be in elective office to make a difference,'' Hawkins said. ``There's lots of things to do, and in between I'll do a little fishing.''

LaserPhoto planned
By LAURA CASTANEDA
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Archaeologists say the tombs of a mysterious city have yielded the first example of the use on children of an ancient art: carving or engraving teeth as a sign of beauty. Evidence of the engraving was discovered on the teeth of a young boy's skeleton found in the ruins of Montezuma's Balcony, whose civilization was far more advanced than any previously thought to exist in the region. Montezuma's Balcony is 310 miles north of Mexico City outside Ciudad Victoria, capital of northeastern Tamaulipas state. Its name is derived from that of Moctezuma, the Aztec king. Tamaulipas, which spent more than $53,000 on the project, plans to open the site to the public this year. Two canyons and a mountain surround the remote, 12-acre city. It is reached by a steep, rocky road that veers two miles off the main highway to 86 huge slabs of stone named the ``grand stairway.'' Only from the top of the stairway can the remains of more than 100 circular structures be seen, each up to 50 feet in diameter, built from stacked and fitted rocks. More than 100 skeletons were found in basements, along with ceramic fragments, food-grinding utensils, pipes, necklaces, arrowheads, knives and small figurines. The remains of the boy, no older than 5, showed evidence of the carving, called dental mutilation, in his two upper incisors and one lower incisor. ``This is a very rare find,'' said Jesus Narez, director of the Montezuma's Balcony restoration project. ``Until now, we have never detected dental mutilations in a person this young.'' In primitive cultures, dental mutilation is believed to be practiced only on adults. It still is done by some Brazilian, Indonesian and African communities. ``We think it hurts a lot, but . . . peyote, which was commonly used in those times, was probably used to put the child to sleep or dull the pain,'' Narez said. Several other things make Montezuma's Balcony unique, said Narez, curator-investigator of the architectural and cultural collections of northern Mexico at the National Museum of Anthropology and History in Mexico City. He said two groups of people lived there: the Grassiles, thin and fine featured, and the Robustus, big-boned and heavy. Archaeologists chose the names. ``At least for now, we think they lived there together, but radiocarbon testing is being done to determine if they were there at the same time or if one group followed the other,'' Narez said. According to Narez, the city's 3,000 people probably lived between the years 600 and 1400. The elite occupied in the structures and were buried in their basements, and the others lived in wooden huts, he said. References to Montezuma's Balcony appeared in a researcher's report in the mid-1800s, and there was another report in the 1940s. Work on the site began in 1988 and was completed in August. Although their culture was higher than others in the area, the Montezuma's Balcony residents were not as advanced as the Teotihuacans, Zapotecs or Mayas of southern Mexico, who built pyramids and cities in the same period. Northern tribes like the Huastecas the warrior-like Chichimecas, led more primitive, simpler lives than the people of Montezuma's Balcony, Narez said. ``We never thought we'd find these types of buildings so far north,'' he said, adding that huge pieces of rock used to build the Montezuma's Balcony structures were moved with the aid of planks and rope. ``A tribal group with limited organization would not have had sufficient social structure to construct these buildings,'' he said. ``They must have had chiefs, priests, workers and so on.'' He said the site probably was chosen because only the side with the ``grand staircase'' would have to be guarded. Circular structures are typical of Huastecas. Dome-like huts of palm and wood built over basements were believed to lesson the impact of hurricanes and cyclones. Montezuma's Balcony may have been part of a commercial corridor, Narez said, because artifacts like pipes and necklaces show influences of tribes from farther north like the Kaddo, Adena, Apaches and Mississippians. He said how its people became extinct had not been determined. ``We can only guess at this point,'' he said. ``Climate changes may have made it hard to get enough to eat. There may have been frequent fighting with the Chichimecas. There may have been illness.''

DOC.HEAD: Harold Pinter: Britain's Angry Old Playwright at 60
DOC.TEXT: Harold Pinter, the most influential playwright of his generation, approaches his 60th birthday as an angry artist who hasn't written a full-length play in 12 years. To celebrate his birthday on Oct. 10, Pinter is being remembered with a flurry of revivals and the delayed publication of a decades-old novel. But there also is a sense among admirers that he has momentarily lost or squandered his gifts. The man who turned the conversational pause into an emotional minefield is now known as much for his volatility as for his creative talent. ``Angry old man,'' read the headline of a Sept. 16 cover story in Britain's Sunday Correspondent magazine focusing on his personal belligerence, not his literary output. In the late 1950s and throughout the next decades, Pinter codified a style steeped in verbal evasion and violence, menace both spoken and not. Its effect was felt in the United States in the plays of Sam Shepard and David Mamet and throughout British literature, which suddenly had a new adjective: Pinteresque. Such plays as ``The Birthday Party'' and ``The Homecoming'' examined the sour, even horrifying underside of domestic rituals. Their working-class milieu reflects Pinter's early life as the son of a Jewish tailor from London's East End. He began his career in the provinces as an actor. In ``Old Times'' and ``Betrayal,'' he took a literary scalpel to highly charged erotic triangles. ``Betrayal,'' written in 1978, was his last full-length play. Reflecting on his career right now, colleagues wonder whether he's capable of another one. ``Maybe he's said all he wanted to say,'' says actress Eileen Atkins, who starred in Pinter's brief play, ``Mountain Language,'' two years ago. ``He hasn't got a play to write, alas,'' Sir Peter Hall, his longtime director, says. But he has many works worth reviving. This month Hall began rehearsals for a 25th-anniversary production of ``The Homecoming,'' which he previously directed in London and on Broadway and filmed in 1973. The play originally starred Pinter's first wife, actress Vivien Merchant, who died in 1982, two years after their divorce. His first major play, 1958's ``The Birthday Party,'' is on national tour and arrives in London on Nov. 20. ``Betrayal'' comes around again next year, opening Jan. 22, 1991, at north London's Almeida Theater. Rehearsals start in April for a West End revival of ``The Caretaker,'' which Pinter himself will direct. All of which reminds admirers how a once-prolific output has dried up. In the 1980s, Pinter's only stage plays have been one-acts: ``A Kind of Alaska'' (1982), ``One for the Road'' (1984) and the 20-minute ``Mountain Language'' (1988). Even his new novel ``The Dwarfs,'' published Oct. 1, resuscitates a work first begun, and then abandoned, more than 30 years ago. ``I've been very busy doing a lot of other things,'' Pinter said in a radio interview last month for the British Broadcasting Corp. ``I haven't any plans to write a play at the moment.'' These days, it's Pinter's politics, not his plays, that make headlines. ``Yanquis go home!'' the writer argued in Britain's Independent On Sunday newspaper in May. The piece was a broadside against American policy in Latin America. Two years earlier, Pinter and his second wife, Lady Antonia Fraser, formed the 20th July Group, a forum for anti-Tory opinion designed to oppose the policies of Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``I strongly feel it's my job as a citizen of this country to keep an eye on these things,'' he sad in the BBC interview. When not distinguishing himself with his political outspokenness, Pinter raises eyebrows with his choice of projects. A former actor, he has turned more and more to directing shows that scarcely seem worth his time. In 1986, he directed Faye Dunaway in ``Circe and Bravo,'' by American writer Donald Freed, to mixed reviews. In May, he staged an American satire, Jane Stanton Hitchcock's ``Vanilla,'' on the West End. The play received harsh reviews and closed seven weeks later. Screenwriting also keeps him occupied. Having written such 1960s classics as ``The Servant,'' ``Accident'' and ``The Go-Between,'' he began the last decade adapting John Fowles' ``The French Lieutenant's Woman.'' He wrote two recent movies: ``The Handmaid's Tale,'' released last spring, and the imminent ``The Comfort of Strangers,'' based on the Ian McEwan novel. Pinter told the BBC that it was ``absolute nonsense,'' however, to assume his playwriting days were finished. ``There's nothing I'd love more,'' he said. ``I'm 60 any minute, and I've got plenty left in me, I think.''

DOC.HEAD: Bradys on Stage Draw Bunches of Fans - But Why?
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: OK, video kids, fill in the blank: ``Here's the story ``Of a man named - - - - -'' If you answered ``Brady,'' get in line for the unlikeliest hit on Chicago's theater scene: ``The Real Live Brady Bunch.'' The show is a live, word-for-word re-enactment of an episode from the early 1970s television series, ``The Brady Bunch.'' The all-adult cast plays it straight, from the dopey sing-along theme song to little Cindy's irritating lisp. The show has become so popular since beginning its Tuesday night run in early June that the 110-seat Annoyance Theater added a second weekly performance in mid-August. The cramped theater in a funky, North Side neighborhood charges $7 a ticket. If ``The Real Live Bradys'' is art - and not even the actors agree on that point - it may be the first case of art imitating TV sitcom life, a kind of life so far removed from the real thing that it's, well, laughable. A concept this loopy could only have been hatched by people with genuine affection for the Bradys: sisters Faith and Jill Soloway, who jointly produce and direct the shows for the Metraform theater company. ``We pay tribute to the Bradys, we don't disrespect them,'' Jill said. Like the young professionals who fill the theater, the Soloways are in their mid-20s and grew up watching the Brady Bunch, which stayed on television from 1969-'74 and ran as an hour-long series in 1977 before hitting the rerun trail. ``We were all really jealous of the Bradys,'' Jill said, a sentiment also expressed by several spectators at a recent performance. Brady envy? It's not hard to understand. In their suburban digs, the Bradys resided in a universe far removed from the social and political turmoil of their times. Teen-ager Greg Brady never worried he might be drafted and sent to Vietnam. No Brady ever wondered if Nixon was a crook. Nor were the Brady children ever stressed by the dynamics of their mix-and-match family: a widower and his new wife, her three daughters, his three sons and Alice, their old-maid housekeeper. Brady family crises involved such mundane aggravations as Dad's misplaced architectural plans and middle daughter Jan sneaking a peek at eldest daughter Marcia's diary. And as self-styled Brady historian Max Merlin, a Northwestern University film student, observed, ``their problems always worked out in 23{ minutes.'' Actress Eve Plumb, who played Jan in the series, experienced the Brady revival first-hand when the Soloway sisters flew her in from Los Angeles to guest star in one of their shows during the summer. She played a bit part, choosing not to reprise her role as pubescent Jan at age 32. It was ``a totally bizarre experience,'' Plumb said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles, where she is a rotating cast member of the Groundlings, an improvisational troupe. She said she doesn't understand the Bradys' enduring appeal, but thinks the Chicago show is ``sort of a hoot.'' ``Brady Bunch'' creator Sherwood Schwartz, who also gave us ``Gilligan's Island,'' suggested the lure of the Bradys is mostly nostalgia. ``It's something people have as a reference point in their youth, and they hold fond memories of those shows,'' he said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles. But Chicago actress Jane Lynch, who plays mother Carol in ``The Real Live Bradys,'' holds that nostalgia is only part of the show's draw. She said the other half - the element that transforms ``The Real Live Bradys'' from camp into art - is the realization by audience members that the Bradys' uncomplicated lives were nothing like what life turned out to be. ``A teacher once told me the purpose of art is to enlighten and inform,'' Lynch said. ``This informs us as to what we bought into as children and enlightens us that it was crap.''

DOC.HEAD: SILVER TONGUES AND DEADLY BULLETS: A Look at Gangster Films
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The violence of ``GoodFellas'' and other current mob movies hasn't rattled those who crusade against rap and heavy metal. But in the early 1930s, police and concerned citizens agreed something had to be done about the ``too live crew'' of gangster films. The New York Patrolman's Benefit Association passed a resolution calling for a ban on films that ``glorify the lives of gangsters, gunmen and racketeers.'' The Better Films Committee of Montclair, N.J., blamed the death of a 12-year-old boy on a gangster movie the murderer had seen. The main culprits were ``Little Caesar'' and ``The Public Enemy.'' No matter that stars Edward G. Robinson and James Cagney got theirs in the end; who could possibly root for the coppers when the bad guys were played by better actors (with better wardrobes)? Hollywood tried. Cagney insisted he was ``sick of carrying guns and beating up women. Movies should be entertaining, not bloodbaths.'' And when ``Scarface: The Shame of the Nation,'' was released in 1932, a grim warning was placed at the beginning of the film: ``This picture is an indictment of gang rule in America and of the callous indifference of the government to this increasing menace to our safety and our liberty. ... What are YOU going to do about it?'' But director Howard Hawks undermined the message; the thugs stole the show. None of the speechmaking by the film's police commissioner was as effective as watching George Raft coolly clip paper dolls or Paul Muni gun down fellow mobster Boris Karloff at a bowling alley, a bullet knocking down the 10th pin. ``Being a gangster was better than being president of the United States,'' Ray Liotta boasts as gangster Henry Hill in the current ``GoodFellas.'' Muni's Tony Camonte felt the same way as he stared outside his apartment at a neon sign that read ``The World Is Yours.'' Gangsters really weren't that different from the old Hollywood bosses. They talked tough, wore fancy clothes, cut million-dollar deals. They grew up poor and had little education, but made it to the top through hard work, ruthlessness and a strong belief in free enterprise. Death was inevitable - taxes were not. `` . . . because they ennoble energy and because they are low born, cocky, and self-sufficient, they demonstrate what one can accomplish against all the odds outside the traditions,'' film critic Neil Gabler wrote in ``An Empire of Their Own,'' his book about Hollywood. Current mob movies include ``Miller's Crossing,'' starring Gabriel Byrne as an Irish mobster with conflicting loyalties; ``State of Grace,'' another story about Irish mobsters, this one set in New York's Hell's Kitchen and starring Sean Penn, Gary Oldman and Ed Harris; and Martin Scorsese's ``GoodFellas.'' The highly publicized ``The Godfather: Part III,'' again directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is due in November. ``The Godfather,'' released in 1972, won the Academy Award for best picture and ``The Godfather Part II'' did the same two years later. No one can really identify the first gangster film, but D.W. Griffith's ``Muskateers of Pig Alley,'' released in 1912, contained some of the classic elements: a young couple trapped in a war between rival gangs, a saloon, a dance hall, crooked cops and gunmen with nervous hands. ``The Gangsters'' and ``The Making of Crooks,'' released during the next few years, included such devices as a policeman working undercover (a major part of the 1949 classic ``White Heat'') and a pool hall where crooks and aspiring crooks gathered. By the late 1920s, all a Hollywood producer had to do was pick up the newspaper to get inspiration. ``Torn From Today's Headlines'' was how one publicity department described the gangster films. ``Scarface,'' for instance, has a plot similar to the notorious St. Valentine's Day massacre. Al Capone (nicknamed ``Scarface'') was feuding for control of Chicago's bootlegging operations. On the morning of Feb. 14, 1929, four men - two dressed as police officers, raided rival George ``Bugs''Moran's garage headquarters. They lined up the men against a wall feigning a routine frisk, but instead shattered their bodies with bullets. ``More and more is the realization growing that pictures can and do play an all-important part in the cultural and educational development of the world,'' said Jack Warner, the studio chief at Warner Bros., which produced most of the gangster films. ``I do not mean we should strive for so-called intellectual films, but we should strive for pictures that provide something more than a mere idle hour or two of entertainment.'' This was tabloid moviemaking, 90 minutes (or less) of screaming headlines, random violence and sex as gentle as a grapefruit in the kisser. Asked how Camonte (Muni) got the scar on his face, an associate snapped, ``In a war - with a blonde in a Brooklyn speakeasy.'' Darryl Zanuck, the young production chief at Warner's, was the mastermind behind many of the best gangster films, including ``Little Caesar'' and ``Doorway to Hell.'' Of Cagney's character in ``The Public Enemy,'' he boasted: ``Every other underworld picture has had a thug with a little bit of good in him. He reforms before the fade-out. This guy is no good at all. It'll go big.'' Warner's churned out product like a machine gun spitting bullets. Films were often completed in less than three weeks, with directors rushing from set to set and writers at times working on 10 projects at the same time. Cagney once made six pictures in a span of 40 weeks. Some of Hollywood's biggest stars began as tough guys and ``molls.'' Spencer Tracy appeared in a series of gangster films, notably ``Quick Millions,'' when he was under contract to Fox in the early 1930s. At MGM, Clark Gable was a gangster in several films, edging just slightly toward the right side of the law as he became more famous. Jean Harlow had a supporting role in ``The Public Enemy,'' Bette Davis appeared opposite Tracy in ``20,000 Years in Sing Sing'' and Cagney in ``Jimmy the Gent,'' and Barbara Stanwyck was no angel as the star of ``Baby Face.'' But by 1933, the first run of gangster films was soon over. In 1933, the repeal of Prohibition ended the bootlegging wars and the following year the Hays Office's production code called for the violence to be toned down and demanded a stop to all the ``passions that stimulate the baser emotions.'' Gangsters remained on the screen, but soon the best films were often parodies (``A Slight Case of Murder''), reflections on aging (``High Sierra'') or chronicles of a time (``The Roaring Twenties'') when silver tongues and deadly bullets gave small-time hustlers the chance to be big shots. ``Out of this mix of energy, suspicion, gloom, iconoclasm and liberalism came not only a distinctive kind of film, but also a distinctive vision of America - particularly urban America,'' Gabler wrote. ``It was a . . . world where one's only hope and only meaning lay not in higher morals, not in love, not in family, not in sacrifice, but in action leavened by a sense of honor.'' Camonte, with a reassuring pat to his coat pocket, put it another way: ``In this business, there's only one law you gotta follow to keep out of trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Trying To Make Souter the Benchmark Conservative Appointment
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Although David H. Souter isn't their kind of Supreme Court justice, some influential Senate Democrats are trying to make him a benchmark, advising President Bush that they'll fight any future nominee who is markedly more conservative. The advice accompanied overwhelming Senate consent to Souter, who takes his Supreme Court seat on Tuesday. Democrats said they couldn't expect a more moderate choice from Bush - but wouldn't accept one with more restrictive constitutional views. They may not have a lot of choice. As Republicans were quick to note, Bush won the right to nominate judges by winning the White House in 1988. One Republican said it was all an opening salvo in the next round over the Supreme Court. Bush will likely appoint more than one justice, certainly if he wins a second term in 1992. Therein lies the problem for Democrats trying to keep the court from turning more sharply to the right. It already has turned, since seven of the nine justices were nominated by Republican presidents. ``That pendulum swings,'' reflects Justice Harry A. Blackmun, a Republican appointee but an ally of the dwindling liberal bloc on issues like abortion and affirmative action, the agenda by which the spectrum now is defined. He is one of two justices over 80 and he sees a swing to the right as a change that will last for generations. ``It will stay that way now for 40 or 50 years, I'm sure,'' he said in an interview earlier this year, before the retirement of Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the man Souter succeeds. Souter was approved 90 to 9 last Tuesday. The opposition votes came from liberal Democrats, who fear that he will tip the court toward reversal of its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. But theirs was no more than a protest vote because Bush never would name a justice who would satisfy liberals on that point. In Souter, they got a nominee with no clear statements or prior rulings on the issue, so nobody knows how he'd rule. He said he has no agenda on abortion, and would listen to the arguments before making up his mind on any ruling. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., who ran the Souter hearings and voted for confirmation, said that if Bush were to nominate someone opposed to abortion rights, the odds on confirmation would drop to even at best. But Biden also said that if the Democratic Senate were to reject nominees who weren't committed to abortion rights, there would be an impasse and ``an eight-man court for as long as the president is president ... ``He obviously has no intention of submitting, and will never submit, a nominee who adheres to my very different point of view on this matter,'' said Biden, who supports abortion. ``I know that and we all know that.'' Biden said that Bush should not read the wrong message into the overwhelming vote for Souter. The vote doesn't guarantee easy confirmation for future nominees, he said, adding ``hardliners who believe that the Constitution is meant to be read very narrowly'' would not be acceptable. That's easier said than enforced, even with a Democratic majority in the Senate. When the Senate voted 58 to 42 to reject Robert H. Bork three years ago, it was dealing with a high-profile political target - a man with sharp, confrontational, conservative positions. And the vote followed a month of campaigning, complete with television commercials, by a liberal coalition opposed to Bork. But there was not a single Senate vote against the confirmation of President Ronald Reagan's other three court nominees, all conservatives, all approved unanimously. With Biden and other Democrats arguing that Souter is as far right as Bush should dare go, Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, protested what he said ``appears to be in large part a thinly-veiled, extraordinary, unfortunate and, in my view, unconvincing effort to set the parameters'' on future nominees. Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., said a president has the right to his choice unless opponents of confirmation can prove a nominee unfit. The Democrats don't buy that - at least when Republicans hold the White House. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., who opposed Souter because of his philosophy, argued the opposite case 23 years ago, when President Lyndon B. Johnson named Thurgood Marshall to the court. Kennedy said then that the Senate should consider the background, temperament, qualifications and integrity, not whether the views of a Supreme Court nominee coincide with their own. Thurmond was one of the 11 senators who voted against Marshall's confirmation in 1967. Inconsistency is bipartisan. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Rehab Center Reneges on Smoking Ban
DOC.TEXT: When Robin D. was in her late 20s fighting heroin addiction, Gateway Rehabilitation Center allowed smoking. She kicked heroin, but she couldn't kick cigarettes. Last summer, Robin died of emphysema. She was 43. ``That just pushed me over the brink,'' Gateway's co-founder and medical director, Dr. Abraham Twerski, said. Her death strengthened his determination to help alcoholics and drug users stop smoking cigarettes, which he noted kill more Americans than all other drugs combined. So last October the 139-bed center 20 miles northwest of Pittsburgh repainted its yellowed walls and banned smoking by patients and staff. But after effectively treating drug and alcohol abusers for 18 years, the ban lasted just eight months. ``It was easy to write a policy. It was hard to make it work,'' Neil Capretto, director of treatment, said. At first, Gateway treated nicotine like any other mood-altering substance. ``You use - you're kicked out,'' Sharon Eakes, director of therapy programs, said. Patients, whose last names are abbreviated to protect their privacy, argued and pleaded. Alcoholic Joe M. begged through tears to be admitted to Gateway's relapse program and be allowed to smoke, and Ms. Eakes had to turn him away. Fuming patients demanded the right to smoke. During one community meeting, one patient threatened to call in the American Civil Liberties Union, Ms. Eakes said. Leeann Unitas, patient evaluator, remembered the feeling among patients as: ``Not right now. I can't do everything at the same time.'' Gateway held its ground and many patients held theirs, smoking on the sly under the threat of dismissal. And they lapsed into addictive behaviors: - Family and friends smuggled in tobacco. - People drove up to the center at odd hours, dropped off packages and sped away. - A black market developed in which a single cigarette sold for $3 to $5. - Nicotine products were hidden in toilets, ceilings, radios and even body cavities. - Patients went AWOL to walk to the corner gas station to buy cigarettes. ``They were sneaking out at night, climbing out of windows,'' Capretto said. The risks were great. For some, Gateway is the last chance to salvage a relationship with a spouse fed up with drug abuse or to keep a job where the boss has warned to dry out or move on. Knowing what was at stake and seeing toughness fail, administrators softened and allowed illicit smokers two warnings before cutting them loose. But the change just created an extra level of bureaucracy with lists of patients warned once and twice. The smoking and dismissals coninued. The policy grated on staff members, too. Employees who quit smoking felt the same pressure and frustration as the patients. Among the workers were recovering drug users who didn't appreciate being treated like addicts again. ``It was as if they were being told their recovery didn't count,'' Ms. Eakes said. Employees smoked at home, then felt guilty enforcing Gateway's rule against patients. Sympathetic staffers pretended not to see patients smoking, Ms. Eakes said. For her, the last straw came when a convict ordered by the court to lose his addiction was kicked out of Gateway. He had been caught walking down the road to K mart for cigarettes, she said. The man went back to jail - for smoking. By May, the dropout rate had tripled and the non-profit treatment center was losing money. More importantly, values were at stake. The quality that Gateway tries hardest to instill in patients fighting addictive behavior - honesty - was being undermined. Today, Gateway holds to a tenuous compromise, created in part after officials learned at a convention last spring that other ``smoke-free'' clinics allowed smoking in restricted areas. Patients are not permitted to smoke during lectures or group therapy, which take up most of their time. But they may smoke in their leisure time in a designated area outdoors. ``That's going to hurt a lot of people,'' said Darryl S., a coal miner who managed to kick alcohol and cigarettes in a four-week program at Gateway. ``Every few days, I think about it,'' he said. ``You do something for so long. You pick a cup of coffee up - well, a cigarette goes with it.'' But the urge passes in 30 or 40 seconds, he said. Now proudly nicotine- and alcohol-free, he spends more time with his family and rides a bicycle nearly every day. Terry S., 49, hung in and also kicked nicotine and alcohol at Gateway. But the tobacco lure proved too strong for Terry, an accounting manager in West Virginia with his own office and plenty of opportunity to puff his usual 30 cigarettes a day. ``Today, I'm smoking,'' he said. ``I don't know if it's the pressure or the stress. I would truly like to quit.'' It could take years, but Twerski hopes to try again to establish a truly smoke-free clinic. ``We're looking as to what happened. It's all very recent. We've got to do our homework,'' he said. ``I still hope to go for the full loaf.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 8

DOC.HEAD: New Research Links Cholesterol Cutting With Violent Death
DOC.TEXT: Doctors have long felt justified urging Americans to lower their cholesterol. Even though many of them probably won't benefit, cutting fat out of the diet certainly cannot hurt anyone. Or can it? Evidence is mounting that people who lower their cholesterol do indeed reduce their risk of dying from heart disease. But a new report concludes that is completely offset by a striking increase in another way of death. For reasons no one can explain, when people reduce their cholesterol, they seem to become more likely to die from accidents, suicides, murders and other violent tragedies. ``The questions about adverse effects of cholesterol reduction are not at all answered,'' said Dr. Matthew F. Muldoon, who directed the study. ``That causes a lot of problems for the strategy that you give cholesterol reduction to everybody because it doesn't do any harm. That can't be said with much confidence.'' Could it be that by at least one measure, lowering cholesterol does as much harm as good? The discovery is so difficult to understand that experts are cautioning people against suddenly going back to wolfing down slabs of roast beef and gobs of ice cream. Stick to the low-fat regimen, they urge, until they sort out what's happening. ``It's an interesting and disturbing phenomenon,'' said Dr. John LaRosa, dean for research at George Washington University Medical Center. ``Expressing concern is appropriate but not making policy changes based on this.'' Health policy rarely changes as a result of a single study. And in this case, Muldoon and a few other skeptics are up against the inertia of public belief in the evils of cholesterol as well as the interests of a corps of influential heart specialists who want to change Americans' way of eating. Hints that lower cholesterol is linked with some forms of cancer and strokes have not cooled anti-cholesterol zeal. Neither have niggling doubts about whether old people, women and children need to worry about their cholesterol. The chief vehicle for promoting the mainstream view is the government's 5-year-old National Cholesterol Education Program. Its goal is to persuade people to get their cholesterol checked, eat less saturated fat and lower their average cholesterol level by 10 percent. ``It is a very prudent public health policy,'' said Dr. James Cleeman, the program's coordinator. ``This study does not shake my confidence in the wisdom of that approach.'' Nonetheless, the latest research increases doubts for some. ``The finding that there is no clear benefit in total mortality is of concern,'' said Dr. Paul Meier, a tatistician at the University of Chicago. ``It's cause for being more circumspect in insisting that everybody has got to get his cholesterol down.'' Lowering cholesterol reduces the risk of heart attacks. Since heart attacks kill 500,000 Americans a year, many assume that lower cholesterol also helps people live longer. But proof is skimpy. Several studies that have delved into the health effects of cholesterol reduction have been too small or too short to yield definite conclusions. So Muldoon, a University of Pittsburgh researcher, decided to combine results of several studies to see if a statistically meaningful picture emerges. His report, published recently in the British Medical Journal, joined the statistics of six comparison studies conducted on a total of 24,847 healthy men. These people either reduced their cholesterol levels an average of 10 percent or carried on without change. Muldoon calculates that for every 100,000 people who cut their cholesterol, there are 28 fewer deaths each year from heart disease. But there are also 29 more deaths from suicides, homicides and accidents. Thus, as many lives are lost as are saved. ``It hasn't been a large enough increase to cause a national cry of alarm, but anybody carefully analyzing the facts has to be concerned about it,'' said Dr. Thomas James, president of the medical branch of the University of Texas at Galveston. One of the most puzzling aspects of this discovery is that there is no obvious scientific explanation. Muldoon raises three possibilities: - Cholesterol is an important ingredient of the body's cells. Perhaps lowering the body's supply changes brain chemistry and behavior, and this somehow makes people more reckless or aggressive. - People find it ``chronically frustrating'' to give up the food they like, and this also makes them more apt to die tragically. - The cholesterol-lowering drugs tested in the studies tasted awful and caused intestinal problems. ``There may be a susceptible group of folks where this pushes them over the edge,'' Muldoon said. Actually, the study's findings are no surprise to people who have followed the major cholesterol experiments of the 1980s. The first strong evidence that lowering cholesterol cuts the risk of heart disease came in 1984 when researchers finished the Lipid Research Clinics Coronary Primary Prevention Trial. Men who took cholesterol-lowering drugs in this experiment reduced their heart disease rate by 19 percent, but they didn't live longer. While they experienced eight fewer coronary deaths than a comparison group, they suffered seven more violent deaths. At the time, researchers dismissed the increase in violent deaths as a statistical fluke. There was no obvious connection among these unfortunate people. One was murdered. Others committed suicide. Some died in car accidents, including ones in which they were not even behind the wheel. However, three years later, the Helsinki Heart Study found something similar: 11 violent deaths in those with lower cholesterol, four in the comparison group. In all, researchers have conducted six studies to test the effects of lowering cholesterol alone on otherwise healthy people. When Muldoon combined their results, he found the chance of dying from suicide or violence nearly doubled after cholesterol reduction. Muldoon said other lines of research also have suggested links between behavioral problems and cholesterol. Unusually low cholesterol levels have been seen in criminals, murderers and people with aggressive conduct disorders or poor self-control. A study by Dr. J.R. Kaplan of Bowman Gray School of Medicine looked at the effects f cholesterol on monkeys. He found that animals fed a low-fat diet like the one recommended by the American Heart Association to lower their cholesterol committed 50 percent more aggressive acts than did those eating fat levels closer to the typical American diet. Even if Muldoon's theory is correct, backers of the war on cholesterol argue that too much is made of death. By warding off heart attacks, cholesterol reduction saves money, reduces misery and helps people lead healthier lives. Dr. William Castelli, director of the Framingham Heart Study, said Muldoon ``is trying to make the public believe that all that happens to you is death. Well, it's the least that happens to you. ``When you have your heart attack, you're not going to die,'' he said. ``You're going to be alive and chronically ill for the rest of your life. We can prevent that.''

DOC.HEAD: Fluoride Controversy Far from Over
DOC.TEXT: Public Enemy No. 1. A communist plot. Nerve-poison. In the 1950s, opponents of fluoridation marshaled rhetoric and research to fight what they called the poisoning of public water supplies. Some doctors linked fluoride to indigestion, deafness, and skin and mental diseases. Today, fluoride is mainstream. Toothpaste tubes blare it. Bottled drinks and mouth rinses contain it, and doctors recommend it. Sixty-one percent of Americans live in communities with fluoridated public water. But the debate is far from over. Take Jody Morgenegg, who gathered signatures and handed out fliers seeking to stop the Scotia village board from putting fluoride in the water system. ``It's carcinogenic,'' she said. ``We feel it's not appropriate to adulterate the water with it.'' Or Jim Palmer, one of several board trustees who voted to fluoridate village water earlier this year: ``It's going to protect the children in the years their teeth are really forming.'' The board won, and Scotia has been fluoridating its water since March. Most major American health organizations - including the U.S. Public Health Service, the American Dental Association and the American Medical Association - have endorsed fluoridation, and cite hundreds of studies that show fluoride reduces dental caries. Most health organizations recommend one part per million when fluoridating drinking water. ``It's a safe and effective means of preventing tooth decay,'' said Darrell Sanders, fluoridation engineer with the federal Centers for Disease Control. But a vocal minority condemns fluoride as an industrial waste product that not only mottles teeth, but kills thousands of people every year. ``If you're drinking fluoridated water for 20, 30 years, you're probably increasing your cancer risks by 5 to 15 percent,'' John Yiamouyiannis, a biochemist in Delaware, Ohio, said. This year, debate over fluoride rose a notch with the release of a study by the National Toxicology Program showing that some male rats given high doses of fluoride in water suffered higher rates of bone cancer than rats and mice on lower doses. The author of the study, Dr. John Bucher, said the results provided only ``equivocal evidence'' that fluoride is linked to cancer. Scientists first linked the mottling of teeth to fluoride early this century in parts of the Southwest. They found the condition - often called ``Colorado brown stain'' or ``Texas teeth'' and known today as fluorosis - in places with high natural levels of fluoride in drinking water. Fluoride, a compound of the element fluorine, is found in rocks and soil and in at least trace amounts in natural water supplies. Later research among children, including pilot studies in Newburgh, N.Y., and Grand Rapids, Mich., in the 1940s, showed that controlled amounts of fluoride in water sharply reduced tooth decay. At first, scientists were unclear why. Today, fluoride is believed to reduce the solubility of enamel in acid and can remineralize enamel that has suffered decay. Since then, fluoridation has spread. The Pennsylvania Legislature is considering a bill that would require most water companies in the state to fluoridate. At least eight other states have passed similar bills, said Dr. H. William Gross, chairman of Partners For Better Oral Health, a coalition of groups backing the Pennsylvania bill. The reduction in dental caries in the decades since fluoride was introduced is substantial. The rate of tooth decay has declined by as much as 75 percent to 80 percent since the 1940s, according to a 1988 study by the National Institute for Dental Research. But opponents of fluoridation attribute the decline to better infant nutrition and dental hygiene, and contend most of the studies linking fluoride to tooth decay reduction are biased. Instead, they say fluoride is a lethal by-product of the phosphate industry. Dr. Albert Burgstahler, a professor at the University of Kansas, said he has treated people for ``fluoridation poisoning'' - chronic fatigue, headaches and gastrointestinal problems. ``When patients switch to non-fluoridated water, they found that their symptoms cleared up,'' Burgstahler said. ``It's the non-specific syndrome,'' said Stephen Corbin, a dental public health specialist with the CDC. ``None of that stuff has been attributed to fluoridation exposure.''

DOC.HEAD: More Colleges Responding to Vegetarians' Needs
DOC.TEXT: Vegetarian students considering colleges have to look at more than just the course catalog. At some schools they could be end up surviving on salad bars and peanut butter, while at others, entire dining rooms are devoted to vegetarian food. ``Food service directors are really working hard in meeting each segment of the student population's expectations,'' said Clark Dehaven of the National Association of College and University Food Service in East Lansing, Mich. Vegetarian eating has grown slowly but steadily over the last decade in colleges, Dehaven said, but Vegetarian Times magazine said it could find no public high schools that have developed vegetarian menus. An estimated 8 million to 9 million Americans are vegetarians. The Marriott Corp., which provides food for about 400 colleges, offers at least one vegetarian entree at lunch and dinner in addition to salad bars and yogurts, spokeswoman Kathy Boyle said. The company had about a dozen vegetarian recipes in its menu rotation 15 years ago, and now has about 50, including carrot loaf with pea sauce, curried vegetables with beans and sunflower seeds, and vegetable quiche, she said. ``I think it's a matter of taking the time and investing the time in the students and developing a program,'' said Paul Tuennerman, director of dining services for Morrison Custom Management, which provides the food at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania. ``A year and a half ago, I thought a vegetarian entree was rice with cheese on it,'' he said. Then Tuennerman began meeting with vegetarian students, reading books and testing recipes. Now the school serves such dishes as tofu Oriental salad, carrot loaf, eggplant con queso, and Moroccan stew with yams, raisins, carrots and other vegetables. There are two vegetarian choices at every meal, one of them vegan, meaning no animal products of any kind. Lacto-ovo vegttarians eat no flesh but do eat eggs and dairy products. At Oberlin College's lacto-ovo ``veggie dining hall,'' there also is a vegan option for lunches and every other dinner, said dietitian Rebecca Stotter. About 20 percent of Oberlin's 2,200 students eat vegetarian, and there's usually a waiting list for the dining hall, she said. ``We're finding more students are wanting strict vegan entrees. Health reasons, possibly ethical reasons, too,'' Stotter said. ``It seems to me that it's increasing. ... I do think more colleges are offering vegetarian options.'' Yale University has served vegetarian food since the early 1970s, but only started offering a vegan menu in the spring of 1989, said Karen Dougherty, executive dietitian for the division of dining halls. ``We have noticed that students are eating down the food chain,'' Dougherty said. ``They are eating less beef and more chicken and fish. And the vegetarian students are eating more vegan dishes.'' But at some places, there may not be much more than ``rabbit'' food. ``I think a lot of places right now are like that,'' said Lige Weill of the Vegetarian Awareness Network, a Washington-based non-profit organization that disseminates information about vegetarianism. Cindy Meyers, a sophomore at the University of Kentucky at Lexington, is collecting signatures on a petition in an effort to get more vegetarian food in the cafeterias at her school. Last year, she said, ``I'd eat the same things every day - salad potatoes, that sort of thing.'' But she said she is finding less variety in the cafeteria she frequents this year. ``It's not only that there aren't many choices like vegetarian lasagne, but it's also green beans cooked in bacon or that sort of thing that you don't know about,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Self-Esteem and Exercise: Can Workouts Give You Good Vibes?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on sports wires as BC-Lifestyle Sports.
DOC.TEXT: After a strenuous workout, you can feel proud - and not just because you survived. Exercise, some researchers say, might improve your self-esteem - although they say you can't bank on it. ``All I have is anecdotal information, and it appears those who persist in exercise say, `Yeah, it enhances self-esteem,' '' said Wynn F. Updyke, associate dean of health, physical education and recreation at Indiana University in Bloomington. Updyke is setting up a study to check the relationship between exercise and self-esteem. He and his colleagues intend to give physical and psychological tests to about 800 students from fourth grade on, for at least three years. They want to study changes over time so they can search for possible cause and effect. The researchers plan to test the idea that confidence in a student's physical abilities generalizes into confidence about himself, and they want to see if improved exercise performance generalizes into better grades. Previous research generally has reported that people who exercise tend to have higher self-esteem, said Robert J. Sonstroem, a professor of physical education at the University of Rhode Island. However, it hasn't been proved if exercise causes a change - and, assuming it does, how important exercise is compared with other causes, he said. Although Sonstroem believes exercise might raise a person's opinion of his body, which could lead to higher overall self-esteem, others are less certain. ``I think that question is still out,'' said Don Hellison, a professor of physical education at California State University at Chico. ``Do we think about ourselves in a holistic way, or in terms of roles and abilities?'' Self-esteem about physical appearance, fitness and competence in sports might correlate with each other without generalizing into an overall feeling, said Hellison, who is working with Updyke to plan the study. Another issue is that self-esteem seems to have a lot of behavioral roots, making it difficult to find a measurement system that can tease the roots apart, Updyke said. In physical education, for instance, ``it's never just exercise, it's always sports or some other sort of skillful activity,'' he said. The fitness tests to be used in the study will try to reduce the skill component by including such standard laboratory measures as stationary bicycle riding, Updyke said. If the results are positive, they may indicate something else about self-esteem - that trying and succeeding is good for your emotional health, Updyke said. If that's the case, then programs to improve self-esteem through exercise might empower disadvantaged students to take charge of their lives in other areas, the research outline said. For that matter, Sonstroem said, the amount of exercise you do may be less important than how you feel about your accomplishments in doing it. ``Nothing succeeds like success with self-esteem,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Expert: Rural Hospitals on Critical List
DOC.TEXT: Rural hospitals that don't adopt some of the strategies of their big-city rivals have little hope of fiscal recovery, a federal health expert said. ``Rural hospitals need to develop more aggressive marketing strategies, using radio and television at times, as well as aggressive community campaigns,'' said Jeffrey Human, executive director of the Office of Rural Health Policy for the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. ``Hospitals need to be promoted within their communities,'' said Human. ``And citizens need to know that if they don't support their hospitals, they'll lose them and the access to health care they can afford.'' Human said one in 10 rural hospitals closed in the last decade. Six hundred of the remaining 2,500 are in dire fiscal condition, he said at a state rural health conference last month. ``The consequences of the closure of a rural hospital to local residents are almost always more significant than the closure of one of many urban hospitals,'' said Human. Contributing to the failing health of rural hospitals, he said, are: - Rural hospitals are paid 25 percent less than urban hospitals when reimbursed by Medicare for comparable procedures. - Falling admissions caused, in part, by physicians referring patients to urban hospitals. - A large percentage of rural patients unable to pay hospital bills. - Shortage of doctors, nurses and other professionals. ---
DOC.HEAD: Tlingit Fish Trap May Provide Glimpse Into Indian History
DOC.TEXT: The remains of a 700-year-old fish trap may shed some light on the history of the Tlingit Indians in southeastern Alaska. A fisherman found the trap along an eroding bank of Montana Creek last year. A curved and fragile section of the basket trap is being kept in a plastic tub filled with water at the Alaska State Museum because it is too delicate to expose to air, which would reduce it to dust. Root lashings on the trap disappeared before workers' eyes when exposed to the air, said Steve Henkriskon, museum collections curator. The surging creek, a tributary of the Mendenhall River, apparently covered the trap with mud and silt hundreds of years ago. The mud cut off oxygen, helping to preserve the trap, Henrikson said. After collaborating with several agencies and organizations, Henrikson and archaeologist Wally Olson removed one-third of the trap from the water in May. The rest remains buried under a protective layer of mud. Recent carbon testing dated the cylindrical trap to sometime between 1270 and 1410 more than 300 years before Russian explorer Vitus Bering came to Alaska. The techniques Tlingits used to build the traps have been lost, said Steve Langdon, an anthropologist at the University of Alaska Anchorage. Jon Erlandson, an anthropology professor at the University of Oregon, said the trap has the potential to tell anthropologists how the devices were constructed. Erlandson and his wife, anthropologist Madonna Moss, formerly worked at the University of Alaska Fairbanks and have seen the trap at the museum. He said the trap is clearly a Tlingit artifact, likely from the Auke Tlingit Indians. The Montana Creek trap also may help settle a debate about when the Tlingits settled in southeastern Alaska. Some historians contend they were relative newcomers, settling in the area as recently as 300 years ago. But some anthropologists believe Tlingits may have settled in the region as long as 3,000 years ago.

DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan endorsed the $500 billion deficit-reduction package, telling Congress that failure to approve it would have serious consequences for an already weakened U.S. economy. Greenspan's views were considered crucial to chances for success by the Bush administration, which hopes the Fed will support the pact by lowering interest rates. Greenspan did not specifically promise to lower interest rates but he replied with an emphatic ``most certainly'' when asked Wednesday whether he believed an enacted budget agreement would exert downward pressure on rates. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An ill-advised excursion into risky investments, not the high interest rates used to tame inflation early in the 1980s, caused the savings and loan debacle late in the decade, former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker said. ``The industry could have survived that episode (of high interest rates) and the great bulk of it did,'' Volcker told the House Banking Committee on Wednesday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Rising oil prices from the Persian Gulf crisis helped push up the value of orders to factories for manufactured goods 1.8 percent in August, the government reported. Analysts said Wednesday that the oil-inflated boost disguised the weakness in the industrial sector. ``To me, the number excluding petroleum is consistent with our view that the economy is sliding and slipping into a recession,'' said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist with the Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The judge presiding over the government's conflict-of-interest case against Neil Bush went against professional ethics by talking to reporters about the case, some legal experts say. But the administrative law judge, Daniel J. Davidson, said his remarks didn't prejudice the case or indicate that he leans ``one way or the other.'' In two newspaper interviews published just before the start of a public hearing on regulators' charges against the president's son, Davidson called the savings and loan case ``a pain,'' ``a political football'' and ``one of the minor ones'' from a legal standpoint. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Four transactions prosecutors have chosen to prove that Michael Milken made a career of lawbreaking have one thing in common: They all involve taking advantage of clients. Legal experts said Wednesday that the theme contrasts starkly with the defense portrait of the junk bond financier now and in the past as a man who made a few mistakes to better serve his customers. In picking its silver bullets for a mini-trial that begins next week on allegations to which Milken has not pleaded guilty, the government wants to challenge defense claims that Milken's crimes were aberrant. --- NEW YORK - Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. unveiled an ambitious plan to improve profitability that assumes Campeau Corp.'s U.S. retailers will emerge from bankruptcy next year. The business plan for the years through 1996 includes selected store closings, but no outright sales of entire department store chains. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Goldman, Sachs & Co. has formed a large fund to invest in debt-laden companies, becoming one of the first prominent Wall Street brokerages to see opportunity in the excesses of the 1980s. The venerable firm said Wednesday that since April, it has raised $683 million for the fund from major U.S. and foreign pension funds, international banks, university endowments, insurance companies and individuals. In addition, the firm contributed $100 million of its own capital and will serve as general partner of the fund, called the Water Street Corp. Recovery Fund I, L.P. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The United States and Canada will open negotiations early next year on deregulating air traffic between the two countries, their transportation agencies say. Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner told reporters the talks could include the possibility of permitting Canadian airlines to open hubs in the United States and American air carriers to open hubs in Canada. Deregulated cross-border flights could expand traffic between the United States and Canada by 15 percent, officials said Wednesday. ---

The stock market retreated near the close of a quiet session Wednesday, faced with revived upward pressure on oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished with a 15.84-point loss at 2,489.36. The dollar fell, while gold bounced higher. On other commodity markets, copper futures rallied; grains and soybeans advanced; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher. Bonds closed mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Debating Whether It's Hit Economic Trough
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Is Britain, Europe's economic miracle of the 1980s, in a recession? It depends whom you ask. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says no. She criticizes ``voices of gloom'' for exaggerating ``short-term economic difficulties,'' and insists interest rates will stay high until the 10.6 percent inflation rate is tamed. But many business people and economists say yes. Britain's largest employers group, the Confederation of British Industry, is calling for a cut in 15 percent interest rates to ``to ensure that the recession is not any deeper than it needs to be.'' ``Britain's economy is in a recession and there is now room for a gradual easing in interest rates,'' said David Kern, chief economist of National Westminster Bank. Britons have enjoyed eight years of sustained economic growth, which was thought to have ended a cycle of high inflation and high interest rates. Now the country is suffering what many economists call the same old symptoms, and is putting in the worst performance of the major industrialized countries. The generally accepted definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of negative or zero economic growth. One of the difficulties, however, is pinpointing when a recession has begun. Mrs. Thatcher, addressing the Welsh Confederation of British Industry last week, complained that newspapers already have proclaimed the beginning of a world recession, ``a return to stagflation and an end to the United Kingdom economic miracle.'' She said every new statistic, including the latest monthly survey by the Confederation of British Industry, is interpreted as heralding ``the onset of a major economic downturn.'' The confederation survey showed confidence in Britain's manufacturing had hit the lowest point in eight years and provided clear evidence the economy had moved into recession. ``Business risks talking itself into a completely unjustified mood of doom and gloom, a kind of artificial psychological trough,'' Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe said last week. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said the word recession implies a slump as deep as the Great Depression. ``We are not in those sorts of circumstances,'' he said. ``We have a significant but necessary slowdown at the moment.'' But Karl Otto Poehl, president of Germany's Bundesbank, or central bank, disagrees. ``The U.K. is already in a recession,'' he said last week. Kern of National Westminister Bank said the recession signals include a rise of 20,000 in the number of jobless in August, up from 13,000 in July, and a Dun & Bradstreet Corp. report of a 35 percent increase in business failures in the first nine months of 1990, to the highest number in a decade. He predicts economic growth will fall 0.8 percent in the third quarter and 1 percent in the fourth. The economists offered one consolation: that the setback won't be as bad as last time around. During the last recession, which began in the first quarter of 1980, economic contraction lasted five straight quarters. ``It bears absolutely no comparison with 1980-1981, which was more painful,'' said Kevin Darlington, an economist at the London investment firm UBS Phillips and Drew. If interest rates come down, Britain's economy could recover next year, the economists say.

DOC.HEAD: Mutual Fund Performance Confirms Tough Economic Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Mutual Funds-List
Graphics
DOC.TEXT: The millions of Americans who sock away money in mutual funds didn't escape the pain and suffering on Wall Street during the past three months. In addition to taking a toll on the blue chips of the Dow Jones industrial average, the quarter that ended Sunday belted funds across the board. The Persian Gulf and the weakening economy were to blame. ``There were very few places to hide in the third quarter,'' said Michael Lipper, whose company, Lipper Analytical Securities Corp., released its quarterly performance report on nearly 1,800 mutual funds Wednesday. Lipper groups the funds into 27 categories based on the type of investments they make, such as growth stocks or corporate bonds. Two-thirds of these groups performed as poorly as they did in past recessions. And the worst may be yet to come. ``If we look at our measures of prior down markets compared with the present, there may be more to go,'' Lipper said in an interview. Mutual funds are a popular way for individuals to invest in the stock, bond and money markets. By pooling the money of many investors, mutual funds can buy a wider variety of securities than could a single investor, limiting the risk should any of the investments go bad. Lipper's figures were for funds that invest in stocks and taxable bonds. They did not include money market mutual funds, a popular investment alternative to savings accounts, or funds that invest in tax-exempt government bonds. Among the funds in the ranking, those that invest in stocks fared the worst during the third quarter, declining an average of 15.5 percent. That compares with a gain of 5.9 percent in the second quarter. By comparison, the 30-stock Dow Jones average had a negative return of about 14 percent during the quarter, assuming dividends were reinvested, while Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, another popular gauge of the stock market, lost 13.7 percent, Lipper said. A decline in stock funds also was not surprising given the unusually strong performance of these funds in the 1980s, Lipper said. The top-ranked fund in the 10 years ended Sept. 30, Fidelity Investment's Magellan fund, grew 622.7 percent, which he called ``unsustainably high.'' The Iraqi standoff also took a toll on many bond funds during the quarter, since bond prices are extremely sensitive to the inflation caused by higher oil prices. Funds that invest in long-term, taxable bonds declined 0.8 percent on average during the quarter, compared with a gain of 3.2 percent in the second quarter. The only groups of funds that grew were so-called world income funds, which invest primarily in corporate bonds worldwide, and gold funds, which buy stock of gold mining companies as well as gold bullion and coins. Both were up about about 4 percent. However, individual funds in other groupings also rose, including funds that invest in energy companies that benefitted from the oil price runup, Lipper said. Among the losers were funds that invest in science and technology companies, financial services, environmental companies and small businesses, he said. So what should an investor do? David McLaughlin, a financial adviser with Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottseville, Va., said that depends on the objective of the investment. If it's for retirement, it may be safe to stay in stock funds, since the long-term trend of the stock market is up despite periodic slumps. These investors should look for funds that have a good record in bear markets, he said. But for shorter-term investments, consider short- and medium-term government securities, McLaughlin said. Signs of a looming economic downturn were evident at the end of the second quarter, Lipper said, when half of the Lipper fund groups were performing as they did in previous recessions. Now, with two-thirds of them performing this way, there is no doubt about the state of the economy, he said. But there's some short-term positive news for fund investors, he said. ``We're down far enough that we can have a rally in this fourth quarter'' as some investors sense the fund prices are cheap enough to make them attractive, he said. During the third quarter, the top-performing fund was Dreyfus' Capital Value fund, up nearly 13 percent in total return. For the year ended Sept. 30, the top gainer was Equity Strategies, a small fund that invests in bankrupt companies and is closed to new investors. The worst performer for the quarter and the year ended Sept. 30 was the Prudent Speculator: Leveraged fund, which plummeted almost 47 percent for the quarter and 51 percent for the year. The fund borrows money to make its investors' money go further, increasing its risk in a down market, Lipper said. For the past 10 years, the worst-performing fund was the 44 Wall Street Fund, which dropped almost 83 percent in return. Lipper called it a ``stock-picking fund'' that has had a ``checkered career.''
