DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Seeks New Tax Shelters
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to give $11.1 billion in new tax breaks to small corporations is being criticized as opening the door for wealthy investors to duck their share of federal taxes. The Bush administration is pushing the new incentives as a substitute for the capital gains tax cut that congressional leaders refused to accept. Some of those leaders are suspicious of the substitute, which actually includes a small capital gains reduction. The proposal is attached to the $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction agreement that President Bush and congressional leaders reached this week. The tax break proposal ``has very serious flaws,'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said Wednesday. ``I think it will lead to a substantial increase in tax shelters and great abuse.'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, also has reservations. If the proposals ``are growth incentives, he thinks they promise only to help tax shelters grow,'' an aide said. Public outrage about tax sheltering was a major factor in the sweeping income tax overhaul in 1986. Before then, many wealthy individuals and profitable corporations were able to cut their taxes to almost zero by making investments - many with no chance of success - that offered huge up-front deductions. A Chamber of Commerce official said the new provisions could be drawn tightly enough to avoid reviving such tax shelters. Bush said the plan would provide ``powerful new incentives for productive investment in the kinds of companies that account for much of America's job growth.'' The key part would allow a person to deduct 25 percent of the first $50,000 invested in a year in a ``small corporation.'' Such a corporation would be defined as one with non-borrowed capital of $50 million or less. Critics said the definition is so broad it could cover some giant companies so heavily in debt that stockholder equity falls below the $50 million threshold. Others noted the possibility a big company could split into smaller divisions in an effort to attract investors looking for tax breaks. ``It's an outrage and probably stands a shot at being knocked out of the budget package,'' said Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-financed group. ``We don't see the need to encourage people to invest their money in ways that don't make sense for them in the absence of a tax incentive.'' The special deduction and several other small-corporation incentives were written into the budget agreement at the administration's insistence. That occurred after congressional leaders refused to accept Bush's proposal to cut the capital gains tax, on grounds that nearly 80 percent of the benefit would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. Capital gains, the profits from the sale of investments, are fully taxed at the same rates as other income. One of the proposed incentives is a new capital gains tax cut - albeit a narrow one. It would allow an investor in a small corporation to avoid tax on up to half the price for which the stock was sold, as long as it was held at least five years. Steve Entin, an analyst with the conservative Institute for Research Into Economics of Taxation, who wants a broad capital gains cut, said the incentive package is so narrowly drawn that it would benefit ``only a handful of well-to-do people who could afford to sink a substantial portion of their money into risky small companies.'' Ordinary investors have to diversify to reduce risks, Entin said, and there is little in the package for them.

DOC.HEAD: New Claims Common Thread: Milken Took Advantage of Clients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Milken-Charges-Glance
DOC.TEXT: The four transactions prosecutors have chosen to prove that Michael Milken made a career of lawbreaking have one thing in common: They all involve taking advantage of clients. Legal experts said that theme contrasts starkly with the defense portrait of the junk bond financier now and in the past as a man who made a few mistakes trying to better serve his customers. In picking its silver bullets for a mini-trial on allegations Milken has not been formally charged with or pleaded guilty to, he government wants to challenge a posture that Milken's crimes were aberrant. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood ordered the unusual proceeding so she could better understand Milken and devise an appropriate sentence. Three of the transactions involve some form of trading on nonpublic information available to Milken about a client - behavior now viewed as a sinister and deliberate breach and not a technical regulatory violation. Three of the allegations involve dealings with Ivan F. Boesky, the disgraced stock speculator who spent time in prison and gave the government the lion's share of its dirt on Milken. ``Contrary to his efforts to characterize the crimes he committed as petty, Milken's crimes were neither technical or victimless,'' the government said in its lengthy pre-sentencing memorandum. The Justice Department claims against Milken will be aired at the special hearing scheduled to begin Oct. 11 after Wood on Wednesday pushed back the start date by two days. They were included in the government's memorandum, designed to persuade Wood to sentence Milken to a long prison term. Milken, former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s high-yield bond department, faces a maximum 28 years in prison on six felonies to which he pleaded guilty in April after a nearly four-year investigation. The transactions to be taken up at the court hearing involve allegations of insider trading and other violations in trading securities of Caesar's World Inc., MGM-UA Entertainment Inc. and Storer Communications Inc., and manipulation of Wickes Cos. stock. In court papers, Milken's attorneys said their client did nothing wrong in the transactions. Prosecutors plan to call up to 14 witnesses to bolster their claims, including Boesky and several former Drexel employees. After Milken's guilty plea, his chief lawyer, Arthur Liman, noted that the six counts didn't involve insider trading and most of them were ``instances in which Michael went too far in helping clients.'' Now, the government is using legal precedent to offer the unproven claims at sentencing as evidence of years of wrongdoing. Judge Wood asked prosecutors to limit their presentation to under five of about 35 unproven crimes. ``The common denominator to the cases . . . is the government is able to allege a breach of Milken's and Drexel's duty to their client,'' John C. Coffee Jr., a Columbia University law professor who has followed the case closely, said Wednesday. ``They tend to line up not as overzealousness on behalf of the client but predatory behavior against a client,'' he said. For instance, the government claims Milken illegally used information from his role advising Turner Broadcasting System about its 1985 acquisition of MGM-UA in a stock trading scheme with Boesky that netted more than $3 million. By buying large amounts of MGM-UA stock when the deal looked good, the government alleges, Milken made handsome profits and generated a false sense of the deal's viability. When the deal appeared to sour, Milken and Boesky stopped buying, according to the government's pre-sentencing memo. Milken's attorneys say the charges aren't supported by the timing and prices of Boesky's stock purchases. In the Storer transaction, the government claims Milken and Boesky took advantage of a 1985 bidding war over the Drexel client to buy and sell the company's stock, making more than $1 million in profits. Milken's lawyers say the government's facts are wrong and Milken did nothing illegal. Court papers also allege Milken bribed money managers into buying risky Storer securities by selling other Storer securities at below market value. The government alleges thatcash proceeds from the Storer transactions surpassed $325 million, with Milken and another unidentified individual personally making $172 million in 1988. The Caesar's transaction alleges Milken in 1983 bought more than $3 million in securities of the company after meeting with Caesar's executives to discuss restructuring its debt. Drexel managed the restructuring. The defense memo said the government had offered a distorted picture of events in all the transactions and in some instances omitted evidence it has that would undermine the claims against Milken.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Milken-Charges
DOC.TEXT: Here are details of four alleged illegal transactions prosecutors claim were committed by junk bond financier Michael Milken that will be aired at a special court hearing starting next week. The allegations were contained in the government's pre-sentencing memorandum accusing the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. financier of widespread wrongdoing beyond the six felonies to which he has pleaded guilty.
DOC.HEAD: MGM-UA Entertainment Inc.
DOC.TEXT: The government alleges Milken tipped Ivan F. Boesky about the proposed 1985 acquisition of MGM-UA by Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which was receiving financial advice from Drexel and Milken. Boesky allegedly bought and sold MGM-UA securities at Milken's direction and later split more than $3 million in profits. The government says the trading enhanced the likelihood of the deal's success by creating artificial demand for MGM-UA stock and that Milken misappropriated information from Turner to generate illegal trading profits. Milken's attorneys say the charges aren't supported by the timing and prices of Boesky's stock purchases.
DOC.HEAD: Caesar's World Inc.
DOC.TEXT: The government claims Milken used nonpublic information to buy more than $3 million in Caesar's bonds in 1983 prior to announcement of debt restructuring managed by Drexel. The government says the bonds were bought by Drexel and sold two days later to Milken's personal retirement account. The government says the idea for a debt-for-stock swap was broached at a June 29, 1983, meeting among Milken, other Drexel executives and Caesar's representatives. The government claims Caesar's officials favored the idea and committed to it July 1; the defense maintains that didn't happen for a week. The bond purchases by Drexel were dated June 30 and in turn were sold to Milken a day later. Milken's lawyers said the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1985 investigated the trading and found no wrongdoing. They said Caesar's had not decided on a restructuring when Drexel made the purchases.
DOC.HEAD: Storer Communications Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors allege Boesky bought Storer securities in July 1985 after Milken tipped him about a proposed leveraged buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co., which hired Drexel to secure financing. Prosecutors claim more than $1 million in trading profits were credited to Drexel in January 1986. According to court papers, Milken allegedly bribed money managers to buy risky Storer securities by selling other securities of the Florida cable television company at below market value. They allege Milken also misappropriated warrants that would allow a purchase of 25 percent of the company to private partnerships in which he had an interest. The government alleges that cash proceeds from the Storer transactions surpassed $325 million, with Milken and another unidentified individual personally making $172 million in 1988. Milken's lawyers say the claims are ``based both on misunderstandings and misstatement of the facts and the law.'' They say KKR gave Drexel discretion to sell warrants and that money managers have denied the alleged kickback arrangement.
DOC.HEAD: Wickes Cos.
DOC.TEXT: The government claims Milken asked Boesky to buy a large block of shares of Wickes, a California building products business, to push up its stock price and make it qualify for a special and costly dividend. Wickes hired Drexel in 1985 to raise money via a series of securities offerings, including two promising a high fixed dividend of $2.50 per share. The company did not have to redeem the shares for three years unless its stock closed above $6.12{ for 20 out of 30 consecutive trading days. The government alleges Milken pushed his traders to find buyers of Wickes stock to drive up the price. When the stock reached the level on 19 of 28 days in spring 1986, Milken allegedly had Boesky buy 1.9 million shares late in a trading day, pushing it above the required level. That helped Wickes avoid having to pay the expensive dividend for the full three years.

DOC.HEAD: Executives Planning for End of Bankruptcy Proceedings Next Year
LaserPhoto of Oct. 3
DOC.TEXT: Despite expecting weak sales for the rest of this year and into next, executives running Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. are planning for the retailers to emerge from bankruptcy in 1991. The sister retailers owned by financially distressed Campeau Corp. on Wednesday unveiled a business plan for the years through 1996 that includes store closings, but no outright sales of entire department store chains. Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Allied and Federated, said the plan is the foundation on which to build a proposal to get out of bankruptcy proceedings. He said Allied and Federated are making a push to get out of bankruptcy as quickly as possible because the longer the process drags on the costlier it will become. Neither Questrom nor James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Allied and Federated, would provide specific information on what the reorganization proposal would contain. They refused to state how much money would be offered to creditors who collectively are owed around $7.7 billion. Most of the debt was amassed when Canada's Campeau bought Allied and Federated with borrowed money in the 1980s. The judge supervising the bankruptcy in a Cincinnati court last month gave Federated Stores Inc., the holding company for Allied and Federated, until Feb. 28 to submit its reorganization plan. Companies operating under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act are allotted time in which they have the exclusive right to come up with their own plans. Federated has been granted two extensions. The executives said the reorganization plan, which must be approved by creditors and U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., would not propose chopping off any Allied or Federated divisions. Among the nine chains they run are such well-known retailers as Bloomingdale's, Bon Marche, Burdines, Jordan Marsh, Lazurus and Rich's. The business plan presented Wednesday projects operating earnings of Allied and Federated will more than double over the next six years. Operating profits, which represent earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, are forecast to grow to $1.13 billion in 1996 from an estimated $486 million this year. The plan forecasts sales will rise to $9.89 billion in 1996 from $7.22 billion in 1990. Questrom said the plan contains seven key elements that will be implemented throughout all Allied and Federated chains. ``It's not a plan that gets us to the moon. It's one that's realistic,'' he said. It focuses on basic merchandising matters and realigns various retail functions, such as buying, to make them more centralized. An emphasis will be placed on keeping inventory fresh and improving the retailers' abilities to respond quickly to changing consumer tastes. It also envisions capital expenditures of $1 billion for remodeling and maintenance. Some 16 new stores plus some replacements are slated to be opened. An unspecified number of store closings are contemplated. Zimmerman said stores that are failing to generate sufficient cash flow will be shut down. But he declined to say which of Allied's and Federated's 250 stores are likely to go out of operation. Zimmerman and Questrom said they believed pruning poor performers would provide a better return to creditors than trying to sell off whole divisions. Questrom, who was recruited after Allied and Federated filed the bankruptcy petition Jan. 15, claimed progress will be slow in turning around the retailers in the near future. The business plan assumes that the country will be in a virtual recession from about now through three quarters of next year. He said Allied and Federated won't engage in drastic discounting this year to boost sales, as they have ben accused of doing in the last Christmas season. He said the retailers haven't bought too much merchandise so they won't be stuck with excessive inventories if business is as bad as some forecasters say it will be. Inventories, at the end of August, were about $330 million below the level of a year ago, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Goldman Sachs Forms $783 Million Fund
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Goldman, Sachs & Co. said Wednesday it has formed a large fund to invest in debt-laden companies, becoming one of the first prominent Wall Street brokerages to see opportunity in the excesses of the 1980s. The venerable firm said that since April, it has raised $683 million for the fund from major U.S. and foreign pension funds, international banks, university endowments, insurance companies and individuals. In addition, the firm contributed $100 million of its own capital and will serve as general partner of the fund, called the Water Street Corp. Recovery Fund I, L.P. The fund's strategy of targeting troubled firms marks a big departure from the goals of multimillion dollar funds of the 1980s, which sought takeover targets or took companies private in highly leveraged deals. Other smaller investment concerns have seen potential rewards in getting distressed companies back on their feet, but Goldman's entry into the business signaled an interest on a much larger scale. Mikael Salovaara, head of Goldman's leveraged finance group and supervisor of the fund's daily activities, anticipates annual returns of between 25 percent and 35 percent for investors, who contributed a minimum $5 million to participate. In taking large positions in financially troubled companies, the fund will ``work as an active partner with managements whenever possible to help them restructure financially,'' Goldman said in a statement. In the past four months, Salovaara said, the fund has invested a total of $250 million in 10 companies, most of which are Fortune 1,000 concerns. Salovaara refused to identify them. ``The restructuring we anticipate taking place will see a company shrink the amount of outstanding debt . . . through bankruptcy if it comes to that, and allow it to have a strengthened balance sheet,'' Salovaara said. In the aggressive takeover days of the 1980s, investment firms and partnerships raised millions to establish funds that invested in acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. Since then, however, the stock and junk-bond markets have been battered and the economy has weakened, forcing companies burdened with heavy debt loads into bankruptcy or restructurings. Coniston Partners, one of the most prominent takeover alliances of the 1980s, said in June that it would disband a $700 million investment pool because of the continued shrinkage of the mergers and acquisitions market. Both suitable takeover targets and adequate financing had become scarce. In its heyday, Coniston's biggest targets included Gillette Co., Allegis Corp. and TW Services Inc. Coniston also agreed to participate in the employee-led buyout of United Airlines. Salovaara said buying into trouble companies is ``clearly an area people need to look at. We have a lot of companies with way too much debt on their balance sheets, and unless that situation is changed outside of bankruptcy court, it will end up being changed inside bankrutpcy court.''

DOC.HEAD: Volcker Blames Deregulation, Poor Supervision for Thrift Mess
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker denies that the high interest rates he encouraged in the early 1980s spawned the problems of the savings and loan industry later in the decade. Volcker, appearing Wednesday before the House Banking Committee, said the industry's ill-advised excursion into risky investments, not the highest interest rates since the Civil War, proved its downfall. ``The industry could have survived that episode (of high interest rates) and the great bulk of it did,'' he said. As head of the nation's central bank from 1979 to 1987, Volcker quelled the double-digit inflation of the 1970s by drastically slowing the economy with interest rates topping 20 percent. ``It was very painful, but I don't think it was the fundamental cause of what was happening in the late 1980s,'' he said at the second of a series of hearing exploring the roots of the S&L mess. Banking Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, who once sought to impeach Volcker for his monetary policy, agreed that interest rates weren't the fundamental cause, but he said they were a contributor. Volcker primarily blamed the losses on the expansion of S&Ls into investments outside their traditional role of mortgage lending and serving family financial needs, and on the inability of inexperienced S&L examiners to monitor the new business. ``The whole atmosphere during those years was not conducive to strict supervision and strict regulation ... it was not in the air, so to speak,'' he said. Volcker was particularly critical of S&Ls' direct investment in commercial real estate projects as part-owners rather than as lenders. ``That is the single area that's bankrupted more savings and loans than any other area,'' he said. ``I thought that was a bad idea to start with. ... I think that events have clearly demonstrated that it was even more catastrophic than I thought,'' Volcker said. ``It is just an area that inherently is rife with conflicts of interest and temptations for self-dealing.'' Former thrift regulator Edwin J. Gray, who appeared with Volcker, blamed former Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and other Reagan administration officials for his inability to hire and keep the competent examiners needed to oversee S&L expansions. Regan, who appeared before the panel Monday, characterized Gray as an absentee regulator who as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board from 1983 to 1987 served as a front man for the industry. Gray denied the charges. ``Regan ... simply never lifted a finger to help us in any material way to avert the thrift crisis,'' he said. Gray said Regan and the Office of Management and Budget opposed his efforts to hire the examiners needed to monitor the activities of thrifts in states with liberal laws and denounced the system of state-regulated, but federally insured thrifts. ``The only reason why we ever had a dual federal-state thrift system ... was that this enabled state politicians to get political contributions,'' he said. Gray also said Regan, a former chairman of Merrill Lynch, opposed his effort to clamp down on brokered deposits. Such high-interest-rate deposits placed by money brokers are blamed for fueling the explosive growth of risk-taking S&Ls. Merrill Lynch was the leader in that business. ``The U.S. Treasury Department, headed by Donald Regan, lined up with the money brokers against the federal deposit insurance agencies. ... He opposed the deposit insurance agencies' brokered funds regulation,'' Gray said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei, Dollar Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, but the pace of trading eased after two days of feverish activity. The dollar fell against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 571.20 points, or 2.56 percent, to close at 22,278.19 points. The average shed nearly 50 points in heavy trading on Wednesday after a record surge the previous day. Trading was a thin 320 shares, or about half of Wednesday's volume. Many players stayed away to avoid the effects of arbitrage trading by major securities houses, said Amy Yip, manager of sales for Baring Seucrities. ``Today was a relatively quiet and stable (cash) market, although it drifted down'' on ``very, very thin activity,'' she said. ``The markets are waiting to see the employment report from the United States,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst for Nomura Securities. The September employment report is due out in Washington on Friday. Other influences included a decline on Wall Street overnight and higher oil prices. Higher oil prices alone will not hurt the economy greatly over the short term, said Tsutomu Toichi, research coordinator and chief economist for the independent Institute of Energy Economics. What would really hurt is higher prices over the long term, or worse, disruption of supply. ``The key is how long the high prices continue: For one year, two years, three years? If the high prices continue for four years, then the Japanese economy can cope,'' Toichi said. ``But the world economy will be so severely damaged (and that) will have an impact on the economy.'' Some analysts saw the market turning up, but only temporarily. ``We expect to see the market fall below Monday's low sometime in the first quarter of next year,'' said Pelham Smithers of Shearson, Lehman Hutton Asia Ltd. On Monday, the Nikkei index fell as low as 19,781 points. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 135.90 yen, down 0.75 yen from Wednesday. Traders said the dollar slid in reaction to comments by U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan indicating that U.S. interest rates might fall. Greenspan said Wednesday that the proposed U.S. budget would ``almost certainly'' depress interest rates. He told a Congressional committee that failure to approve the budget's $500 billion deficit-reduction package would be a ``grave mistake'' with serious consequences for an already weakened U.S. economy. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark 10-year government bond fell to 8.290 percent by 3 p.m., down from 8.310 percent on Wednesday. The price rose to 82.40 yen, up from 82.32 yen on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Exports Seen Down Slightly in New Fiscal Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Farm commodity exports are expected to decline a bit in the fiscal year that began this week, mainly because of hefty grain supplies throughout much of the world. The Agriculture Department says another reason, although not a large factor, is the historic joining of the two Germanys on Wednesday, which will mean a slip in corn exports. East Germany typically bought about 500,000 metric tons annually. But with unification, the new Germany becomes part of the European Community, said Stephen MacDonald of the department's Economic Research Service. Suddenly, it becomes too expensive to import U.S. corn. ``Their price goes up and that price is protected by the (EC) tariff,'' MacDonald said, commenting on a report in the October issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. Normally, West Germany has not been a significant U.S. corn market, he said. Some has been imported, but mostly for industrial uses. The main reason for a weakening of U.S. farm export prospects is large foreign supplies of wheat, rice and corn in both the importing and exporting countries. In some measure, the outlook for 1990-91 could reflect what happened in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, although USDA analysts say it's too early to make flat predictions. Also, they say, there are many variables relating to the Mideast crisis, energy costs and global finances. But in 1989-90, U.S. agricultural exports probably reached 148.5 million metric tons, worth $40 billion, both slightly more than the year before, the report said. ``Export volume likely rose about 2 million tons (in 1989-90), as larger corn and soybean exports offset lower wheat exports,'' the report said. ``During the first 10 months of fiscal 1990, corn exports rose 8 million tons, soybeans rose 2.5 million, and wheat exports fell 7 million.'' The drop in U.S. wheat exports was attributed to larger prospective crops in several major importing countries, including the Soviet Union and China; rising supplies among competitors, especially Canada; and the anticipation of foreign buyers that prices would decline in the future. Total U.S. agricultural exports to China dropped more than 40 percent last fiscal year, mostly because of the decline in wheat shipments. In the first nine months of the fiscal year, the report said, China's wheat imports from all sources fell nearly 10 percent, and the U.S. market share dropped to about 25 percent from 50 percent. Meanwhile, Australia and Canada increased their share of the Chinese market. Wheat exports to Egypt also have weakened, the report said. This has been due mostly to Egypt's difficulty with past-due payments for U.S. credit extended in earlier years. Egypt's imports of U.S. vegetable oil, tallow and poultry meat also are down, although sales of short-staple cotton were up sharply as Egypt continued to increase its exports of textiles and long-staple cotton. ``The U.S. ban on trade with Iraq and the U.N. general trade embargo helped lower fiscal 1990 U.S. agricultural exports to Iraq by $200 million from a year earlier,'' the report said. ``Wheat and soybean meal likely accounted for most of the decline. Sunflower oil exports also were down.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Imagine, a joint expedition of U.S. and Soviet Union bug hunters hacking their way through the Amazon jungle looking for a natural enemy of the Colorado potato beetle. That's a bit far-fetched, but not by much. The Agriculture Department says the expedition to the hinterlands of Brazil bgan this week, including three entomologists from the department's Agricultural Research Service and one from the Soviet Union. Robert F.W. Schroder said in a report released by the agency that the Colorado potato beetle is ``the single most important pest of potatoes in both countries.'' The pest also eats tomatoes and eggplants. Although the beetle itself is not a resident of Brazil, there are 200 closely related species. And the scientists will be looking for enemies of those relatives, seeking some that would also attack the potato beetle. Schroder said the team will use sweep nets to collect live potential beetle enemies along roadsides, into the bush and forested areas ``wherever our guide takes us.'' Other scientists include Michael M. Athanas, who works with Schroder at the agency's research center in Beltsville, Md., and Benjamin W. Puttler, who recently retired from the agency's laboratory in Columbia, Mo. The Soviet scientist is Ivan Kriak of the All Union Institute for Biological Methods of Plant Protection in Kishinev, Moldavia. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Agriculture Department says the Soviet Union has bought an additional 150,000 metric tons of U.S. soybean meal under a long-term grain agreement between the two countries. Officials said Wednesday that private exporters sold the meal for delivery through Dec. 31. The current agreement, including a three-month extension, will expire at that time and a new five-year pact will take over. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department. No selling prices or further details were released. Under the current grain agreement, the Soviet Union bought more than 1.37 million tons of soybean meal during the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, along with 342,000 tons of soybeans. Grain purchases during the year totaled 20.3 million tons, including nearly 16.5 million tons of corn and 3.8 million tons of wheat.

DOC.HEAD: Town's Future Uncertain as Paper Mill Closes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GS1
DOC.TEXT: When Dave Backus graduated from Watervliet High School in 1978, there was never any question what he'd do next. Like many of his classmates, he went to work in the town's 80-year-old paper mill, following his father and grandfather, as well as his mother and aunt and uncles. Now the future is anything but clear. Watervliet Paper Co., the biggest employer in this southwestern Michigan town of 1,867, has been idle since June, when its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection. The mill's employees are among hundreds of thousands of factory workers left jobless in recent months as the nation's unemployment rate worsens. Michigan has the worst unemployment among top industrial states. Backus, 31, sits at home most days now, collecting his last few unemployment checks and awaiting word on whether anyone wants to buy the mill and rehire its 250 workers. He wonders if he'll have to leave his hometown to find work. ``After all we've been through, I don't even want to go back - but I will,'' he says in his living room, over the noise of an ``Andy Griffith Show'' rerun. ``The paper mill is all we know.'' Some mill workers have moved away. Others have taken the few full-time jobs available in the area. Most are reluctant to leave while the mill's fate remains uncertain. They say no other business in the rural area can come close to matching the $10 an hour they earned at the mill, and they worry things are little better elsewhere. Michigan leads the nation's 11 largest industrial states in unemployment with a seasonally adjusted 7.9 percent jobless rate for August. Watervliet is in Berrien County, which has a 7.2 percent jobless rate. The national jobless rate in August was 5.6 percent - a two-year high. The Labor Department will release September unemployment figures Friday. Since March 1989, the number of factory jobs nationally has fallen by more than 450,000. Nick Khouri, an economist for the Michigan Senate Fiscal Agency, predicts the state's jobless rate will be 8.5 percent a year from now. ``With the increase in the price of oil continuing to drain the economy, we're going to see even more of an economic slowdown in the next six to 12 months,'' Khouri said. The closure forced Mayor Robert Flaherty, who relies on the mill for 35 percent of the municipal tax base, to eliminate the position of police chief. There will be more cuts if the mill doesn't reopen soon. Watervliet went through the same kind of emergency two years ago when the mill's previous owner closed the mill. In March 1989, residents rejoiced when Kalamazoo-based Kapaco Group Inc. bought the mill and rehired every worker. Kapaco had it running at full speed again within a few months, churning out 140 tons a day of coated paper used for playing cards, product labels and catalogs. ``They told us we were making the greatest paper in the world,'' says idle worker Joe Crady, sipping iced tea at the counter of Jasmine's Family Restaurant, where his wife works as a waitress. ``I still don't understand what happened.'' Adding to the pain of joblessness is a dispute over health insurance. Kapaco allegedly continued payroll deductions after canceling its insurance program. Kapaco Chairman Richard Jones declined to comment on the matter, saying it would be worked out in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Kalamazoo. Merchants say they've been only mildly affected by the shutdown so far, but they worry about a bleak holiday season and an even darker future. ``I don't know how long I'll be able to last,'' says A.C. Bolin, who owns a furniture store on Main Street. ``Nobody here's making enough to even be thinking about buying furniture.'' If the mill doesn't reopen, hope centers on the city's small-town charm, surrounding fruit farms and scenic Paw Paw Lake, which keep it popular among vacationers from Chicago. Officials also are trying to attract new industries, playing up the town's easy access to Interstate 94, which links Detroit and Chicago. ``We're optimistic things are going to work out,'' says David Gearhart, a supermarket owner and chairman of the town's business association. ``I don't think you're going to see Watervliet dry up.''

DOC.HEAD: Helms Raps GAO Report Defending Chilean Grape Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A government report that finds no fault with last year's temporary ban on fruit from Chile is ``riddled with holes and replete with inaccuracies,'' Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., contends. The report by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, looked into the finding last year of two grapes from Chile tainted with cyanide and the subsequent five-day suspension of all fruit imports from Chile. A draft copy of the GAO study circulated among news media on Wednesday and Helms says it should not be released in final form until the agency resolves several ``serious contradictions and unsupported assertions.'' ``It is riddled with holes and replete with inaccuracies. It simply does not measure up to the usual standards of the GAO,'' Helms said in a letter to Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher, who heads the office. ``GAO has failed to present any analysis which would explain how FDA was able to find only two contaminated grapes among millions, before it then issued a false alarm banning Chilean fruit and forcing its destruction in retail and wholesale outlets,'' Helms said. ``This failure to provide any explanation for the `miracle find' alone invalidates the entire report.'' The GAO concluded after ``extensively evaluating FDA's laboratory testing procedures,'' that there was no merit to charges from Chile that the tests were botched and fruit samples mishandled. Chilean growers say they lost $333 million by the five-day import suspension. ``We found that FDA's discovery of cyanide in Chilean grapes was based on generally accepted tests that were conducted properly,'' the GAO told Helms, who had requested the investigation. ``Based on its finding, FDA acted within its legal authority to suspend imports of Chilean fruit.'' A Washington law firm that represents the Chilean Exporters Association raised points similar to Helms' in a lengthy response and said the report ``is riddled with errors, omissions and blind faith acceptance of FDA excuses for inexcusable procedures and decisions.'' The statement by the firm of Lepon, McCarthy, Jutkowitz & Holzworth said the association's own experiments ``proved that it was virtually impossble to inject and retain significant amounts of cyanide in grapes. It wondered, too, about ``the incredible claim that FDA found two and only two grapes that had been injected with cyanide out of 90,000 pallets en route to the United States, after looking at only 12 pallets.'' On March 2, 1989, an anonymous caller told the U.S. Embassy in Chile that he had poisoned fruit destined for the U.S. and Japan to draw attention to the poor living conditions of Chilean workers. Neither the type of fruit nor the ship on which it was being sent was identified. The FDA increased its inspections of Chilean fruit and on March 12 - after checking 1,200 crates of grapes from one ship arriving in Philadelphia - found two grapes laced with cyanide. It issued its ban the following day. Two more warnings were telephoned to the embassy but no more contaminated fruit was found. The GAO said it had not investigated the $333 million loss claim by the Chilean Exporters Association. The agency said it used four outside consultants to evaluate the adequacy of FDA's testing and sample protection methods and to assess the reliability of FDA's findings. But Helms said the report is filled with conjecture, leaves major scientific deficiencies unaddressed and does not consider whether ``FDA's apparently lax security measures were adequate to prevent adulteration of the sample after it was taken into custody.''

DOC.HEAD: Banks Up Against Deadline For UAL Buyout Decision
DOC.TEXT: The final push by United Airlines employees to secure loans for a $3.8 billion buyout of parent UAL Corp. is yielding encouraging results, says a source close to the deal. But the outcome of the effort isn't expected to be known until tonight, the deadline imposed by the union-led group for bankers to say whether they will finance the bid to create the nation's largest employee-owned company. ``The informal feedback we've gotten has been good and somewhat encouraging,'' the source said Wednesday. ``But there is a big difference between informal feedback and commitments.'' UAL's board has given the employee group until next Tuesday to present a fully financed buyout package. The buyout group, led by United's unionized pilots, machinists and flight attendants, originally sought to secure commitments for a $2 billion loan by Wednesday. They extended the deadline for one day after four lead banks tentatively agreed to kick in a total of $1.4 billion, the source said. The four - Bankers Trust New York Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp., Security Pacific Corp., and First Chicago Corp. - had until the close of business Thursday to receive commitments from about 20 other banks to complete the financing, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The source said the other banks would not necessarily have to pledge $600 million by Thursday but would have to commit enough to ensure ``a successful syndication.'' The lead banks have not defined that amount. ``It would be the judgment of each of the four banks whether the syndication has been successful and whether amounts they are prepared to provide have been committed,'' the source said. Financing commitments received after Thursday would be welcomed, the source said. Employee group spokeswoman Martha Cid would not comment the buyout effort, which has been alive in one form or another for nearly four years. UAL's stock slipped 25 cents to $111.75 Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, ending three straight days of strong gains that had boosted its value by more than $21 a share. The employees are trying to put together a package that would pay UAL shareholders about $175 a share - $150 in cash and $25 in securities, the source said. That would be lower than the $201-per-share, $4.4 billion bid that the board initially accepted in April. The package would leave 15 percent of UAL's stock in the public's hands, according to the source; the April offer did not include any public ownership of UAL.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Cargo Jet Program In Deeper Financial Trouble
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A confidential Pentagon analysis of the McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s C-17 cargo jet program shows a cost overrun of up to $500 million, a newspaper reported today. A company official acknowledged the overrun but disputed the figure. Unidentified defense officials told the Los Angeles Times they expect the overrun to cause serious financial and political trouble for the aerospace company. ``The real concern now is that this thing could blow up politically,'' a Pentagon source was quoted as saying. McDonnell Douglas Vice President Michael Birch confirmed Wednesday the company likely will overstep its $4.9 billion budget for developing the C-17, but not by $500 million. ``We know it is going to be high, but not that high,'' Birch said. Until last week, the company was projecting that C-17 development would run $300 million below budget. The C-17 is being developed and produced in Long Beach at McDonnell's Douglas Aircraft Co. subsidiary, which employs 40,000 people. Last week, the Pentagon said it stopped paying McDonnell for work on the cargo jet after questioning the contractor's project cost estimates. The Pentagon has withheld $300 million so far. But Birch said McDonnell Douglas is certain it will profit from the C-17. ``We feel confident that we can make money on the C-17,'' Birch said. ``We are not going to do anything that hurts the long-term health of the corporation.'' Even with the cost overrun, Birch said McDonnell will not incur losses on the C-17 program until the combined ceilings of three different contracts are exceeded. The contracts include the $4.9 billion development contract and two production contracts totaling $6.57 billion, Air Force spokesman Capt. George Sillia said. Birch said McDonnell will borrow if necessary to overcome current problems with the C-17. ``We still have adequate capacity to borrow,'' he said. ``We still have hundreds of millions of dollars before we would exceed our debt coverage.'' McDonnell is $2.9 billion in debt. In a new credit agreement reached with bankers earlier this year, McDonnell can run debt up to $3.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Group: Oil Companies Destroying Ecuador's Rain Forests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A South American oil pipeline built over a major earthquake fault line is responsible for more spilled oil than gushed from the Exxon Valdez, an environmental group charged. The Natural Resources Defense Council said oil development by Texaco Inc. and other companies was destroying Ecuador's 32 million acres of tropical rain forest. It demanded that Texaco establish a $50 million fund for emergency cleanups and implement environmental controls to prevent further contamination of the rain forests. ``The company bears at a minimum a moral responsibility to make appropriate reparations,'' the group said in a report on results of its 18-month on-site investigation. A Texaco spokesman, Dave Dixon, said the company did not receive a copy of the report and therefore could not comment on specific charges. But, he said, ``In all its operations, Texaco's policy is to operate in accordance with the highest standards of environmental conservation.'' The report was released Wednesday at a press conference attended by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an attorney for the group who went to Ecuador in July with its investigative team. He said contamination from spilled oil and poisonous wastes from hundreds of oil wells was some of the worst he has seen. ``Children have pus coming out of their eyes from bathing in streams, animals are dead ... adults have rashes covering their bodies,'' Kennedy said. The government of Ecuador has recorded about 30 major oil spills from the Trans-Ecuadorian pipeline between 1972 and October 1989, with an estimated loss of 16.8 million gallons of oil, the council said. The pipeline was then operated by Texaco, it said. The Exxon Valdez oil tanker spilled about 10.8 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound in Alaska in March 1989. The environmental group said that besides spills, more than 4 million gallons of untreated toxic wastes are discharged daily into unlined pits and ultimately seep into streams and aquifers. The pipeline is particularly vulnerable to spills because it crosses a major Andean fault. In March 1987, earthquakes caused 5.9 million gallons of oil to spew into the Coca River. Cleanup efforts are primitive, at best, the group reported. Kennedy said he saw residents of the Cuyabeno Wildlife Reserve using their bare hands to scoop oil into plastic bags during a cleanup. The bags were buried in open pits. At an oil well near the Shuara community he saw a man walk into a pit filled with toxic wastes from oil production hauling out logs and sticks to clean it up. ``He was submerged in oil. You could only see the whites of his eyes,'' Kennedy said. Besides its charges against Texaco, the environmental group urged Conoco, a subsidiary of Du Pont Co., to cancel plans to drill oil in the region, saying it would risk irreparable injury to the indigenous Huaorani people. Ed Davies, president and general manager of Conoco Ecuador, said in a telephone interview from Quito, Ecuador, that the company was working closely with the Huaorani, who number only 1,580, to ensure oil development does not harm them. Environmental problems in Ecuador's tropical rain forests result from an outdated mindset about oil drilling, he said. ``They really are 20-year-old developments that the entire oil industry recognizes must change. And Conoco is committed to doing development in a responsible manner,'' Davies said.

DOC.HEAD: Fiat, French Electronics Group Announce Accord
DOC.TEXT: Italian auto giant Fiat SpA and the French electronics group Cie. Generale d'Electricite on Thursday unveiled a cooperation plan that will involve an exchange of stock and industrial activities. Under terms of the deal announced by both companies, Fiat will acquire 6 percent of CGE's capital, from CGE's existing shares and from a new issue of convertible bonds. In return, CGE will get about 3 percent of Fiat's capital, becoming one of the largest Fiat's shareholders after the controlling Agnelli family. The companies valued the transaction at roughly $370 million. The accord is aimed at expanding their industrial activites in the telecommunications and car battery markets. They plan to create a 50-50 European holding company to manage and develop the alliance, especially in high-technology. Other terms include: - CGE's Alcatel Face unit will merge with Telettra, a telecommunications equipment concern 90-percent-owned by Fiat. Telettra will be valued at about $2.2 billion and will become a leader in microwave and cable transmission equipment, Alcatel said. - Fiat will take a controlling interest in CGE's battery unit, Cie. Europeenne d'Accumulateurs, which holds 14 percent of the European auto battery market. The unit will combine with Fiat's Magneti Marelli auto unit. - Fiat said talks are under way to transfer a controlling interest in its railway unit to Gec-Alsthom, a maker of railway equipment 50 percent owned by CGE. Fiat has been seeking international cooperation and joint ventures to face the growing competition of U.S. and Japanese companies in the European markets. Fiat recently signed an agreement with Ford to take over the tractor division of the U.S. group and also acquired Enasa, the Spanish heavy truck manufacturer. The Italian group is known to be in talks with Ford and Chrysler for cooperation and possible mergers in the industrial vehicles and four-wheel-drive car sectors.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Drops in West But Rises in East
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a half-million people were jobless in what was East Germany as the two German states united, the Federal Labor Office reported Thursday. Sharply-rising unemployment in former East Germany is one of the major problems facing the newly united nation. The transition to a free market ecomony after four decades of Communism is forcing many former East German companies to close or to lay off workers. The Federal Labor Office said the unemployment rate in former East Germany rose to 5 percent in September, from 4.1 percent. Economists say that up to 4 million eastern Germans could end up losing jobs as unprofitable state-run companies are shut down. The latest former East German company to close is the Dresden-based camera manufacturer Pentacon, which employed about 5,000 people. In former West Germany, however, the unemployment rate fell to 6.6 percent in September from 6.9 percent in August, the Labor Office said.

DOC.HEAD: Toshiba, Apple Negotiating Joint Project
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. has entered into negotiations with Toshiba Corp. to develop lower-priced computers, Toshiba officials confirmed Thursday. The announcement comes days after Japan's Sony Corp. said it is discussing forging business ties with Cupertino, Calif.-based Apple, one of the leading U.S. personal computer makers. Toshiba spokesman Masao Mochizuki said Apple recently proposed the alliance, but he declined to elaborate. Analysts say Apple is seeking to diversify its product line and lower prices. ``Apple's computer is good in performance, but is rather expensive at present, so Apple is trying to develop new mass-production models to expand its market shares in Japan,'' said Yasumichi Satoh, an analyst with Sanyo Investment Management Co. Toshiba, a leading Japanese electric machinery maker, currently supplies Apple with semiconductors for its personal computers. According to Kyodo News Service, Apple is discussing an agreement under which Sony would make personal computers in Japan to be marketed under Apple's name. Sony now produces computer disk drives and displays for Apple Computer. At a board meeting held in Tokyo last week, Apple Chief Executive officver John Sculley told reporters that his company is bent on expanding its limited presence in Japan.

The stock market showed no clear trend today in another indecisive session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials edged up 1.98 to 2,491.34 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 319 up, 532 down and 441 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 15.89 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said whatever enthusiasm traders had mustered for a compromise reached last weekend on the federal budget seemed to have faded. The plan has been the subject of some sharp criticism in Congress, raising questions about its chances for passage. At the same time, fresh evidence of the weak state of the economy loomed in Friday's scheduled Labor Department report on the employment situation in September. The figures are expected to show an increase in the unemployment rate, probably to 5.7 percent, from 5.6 percent in August. Among the blue chips, McDonald's rose ] to 27]; Procter & Gamble gained \ to 77]; Philip Morris dropped [ to 48, and General Electric was down { at 54. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .11 to 170.69. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .68 at 308.57. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 15.84 to 2,489.36. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 557 up, 956 down and 448 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 135.49 million shares, against 188.32 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Half of Executives Don't Like Speaker Phone Conversations
DOC.TEXT: Almost half of the business executives contacted in a survey say they can't stand phone conversations where the other party is on a speaker phone, pointing out another technological innovation that's causing friction along with its benefits. Like the mushrooming of fax machines, the proliferation of speaker phones in recent years as standard office equipment apparently has caused a backlash. ``Executives today are increasingly inundated with more efficient but less personal means of communication, such as a fax that anybody can read or a telephone conversation via speaker phone that any passerby can overhear,'' said Robert Half, founder of Accountemps, the temporary-worker agency that sponsored the survey. The main concern cited by those surveyed who oppose speaker phones was the potential lack of privacy, Accountemps said. The next most frequent complaint was the sound quality of speaker phone conversations, which often seem to resemble a conversation in an echo chamber. Another sore point was the belief that speaker phone calls are impersonal or patronizing. The survey, conducted by a market research firm, involved questions posed to 200 executives at the nation's 1,000 largest companies, Accountemps said.

DOC.HEAD: Help-Wanted Index Falls, Signaling Labor Market Softening
DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Help-wanted advertising volume dropped in August, in another sign of a softening in the labor market and the overall economy, according to a monthly survey released Thursday. The Conference Board, a business research group, said its index measuring help-wanted advertising volume in 51 newspapers nationwide declined five points in August to 127 from July and 20 points from its year-ago level. Advertising volume rose by 7.7 percent in the region that includes newspapers in Birmingham, Ala., Louisville, Ky., and Knoxville and Nashville, Tenn. It also rose by 3.4 percent in Denver, Phoenix and Salt Lake City, but declined elsewhere in the country. The biggest drop, 6.6 percent, was in the region including newspapers in Kansas City, Mo., Minneapolis, Omaha, Neb., and St. Louis. The tally showed that the south Atlantic states had begun to join the rest of the East Coast in a sharp decline in labor market conditions. The southwest oil region, though, lost little ground, indicating continued recovery from the mid-1980s oil slump, the Conference Board said. Overall, 22 percent of the surveyed labor markets showed rising want-ad volume in August, down from 57 percent in July. Unemployment rose to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent the previous month. ``The labor market is in a slump and is unlikely to recover over the next 12 months,'' Conference Board economist Ken Goldstein said. Help-wanted advertising volume is considered to be sensistive to labor market conditions, providing a measure of change in job supply.

DOC.HEAD: EC Unveils Plan to Reduce Farm Subsidies in World Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: The European Community said Thursday it would be willing to trim costly export subsidies for farmers, although it still refused to embrace the sharp cuts demanded by the United States. The community's executive body unveiled its latest agriculture position in international trade talks that have been stalled by a bitter dispute between the 12-nation trading bloc and the United States over farm payments. Ray MacSharry, the community's top agriculture official, said in a statement that the proposal ``strikes a careful balance between the needs'' of European farmers and the desire for a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of trade talks. The four-year negotiations, which are scheduled to end in December, are aimed at overhauling the world trading system. They are designed to reduce barriers to trade in 15 areas, including agriculture, textiles and other manufactured goods and services such as banking and investment. Community officials have been fighting to protect their export subsidies, which are designed to help local products find buyers on the world market. They contend getting rid of the program would mean higher farm prices in Europe and cost millions of jobs. But the United States objects to the program as giving an unfair advantage to farmers overseas. The community's new proposal would cut farm payments by 30 percent for such products as cereals, rice, sugar and livestock to 1996. A 10 percent reduction is proposed for fruits, vegetables and tobacco. In return, it wants to raise protective measures for such commodities as oilseeds. The community also said it will not give new export subsidies for commodities not covered now. Moreover, it said it is willing to translate these changes into numbers and then ``re-evaluate this quantification.'' The U.S. Mission to the European Community had no immediate reaction to the proposal. The EC statement appeared to signal the community's willingness to bargain for reductions in export subsidies, although not to the level the United States has been pushing for. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills has said the United States intends to propose a 10-year plan for reductions of up to 70 percent in domestic farm supports and import duties and even greater reductions in export subsidies. The United States backed off a previous demand that export subsidies be eliminated. But it still wants the community to widen its markets to foreign farm goods and slash farm payments that encourage overproduction. The final offer must be approved next week by the member nations' farm and trade ministers.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Lower on Poor Futures Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower Thursday on the London Stock Exchange, depressed by a poor showing on the stock index futures market. A futures-led rally, which earlier in the week pushed the main 100-share index 95 points higher, ran out of steam, traders said. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 16.6 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,070.4. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 17.7 points to close at 1,601.3. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 7.43 points to close at 1,103.98. Volume was a moderate 421.3 million shares, up from Wednesday's 389.9 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar dropped in European dealings today and hit a postwar low against the German mark. Gold continued climbing for a third day. The dollar hit a low of 1.5310 against the mark in early afternoon trading, breaking the previous postwar low of 1.5385 reached on Aug. 27. Anticipation of lower U.S. interest rates, bolstered by comments Wednesday from U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, helped push the dollar lower throughout the day, dealers said. Lower U.S. interest rates dampen demand for U.S. investments and therefore the need for dollars. Greenspan endorsed the government's deficit reduction budget proposal, saying enactment of the plan would ``lessen pressures in credit markets'' and help investment and economic growth. Earlier, he said a credible agreement could prompt the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates. ``When the agreement on the budget came out, people didn't know what was going to happen,'' a senior dealer in London said. ``Now that Greenspan more or less told the market the rates were going down, that set the whole thing on fire.'' In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.75 yen to a closing 135.90 yen. Later in London, it fell to 134.00 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was trading at 134.09 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9115 from $1.8990 late Wednesday. In New York one pound cost $1.9075. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5340 German marks, down from 1.5435; 1.2760 Swiss francs, down from 1.2845; 5.1400 French francs, down from 5.1747; 1.7300 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7410; 1,150.00 Italian lire, down from 1,160.25, and 1.1485 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1516. Selected midday dollar rates in New York included: 1.5369 German marks; 1.2723 Swiss francs; 1,151.25, and 1.1484 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $396.25 a troy ounce from $390.75 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $396.25 from $390.50 bid late Wednesday. Hong Kong markets were closed for the Chinese Mid-Autumn Festival. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.71 a troy ounce from $4.70 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Defense Secretary Named Chairman of General Instrument
DOC.TEXT: Donald H. Rumsfeld, who served as defense secretary under President Ford, on Thursday was named chairman and chief executive officer of General Instrument Corp. The announcement was made by Ted Forstmann, the senior partner of Forstmann Little & Co., the New York corporate buyout firm that bought General Instrument in August for $1.6 billion. Rumsfeld, 58, served under three presidents and held various government posts over a 15-year period. He was a congressman, the U.S. ambassador to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and White House chief of staff as well as defense secretary. Upon leaving government service in 1977, Rumsfeld was named president and chief executive of G.D. Searle, a pharmaceutical company. He most recently was an adviser to William Blair and Co., a Chicago investment bank. Rumsfeld succeeds Frank Hickey, who was chairman and CEO of General Instrument since 1975. Hickey, 62, will continue to serve on the company's board. New York-based General Instrument is a major equipment maker for the cable television and direct-broadcast satellite television industries. It also makes semiconductor devices.

DOC.HEAD: Bass Plans Billion-dollar Investment in Holiday Inns
DOC.TEXT: British brewer Bass PLC said Thursday it plans to invest $1 billion in its Holiday Inn hotel chain over the next three years. Bass Chairman Ian Prosser said it will spend the money on improving facilities and ``developing new concepts and new ideas.'' ``The Holiday Inn Worldwide business offers significant long-term profit potential, which we are determined to capture. This investment is part of our strategy to ensure continued development,'' he said at a gathering of Holiday Inn franchisees in New York. A copy of his comments was made available in London, where Bass is based. Investment in Bass's traditional core brewing, pub retailing, soft drinks and leisure industry interests would continue, the chairman said. They all ``have significant opportunities to grow.'' Bass acquired the North American assets of Holiday Corp. in August for $1.98 billion after paying $475 million for the company's international hotel businesses in a deal completed in 1988. The billion-dollar investment would cover the 50,000 rooms that the company said in June it would add to the chain in the coming years. The chain now has 315,695 rooms in 1,584 hotels.

The stock market was widely mixed in a bouncing session today, registering what analysts described as continuing uncertainty about the economic outlook. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 20 points at midmorning, was up 13.86 at 2,503.22 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. But losers slightly outnumbered gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 691 up, 724 down and 469 unchanged. Analysts said whatever enthusiasm traders had mustered for the compromise reached last weekend on the federal budget seemed to have faded. The plan has been the subject of some sharp criticism in Congress, raising questions about its chances for passage. At the same time, fresh evidence of the weak state of the economy loomed in Friday's scheduled Labor Department report on the employment situation in September. The figures are expected to show an increase in the unemployment rate, probably to 5.7 percent, from 5.6 percent in August. Among actively traded blue chips, Philip Morris dropped \ to 47~; General Electric was unchanged at 54{; Boeing rose { to 43[, and Pepsico gained | to 24}. Navistar was the volume leader, off \ at 2] in trading that included a 2.93 million-share block at 2{. Digital Communications Associates tumbled 4[ to 10~. The company reported sharply lower earnings for the quarter that ended Sept. 30. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks edged up .19 to 170.99. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.30 at 307.95. Volume on the Big Board came to 107.04 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
For Release Sunday, Oct. 7
DOC.HEAD: Retailers May Be Looking Through Rose-Colored Glasses
With BC-Campeau Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: When things started looking bleak for Bloomingdale's corporate parent last autumn, a Manhattan movie theater near the famous department store proclaimed on its marquee ``Good Luck Bloomies!'' Now, a photograph of that message hangs on the wall outside the seventh floor board room at the Bloomingdale's headquarters. It reminds executives of the goodwill that has accompanied the retailer since it entered bankruptcy proceedings in January. To customers, nothing seems much different. But changes lie ahead at Bloomingdale's and the other eight chains of U.S. department stores entangled in bankruptcy litigation by the sins of their parent, Campeau Corp. Although hurt by the current spending slump and sure to suffer if the looming recession bears down on the economy, the retailers probably will pull through bankruptcy - although not necessarily intact. Executives running Campeau's U.S. retail arms, Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. are so sure of a successful conclusion to bankruptcy reorganization that they are planning on it. Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Allied and Federated, joined by James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer, presented a long-term business plan this past week that assumes the retailers will emerge in 1991. Questrom told a New York news briefing the Allied and Federated case could be one of the more successful bankruptcy reorganizations ever in retailing. ``I think it's a testimony to the strength of our organizations that they have survived this,'' he said. History might judge Questrom and his colleagues as overly optimistic. In fairness to them, they acknowledged there are legal complications to unravel before the retailers are ready to operate without constraints. A tax conflict must be resolved with the Internal Revenue Service and junk bondholders threatening to sue Allied must be placated. Howard Davidowitz, chairman of Davidowitz & Associates Inc., a New York-based retail consulting firm, said presentation of the upbeat business plan marked a preliminary skirmish in what will be a long negotiating battle between the forces of Federated and Allied and their creditors, who are collectively owed around $7.7 billion. The debt was heaped on the retailers when the Canadian real estate developer Campeau bought them in the 1980s. The retailers are posturing now; trying to persuade creditors how valuable their department stores are. That way creditors might think they are getting a good deal if they're offered stakes in Allied and Federated, Davidowitz said. Campeau's U.S. holding company, Federated Stores Inc., is developing a reorganization plan. In it, Federated will make compensation offers to creditors. The offers to the banks, suppliers and holders of junk bonds, likely will be far less than 100 cents on the dollar, possibly a combination of cash and interests in a reorganized company. Federated so far has obtained two extensions in the time in which it has the exclusive right to write its own plan. Last month, a federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati delayed the deadline to Feb. 28 from Sept. 12. Companies operating under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act almost always need longer ``exclusivity periods'' than judges initially allot. Allied and Federated, which together operate 250 stores in 27 states and employ about 100,000 people, wanted the deadline pushed past Christmas so they could tote up their take from the year's biggest sales season before proposing how their holdings might be divvied up. It might not make much difference, though, because the retail industry's holiday will be mediocre at best. The Allied and Federated business plan for the years through 1996 expects recessionary conditions to prevail from now through next year's third quarter. The Allied and Federated chains, with some exceptions, have had unimpressive sales so far in 1990. Revenue slipped to $3.11 billion in the first half of this year from $3.2 billion a year earlier. Monthly statements submitted to bankruptcy court show they continue to bleed money. Questrom and Zimmerman stressed at the briefing that the reorganization plan would not propose selling entire divisions of Allied or Federated. Instead, they will close individual stores that fail to produce enough cash. After Questrom was recruited to run the retailers while they reorganized, the proposed sale of Bloomingdale's was scrapped. Apparently, even the crown jewel in Federated's collection couldn't attract high enough bids. Regardless, outsiders doubt Federated and Allied can be preserved in their present forms. Whole chains could go their separate ways as pieces of the Campeau empire are carved up to pay creditors' claims. Tortuous negotiations are in store, with creditors fighting for what they think they should get. Davidowitz said asset sales will be the answer as impatient creditors seek to get as much money as possible as soon as possible. With today's weak economy, creditors will be less willing to accept equity stakes and bet on getting better returns sometime in the future. ``How else are they going to get cash without selling assets?'' Davidowitz said. ``They're going to have to have billions in cash. They're just going to have to sell divisions.'' ``I think they're definitely going to emerge from bankruptcy but you're not going to recognize them,'' he said. ``They will emerge four or five years from today as a much smaller company. Even the divisions they keep will have fewer stores.'' Experts say average shoppers don't know and don't care that Allied and Federated are in a serious financial predicament. Bloomingdale's has tried to preserve its pizazz and still conducts retailing as theater, complete with splashy promotions and celebrity-studded galas. Since last autumn, the retailer has thrown about 10 chain-wide events, including one this September saluting Spain and promoting Spanish merchandise. ``I don't see that the retail operations, from a consumer's point of view, have any changes. It seems to me to be business as usual,'' said Diann Valentini, who shops with an extra critical eye because of her job at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York. Valentini, assistant chairwoman of FIT's fashion buying-merchandising department, said popular suppliers still are prominent at Bloomingdale's. The chain continues to carry trendy merchandise and has been able to ride the crest of fashion waves. It's difficult to endure the scrutiny of a bankruptcy court judge and creditors, but Allied and Federated have handled it well, said Lewis S. Rosenbloom, an attorney with the Chicago law firm Winston & Strawn. Rosenbloom, who represents unsecured creditors in the Federated case, said the situation is unusual for a retailing bankruptcy because the problems that drove the department stores into bankruptcy weren't related to merchandising. The retailers have benefitted from the goodwill of suppliers and financial backers. ``In my experience, what we have seen thus far in terms of the level of support is quite extraordinary,'' Rosenbloom said. ``The vendor support has been substantial.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv Sunday, Oct. 7

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of New England Sells Investment Banking Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of New York has purchased Bank of New England Associates, the investment banking subsidiary of the Bank of New England, for an undisclosed price. The subsidiary will be renamed Bank of New York Associates, officials said, and will act as an intermediary in arranging mergers, acquisitions, private placements of debt, equity securities and financial restructuring services. Bank of New York's major services include corporate banking, retail banking, trust and investment management, securities processing and financial market services. BNE, which lost more than $1 billion in 1989, has been shedding assets and its work force since coming under increased government scrutiny when the region's economy began to slide and the real estate market exposed piles of bad loans. The bank lost $46.6 million in the first quarter of 1990 and more than $30 million in the second quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Robust German Business Boosts Woolworth's Revenue
DOC.TEXT: Retailer Woolworth Corp. Thursday said its September sales picked up from the prior month's pace thanks to robust business in Germany. Harold E. Sells, Woolworth's chairman and chief executive, said demand in the newly united Germany will help compensate for a sluggish retailing environment at home. ``Today, as the North American economy appears to be temporarily slowing, we see Germany picking up the pace enough to offset possible `shortfalls' elsewhere,'' Sells said. In remarks at a retail industry conference, Sells reaffirmed Woolworth's intention to expand its presence in Germany and open new stores in what had been East Germany. East and West Germany united formally on Oct. 3. The German subsidiary of Woolworth plans to open one or two new outlets by the end of this year in the former East Germany. The retailer is looking at six to eight sites for potential stores to be opened there in 1991, Sells said. He said Woolworth is ``proceeding at a cautious pace until the stability of the market can be assessed.'' But he added that he believes the area of former East Germany could support ``upwards of 50 to 60 Woolworth stores.'' Woolworth has done business in Germany since the 1920s. Currently, it operates 426 stores there, including 292 general merchandise stores and 134 specialty stores. Sells said Woolworth's geographic diversity ``reduces the potential impact of unfavorable political or economic developments in any single market.'' Woolworth, which operates numerous specialty chain such as Foot Locker in addition to the Woolworth variety stores, does business in Canada, Europe and Australia besides the United States. It has its world headquarters in New York. A summary of Sells' comments to the conference sponsored by the investment company Salomon Brothers was released by his office. In other comments, he said Woolworth's worldwide sales rose 15 percent in the eight weeks ended Sept. 29 from a year earlier. That followed a 13.2 percent sales gain for the four weeks through Sept. 1. Sells said Woolworth's September revenue was ``well ahead of the August pace'' largely because of the ``continued sharp gains in Germany.'' He didn't provide specific figures. Woolworth, along with most of the nation's other big retailers, is scheduled to release its results for the five weeks ending Oct. 6 next Thursday.
