DOC.HEAD: Public Videophone Service Would Bring Dream to Fruition
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese company is trying to make a futuristic dream come true by opening an international video telephone service for the public. Six Japanese women and a child sitting in the fffice of Videocom International Corp. squealed with delight this week as they listened to - and watched - friends and relatives in Singapore. Their friends spoke from a telephone office equipped with a similar terminal, which looks like a small television with a built-in camera. Service between Tokyo and Los Angeles is expected to start this week with New York and London to follow. ``It was fun, great'' said Izumi Sueda, 36, who with a friend talked in Tokyo with two friends in Singapore. But would they buy one? Most consumers around the world be skeptical, analysts say. ``There certainly will be individuals who are eager to see their relatives, but I don't really think it will catch on,'' said David Benda, head of research and a specialist in electronics for Barclay's de Zoete Wedd Securities in Japan. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. developed a videophone in the 1950s. But the company let it ``drop by the wayside in terms of marketing and product development,'' said John Murray, senior technical support manager at AT&T's Tokyo office. AT&T studies showed business people missed the personal contact of meetings. ``People would still rather jump on the plane and rack up those frequent-flier miles. There's something about getting out of the office,'' he said. Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp., Japan's largest telecommunications company, lists only 25 videophone customers among its 50 million customers. About 200 customers use telephones that provide a series of still color pictures of speakers and listeners, while 150,000 use similar machines that provide black and white pictures, NTT says. Analysts list a few reasons why Videocom's service may also be limited in the immediate future. One is cost. A videophone costs more than $2,200, compared to $73 to $365 for an ordinary telephone, NTT says. Meanwhile, a 15-minute call from Japan to the United States costs $40, and from Japan to Singapore, $49. Videocom, which is 36 percent-owned by Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co., Japan's main international telecommunications company, offers an international video conference service at roughly 10 times the price of a videophone call, but with much clearer video pictures. Another problem is inconvenience. At least two machines are needed for a video call. Moreover, they need to be the same type because machines produced by different companies often cannot communicate, said Toshio Satoh, Videocom's president. For that reason, Videocom's service in Singapore is limited to a single Singapore Telecom office and in Los Angeles to the office of a private company, Equal Access Corp. The service operates only between 8 a.m. and 8 p.m. local time in Japan. Despite the drawbacks, Videocom hopes that several changes will help win customers. One is the growing use of digital telecommunications lines, which send information using digital instead of analog signals. Digital signals, used by Videocom, are clearer than analog and can carry more information. Such digital technology ``will force us to take a second look'' at videophones, AT&T's Murray said. Fiber optic cables, which will become increasingly common in the future, can transmit even more information, resulting in clearer pictures at lower cost. Images on Videocom's equipment, manufactured by Mitsubishi Corp. using KDD technology, now are fuzzy and slightly jerky. Also, the International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee is expected this year to set standards for videophones that should encourage manufacturers in the United States, Europe and Japan to make machines that can communicate with each other, he said. ``If people are accustomed to the video telephone, then in the near future, there will be an opportunity to promote or market our equipment to them,'' Satoh said. More demand will bring lower prices within ``one or two years,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Ordered to Improve North Sea Work Supervision
DOC.TEXT: The government confirmed Thursday it ordered Amoco U.K. to improve work supervision on a North Sea gas platform or face criminal prosecution. The Sept. 17 action by the Department of Energy followed an inspection on the Amoco Alpha platform in the Leman field off the Norfolk coast, the department said. The disclosure that an improvement notice had been served on Amoco was made Thursday by Roger Lyons, assistant general secretary of the technical workers union. The union claims the platform doesn't have enough supervisors and that workers are being required to work up to 18 hours a day. A spokesman for Amoco wasn't immediately available for comment. Amoco Alpha is at the hub of the Leman gas system which produces about 10 percent of Britain's gas supplies. The notice said Amoco was failing to provide a proper system of work and proper supervision for contractors, and gave the company until Nov. 30 to make improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Announce Settlement with FCC Over Alleged Overcharges
DOC.TEXT: New England Telephone and New York Telephone have agreed to pay $1.4 million to the U.S. Treasury and a $35.5 million rebate to long-distance customers to resolve allegations they overcharged customers through a subsidiary, the Federal Communications Commission said Thursday. The FCC in February said it intended to fine the two companies $1.4 million - a record amount - over apparent violations of FCC rules governing transactions between regulated telephone companies and unregulated affiliates. The FCC had ordered the companies to return $35.5 million to customers because of alleged overcharges to NYT and NET by Materiel Enterprises Co., an unregulated Nynex purchasing subsidiary. The $1.4 million payment announced Thursday is a voluntary contribution and not a fine, the FCC said. Under what's known as a consent decree, Nynex admitted no guilt and the FCC said it had made no findings of wrongdoing and was ending its enforcement action. Nynex agreed to the $35.5 million rebate, to be made within 30 days, and would take other accounting steps to resolve allegations of excess profits on plant and equipment purchased from the Materiel Enterprises subsidiary. Local phone rates will not be affected. ``We hope this puts to rest any questions concerning Nynex's desire to comply with all FCC regulations and policies in transactions among affiliate companies,'' Nynex Chairman William C. Ferguson said in a statement. The agreement ends one of several pending federal or state actions against Nynex, one of the seven regional Bell holding companies created in 1984 from the old Bell System. Nynex also has been the focus of investigations that New York Telephone suppliers helped pay for bawdy parties and prostitutes at annual conventions of company employees in Florida from 1984 to 1988. Nynex has denied that any ratepayer funds were involved in the conventions. In May, the Justice Department filed a one-count criminal indictment alleging Nynex violated the information services restrictions on the regional Bell companies. Nynex denied wrongdoing. On Wednesday, New York state utility regulators authorized a study into whether Nynex should be forced to divest New York Telephone. The FCC in February had said Materiel Enterprises apparently overcharged NYT and NET by $118.5 million from 1984 to 1988. Of that, the FCC said, $35.5 million was passed through to long-distance customers. Long distance companies such as AT&T, MCI and US Sprint pay ``access charges'' to Nynex and other regional Bells, and those charges are figured into long-distance prices. Toby Webb, Nynex's vice president for government affairs, said Thursday he could not estimate how much the $35.5 million rebate would affect long-distance prices for New York and New England phone customers. Webb said Nynex had agreed to the latest consent decree in order to avoid a potentially long court battle over accounting and purchasing procedures that no longer were in effect. Materiel Enterprises was merged into New York Telephone and New England Telephone earlier this year, thus making Materiel a fully regulated company under FCC rules. ``The agreement is preferable to engaging in prolonged litigation over past events and practices which have been changed,'' Webb said. ``It is time to focus fully on meeting the needs of our customers.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Shipping Free Cigarettes to Troops Violated Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A shipment of donated cigarettes was inadvertently sent to U.S. troops in the Middle East in violation of a Defense Department policy of discouraging the use of tobacco, the Pentagon said Thursday. ``A unit did mistakenly ship four or five pallets of donated cigarettes, not being aware of the directive against such a practice,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said. He said the unit was reminded of the directive and no further shipments were sent. He did not identify the unit. ``Tobacco products are not an acceptable gift for distribution to service personnel,'' the spokesman said. He said department regulations prohibit the military services from distributing or transporting free tobacco products for the troops. Cigarettes can be purchased at post exchanges in the Persian Gulf region as elsewhere, Williams said. ``Department of Defense policy is that smoking is one of the leading preventable causes of disease and death among military personnel,'' he said. ``The department discourages the use of tobacco products and encourages those who use tobacco to quit.'' In response to a question, Williams said he did not know how many packages of cigarettes were on the pallets. Nor did he say who had donated the cigarettes. ``I think they have been consumed,'' he said. Earlier this week, Philip Morris U.S.A. said it had donated 2 million cigarettes to U.S. troops in response to letters from the soldiers. That followed a Sept. 25 announcement that Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp. planned to send an undisclosed number of smokes to the troops. The announcements drew strong criticism from anti-smoking groups, who attacked the tobacco industry for what they called a ploy to subvert Defense Department policy and hook a new generation of smokers.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Sues 37 Firms for Merchandise Piracy
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. sued 37 companies Thursday for illegally using Disney characters on clothing and other merchandise in Florida, the company said. The anti-piracy suit - Disney's 26th since 1985 - charged the defendants with copyright infringement, false designation of origin and unfair competition. Disney accused the 37 companies representing about 50 stores of selling sweatshirts, T-shirts, hats, watches, clocks, sun catchers, dolls and other items depicting Mickey and Minnie Mouse, Donald Duck, Goofy and Pluto. Among the defendants was Gala Enterprises of Central Florida, a chain of more than 25 retail stores near Walt Disney World. Fifteen of its stores were named in the action. Company representatives were not immediately available for comment. The other 36 defendants were retail establishments, many of them small gift shops, said Disney attorney John J. Tormey III. The federal suit seeks an injunction to prevent further sale of the merchandise plus damages of at least $50,000. Disney has been known for vigorously protecting its trademarks, at one point threatening to sue a day-care center for paintings of Disney characters on the building's walls. In the last four years, Disney has previously filed anti-piracy suits against about 1,070 defendants in 11 states and the District of Columbia. Despite the latest lawsuit, piracy of Disney products ``will crop up again,'' said Tormey. ``When you look at the 37 named in the suit today, you're looking at the tip of the proverbial iceberg,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $865.4 Million in Latest Week to Record $409.96 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds rose $865.4 million in the latest week to a new record of $409.96 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday broke the previous record of $409.09 million set a week earlier. That figure originally was reported as $409.12 million but was revised by the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. In the latest week, it said, assets of 255 general purpose funds rose $192.9 million to $145.74 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds increased $85.6 million to $165.9 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds rose $586.9 million to $99.03 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.48 percent from 7.47 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained steady at 7.47 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 47 days, up from 46 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts was 6.05 percent as of Wednesday, the same as a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained steady at 5.02 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.68 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.69 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.82 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.83 percent; 7.92 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.94 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged from a week earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders Lure Residents To Buy Stock
DOC.TEXT: Forget those dour economic forecasts for a couple days. Business leaders are trying to put a bright face on Massachusetts by giving residents a small bargain for buying stock in the state's companies. The effort was dubbed ``Take Stock in Massachusetts Business.'' It opened with the start of trading Thursday on the Boston Stock Exchange, and the window will close at the end of Friday's session. For the two days, the stock exchange agreed to waive transaction fees for brokerage firms that in turn waived commissions for residents who buy stock in companies headquartered in Massachusetts. ``It's an opportunity for the people of Massachusetts to be partners in their own economic future,'' said Gerald Scott, organizer of the program, who launched the sesion by ringing an old-fashioned school bell. Lately, the state's economic future has looked grim. Unemployment has risen sharply, as the once-powerful computer, financial and construction sectors have suffered heavy beatings. But the organizers of the stock program insisted that all is not bad in Massachusetts - some companies are performing well. Larry Vale, a spokesman for Keane Inc., a Boston-based software company, pointed to his firm as an example. Vale, who participated in Thursday's opening, said Keane's net earnings grew by 24 percent last year. ``In this gloom and doom mentality, people tend to forget that below the surface there are good companies,'' he said. Even some companies that have been battered recently can be good stock buys, investment analysts said. Ed Sullivan, representing Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., mentioned Digital Equipment Corp. and Bank of Boston Corp. as two high-profile companies that have been hurt recently but should perform well in the long run. For investors who think they have found a good buy, they will avoid paying commissions that range from about 1 percent to 3 percent. That means a person buying $5,000 worth of stock will save anywhere from $50 to $150. People taking advantage of the program must buy at least $1,000 worth of stock but no more than $25,000. Organizers cautioned that investors shouldn't buy stock simply because they can save a small amount of money on commissions. Instead, the main reason is to make a long-term investment. Similarly, Scott said he didn't expect a tidal wave of in-state investments during the two-day program. But he said it should make Massachusetts residents more interested in and aware of the different companies based in the state.

A late rally in blue chips provided one of the few highlights in a mixed and sluggish session in the stock market Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 20 points at midmorning, closed with a gain of 27.47 at 2,516.83. But declining issues slightly outnumbered advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 731 up, 780 down and 465 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 145.41 million shares, against 135.49 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 176.03 million shares. The upswing in blue chips was attributed primarily to computer-program buying by professionals engaged in multiple trading strategies involving options and futures on stock indexes. Otherwise, analysts said there had been little in the news to dispel investors' worries about the economic outlook and impending corporate earnings reports for the third quarter of the year. The enthusiasm investors initially mustered for the compromise reached last weekend on the federal budget appeared to have faded. The plan has been the subject of some sharp criticism in Congress, raising questions about its chances for passage. At the same time, fresh evidence of the weak state of the economy loomed in Friday's scheduled Labor Department report on the employment situation in September. The figures are expected to show an increase in the unemployment rate, probably to 5.7 percent, from 5.6 percent in August. Gainers among the blue chips included Eastman Kodak, up 1[ at 38]; International Paper, up 1{ at 47{; Procter & Gamble, up 1{ at 78|; American Telephone & Telegraph, up } at 32\, and McDonald's, up { at 27{. Navistar ranked among the volume leaders, unchanged at 2| in trading that included a 2.93 million-share block at 2{. Elsewhere, several stocks were depressed by adverse earnings surprises. Digital Communications Associates tumbled 4] to 10|. The company reported sharply lower earnings for the quarter that ended Sept. 30. Toro Co., which said it expects to post a loss for the fiscal quarter ending Oct. 26, fell 2} to 12\. Ingersoll-Rand dropped 5~ to 33\. The company said its profits for September and the third quarter didn't live up to expectations. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $3.76 billion, or 0.13 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .53 to 171.33. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.05 to 368.42, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.29 at 312.69. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 1.56 to 349.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 308.14, down 1.11.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Off on Interest Rate Speculation; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar dropped against all major foreign currencies Thursday amid selling on the widespread assumption that U.S. interest rates will fall in the near future. Gold prices eased in U.S. trading after climbing on precious metals markets abroad. The heaviest dollar selling in the United States occurred when activity began. Domestic foreign exchange dealers took their cue from Europe, where the dollar earlier had touched a new postwar low against the German mark. John McCarthy, chief dealer at the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank's office in New York, said the strong dollar sales subsided as the session progressed. But the dollar still closed lower than the day before. Dealers were given an incentive to dump dollars by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's comments to a congressional committee on Wednesday. Speaking in support of the fiscal 1991 budget proposal, Greenspan indicated the central bank would pursue a more generous credit policy if Congress enacts the compromise on cutting the federal deficit. A looser Fed policy would lead to lower U.S. interest rates, which would tend to curb dollar demand by making returns on dollar-denominated investments less rewarding than foreign alternatives. The report due Friday on the September employment situation is expected to reconfirm the economy's weakness and possibly weigh down the dollar further. A downturn in the economy in itself could cause interest rates to fall - even if the Fed doesn't give them a nudge. In Europe, the dollar hit a low for the post-World War II era of 1.5310 against the mark in early afternoon trading, breaking the previous postwar low of 1.5385 reached on Aug. 27. It traded at 1.5340 marks late in New York, down from 1.5420 late Wednesday. The dollar also weakened against the Japanese yen. In Tokyo, it fell 0.75 yen to a closing 135.90 yen. Later in London, it fell to 134.00 yen. The dollar closed at 133.83 yen in New York vs. 136.04 yen Wednesday. The British pound rose to $1.9115 from $1.8990 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.9145 to buy a pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.9025. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late quotes, included: 1.2800 Swiss francs, down from 1.2835; 5.1375 French francs, down from 5.1660; 1,149.00 Italian lire, down from 1,155.75; and 1.14865 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1516. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, were: 1.5340 German marks, down from 1.5435; 1.2760 Swiss francs, down from 1.2845; 5.1400 French francs, down from 5.1747; 1.7300 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7410; 1,150.00 Italian lire, down from 1,160.25, and 1.1485 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1516. Gold prices were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, bullion for October delivery settled at $392.30 a troy ounce, down $1.60 from Wednesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a bid for gold of $393.20 an ounce, 75 cents below Wednesday's 4 p.m. EDT bid. In London, gold rose to a late bid of $396.25 a troy ounce from $390.75 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $396.25 from $390.50 bid late Wednesday. Hong Kong markets were closed for the Chinese Mid-Autumn Festival. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.668 a troy ounce, down from $4.690 on Wednesday. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $4.71 a troy ounce from $4.70 bid late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Belly Runup Peaks
DOC.TEXT: A powerful three-day surge in pork belly futures prices peaked Thursday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange as buying interest sparked by a surprising government hogs-and-pigs report exhausted itself. Frozen pork bellies for delivery in February closed above Wednesday's closing price but below the day's high of 64.9 cents a pound, which represented a gain of nearly 12 percent since Friday. On other commodity markets, livestock futures were mixed; energy futures were mixed; precious metals retreated; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Pork bellies settled .65 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February up .25 cent at 64.45 cents a pound. Pork bellies had risen the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday in reaction to Friday's quarterly hogs-and-pigs inventory. The Agriculture Department report included an estimate of the number of pigs born during the summer that was 2 percent lower than in 1989. Most market analysts had expected summer farrowings to be unchanged or even a little higher than a year earlier. The unexpectedly low number means the number of hogs available for slaughter in the first quarter of 1991, when those piglets mature, also will be below the year-ago level, said Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. He said most observers had expected the slaughter rate to level off or begin to rise in the first quarter. ``What we did not expect was that the decline in slaughters from a year earlier would be extended into next year, which means it's going to be at least next spring before we get increases in the hog slaughter compared to the year previous,'' Levitt said. The market also was supported recently by indications that frozen belly supplies are virtually depleted, he said. Phil Stanley, a livestock consultant for DEC Futures Inc., said the relative weakness Thursday in the belly market also reflected profit-taking by traders who had taken bullish positions ahead of the report. In livestock trading on the Merc, live cattle futures settled .08 cent to .33 cent lower with October at 79.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .20 cent higher with October at 87.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .62 cent lower to .65 cent higher with October at 57.25 cents a pound. Crude oil and gasoline futures ended lower in a day of volatile trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange as a new push for peace in the Persian Gulf began. Among other Middle East events Thursday, a Soviet envoy carried a secret message from Mikhail Gorbachev to Baghdad and Japan's prime minister met with Iraq's No. 2 leader. And the USS Independence - the first American aircraft carrier in the gulf in 16 years - left the waterway after a brief show of force. Light sweet crude oil futures finished 35 cents to 75 cents lower with November at $36.93 a barrel; heating oil was .34 cent to .90 cent higher with November at 99.92 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .30 cent to 2.35 cents lower with November at 90.86 cents a gallon. Precious metal futures, which have shadowed crude oil's moves since the Persian Gulf confrontation began, fell on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold finished $1.60 to $2 lower with October at $392.30 a troy ounce; silver was 2.2 cents to 2.3 cents lower with October at $4.668 a troy ounce. Soybean futures ended lower on the Chicago Board of Trade after a late round of profit-taking but corn and wheat futures rose for the third straight day. With the soybean harvest due to begin in earnest within a week, many traders cashed out of the market with profits produced by Wednesday's sharp advance, said William Biedermann, research director for the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. Wheat futures settled 2 cents lower to } cent higher with December at $2.75 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2 cents higher with December at $2.30} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.23\ a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 4\ cents lower with November at $6.17} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Broadest Measure of Money Supply Falls
DOC.TEXT: The broadest measure of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended Sept. 24, while the second-broadest measure grew slightly, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,316.2 billion from $3,315.6 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,085.8 billion from $4,093.3 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $821.7 billion from $820.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the past 52 weeks was 5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in the past year in M3 was 1.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,299 billion, a 3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,083.4 billion, up 1.5 percent, while M1 rose 4.2 percent to an average of $815.2 billion. In other reports: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $503 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $513 million the previous week. - The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.4 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, down from $318.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Black & Decker Sells Four Emhart Divisions To Meet Debt Payments
DOC.TEXT: Tool and appliance giant Black & Decker will sell four divisions for $150 million in order to meet payments on nearly $4 billion in debt taken on when it bought Emhart Corp. The company agreed to sell its True Temper Hardware division to Huffy Corp. of Dayton, Ohio, for about $55 million, Huffy said Thursday. In addition, Black & Decker is selling its Medic division, the medical computer system unit of Planning Research Corp., to a management-led buyout group; and its domestic capacitors operation to an investment group, Yosemite Investment Inc. The company announced Wednesday it had agreed to sell GardenAmerica, which makes watering devices for lawns, for $40 million to James Hardie Industries Ltd. of Australia. The total sale price of all four divisions is expected to be about $150 million, said the Towson, Md.-based company. ``We are pleased to announce another step in our program to reduce our acquisition debt by $1 billion,'' Black & Decker chief executive officer Nolan Archibald said. ``When the proceeds of these sales are applied, reductions will total approximately $700 million.'' Black & Decker bought Emhart Corp. last year with $3.8 billion in borrowed money. Since then, the slumping economy has cut into sales, leaving it strapped to make debt payments. Emhart is a Farmington, Conn., maker of industrial and consumer products. Clifford Ransom, an analyst with Ferris, Baker Watts in Baltimore, said the move is good news for Black & Decker stock, which has taken a beating. ``People have been concerned over delays in selling assets,'' Ransom said. ``This set of announcements indicates that program was only delayed, not derailed. So it's good news.'' Black & Decker stock, which had traded as high as $24 in the last year, closed down another 75 cents to $8.87{ Thursday, after falling $1 the previous day. Black & Decker was required to sell about $150 million in assets by the end of the year as part of its bank loan agreement, Ransom said. ``The valuations they're getting for these businesses look good, although the details have been sketchy,'' Ransom said. ``GardenAmerica looks like it was (bought) at 13 times operating income, which is good. True Temper looks like it's between eight or nine times operating income. I would guess that's a pretty good price.'' The company also announced it had signed contracts to sell certain properties in the United Kingdom and France. Earlier this year, Black & Decker sold its Bostik adhesives division for $345 million; its footwear materials division for $125 million; and the European operations of its Arcotronics capacitor business for $80 million.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Government Imposes Higher Oil Prices, Asks Soviets for Help
DOC.TEXT: The Czechoslovak government, facing a winter of higher oil costs and dwindling Soviet supplies, imposed higher oil and gasoline prices Thursday and appealed to Moscow for help. Measures taken by a ''crisis team'' of government officials, announced in a TV address by Economics Minister Vladimir Dlouhy, are aimed at stemming a near panic about potential fuel shortages, the state CTK news agency said. ``To make it simple, the main problem is that oil is much more expensive now,'' Dlouhy said on national television. The Soviet Union, for years the main oil supplier in East bloc countries, is unable to fulfill its quotas. At the same time, it will begin demanding scarce convertible currency for its oil beginning Jan. 1. Many of the countries have lost supplies of Iraqi oil because of their support for the U.N. sanctions against Saddam Hussein, and their fragile economies are facing much higher prices on the world market. Elsewhere, Poland announced it would import oil from Iran to make up for dwindling Soviet supplies and losses caused by the Gulf crisis. Dlouhy estimated Czechoslovakia's loss because of the Gulf crisis at about $1.4 billion. Beginning midnight Friday, Czechoslovak consumers will be allowed to buy only about six gallons of gasoline in October at the official price of about $3 a gallon. Additional gasoline will cost about 25 percent more. Motor and heating oil will be increased from about $2.24 dollars to $3 a gallon. New limits for November will be announced later, CTK said. Premier Marian Calfa appealed for urgent talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzkov on faltering Soviet oil supplies. Soviet supplies began falling in the first half of the year, and the shortfall led to a panic in July that forced the government to drive up the price by 50 percent, CTK said. CTK quoted Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus as saying that he could not rule out more changes in wholesale prices by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Firms to Offer Youth Publication in Romania
DOC.TEXT: A youth publication with articles about U.S. culture is planned for distribution in Romania by USA Today and Centrade, a Houston-based trading and consulting firm, it was announced Thursday. The 16-page bimonthly publication will be a supplement to the Tineretul Liber, a Romanian daily whose name means ``free youth.'' Centrade is involved in the project as part of a joint venture with the Romanian daily. The articles distributed in Romania will cover U.S. politics, sports, television, movies and culture. They will be provided by USA Today and USA Weekend, a newspaper magazine published by Gannett Co., Inc., and will be translated into Romanian by Tineretul Liber. Articles by Romanian writers will also be included. USA Today will supply photographs. The first edition, with a printing of 300,000 copies, is expected to be on Romanian newsstands in November. Centrade said it will handle advertising for the publication, offering print advertising space to Western firms wishing to reach Romanian consumers. The Romanians will be responsible for layout, printing, distribution and sales.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Steps Down in Drexel Case
DOC.TEXT: The federal judge overseeing the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. bankruptcy withdrew from the case Thursday because he is considering a job at a law firm that has represented a Drexel creditor. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III said he was stepping down from the bench after seven years to return to better-paying private practice. Attorneys for Drexel and creditors said the departure would delay proceedings while his replacement becomes familiar with the largest collapse of a financial firm in Wall Street history. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Frank Conrad, who sits in Rutland, Vt., was named to take over the Drexel proceedings. Attorneys said Conrad has indicated he will spend about two weeks per month in New York on the case. Buschman, 46, was appointed to a 14-year term in 1983, but said he had ``regretfully concluded that the financial needs of my family will not permit me to continue to serve out the remainder of the term to which I was appointed.'' The judge said he was under consideration for a job at an unidentified law firm that has represented a creditor in the Drexel case but not filed any pleadings or argued in court before him. Buschman said that he was not required to disqualify himself from the case and he was reluctant to burden another judge with the case, but ``in an excess of caution I think it appropriate to request that these cases be reassigned.'' The judge also had presided over the Chapter 11 proceedings of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. Buschman won praise from attorneys in the seven-month-old Drexel case for his preparation, attention to detail and ability to control often contentious proceedings. ``I'm sorry we're losing him,'' Alan Miller, an attorney for Drexel, said. ``This has been a difficult case and I think he's done a job of keeping it under control.'' Attorneys said they expected delays in the case while Judge Conrad digests the background of the bankruptcy proceedings to date. ``You can't read a case and a file, you also have to understand some of the dynamics that go into a decision,'' he said. ``It's a very complicated bankruptcy case with a number of inter-relationships,'' said Barry Dichter, who represents a large Drexel creditor. ``It will take a new judge some time to understand the complexities.'' Drexel filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors in February in the aftermath of a junk bond market collapse and a failure to recover from its guilty plea to federal securities violations. Drexel still is liquidating its large securities portfolio and drawing up, along with creditors, a reorganization plan.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Gives UAW Contract Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Thursday gave the United Auto Workers union a comprehensive proposal for a new national labor contract that, according to one company official, mirrors the contract reached with General Motors Corp. The union, which ratified a three-year agreement with GM late last month, has insisted that the UAW-GM agreement serve as a model for contracts with Ford and Chrysler Corp. Except for one provision on overtime pay, Ford isn't expected to have trouble agreeing to a contract similar to GM's. ``I think probably Ford has fallen in line with that,'' said the company official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The UAW agreements with the Big Three cover more than 450,000 active workers - about 300,000 at GM, about 100,000 at Ford and about 60,000 at Chrysler. The GM-UAW agreement raises base wages by 3 percent in the first year and includes lump-sum increases equal to 3 percent of base wages in the second and third years. Cost-of-living protection on wages would be maintained and retirees will receive more money. It guarantees income for employees laid off for more than 36 weeks during the life of the agreement and makes no changes in health-care provisions. The pattern agreement also contains a new provision boosting the penalty for excessive overtime worked in a week. Ford has been using overtime much more liberally than the two other U.S. automakers, and the union has suggested it be curtailed and the company hire more workers. Neither company nor union officials would talk about specific provisions of the proposal offered Thursday. They issued a joint statement saying only that the proposal was delivered and that the union was studying it. A union official, who also requested anonymity, said studying the document and holding some meetings of bargaining subcommittees would take negotiators into Thursday night. On Tuesday, UAW President Owen Bieber said he expected negotiations with Ford could be completed by the end of the week. Company Vice President Peter Pestillo said that was possible. After a contract is ratified by Ford workers, the union will turn to Chrysler, where it faces an uncertain reception. The No. 3 automaker has said it may not be able to afford a contract similar to the other autoworkers', but the union is expected to push for the model agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up-Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 226,317 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 215,272, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 194,992 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 147,457 cars this week, compared with 135,275 a week ago and 132,764 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 78,860, compared with last week's 79,997 and last year's 62,228. Canadian automakers were to build 26,987 cars this week, up from 23,945 a week ago and up from last year's 16,609. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,136, compared with 15,945 a week ago and 17,947 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: New Chip Trade Pact Proposal Would End Price Controls
DOC.TEXT: American computer and semiconductor makers, feuding for years over a computer chip trade agreement with Japan, announced a new trade plan Thursday that could bring lower prices to consumers. The proposed pact, which industry leaders said received an encouraging response from Bush administration officials, would end price controls on imported memory chips and remove an irritant in U.S.-Japanese relations. The proposal for a new 5-year agreement to succeed the 1986 U.S.-Japan Semiconductor Trade Agreement, set to expire next July 31, marks the first time chipmakers and computer makers have joined to achieve the same trade policy. U.S. Chipmakers pushed for the 1986 agreement to stop Japanese companies from ``dumping'' unfairly priced memory chips in the United States. But U.S. computer makers complained the agreement kept prices high for a key component of their products. If the new pact is adopted, it could bring down the cost of memory devices and be a bonanza for consumers and computer makers, analysts said. Top executives of both industries, represented by the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group, and the Computer Systems Policy Project worked for months on the new proposal. The computer group, founded last year, includes the chief executives of International Business Machines Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co., Apple Computer Inc., Sun Microsystems Inc., Tandem Computers Inc., Compaq Computer Corp. and five other companies. Wilfred Corrigan, chief executive officer of LSI Logic Corp. and chairman of the semiconductor group, said in Washington that the proposal is ``based on the premise that open markets and the availability of semiconductors at reasonable prices will promote the health of the U.S. electronics industry, foster better relations between the U.S. and Japan, and allow market forces to function freely.'' Rod Canion, chief executive officer of Compaq and vice chairman of the computer group, said it is important that both groups speak with ``a united voice'' on issues of high-tech trade. Industry analysts praised the two sides for putting aside their differences. ``The fact that they can speak with one voice to Congress and the administration is very significant,'' said Marc Elliot of Dataquest Inc. in San Jose. ``I think you'll see a lot more cooperation out of the Bush administration because of that.'' Instead of using ``fair market values'' to determine the prices at which Japanese chips are sold in the United States, the proposal calls for ``fast track'' investigations by the Commerce Department of dumping allegations. ``Anything that takes away from the fair market value and that level of accountability is going to be favorably looked on by the Japanese,'' Elliot said. ``They consider themselves to be honorable people who don't need to be treated like children. I think that's what this trade policy did. I think it will ease some of the animosity that has existed.'' The proposal acknowledges the success of the current trade agreement and lawsuits in getting Japanese companies to stop dumping, and urges less government involvement. It calls for a halt in an investigation into dumping of memory chips called DRAMs. ``This proposal is very promising in that it focuses on the real issue, which is access to the Japanese market,'' said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter. The proposal seeks to boost the U.S. share of overall semiconductor sales in Japan to 20 percent by the end of 1992, and calls for review of further targets in 1993. ``When the original trade agreement was signed, the U.S. had about 10 percent of the Japanese (semiconductor) market, and they had about 10 percent of our market,'' Murphy said. ``Now we have about 11 percent of their market and they have about 17 percent of ours. So the original agreement actually caused the problem, in my view.'' One of the problems, he said, is that about 20 percent of U.S. chip production is for military devices that the Japanese don't need, and about 40 percent of Japan's demand is for cheap chips for consumer products, which U.S. chip companies aren't interested in making. ``So by the time you exclude military and consumer chips, you wind up with a relatively small area in which we make chips that they use,'' he said. The biggest beneficiaries in the semiconductor industry, he said, would be the U.S. companies that make standard microprocessors, such as Texas Instruments Inc., LSI Logic and Chips & Technologies Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers to Benefit From $432 Million Natural Gas Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 7th graf, None of . . ., to UPDATE with Oxy statement; PICKUP 8th graf pvs, ``Irrespective of . . .
DOC.TEXT: Pipeline companies that allegedly profited illegally from higher natural gas prices in the early 1980s agreed Thursday to a $432 million settlement in an antitrust suit brought by utilities. Consumers should get 100 percent of the settlement after legal costs, probably in the form of credits on their bills and lower rates, according to the attorneys general of Missouri and Kansas. The settlement also includes a guarantee of natural gas for the next 20 years at what is expected to be lower than market rates, said Attorneys General William Webster of Missouri and Bob Stephan of Kansas in announcing the settlement. Agreeing to the settlement were Amoco Production Co., Oxy USA, Inc. and Williams Natural Gas Co. Amoco and Oxy had settled a week ago, but details of the agreement were not released because of a gag order issued by U.S. District Judge Earl O'Connor. The case against Williams then went to trial. The parties negotiated until 4 a.m. Thursday, cleaned up details later in the morning, and O'Connor dismissed the case late in the morning. None of the defendants admitted liability in the settlement. Oxy said in a statement released late Thursday its share of the settlement comes to $24.5 million. Amoco and Williams would not disclose the amounts they agreed to pay. ``Irrespective of one's feelings regarding the merit of our position, you reach a point where it makes more sense to put the issue behind you and turn your attention to the business at hand. This is such a time,'' said Joseph H. Williams, chairman and chief executive officer of Tulsa, Okla.-based Williams. Details of the plan must be approved by the Missouri Public Service Commission and the Kansas Corporation Commission. The case was taken to court starting in 1984 by utilities and the states. The suits, which alleged antitrust violations from 1979 to 1984, were then consolidated.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Markets Quiet; Analyst Sees `Eye of Hurricane'
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices eased back Thursday, reflecting what trading professionals called a temporary respite from the wild swinging on the futures market. ``There's a definite feel of being in the eye of a hurricane,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. Light sweet crude oil fell 39 cents to $36.93 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange for November delivery contracts. Unleaded wholesale gasoline fell 2.28 cents to 90.86 cents a gallon on November contracts, while wholesale home heating oil rose .51 cent to 99.92 cents a gallon for November contracts. Later contract months were lower for crude, mostly lower for gasoline and higher for heating oil. The lackluster trading followed drops in crude prices totaling more than $5 per barrel early in the week and a rally of more than $3 per barrel on Wednesday. Traders said they were taking things easy through Thursday's session while waiting to see what Iraq might say during a scheduled evening address to the United Nations, that was eventually canceled because of a nose bleed suffered by the Iraqi ambassador. ``We're really not going anywhere right now,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The Iraqi U.N. ambassador, Abdul Amir al-Andari, had been expected to respond to President Bush's suggestion Monday that an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait could lead to ``opportunities'' toward a broad Middle East peace settlement. Traders had said a more conciliatory stance from Iraq could send prices even lower, while more saber-rattling could push them back up. Oil's sharp decline early in the week seemed to strip away the ``war premium'' that had elevated crde futures to new heights as speculators bet that hostilities in the Gulf could lead to supply shortages. Thursday's trading failed to sustain the rally from Wednesday, making buyers reluctant to get into the uncertain market. Natural gas fell 1.7 cents to $1.898 per 1,000 cubic feet on November contracts, with most other contracts closing higher.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Files Payment Plan For Taj Mahal Subcontractors With SEC
DOC.TEXT: A plan to repay more than $54 million in overdue bills to subcontractors who worked on Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort was filed Thursday with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission. The casino said it had already paid $15 million in cash and would pay another on $3.2 million in cash by Oct. 15 for construction work on the mammoth casino, which cost $1 billion to build. In addition, the casino pledged $36.4 million in notes that will come due on Aug. 15, 1995. The notes bear 8 percent interest in the fourth year and 10 percent in the fifth year, according to the filing. At least four subcontractors who did not go along with the deal have gone to court to enforce payment from the Manhattan developer. The Taj Mahal, which opened amid much hoopla on April 2, has not taken in the $1.3 million a day that analysts have said it needs to break even. Parts of the property remain unfinished. The state Casino Control Commission must approve the plan to repay the subcontractors. The commission has scheduled hearings Oct. 30 to examine the financial stability of the Taj Mahal and Trump's other two casinos.

DOC.HEAD: USW Seeks Restoration Of Pay From USX
DOC.TEXT: The United Steelworkers union is focusing on getting back wage concessions its members made in the early 1980s as the union prepares for the start of talks with USX Corp. The union will ask USX to raise pay $1.25 an hour, Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm, District 15 director and chairman of the USX negotiating committee, said Thursday. Union members at USX make an average of $10.84 an hour, excluding benefits, USW officials said. The USW, representing 18,000 members at USX mines and mills in seven states, opens talks with the nation's largest steelmaker Oct. 15. A four-year contract expires Feb. 1. ``We're only asking to go back to what we made in 1982,'' Palm said at a news conference at a Hilton hotel in suburban Moon Township. Bethlehem Steel Corp., National Steel Corp., Armco Inc. and two financially ailing steelmakers, Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. and LTV Steel Co., all agreed to reinstate pay concessions, Palm said. ``The key word, gang, is pattern plus,'' he said. ``The pattern is out there, and they know what it is. All the companies that signed up to the pattern still are making money.'' USX Chairman Charles A. Corry and Thomas J. Usher, president of USX's steel division, have said the company will stand alone in the talks, ignoring agreements struck with competitors. Statements from both the union and USX said negotiations were scheduled to end Nov. 10. The talks are beginning 3{ months before the contract's expiration, 1{ months earlier than in previous years. The USX statement did not explain the additional time, but Palm speculated the company was pressured by its customers into settling the contract early. Palm said the union will ask USX to pay a penalty into an industry fund for retraining workers if the company schedules excessive overtime. The other steelmakers have accepted the penalty, he said. Union leaders began two days of talks Thursday with presidents and other officials of locals at USX operations. The officials will return to the plants for two weeks of ironing out local issues before returning Oct. 29 for the companywide contract.

DOC.HEAD: Frequent Flyers File Suits Saying American Airlines Breached Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen American Airlines customers are seeking more than $45 million in two lawsuits alleging the company reneged on an agreement to honor its obligations under the frequent-flyer program. The lawsuits, filed Tuesday in Champaign County Circuit Court, both accuse American of breach of contract, fraud and violating federal racketeering law. Tom Stack, a spokesman in Chicago for Dallas-based American, said Thursday the company had not seen the lawsuits and could not comment on them. American has responded to the flyers' complaints previously that they had violated the rules of the program, called ``AAdvantage,'' by transferring and selling mileage credits. One lawsuit, comprising 49 counts on behalf of eight frequent flyers, says American has failed to honor a settlement it reached with the flyers after they filed a series of consumer fraud complaints with the Illinois attorney general in 1988. In the settlement, American said it would let the flyers and others use the credits they had earned under the frequent flyer program, according to the lawsuit. The lawsuit seeks $650,000 in actual damages and $10 million in punitive damages. Punitive damages could be tripled under the federal Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, also called RICO, said the plaintiffs' attorney, Jeffrey Frederick. The second lawsuit, comprising 32 counts on behalf of five plaintiffs, alleges that American failed to honor tickts earned by frequent flyers who were not part of the settlement agreement, Frederick said Thursday. That lawsuit seeks $100,000 in actual damages and $5 million in punitive damages. ``There's got to be some changes in all these programs because no one really knows what's going on, and the airlines are changing the rules at their own whim,'' said Frederick. He said the lawsuits were filed in Champaign for the convenience for many of the plaintiffs who live nearby and for himself. American forced a newlywed couple to cancel their honeymoon plans by refusing to honor their frequent flyer credit on reserved flights to New York and on the Concorde to London, the second lawsuit alleged. Frederick said reservations had been confirmed the day before. He said customers also typically were allowed to fly to a distant destination - such as Hawaii - on frequent flyer credit, only to have the airline refuse to honor their return-trip tickets. The customers then were forced to pay full fare to get home, Frederick said. Like many other airlines, American has been the target of previous lawsuits on behalf of angry frequent flyers who claimed the airlines were failing to live up to their promises. One of the lawsuits, a 2-year-old class action on behalf of 9 million American Airlines customers, is pending in Illinois appellate court, said Gilbert Gordon, an attorney for the plaintiffs in Chicago.
